研究证实了我的个人观察。在一项引人入胜的研究中，研究人员将MBA学生分成小组，让他们在一年中密切合作。每个季度末，每位学生都会进行自我评估，并接受同伴的评价。无论男女，他们的自我评价都高于同伴的评价。然而，在看到反馈后，女性在接下来的几个季度中降低了自我评价分数。男性也降低了分数，但幅度远不及女性。“我们发现，女性能更快地将自我认知与同伴反馈相一致，而男性则会随着时间的推移不断地合理化和夸大自己的形象，”首席研究员玛格丽塔·梅奥在《哈佛商业评论》中写道。“也就是说，在我们的调查中，女性比男性对同伴反馈更加敏感。六个月后，女性对领导力的看法与同伴的评价完全一致。相比之下，男性则继续夸大自己的领导能力。”

There are several ways to look at this. At one level, it certainly suggests that women are more self-aware, which is a great quality for a negotiator. On the other hand, as Mayo points out, “when assimilation of negative feedback involves doubts about one’s competences and lowers confidence, it can discourage women to take on new challenges.” The authors of The Confidence Code , Katty Kay and Claire Shipman, back this up: “ The data is pretty grim,” they write. “Compared with men, we don’t consider ourselves ready for promotions, we predict we’ll do worse on tests, we flat out tell researchers in big numbers that we just don’t feel confident at our jobs.” If women don’t feel as confident in their jobs, what does that say about the confidence they have placing a high value in a negotiation?

对此可以从几个角度来看待。一方面，这无疑表明女性更具自我意识，这对谈判者来说是一项宝贵的品质。另一方面，正如梅奥所指出的，“当负面反馈的吸收导致对自身能力产生怀疑并降低自信心时，女性可能会因此而不敢接受新的挑战。”《自信密码》的作者凯蒂·凯和克莱尔·希普曼也支持这一观点：“数据相当糟糕，”她们写道，“与男性相比，我们认为自己还没有做好晋升的准备，我们预测自己在考试中的表现会更差，我们甚至会直接告诉研究人员，我们对自己的工作缺乏信心。”如果女性对自己的工作缺乏信心，那么这又说明了她们在谈判中对自身能力的重视程度如何呢？

When she was growing up, my Goldman Sachs 10,000 Small Businesses student Dana Sicko would apologize all the time. She would start conversations or emails with, “I’m sorry to bother you, but . . .” or “Sorry to be a pest, but . . .” or “I’m sorry if you’ve already thought about this, but . . .” She diminished her own credibility by apologizing before she started talking. So many women do this, and I’ve been guilty of it myself plenty of times. According to research in Psychological Science , women apologize more because they see more incidents as worthy of apology than men do. It’s like we always think we’re inconveniencing people.

我高盛“万家小企业计划”的学生达娜·西科（Dana Sicko）小时候总是道歉。她说话或发邮件时，开头总是会说：“不好意思打扰您了，但是……”或者“不好意思，我有点烦人，但是……”或者“如果您已经考虑过这个问题了，我很抱歉，但是……”。她还没开口就道歉，这反而降低了自己的可信度。很多女性都有这种习惯，我自己也经常犯。心理科学研究表明，女性道歉更多是因为她们觉得需要道歉的事情比男性更多。好像我们总是觉得自己在给别人添麻烦似的。

As Dana’s confidence grew over the years, she was able to start asking for what she really wanted without prefacing anything with an apology. “It doesn’t make me a bad person to speak out for myself,” she said. “I can say, ‘I’m not ready to budge on this part of a deal, but we can come together on this.’ I apologize a lot less now.”

随着达娜的自信心逐年增强，她开始能够直截了当地提出自己真正想要的东西，而不再需要先道歉。“为自己争取权益并不代表我是个坏人，”她说。“我可以坦诚地说，‘在协议的这一部分我不想让步，但我们可以就此达成一致。’我现在道歉的次数少多了。”

I know how impactful these gendered stories can be because I’ve seen the changes again and again when women question their narratives or completely gut them. Perhaps the most memorable experience I ever had involving gender issues was when I taught at the American University in Cairo (AUC) for the Goldman Sachs 10,000 Women program, a global program where female entrepreneurs are provided with business education, mentoring and networking, and access to capital. The women in the program came to AUC from across the Arab region for this once-in-a-lifetime chance to take their businesses to the next level. The program provided them a much-needed community of like-minded individuals who could share their experiences and challenges, a place where they could find validation for their entrepreneurial goals and vision.

我知道这些带有性别色彩的故事会产生多么大的影响，因为我一次又一次地看到，当女性质疑或彻底颠覆她们的固有叙事时，她们的境况会发生怎样的改变。或许我经历过的最难忘的与性别议题相关的事件，是在开罗美国大学 (AUC) 为高盛“万名女性”项目授课。这是一个全球性项目，旨在为女性创业者提供商业教育、导师指导、人脉拓展以及资金支持。参与该项目的女性来自阿拉伯地区各地，她们来到开罗美国大学，寻求这千载难逢的机会，将自己的事业推向新的高度。该项目为她们提供了一个至关重要的社群，让志同道合的人可以分享彼此的经验和挑战，并找到对其创业目标和愿景的认可。

The lofty academic surroundings of AUC were certainly intimidating at first, and for some, it was the first time they’d been back in a classroom in a long time. In a country where women have often been suppressed or expected to stay home, to break out of that story was huge for these women.

美国大学（AUC）高雅的学术氛围起初确实令人望而生畏，对一些人来说，这是她们多年来第一次重返课堂。在一个女性常常受到压制或被要求待在家里的国家，打破这种固有观念对这些女性来说意义非凡。

Some were compelled to create a new narrative because their husbands had left them with children but without means to support the family. One student had inherited a business from her husband after he passed away. His family was unsupportive—financially and otherwise—and she simply had to take over the business and learn to run it in order to support her children.

有些人被迫重塑人生，因为丈夫去世后，她们独自抚养孩子，却没有经济来源维持生计。一位学生在丈夫去世后继承了一家公司。丈夫的家人在经济和其他方面都不支持她，为了养活孩子，她不得不接管公司，学习如何经营。

My colleagues and I quickly established a sense of community and trust, something we do in every class but which was particularly important in the male-dominated culture. We talked a lot about letting go of the labels placed on them, breaking down hierarchical expectations, and allowing them to open up to who they were as individuals. The staff saw our role as providing a container, holding sacred a space where the women could find and then tell their individual, authentic stories. The experience remains with me as a testament to negotiation’s importance in our journey of self-discovery.

我和同事们很快就建立起一种社群感和信任感，这在我们每节课上都会做到，但在以男性为主导的文化中尤为重要。我们深入探讨了如何放下加诸于她们身上的标签，打破等级观念，让她们能够敞开心扉，展现真实的自我。工作人员将我们的角色视为提供一个容器，一个神圣的空间，让女性能够找到并讲述她们各自真实的故事。这段经历至今仍让我铭记于心，它证明了协商在我们自我发现之旅中的重要性。

“But I’m not a liar”: Negotiation as a story of morality

“但我不是骗子”：谈判中的道德故事

In an exercise I use in class, one student must sell a rare bottle of wine to another. The seller has information indicating that the bottle could be sold for a minimum of $400 before taking a loss, and as much as $1,000. A student named Diane offered to sell the bottle for just $400 right out of the gate. “Why did you set your goal there?” I asked. “You could have reasonably asked for $800 or more.”

我在课堂上布置了一个练习，要求一位学生将一瓶珍稀葡萄酒卖给另一位学生。卖家掌握的信息显示，这瓶酒最低售价为 400 美元，最高可达 1000 美元。一位名叫黛安的学生一开始就提出以 400 美元的价格出售。“你为什么把目标定在 400 美元？”我问。“你完全可以要价 800 美元甚至更高。”

“But I’m not a liar,” she said.

“但我不是个骗子，”她说。

“No,” I agreed. “And neither am I.”

“不，”我同意道，“我也不是。”

“There’s no data to justify $800,” she said.

“没有任何数据可以证明800美元的价格是合理的，”她说。

There actually was data to support the $800 goal and even a $1,000 goal—the wine had gone up in value steadily over a period of years, and if you extrapolated the rate of growth to the present day, actually $1,000 was a totally reasonable expectation. But before I showed her, I pressed, “Where is your data point for $400? Where is your proof for that number? Because I can show you proof for mine.”

实际上，有数据支持800美元甚至1000美元的目标——这种葡萄酒的价值多年来稳步增长，如果将这种增长速度推算到今天，1000美元的预期完全合理。但在给她看数据之前，我追问道：“你400美元的数据点在哪里？你有什么证据支持这个数字？因为我可以给你看我的证据。”

Flustered, Diane said, “If I ask for $400, I don’t lose money and I’m not cheating anyone.”

黛安娜慌乱地说：“如果我要400美元，我不会赔钱，我也没有欺骗任何人。”

She was telling a story about the worth of the bottle (and possibly her own) that sold it short. She feared being “bad.” I rarely hear someone directly label negotiation this way, and I have to confess that when Diane said, “But I’m not a liar,” my hackles rose a little bit and my first instinct was to feel defensive. I teach this stuff, and still I had to remind myself that I wasn’t out of line in my ask, that I wasn’t being dishonest. What Diane verbalized has emotional resonance for so many of us, and there are a thousand subtle societal reasons why. Moralizing the way Diane did can act as a shield to hide what’s really going on. We may be self-sabotaging for not asking what we’re worth; maybe we don’t think we deserve what we’re asking for, but it’s much easier to say, “I’m not a liar,” than to acknowledge that we lack confidence.

她讲述的故事是关于那瓶酒（或许也包括她自己的）的价值，却低估了它的价值。她害怕自己“做得不好”。我很少听到有人这样直接谈论谈判，我必须承认，当黛安说“但我不是个骗子”时，我有点恼火，第一反应是想要辩解。我教的就是这方面的知识，但我仍然需要提醒自己，我的要求并没有过分，我也没有撒谎。黛安的话引起了我们很多人的共鸣，这背后有着无数微妙的社会原因。像黛安那样进行道德说教，可以成为掩盖真相的盾牌。我们可能因为不敢说出自己的价值而自我设限；也许我们觉得自己不配得到我们所要求的，但说“我不是个骗子”远比承认自己缺乏自信容易得多。

I’ve encountered countless people whose default strategy is to pick a minimal number they can live with and proclaim that it’s not negotiable. They’ll say things like, “I didn’t make the best deal, but I skipped the bargaining. I feel like a human being and I don’t care.” Think about this statement for a minute: Bargaining, by this view of the world, undercuts your humanity.

我遇到过无数人，他们的默认策略是先定下一个自己能接受的最低限度，然后宣称没有商量的余地。他们会说：“我没谈成最划算的，但我省去了讨价还价的环节。我感觉自己像个人，我不在乎。” 请仔细想想这句话：按照这种世界观，讨价还价会损害你的人性。

Jennifer, a graphic designer, was in business with three other women and they were all close. For the first year or so of the business, they didn’t have to negotiate with one another over anything very significant; they all had their own clients and worked independently. Then a client asked them to do a project that they needed to work on collectively. Though they broke up tasks for the project, they didn’t discuss how they would split the fee among them at the outset. (Their first mistake, obviously.) Jennifer’s partner Laura did the bulk of the work, but Jennifer did a lot, too—more than anyone had initially intended because the project got more complicated. When the payment for the project came in, the partner who handled the finances said she was giving 90 percent of it to Laura and splitting the remaining 10 percent among the other three partners. Jennifer thought it was unfair and said so. “Man, did that set off a firestorm of judgment!” Jennifer told me. “They said things like ‘This isn’t what our culture is about’ and ‘We all do things uncompensated to help the company.’ I was made to feel like I was being greedy for asking for what I felt I deserved. That there was something morally wrong with saying something was unfair.” Jennifer did not take this feedback lightly. “I felt like a bad human being if I ever brought money up.” When she brought it up another time, one of her partners said, “It makes me trust you less when you begin every conversation with money.”

珍妮弗是一名平面设计师，她和另外三个女性合伙做生意，她们关系非常亲密。在公司成立的头一年左右，她们之间几乎不需要就任何重大事项进行协商；她们各自拥有自己的客户，独立开展工作。后来，一位客户委托她们完成一个需要共同协作的项目。虽然她们已经将项目任务分配完毕，但一开始并没有讨论如何分配报酬。（这显然是她们的第一个错误。）珍妮弗的合伙人劳拉承担了大部分工作，但珍妮弗也做了很多——比任何人最初预想的都要多，因为项目变得越来越复杂。项目款项到账后，负责财务的合伙人表示，她要把90%的款项给劳拉，剩下的10%由其他三位合伙人平分。珍妮弗认为这不公平，并提出了自己的意见。“天哪，这可真是引发了一场轩然大波！”珍妮弗告诉我。 “他们说‘这不是我们公司的文化’，‘我们都无偿为公司做事’之类的话。我感觉自己好像贪婪，因为我要求得到我认为自己应得的报酬。好像说某件事不公平就是违背道德的。” 詹妮弗并没有轻视这些反馈。“如果我提起钱，我会觉得自己像个坏人。” 当她再次提起这件事时，她的一位合伙人说：“你每次谈话都以钱开头，这让我对你越来越不信任。”

For years afterward, Jennifer avoided negotiating with her partners. But her feelings festered. Jennifer’s resentment grew as she felt she couldn’t call out any financial concerns or discrepancies. “I was seriously tormented about this situation, and spent so many nights awake trying to reconcile two things: that I felt I was being treated unfairly, and that I was greedy and selfish for thinking that.” Jennifer’s predicament was multilayered, but as a first step, she needed to sit more solidly in her own awareness that talking about money, that advocating for herself, was not bad . It did not make her a bad person. Now, in her partners’ view, it did, and she needed to digest that so that she could approach them in the right way. I’ll come back to this fraught issue—the how of the ask—in Chapter 4.

此后多年，詹妮弗一直避免与合伙人谈判。但她的不满却与日俱增。她觉得自己无法提出任何财务方面的担忧或分歧，这让她更加怨恨。“我为此备受煎熬，无数个夜晚辗转反侧，试图调和两种矛盾：一方面，我觉得自己受到了不公平的对待；另一方面，我又觉得自己因为这种想法而显得贪婪自私。”詹妮弗的困境错综复杂，但首先，她需要更坚定地认识到，谈论金钱、为自己争取权益并非坏事，也不会让她变成坏人。然而，在她的合伙人看来，她的确如此。她需要消化这一点，才能以正确的方式与他们沟通。我将在第四章中再次探讨这个棘手的问题——如何提出要求。

Jennifer is hardly alone in her struggle. Another entrepreneur came to see me for advice after she’d asked for 360 feedback from her team. Nearly everyone had said, “She’s smart,” and “she’s nice,” but then almost all of the women wrote, She needs to leave her corporate attitude behind. It’s all about money with her, and that’s not the culture of our company. None of the men made this comment. “What’s going on?” she asked. “Are women harder on each other, or what?”

珍妮弗的困境并非个例。另一位创业者在向团队征求360度反馈后前来寻求我的建议。几乎所有人都说“她很聪明”、“她人很好”，但随后几乎所有女性都写道：“她需要摒弃那种官僚作风。她眼里只有钱，而这与我们公司的文化不符。” 男性员工却无人提及此事。“这是怎么回事？”她问道，“难道女性之间对彼此的要求更高吗？”

The answer is yes, sometimes. Women are harder on each other when we go against our expected gender roles. When we see other women act in ways that we don’t feel we can, even though we may want to, our inclination is to punish them.

答案是肯定的，有时候是这样。当女性违背社会对性别角色的固有认知时，她们往往会对彼此更加苛刻。当我们看到其他女性做出我们自己无法做到的事情时（即使我们内心也想这样做），我们往往会倾向于惩罚她们。

There are reasons people have come to see negotiation as morally loaded, and that’s because many negotiators do behave badly. My student Michelle used to work as a litigator for a big firm in New York City, and her experiences reinforced ideas about how strong negotiators fit a certain profile. “Part of the game was to show how tough you could be,” she said. “There was a lot of intimidation, posturing, flexing.” The message she got in her early career was that negotiation “was serious, it was aggressive, it was zero-sum thinking, it was competitive.” If that was what effective negotiation was, she wanted no part of it.

人们之所以会把谈判视为道德问题，是有原因的，因为很多谈判者的行为确实不光彩。我的学生米歇尔曾在纽约一家大型律师事务所担任诉讼律师，她的经历强化了人们对优秀谈判者特定特质的认知。“谈判的一部分就是展现你的强硬程度，”她说，“充斥着恐吓、摆姿态和炫耀。”她早期职业生涯中接收到的信息是，谈判“严肃、咄咄逼人、零和博弈、充满竞争”。如果这就是有效谈判的本质，她宁愿避而远之。

In response, Michelle’s approach to negotiation had always been one of trying to work things out, of making other people happy, with a strong focus on not coming across badly. “There was a politeness factor to my approach,” she said, “a shame factor, a concern about not coming off as greedy or unreasonable or just bad.”

对此，米歇尔的谈判策略始终是努力解决问题，让对方满意，同时非常注重避免给人留下不好的印象。“我的方法里有礼貌的因素，”她说，“还有羞愧的因素，担心自己显得贪婪、不讲道理或者很糟糕。”

But when Michelle left litigation and joined her family jewelry business, she had to scrap every tale she had told herself about negotiation. If she equated setting a high goal with low professionalism, then she wouldn’t succeed in the business. She had to learn to give herself permission to make an ask, and to feel confident that it didn’t make her a bad person. “I’m more comfortable saying, ‘Here are my needs and here’s what I want, and I’m not going to apologize for it.’ I can be pleasant and human about the exchange. I don’t have to be an asshole. But I don’t have to back down, either.”

但当米歇尔离开诉讼行业，加入家族珠宝生意后，她不得不推翻自己之前所有关于谈判的固有观念。如果她把设定高目标等同于缺乏职业素养，那么她在这个行业就无法取得成功。她必须学会允许自己提出要求，并且要相信这样做并不会让她变成一个坏人。“我现在更愿意说，‘这是我的需求，这是我想要的，我不会为此道歉。’我可以以友好和人性化的方式进行沟通。我不需要做一个混蛋，但我也不需要退缩。”

This terrain is really complex, in part because it can be so subtle. It takes a lot of self-awareness to recognize when you’re spinning negotiation into a morality tale. Listen to your inner monologue and pick out its themes. I started this book by explaining that we negotiate every day, so start to notice those incidents. Do you feel like a jerk when you negotiate with someone? Why? Do you feel tough (in a good way) when you negotiate? Why? The judgment you do or don’t put on negotiation is intensely personal, just as your negotiation style must be. Start finding your way by paying attention.

这片领域非常复杂，部分原因在于它非常微妙。你需要很强的自我意识才能意识到自己何时将谈判变成了道德说教。倾听你内心的独白，并找出其中的主题。我在本书开头就解释说，我们每天都在进行谈判，所以要开始留意这些谈判事件。当你与人谈判时，你会觉得自己像个混蛋吗？为什么？当你谈判时，你会觉得自己很强硬（以一种好的方式）吗？为什么？你对谈判的评判，或者不评判，都是非常个人化的，就像你的谈判风格也必须是个人化的一样。从关注自身开始，找到属于你的谈判之路。

It’s our choice to make

这是我们自己的选择。

In the second year of the Trump administration, I taught a class of undergraduates at Wharton that shook me. I’ve been teaching negotiation for fifteen years, and although no year is the same, this class was markedly different. Like many of my undergraduate classes, this one had tremendous diversity in terms of gender, age, race, ethnicity, religion, and life experience. But confidence in negotiation was distinctly lower than I’d seen in years prior.

在特朗普执政的第二年，我在沃顿商学院教了一门本科课程，这门课让我感到震惊。我教谈判技巧已经十五年了，虽然每年的情况都不尽相同，但这门课却格外不同。和我教过的许多本科课一样，这门课的学生在性别、年龄、种族、民族、宗教信仰和人生经历方面都非常多元化。但是，他们对谈判的信心明显低于我往年所见到的水平。

Typically, I focus the first class on goal setting, on the stories we tell ourselves and why they’re so important, and then move on in the next class. Not so in this class. Whenever we unpacked and examined an exercise and the students’ results, I’d ask questions about why they set their goals so low, and we’d be back right where we were in the first class. One student, for instance, said that he had set an aspirational goal, but when he began negotiating with his partner, he lacked the desire to ask for what he wanted. Essentially, he was never convinced that he had the right number in the first place, perhaps because he thought his goal was too lofty. I had variations of this conversation all semester; these students lacked self-confidence because they simply couldn’t change their story. Stepping back, I thought I understood why. The fractious nature of our society and our world more broadly—where we see more open, obvious discord, and a hyper lack of civility—affects all of us in our day-to-day lives. We can’t underestimate how the general ethos of this climate seeps into our psyche. For the most marginalized and underrepresented populations, this discord may be further internalized, becoming their story.

通常，我会在第一节课重点讲解目标设定，探讨我们对自己讲述的故事以及这些故事为何如此重要，然后在下一节课继续讲解其他内容。但这节课却并非如此。每当我们分析练习和学生的成果时，我都会问他们为什么把目标定得这么低，结果我们又回到了第一节课的原点。例如，有个学生说他设定了一个远大的目标，但当他开始和伙伴协商时，却缺乏提出自己要求的动力。本质上，他一开始就不确定自己设定的目标是否合适，或许是因为他觉得自己的目标太高了。整个学期我都听到过类似的对话；这些学生缺乏自信，是因为他们根本无法改变自己对自己的固有认知。冷静下来思考后，我似乎明白了其中的原因。我们社会乃至整个世界都充满了纷争——公开的、显而易见的冲突，以及普遍缺乏文明礼貌——这影响着我们每个人的日常生活。我们不能低估这种氛围对我们心灵的潜移默化影响。对于最边缘化和最缺乏代表性的群体而言，这种冲突可能会被进一步内化，成为他们人生故事的一部分。

As a result of the class climate, we spent most of the semester on setting aspirational goals that they could believe in and thus potentially achieve. Self-esteem became a running theme. In the final class of the year, when I told them to remember that “You are enough . . . just as you are,” half the class (and their professor) was teary. I can’t say that the political climate was solely responsible for the class’s difficulty setting aspirational goals, but I believe it played a huge role. I’ve seen this play out often in my classes at Wharton where young, high-achieving adults carry what appears to be the weight and burden of the world on their shoulders. Their stories are that their parents risked everything for them to be where they are, so they need to make sure they succeed, or that their peers already have their entire lives planned out, so they must do so as well. Compounded with all that’s going on in our world, the issues raised in my class take on a new importance. It’s no wonder emotions run high.

由于课堂氛围的影响，我们整个学期都在努力设定他们能够相信并有可能实现的理想目标。自尊心成了贯穿始终的主题。在最后一节课上，当我告诉他们要记住“你已经足够好了……你现在的样子就很好”时，班里一半的学生（包括他们的教授）都热泪盈眶。我不能说政治氛围是导致班级难以设定理想目标的唯一原因，但我相信它起到了至关重要的作用。我在沃顿商学院的课堂上经常看到这种情况：那些年轻有为的成年人肩负着仿佛全世界的重担。他们的故事是，父母为了让他们走到今天付出了一切，所以他们必须确保自己成功；或者，同龄人已经规划好了人生，所以他们也必须这样做。再加上当今世界正在发生的一切，我在课堂上提出的问题显得尤为重要。难怪学生们的情绪如此激动。

To be clear, people feeling inferior because of their race or ethnicity isn’t new, it’s just much worse than I’ve ever seen it. Words matter and cut to a core of insecurity that has long been simmering. As Wes Moore, the African American activist and writer, told Oprah Winfrey, “There’s a common narrative that we don’t belong in a certain place. An imposter syndrome . . . You’re just waiting for someone to tap you on the shoulder and say, ‘What are you doing here?’” Wes recounted how with every one of his accomplishments, from becoming a decorated veteran to earning a Rhodes scholarship, he thought he wasn’t supposed to be there. It’s true that the originators of the Rhodes scholarship likely never intended for an African American to receive it, and that’s a narrative he could have held on to. But instead, Wes thought of how many people he had never met had worked their butts off, risked their lives, and kept their hope up because of the idea of him. This is the story Wes needed to tell. “ We are never in a room we don’t belong in,” he said. “And we have to have confidence that we belong there, and not just as wallpaper.”

坦白说，人们因为种族或民族而感到自卑并非新鲜事，只是现在的情况比我以往见过的都要糟糕得多。言语的力量不容小觑，它直击人们内心深处长期潜藏的不安全感。正如非裔美国活动家兼作家韦斯·摩尔（Wes Moore）告诉奥普拉·温弗瑞（Oprah Winfrey）的那样：“有一种普遍的说法，认为我们不属于某个地方。这是一种冒名顶替综合症……你总觉得有人会拍拍你的肩膀，问你：‘你在这里干什么？’”韦斯回忆说，从成为一名功勋卓著的退伍军人到获得罗德奖学金，他取得的每一项成就都让他觉得自己不该出现在那里。罗德奖学金的设立者或许从未想过让一位非裔美国人获得这项奖学金，而韦斯本可以以此为借口。但他却想到，有多少素未谋面的人，为了他而拼命努力，冒着生命危险，始终怀抱希望。这就是韦斯想讲述的故事。“我们永远不会待在不属于我们的房间里，”他说。“我们必须确信自己属于那里，而不仅仅是作为背景装饰。”

I’ve had students tell me that I am the story they remember to tell themselves because I’m a woman of color standing at the head of their classroom. It feels weird to hear this, because I still struggle with self-doubt myself and wonder what in the heck they’re seeing. But I also get it. For women like my student Sarah Farzam, who is Iranian, Mexican, and Jewish, who grew up playing with Barbie dolls that never looked like her, who read books and watched shows with characters that never looked like her, seeing an Iranian woman in a position of power matters. Some of my students see me as a woman of color, and others just see a woman, and that’s enough. For my part, I’ve looked up to women like Oprah, Madeleine Albright, and Serena Williams. It’s not that I aspire to be them, but seeing them be the “first”—seeing them, period—inspires me. If they can break through, why can’t we all if we try hard enough? It becomes easier to tell myself a better story. And if I think of this story often enough, I am exercising that muscle of self-confidence to the point that it just kicks in automatically. As a workout fanatic, I love this analogy because there comes a point with every workout regimen where you don’t have to think so hard about the muscles you’ve been developing. Instead, the workout starts and you just go .

有学生告诉我，因为我是一位有色人种女性，站在他们教室的讲台上，所以我的故事成为了他们想要讲述给自己的榜样。听到这话感觉很奇怪，因为我自己也还在与自我怀疑作斗争，常常纳闷他们到底看到了什么。但我也能理解。对于像我的学生莎拉·法扎姆这样的女性来说，她拥有伊朗、墨西哥和犹太血统，从小玩的芭比娃娃和她长得一点都不像，读的书和看的影视作品里的角色也和她长得一点都不像，所以看到一位伊朗女性身居要职意义非凡。有些学生把我当成有色人种女性，有些学生则只把我当成一个女人，这就足够了。就我而言，我一直很敬佩像奥普拉、马德琳·奥尔布赖特和塞雷娜·威廉姆斯这样的女性。我并不是渴望成为她们，而是看到她们成为“第一人”——仅仅是看到她们——就激励着我。如果她们能够突破重围，为什么我们只要足够努力就不能做到呢？这让我更容易为自己讲述一个更美好的故事。如果我经常想起这个故事，就能锻炼我的自信，直到它自然而然地发挥作用。作为一个健身爱好者，我喜欢这个比喻，因为每次健身计划都会有一个阶段，你不需要费力去想你一直在锻炼的肌肉。相反，锻炼开始了，你只需要全力以赴。

Research from positive psychology tells us that the more positive our narrative, the better our results. The wisdom in positivity goes back much further, though. In an old Cherokee teaching, a grandfather tells his grandson that he has two wolves living inside him, fighting viciously: one that embodies everything evil within him—like envy, pride, and ego; and one that embodies everything good—like joy, generosity, and compassion. A similar fight, he says, goes on inside every person. When the grandson asks, “Which will win?” the grandfather answers, “The one you feed.” Where we choose to focus our energy matters. Which wolf we choose to feed has enormous impact on our sense of self-worth and our ability to negotiate with the world that surrounds us.

积极心理学的研究表明，我们的叙事越积极，结果就越好。然而，积极思考的智慧远不止于此。在古老的切罗基族传说中，一位祖父告诉他的孙子，他体内住着两匹狼，它们激烈地争斗着：一匹代表着他内心的一切邪恶——比如嫉妒、骄傲和自负；另一匹则代表着一切美好——比如喜悦、慷慨和同情。祖父说，类似的争斗也发生在每个人的内心。当孙子问：“哪匹狼会赢？”祖父回答说：“你喂养的那匹。”我们选择将精力集中在哪里至关重要。我们选择喂养哪匹狼，会对我们的自我价值感以及我们与周围世界互动的能力产生巨大的影响。

#↩

CHAPTER 2

第二章

when we undercut ourselves to please others

当我们为了取悦他人而牺牲自己时

In a classic episode of The Office , Dunder Mifflin regional manager and lovable narcissist Michael Scott accidentally hits an employee, Meredith, with his car. Her refusal to instantly forgive him becomes Michael’s obsession. Michael tells the camera, “Do I need to be liked? Absolutely not. I like to be liked. I enjoy being liked. I have to be liked. But it’s not like this compulsive need to be liked . . . like my need to be praised.”

在《办公室》的一集经典剧集中，邓德米夫林公司区域经理兼可爱又自恋的迈克尔·斯科特不小心开车撞到了员工梅雷迪斯。梅雷迪斯没有立刻原谅他，这成了迈克尔的执念。迈克尔对着镜头说：“我需要被人喜欢吗？当然不需要。我喜欢被人喜欢。我享受被人喜欢的感觉。我必须被人喜欢。但这并不是那种强迫性的被喜欢的需求……也不是那种渴望被赞扬的需求。”

Of course, what makes satire so funny in the first place is that it amplifies what we know is within us, in some form. Everyone wants to be liked. But unchecked, this desire also gets us into trouble, as we give away our power without recognizing that’s what we’re doing. Those who do this as a matter of course are often called pleasers .

当然，讽刺之所以如此有趣，首先在于它放大了我们内心深处某种形式的渴望。每个人都渴望被人喜欢。但如果放任不管，这种渴望也会给我们带来麻烦，因为我们会在不知不觉中放弃自己的力量。那些习以为常地这样做的人，通常被称为讨好者。

Emily is a quintessential pleaser. Years ago, when she and her new husband bought their first used car together, the negotiation process was laborious. Emily’s husband was in law school and particularly earnest about negotiating. The salesman, Steve, was growing impatient. He made a big deal out of calling his girlfriend to tell her he would be late for their dinner date. He explained the finer points of his romantic life to Emily while her husband pushed for a deal on the last $1,000. When Steve sighed and made a move to call his girlfriend again and push their dinner date back even further, Emily intervened. She told her husband he should let the last of it go—that Steve’s girlfriend was waiting for him. Though this happened fifteen years ago, Emily’s husband still insists he buy their cars without Emily present so she can’t negotiate against him.

艾米丽是个典型的讨好型人格。多年前，她和新婚丈夫一起买第一辆二手车时，谈判过程十分艰难。当时艾米丽的丈夫还在法学院读书，对谈判格外认真。销售员史蒂夫越来越不耐烦，他故意打电话给女朋友，说自己会晚点赴约。在艾米丽的丈夫还在努力争取最后1000美元的时候，史蒂夫却滔滔不绝地向艾米丽讲述自己的感情生活。当史蒂夫叹了口气，准备再次打电话给女朋友，把晚餐约会再往后推迟时，艾米丽出面阻止了她。她告诉丈夫，他应该放弃最后那点儿争执——史蒂夫的女朋友还在等他呢。虽然这件事已经过去十五年了，但艾米丽的丈夫至今仍然坚持不让艾米丽在场就买车，这样她就没法跟他讨价还价了。

The pleaser hates conflict and avoids it at any cost. If someone takes the last swig out of the office coffeepot, the pleaser who comes up behind him makes a fresh pot. It’s not his turn—the guy who took the last cup should do it—but it’s not worth the fight. He just doesn’t want to deal with the headache of it all. But he doesn’t see that there’s a cost to his making the coffee, too: He’s pissed. Why is he always the one to refill the pot? The truth is, by swallowing his ask, by not engaging in negotiation, he is choosing to give away his power.

讨好型人格讨厌冲突，不惜一切代价避免冲突。如果有人喝光了办公室咖啡壶里的最后一口咖啡，后面的讨好型人格就会重新煮一壶。明明轮不到他——应该由喝最后一杯的人来煮——但他觉得没必要为此争吵。他只是不想处理这些麻烦事。但他没意识到，自己煮咖啡也是有代价的：他很生气。为什么总是他去续壶？事实上，他默默忍受，不愿协商，就是在放弃自己的权力。

Or consider the pleaser as a parent. She may not let the tendency show at the office, but when she gets home, she feels so guilty about working so much (or being divorced, or enrolling the kid in tutoring . . . pick your guilt!) that when the kid asks for a second bowl of ice cream, the parent says yes. She doesn’t want any conflict, she just wants to enjoy her child for a bit. So when the kid begs to stay up late, again she says yes. When the kid talks back to her, she lets it go. There is little to no negotiation, just acquiescence. In no time, the parent’s power is gone.

或者想想这种讨好型人格的父母。她可能在办公室里看不出这种倾向，但回到家后，她会因为工作太忙（或者离婚，或者给孩子报了辅导班……随便你选一个理由！）而感到内疚，所以当孩子要第二碗冰淇淋时，她会答应。她不想发生任何冲突，只想享受和孩子在一起的时光。所以当孩子央求熬夜时，她又一次答应了。当孩子顶嘴时，她也选择忍让。几乎没有任何协商，只有默许。很快，父母的主导权就荡然无存了。

Although the domestic sphere is common stomping grounds for pleasers, they are found everywhere. And though you may think of pleasers as predominantly female, that’s not so. Greg, for instance, had ten years of work experience behind him when he took my executive MBA class. For the rare-wine exercise I wrote about in the last chapter, Greg played the dealer who needed to sell the bottle. His character was planning to retire soon, so he wasn’t necessarily looking to develop a relationship with the buyer—just to sell the bottle for as much as possible. Greg looked at the data and determined he could reasonably ask $800, so he set his goal there. Recall that the bottom line, or lowest price before taking a loss, was $400. The buyer’s opening offer was $250. So Greg said he could take $500 for it, they agreed, and the deal was done in minutes.

虽然家庭领域通常是讨好型人格的聚集地，但他们其实无处不在。你可能认为讨好型人格主要是女性，但事实并非如此。例如，格雷格在我开设的高级工商管理硕士课程中，已经拥有十年的工作经验。在我上一章提到的稀有葡萄酒练习中，格雷格扮演了需要出售这瓶酒的酒商。他扮演的角色即将退休，所以他并不一定想和买家建立关系——他只是想尽可能高价地卖掉这瓶酒。格雷格查看了数据，认为他可以合理地要价800美元，于是就把目标价定在了这里。要知道，底价，也就是不亏本的最低价格，是400美元。买家的初始报价是250美元。所以格雷格说他可以接受500美元，双方同意了，交易在几分钟内就完成了。

When we debriefed, Greg saw that in many other groups, the seller got $600, $700, and even $800 for the same bottle of wine. When I asked him why he moved away from his goal of $800 so quickly, he said, “It was hard for me to keep relationships out of it.” At this point in the term, my students had gotten to know one another well. Greg was a really likable guy and popular with the other students. Reputations form quickly in a class like this—everyone expected Greg to be affable, and so he was. “When the buyer came in so low,” he explained of his classmate, who he was friendly with, “I figured there was no way she could pay my goal price.” As we unpacked it further, he explained that he’d wanted to minimize the gap between his goal and the buyer’s opening offer and avoid the back-and-forth. “I didn’t want to appear unreasonable,” he said.

事后讨论时，格雷格发现其他很多小组卖同一瓶酒，卖家都卖到了600美元、700美元，甚至800美元。我问他为什么这么快就放弃了800美元的目标价，他说：“我很难把人际关系排除在外。” 学期进行到这个阶段，我的学生们彼此都很熟悉了。格雷格人缘很好，很受同学欢迎。在这样的班级里，名声很容易形成——大家都觉得格雷格应该很友善，而他也确实如此。“买家出价那么低，”他解释说，指的是他关系不错的同学，“我觉得她肯定付不起我的目标价。” 我们进一步探讨后，他解释说，他想尽量缩小目标价和买家最初报价之间的差距，避免讨价还价。“我不想显得不讲道理，”他说。

Relationships are important, I agree. But Greg was giving away his power—the perceived value of his rare asset—when he could have maintained a friendly rapport and gotten more for the wine. Almost without fail, I can tell the pleasers in the classroom from this wine exercise: They always sell the bottle quickly and for less.

我同意，人际关系很重要。但格雷格放弃了自己的优势——他那瓶稀有葡萄酒的价值——而他本可以维持友好的关系，从而卖个好价钱。几乎每次，我都能通过这个葡萄酒练习分辨出课堂上那些讨好型的人：他们总是能很快把酒卖掉，而且价格更低。

There’s a confluence of reasons for this: First, because they can’t wrap their heads around the true value of the wine, even though there is data to support that story, as I discussed in Chapter 1. Greg knew that the wine was of a rare vintage, for instance. He knew that other dealers had sold the same vintage for $600 and $700 in previous years, and that the value increased each year. This is why he set his goal at $800 in the first place. But he didn’t bring any of those details up with his partner. He didn’t fully internalize these details and grasp that he had an incredible asset in his possession.

造成这种情况的原因有很多：首先，他们始终无法理解这瓶酒的真正价值，尽管正如我在第一章中讨论的那样，有数据可以佐证这一点。例如，格雷格知道这瓶酒是稀有年份。他知道其他经销商前几年曾以 600 美元或 700 美元的价格出售过同一年份的酒，而且其价值逐年增长。正因如此，他最初才将目标价定在 800 美元。但他并没有向合伙人提及这些细节。他没有完全理解这些信息，也没有意识到自己手中握有一笔价值连城的资产。

Second, pleasers want to get the deal done and ensure that everyone is happy. In Greg’s case, he not only liked his classmate and wanted her to continue liking him, but I suspect that he also felt he needed to please me . He hadn’t gotten a deal in the previous two class sessions and wanted to come out of this negotiation able to tell me he closed it.

其次，讨好型人格的人希望达成交易，并确保每个人都满意。就格雷格而言，他不仅喜欢他的同学，希望她继续喜欢他，而且我怀疑他也觉得需要讨好我。他在前两节课都没能达成交易，所以他想在这次谈判中能够告诉我他成功了。

In this chapter, I cover the many forms of the pleaser. Pleasers can be chefs, CEOs, and professional athletes—there’s no one stereotype that fits. Likewise, pleasers can be gruff, they can be stoic, they can be so standoffish that you would never peg them as a pleaser. And yet they are. Most people would never guess that I’m a pleaser. I come across as a little removed, at least at first. But though I don’t have kids, I have a strong maternal instinct that I attribute to my Iranian heritage. Iranians are masters of hospitality, who subscribe to a mantra that “Your comfort is my comfort.” I always want things to be okay for others, though it comes less from a need to be liked and more from a need for everything to be in balance, for everyone around me to be happy.

在本章中，我将探讨“讨好型人格”的多种表现形式。讨好型人格可以是厨师、首席执行官、职业运动员——没有一种固定的刻板印象。同样，讨好型人格也可能粗犷、冷漠，甚至冷漠到你根本想不到他们会讨好别人。然而，他们的确如此。大多数人可能想不到我是个讨好型人格。至少乍一看，我似乎有点疏离。虽然我没有孩子，但我有着强烈的母性本能，我认为这源于我的伊朗血统。伊朗人是待客之道的典范，他们奉行“你的舒适就是我的舒适”的信条。我总是希望别人一切都好，但这并非出于渴望被人喜欢，而是出于一种想要一切平衡、想要身边每个人都快乐的需求。

Even if you are not a pleaser yourself, you need to understand the mentality, as the likelihood is that you are close to someone who is—maybe your spouse, your daughter, your colleague, or your best friend, and it’s important to recognize when they are biting back an ask. I cover what fear of no —saying it and hearing it—has to do with a need to be liked, and how a discomfort with silence plays into an inclination to give away our power. I address the costs of the pleaser mentality gone awry—a cost that looks a lot like resentment—and how pleasers particularly wrestle with being stuck in situations where they recognize they can’t please everyone.

即使你本人并非讨好型人格，你也需要了解这种心态，因为你身边很可能就有这样的人——也许是你的配偶、女儿、同事或挚友。因此，识别他们何时在委婉地拒绝你的请求至关重要。我会探讨害怕拒绝——无论是说“不”还是听到“不”——与渴望被喜欢之间的关联，以及对沉默的不安如何导致我们倾向于放弃自身的力量。我还会谈到讨好型人格失控的代价——这种代价往往表现为怨恨——以及讨好型人格者在意识到自己无法取悦所有人时，会如何挣扎于进退两难的境地。

“I wanted all to be fine and well in the world”

“我希望世界上一切都好。”

One day after a class I gave to entrepreneurs, I noticed a student, Liz, lingering. I took my time packing up my bag, and when we were the only two people left in the classroom, she asked if we could talk. Liz was impressive in every way. She’d been an executive at a large company for years before deciding to start her own business. Now that business was thriving. Liz already had a reputation in class for being smart, confident, and tough yet fair. She looked a little shaken, though, and I suggested we go out for a cup of coffee to discuss whatever was on her mind.

一天，在我给创业者们上完课后，我注意到一个名叫莉兹的学生还在教室里徘徊。我慢条斯理地收拾好书包，等教室里只剩下我们两个人时，她问我是否可以聊聊。莉兹各方面都令人印象深刻。在决定创业之前，她曾在一家大公司担任高管多年。如今，她的公司发展得非常成功。莉兹在班上以聪明、自信、坚韧而公正著称。不过，她看起来有些心事重重，于是我提议我们一起去喝杯咖啡，聊聊她心里想的。

“Class today was pretty intense for me,” she said when we were situated at a nearby café. I thought back over that day’s seminar. We’d talked quite a bit about the tendency so many have to give away their power to please others. It was a lively discussion, but Liz hadn’t contributed much. In fact, she’d been uncommonly quiet.

“今天的课对我来说挺累的，”我们坐在附近咖啡馆里时，她说道。我回想起那天的研讨会。我们聊了很多关于很多人为了取悦他人而放弃自身能力的倾向。讨论很热烈，但莉兹却没怎么发言。事实上，她异常安静。

“I seem really together and everything,” she said. “And I guess I am—now. But there’s some stuff in my past that I hadn’t really worked through, and class today brought it up for me.”

“我看起来一切都很顺利，”她说。“我想现在的确如此。但我过去有些事情一直没能真正解决，今天的课让我又想起了这些事。”

She explained that when she’d joined the large organization where she worked before becoming an entrepreneur, she hadn’t felt worthy of it. “I would often think, Why am I here? This job is too big for me and it’s only a matter of time before they realize it. I was overly tough on myself and thought I needed to perform at a crazy level. I had a terrible case of imposter syndrome.”

她解释说，在她成为企业家之前，刚加入那家大型企业时，她觉得自己配不上这份工作。“我经常想，我为什么会在这里？这份工作对我来说太大了，他们迟早会意识到这一点。我对自己要求过高，总觉得必须表现得非常出色。我当时患有严重的冒名顶替综合症。”

Her boss at the organization was supportive and looked for ways to empower her, repeatedly telling Liz, “You’ve got this.” “I got along really well with him in the beginning,” she explained. “We were completely aligned—it was us against the world, and we bonded over our shared purpose. We spent a lot of time together and became good friends. All along, I grew more confident in the work I was doing. But as time went on, I started noticing things about my boss that I didn’t like. I didn’t like the way he talked about other people. I didn’t like the strategies he used when working with others, which struck me as manipulative. He said inappropriate things to me about my appearance because he had gotten so comfortable with me. I didn’t call him out on his behavior, but I put distance between us. I still did my work to the same level as always, but I avoided spending as much time with him.”

她在公司的上司很支持她，想方设法让她更有力量，经常对莉兹说：“你能行的。” “一开始我和他相处得很好，”她解释说，“我们目标完全一致——我们一起对抗全世界，我们因为共同的目标而紧密相连。我们花了很多时间在一起，成了好朋友。与此同时，我对自己的工作也越来越有信心。但随着时间的推移，我开始注意到一些我不喜欢的上司的方面。我不喜欢他谈论别人的方式。我不喜欢他与他人合作时使用的策略，我觉得那是在操纵别人。因为他和我太熟了，所以他对我的外貌说了一些不恰当的话。我没有当面指责他的行为，但我和他保持了距离。我仍然像以前一样认真工作，但我尽量避免和他待在一起。”

Liz’s boss noticed. After a work event, when Liz accepted a ride home from a colleague, he was pissed. He said, “Don’t you know what it looks like if you drive away with him?” But it made no sense, Liz emphasized, because his alternative solution was that he would take her home. If optics were the issue, that would look just as bad. So Liz shrugged off his concern. “Soon I noticed that I started being left out of meetings. It didn’t matter much to me at first, because I trusted my boss’s intentions, and I was neck-deep in work anyway so I was happy to miss a meeting or two. But as time went on, I had an unsettled feeling.”

莉兹的老板注意到了。一次工作活动结束后，莉兹接受了一位同事的搭车回家，老板却很生气。他说：“你难道不知道你跟他一起开车会显得很没面子吗？”但莉兹强调说，这根本说不通，因为老板提出的另一个方案是他自己送她回家。如果问题出在形象上，那送她回家也一样糟糕。所以莉兹对他的担忧不以为意。“不久之后，我发现自己开始被排除在一些会议之外。一开始我并不在意，因为我相信老板的用意，而且我当时工作已经忙得不可开交，所以不参加一两个会议我倒也乐意。但随着时间的推移，我开始感到不安。”

Liz didn’t take her concerns to anyone else at the company. “I wanted all to be fine and well in the world,” she said. “I wanted everyone—even my boss, from whom I now kept my distance—to be okay, and I suppose I wanted to protect him. So I ignored my instincts. I doubled down on the work I was doing, focusing on the fact that it was going really well. I was getting exceptional results.”

莉兹没有向公司里的任何人倾诉她的担忧。“我希望一切都好，”她说，“我希望每个人——甚至包括我现在疏远的老板——都平安无事，我想我也想保护他。所以我忽略了自己的直觉。我加倍努力地工作，专注于工作进展顺利的事实。我取得了卓越的成果。”

Soon after, her boss took her out for dinner and said, “Liz, it looks like you’re not enjoying your job anymore. We used to spend more time together, but it seems like you don’t have time for me anymore. We don’t communicate the way we once did.”

不久之后，她的老板请她出去吃饭，并说：“莉兹，看来你不再喜欢你的工作了。我们以前经常在一起，但现在你好像没时间陪我了。我们之间的沟通也不像以前那么顺畅了。”

Naturally, Liz wondered what that had to do with her enjoying her job. But she didn’t say that. Instead she said, “No, I love what I’m doing. I love this work.”

莉兹自然想知道这跟她喜欢这份工作有什么关系。但她没有这么说。相反，她说：“不，我热爱我正在做的事情。我热爱这份工作。”

The next week, she said, she went into his office for her scheduled review. He closed the door and said, “This isn’t working anymore.”

她说，接下来的一周，她按计划去他的办公室进行复查。他关上门说：“这样下去不行了。”

Liz’s voice was soft when she got to this part of the story and I could tell she was fighting back tears. “It’s an understatement to say I was flabbergasted,” she said. “I was not only meeting my goals but, in many ways, exceeding expectations. The president of the company had taken the time to praise me during my last meeting with him. My team was efficient and productive, and we all worked really hard. I didn’t know what was happening, or, at least in that moment, why. I was shaking. I left the building without even saying good-bye to my team.

莉兹讲到这里时，声音变得很轻柔，我能感觉到她在努力抑制泪水。“说我当时震惊不已都算是轻描淡写了，”她说。“我不仅完成了目标，而且在很多方面都超出了预期。公司总裁在上次会议上还特意表扬了我。我的团队高效且富有成效，我们所有人都非常努力。我不知道发生了什么，或者说，至少在那一刻，我不知道为什么。我浑身颤抖。我甚至没来得及和我的团队道别就离开了大楼。”

“Almost immediately afterward, I was furious with myself. Why hadn’t I taken the red flags seriously? Why had I shrugged off the encounter at our dinner, when it was clear I wasn’t being evaluated fairly?”

“事后几乎立刻，我就对自己感到无比愤怒。为什么我没有认真对待那些危险信号？为什么在晚餐时，当很明显我没有受到公平评价时，我却对那次遭遇不以为意？”

Liz learned that her boss left shortly thereafter, for reasons she was never quite clear on. But it didn’t change what had happened. Her career at that organization was through.

莉兹得知她的老板不久后就离职了，至于原因她始终不得而知。但这并不能改变已经发生的事实。她在那家机构的职业生涯就此结束。

“In the months and years that followed,” she said, “it was painful for me to think about that job and the way I left. In fact, I was a wreck about it. I’ve only told a handful of people the story. But today brought it all up for me.”

“在接下来的几个月和几年里，”她说，“一想到那份工作以及我离开的方式，我就感到痛苦。事实上，我为此崩溃了。我只跟极少数人讲过这件事。但今天，这一切都再次浮现在我的脑海里。”

I squeezed her hand and we sat quietly together for a while. I didn’t feel she needed me to say anything but rather just needed to be heard. I appreciated the moment of reflection, as it allowed me to sort through my own emotions about what she’d said. That this confident, amazing woman could have doubted herself at the job in the first place was hard to believe. She had given away her power, and there was no way I could spin the story otherwise, nor was she looking for me to. What happened to her happens to women all the time—their desire for everything to be okay for everyone else outweighed their desire for everything to be okay for themselves . And it happens almost instinctually, such that they give away all of their power before they realize it. All I could say to Liz was that I was sorry it had happened. And then I said she could be sure it would not happen to her again.

我紧紧握住她的手，我们静静地坐了一会儿。我觉得她并不需要我说什么，只是需要有人倾听。我很珍惜这段反思的时光，它让我得以梳理自己对她所说的话的感受。难以置信，这样一个自信、优秀的女人，竟然会在工作中对自己产生怀疑。她放弃了自己的力量，我无法改变事实，她也不想让我改变。发生在她身上的事，在女人身上屡见不鲜——她们希望别人一切都好，却忽略了自己。这种事几乎是出于本能，她们在不知不觉中就放弃了所有的力量。我只能对莉兹说，我很抱歉发生了这样的事。然后我告诉她，她可以放心，这样的事不会再发生在她身上了。

Missing the moment to negotiate

错失谈判良机

Needing to be liked isn’t something you would guess of a company founder, sales guy, and tough-seeming New Yorker like James. But people are complicated, and the desire to please runs deep and defies stereotypes. (I also never would have guessed that outside of work James is a minister, which he is!) Last year he had a huge project for an internet company at Madison Square Garden that needed to be done in a short time frame. “I tried to anticipate everything, but in this case I knew that there was a possibility of things not getting done on the timeline of the client wanting it to get done,” he said. But, eager to please, he didn’t raise his concerns with their timetable, and he didn’t say no. And indeed, the schedule started to slip. “There were a lot of factors beyond my control,” James said. “I was relying on other vendors, relying on the City of New York. The customer was calling me and saying, ‘What’s happening? When is this going to change?’ I kept saying, ‘It’s okay—we’ll get there,’ but I didn’t have control of it—not really. I started to shut down.”

你可能很难想象，像詹姆斯这样一位公司创始人、销售员，以及看起来强硬的纽约客，竟然也渴望被人喜欢。但人是很复杂的，取悦他人的愿望根深蒂固，难以用刻板印象来概括。（我也从未想到，詹姆斯在工作之外竟然是一位牧师！）去年，他接手了一个位于麦迪逊广场花园的大型项目，需要为一家互联网公司赶工，而且时间非常紧迫。“我尽力预料到了所有可能出现的情况，但我知道，在这种情况下，有些事情可能无法按客户要求的时间表完成，”他说。然而，出于对客户好感的渴望，他没有提出自己对时间安排的担忧，也没有直接拒绝。结果，工期确实开始延误。“有很多因素超出了我的控制范围，”詹姆斯说道。 “我当时依赖其他供应商，依赖纽约市政府。客户打电话问我：‘到底怎么回事？什么时候才能改变？’我一直说：‘没关系，我们会解决的。’但我根本无能为力。我开始停工。”

In the end, the project was completed, albeit a few days late. The client didn’t care about the delay and was thrilled with the result. But the whole ordeal was incredibly stressful for James. “I just wanted to solve it, make everyone happy so I could move on. . . . If I could do it all over again, I would have been more straightforward with the customer from the beginning. I would have said, ‘I can do this, it’s possible, but just be aware that there are things outside of my control and it might not happen.’ I wish I’d been more confident about being up front with them, instead of feeling I didn’t want to disappoint them.”

最终，项目还是完成了，虽然晚了几天。客户并不在意延误，对结果非常满意。但整个过程对詹姆斯来说压力巨大。“我当时只想解决问题，让大家都满意，然后才能继续下一个项目……如果可以重来，我一开始就会更坦诚地和客户沟通。我会说，‘我可以做到，这是有可能的，但请您明白，有些事情我无法控制，最终可能无法实现。’我希望当时我能更有自信地坦诚相待，而不是害怕让他们失望。”

It’s notable that, just as with Liz’s quick departure from the company she loved, the tendency to please is almost reflexive. Great care needs to be taken to acknowledge that you are in a negotiation at all. Sometimes we don’t even realize that there are opportunities for us to counter with a solution that works for us because we are so used to just going along. Pleasers, in other words, can completely miss their moment to negotiate.

值得注意的是，就像莉兹迅速离开她深爱的公司一样，讨好型人格几乎是一种本能反应。我们需要格外注意，意识到自己正处于谈判之中。有时，我们甚至没有意识到有机会提出对我们有利的解决方案，因为我们太习惯于随波逐流。换句话说，讨好型人格可能会完全错过谈判的良机。

Dylan Reim, a former student of mine, didn’t recognize his predisposition to go along until an in-class exercise wherein he played the part of someone who had received an offer from a start-up. His task was to negotiate the offer’s terms with the HR director. “When I went into that,” he said, “I felt like I was still interviewing. Even though this person and I had never met before, I thought, I can’t have them thinking I’m anything less than committed to this position. This is not a place where I get to negotiate. ” In other words, to his mind, negotiating at all would come off badly. As we discussed in the debrief, though, the exercise was not an interview, it was a negotiation. He had already been chosen. The company had said that they wanted him as much as he wanted to be there. “Remembering that gives you so much emotional leverage,” he said. “You just need to remind yourself that you see them exactly the way they see you.” In other words, sure, you like them, but they like you, too! Asking for more will not change that. Miss the moment too often, and you’re looking at a significant wage gap between those who ask and those who didn’t realize that they could.

我以前的学生迪伦·雷姆（Dylan Reim）直到一次课堂练习才意识到自己有随波逐流的倾向。在那次练习中，他扮演了一位收到初创公司offer的人，任务是与人力资源总监协商offer条款。“当我开始练习的时候，”他说，“我感觉自己还在面试。虽然我和这个人之前素未谋面，但我心想，我不能让他们觉得我对这份工作不够投入。这不是可以讨价还价的地方。”换句话说，在他看来，任何形式的谈判都会适得其反。然而，正如我们在课后讨论中提到的，那次练习并非面试，而是谈判。他已经被选中了。公司表示，他们和他一样渴望加入。“记住这一点能给你带来巨大的情感优势，”他说，“你只需要提醒自己，你对他们的看法和他们对你的看法完全一致。”换句话说，没错，你喜欢他们，但他们也喜欢你！要求更高的薪水并不会改变现状。如果总是错过机会，就会出现那些主动争取更高薪水的人和那些没有意识到自己可以争取的人之间巨大的收入差距。

Former NFL star and former college football coach Hardy Nickerson remembered when he was first hired as a coach with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. Up to that point, his role had been that of a player, and he had agents taking care of him. He’d never had to negotiate for himself. Added to that was the fact that he really wanted this job. His first impulse when the team told him what they were going to pay him was to think, “Okay, I guess that’s my salary.” But then he recalled what he learned in my negotiations course. He now knew his initial thought was reflexive, borne out of a desire to go along to get along. “It occurred to me, wait, no—this is a negotiation ,” he said. “So I said, ‘What if you paid me such-and-such?’”

前NFL球星、前大学橄榄球教练哈迪·尼克尔森回忆起他最初被坦帕湾海盗队聘为教练时的情景。在此之前，他一直是一名球员，有经纪人为他打理一切。他从未需要为自己谈判。此外，他非常渴望得到这份工作。当球队告诉他薪水时，他的第一反应是：“好吧，看来这就是我的薪水了。” 但随后他想起了在我的谈判课程中学到的东西。他现在明白，自己最初的想法是下意识的，源于一种随波逐流的心态。“我突然意识到，等等，不对——这是一场谈判，”他说。“所以我说，‘如果你们给我多少钱呢？’”

We don’t stop to think what would happen if we don’t just go along. And although Hardy’s experience shows that this happens to both men and women, there is also a gender element that can’t be ignored here. In one of the most striking studies I’ve ever seen on the issue, subjects were told that they would be observed playing a word game and paid between $3 and $10. After the game, the experimenter said, “Here’s $3. Is $3 okay?” The men’s requests for more money exceeded the women’s by nine to one .

我们往往不会停下来思考，如果我们不随波逐流会发生什么。虽然哈迪的经历表明这种情况男女都会发生，但其中也存在不容忽视的性别因素。在我见过的最引人注目的一项研究中，受试者被告知他们将参与一个文字游戏，并获得3到10美元的报酬。游戏结束后，实验人员问道：“这是3美元。3美元够吗？”结果显示，男性要求更多报酬的次数是女性的九倍。

There’s a personality trait called sociotropy , more common in women, wherein a person cares a great deal about interpersonal relationships and being accepted by others. People with this personality trait will be overly nurturing, even to strangers. Studies show a correlation between sociotropy and eating more around others, and eating higher-calorie foods, because the sociotropic individual is so inclined to induce feelings of pleasure and not guilt in whomever they’re with.

有一种人格特质被称为“社交倾向”，在女性中更为常见。这种特质的人非常重视人际关系，渴望被他人接纳。他们往往过度关心他人，即使是对陌生人也是如此。研究表明，社交倾向与在他人面前进食更多、摄入更多高热量食物之间存在关联，因为社交倾向者倾向于让身边的人感到愉悦而非内疚。

A friend of mine who is sociotropic recently traveled to France, where her pleaser inclinations shone brightly. The French, in general, do not tend to be overly welcoming, and may even see American friendliness as inauthentic. Even knowing this, my friend constantly squirmed under what she perceived to be French disapproval of her every move or utterance. One evening she was paying the check at a restaurant, and when the waiter came over with a credit card reader, he asked her how much of a tip she would like to leave: 10, 15, or 20 percent? My friend knew that it’s not customary to tip for service in France but rather to leave a euro or two if you have them handy. But she was such a reflexive pleaser that she didn’t want to disappoint or feel awkward around this stranger whom she would never see again. He ended up getting a much healthier tip than he should have.

我有个朋友性格比较外向，最近去了趟法国，她讨好别人的本性在那儿体现得淋漓尽致。法国人通常不太热情好客，甚至可能觉得美国人的热情不够真诚。即便如此，我的朋友还是总觉得法国人对她的一举一动、一言一行都有些不赞同，心里很不自在。一天晚上，她在餐厅结账，服务员拿着信用卡走过来问她想给多少小费：10%、15%还是20%？我的朋友知道在法国，给小费并不常见，通常只要手边有零钱就给一两欧元。但她太习惯讨好别人了，不想让这位以后再也不会见面的陌生人失望，也不想在她面前感到尴尬。结果，服务员拿到的小费远远超过了他应该得到的。

Julia is a management consultant and, like James, she has struggled with that moment when a client makes an ask, and you want more than anything to say yes in order to make them happy. The consultant world is very high-stakes; clients pay top dollar for services like Julia’s, and they expect a lot in return. “There are always moments when you’re in information overload,” she said, “and the impulse in those moments is to squander opportunity to hold your ground. I could be in a room with my consulting team and have my client on the phone telling me, ‘We need this kind of deliverable and your deliverable isn’t getting it right now.’” You may not realize it, but this is a negotiation. It’s subtle, but it is. “They have an ask,” said Julia, “and your response could impact what you have to do . . . sometimes, the information overload makes it impossible to real-time process.” The natural instinct of the pleaser in this situation is to agree to whatever will make the client happy—or at least, happi er . The trap is set. The pleaser says yes even though she’s unsure she can deliver what they’re asking. And then kills herself to please again.

朱莉娅是一名管理顾问，和詹姆斯一样，她也曾遇到过这样的情况：客户提出要求，你恨不得立刻答应，好让客户高兴。咨询行业竞争激烈，客户为像朱莉娅这样的服务支付高价，自然也期望得到丰厚的回报。“总会有信息过载的时候，”她说，“在那种情况下，你往往会因为坚持己见而错失良机。比如，我可能正和我的咨询团队在同一个房间里，客户突然打电话告诉我：‘我们需要这样的成果，而你现在的成果还达不到我们的要求。’”你可能没有意识到，但这其实是一场谈判。虽然很微妙，但确实如此。“他们提出了要求，”朱莉娅说，“你的回应可能会影响你接下来的工作……有时候，信息过载会让你无法实时处理信息。”在这种情况下，讨好型人格的本能反应是答应任何能让客户高兴——或者至少让他们更高兴——的事情。陷阱就此设下。讨好型人格即使不确定自己能否满足对方的要求，也会答应下来。然后，为了再次取悦他人，她会拼尽全力。

Julia will say, “Let me think about that and get back to you.” Or, if she’s able to identify what it is about the client’s ask that concerns her, she’ll say, “Here’s what’s going on in my head, and here are my concerns.” She’ll be open about her lack of confidence in getting them what they want. “I’ll tell them I’m worried about the time my team has. I’ll share a bit more. I’ll explain that the team has focused on this other list of priorities, and engage the client in a discussion around what is actually most important to tackle—people are reasonable, and will accept that there are trade-offs.” Pushing aside her desire to please and sharing her concerns is far better than attesting that she can do it but feeling terror on the inside.

朱莉娅会说：“让我考虑一下，稍后回复您。”或者，如果她能找出客户要求中让她担忧的地方，她会说：“我心里是这么想的，也有些顾虑。”她会坦诚地表达自己对能否满足客户需求缺乏信心。“我会告诉他们，我担心团队的时间不够。我会进一步解释。我会说明团队目前专注于其他优先事项，并引导客户讨论真正最重要的问题是什么——大家都是通情达理的，会接受权衡取舍。”与其明明内心忐忑不安却信誓旦旦地说自己能做到，不如克制住想要取悦客户的冲动，坦诚地表达自己的担忧。

Time management coach Elizabeth Grace Saunders writes about how a big piece of the boundaries problem is that people set up unrealistic expectations for how their role is defined. For instance, say you’re a manager and you always keep your door open when you’re not in meetings, because you feel that accessibility is part and parcel of being a good manager. The problem is, that means that you never get the work that requires quiet done during work hours, and so you end up doing that work during family time. Saunders argues that the solution is redefining what it means to be a good manager. Sure, a good manager is reasonably accessible, but a good manager also shows how important it is to focus on high-priority work. “In instances like this,” she says of the manager who won’t close her door, “you’ve set up strict rules about what someone in a role should or shouldn’t do; but in fact, these rules are negotiable.”

时间管理教练伊丽莎白·格雷斯·桑德斯指出，界限问题的一个重要根源在于人们对自身角色设定了不切实际的期望。例如，假设你是一位经理，在非会议时间总是敞开着办公室的门，因为你认为保持开放是优秀经理的必备素质。问题在于，这意味着你永远无法在工作时间完成那些需要安静环境的工作，最终只能在陪伴家人的时间里处理这些工作。桑德斯认为，解决之道在于重新定义优秀经理的含义。诚然，优秀的经理应该保持一定的开放性，但同时也要展现出专注于高优先级工作的重要性。“在像你这样不愿关门的经理身上，”她说道，“你为某个职位的人设定了严格的规则，规定了他们应该做什么或不应该做什么；但实际上，这些规则是可以协商的。”

For pleasers who struggle with no , then, a few things are helpful to keep in mind: (1) Watch your reflexive instincts. It’s too easy if you’re energetic and generally a “can-do” kind of a person to say yes and miss the negotiation altogether; and (2) remember that saying yes to one thing might well be saying no to another. Saying yes to a demanding client at work means more pressure and less sleep; saying yes when the French waiter asks if you want to leave a big tip means you don’t have enough budgeted to take your kid out for a special dessert afterward. Something has to give, and that something might be your critical self-care, so knowing that can help you be more strategic about what you say yes to. And (3) check whether your reason for the yes is intertwined with an unrealistic definition of your role. Don’t blindly accept this definition—question it. This is harder than it may seem, because often just the promise of a business relationship is enough to make us overcommit.

对于那些难以拒绝别人、总是讨好别人的人来说，以下几点值得注意：（1）注意你的本能反应。如果你精力充沛、总是“干劲十足”，很容易就会一口答应，从而完全忽略了谈判的必要性；（2）记住，答应一件事很可能意味着拒绝另一件事。答应工作中要求苛刻的客户意味着更大的压力和更少的睡眠；答应法国服务员是否要给高额小费意味着你没有足够的预算带孩子出去吃甜点。总要有所取舍，而你可能需要牺牲一些自我关怀，所以意识到这一点可以帮助你更策略性地选择答应的事情。（3）检查你答应的理由是否与对自身角色的不切实际的定义有关。不要盲目接受这种定义——要质疑它。这比看起来要难，因为通常仅仅是建立商业关系的希望就足以让我们过度承诺。

Resentment: The hidden danger for the pleaser

怨恨：讨好者的潜在危险

Women are particularly prone to be pleasers, but it may surprise you that I have seen this with pro football players, too. There is a common dynamic in which NFL players—and professional athletes in general—have friends and family around them who always lean on them for money. When this happens, the athletes feel like they can’t say no because they’ll appear ungrateful for their good fortune, or greedy, or perceived as if they’re turning their backs on those who supported them before they “made it.” So they say yes, and yes, and yes, until they become resentful.

女性尤其容易取悦他人，但你或许会惊讶地发现，我在职业橄榄球运动员身上也观察到了这种现象。NFL球员——以及所有职业运动员——身边总有一些亲朋好友依赖他们花钱，这很常见。在这种情况下，运动员觉得自己不能拒绝，因为拒绝会显得不知感恩、贪婪，或者像是在背叛那些在他们“成名”之前支持他们的人。所以他们只能一味答应，直到心生怨恨。

When Hardy Nickerson was chosen as a fifth-round draft pick for the Pittsburgh Steelers back in 1987, the newspapers reported that he’d signed for a quarter of a million dollars (which, by today’s standards, is laughably low for a fifth-round pick). His extended family thought they’d hit the jackpot—that they would no longer have to work, that Hardy could pay off their car payments and pick up random expenses. But no one did the math—it was a multiyear contract, so he made $75,000 a year before taxes. Still, he said, it was good money and he helped wherever he could. Things changed when he had children of his own and his financial focus changed to providing for them. “Telling people no is hard,” he said. “You think, ‘They were with me when I wasn’t so-and-so,’ which makes it difficult. But I’ve had to tell my mother no. I had to tell my father no.” He said it created a lot of resentment all around, but now he has a better perspective on it. He transitioned to the role of coach—for high school, college, and the NFL—and has mentored dozens of young players. “What I try to tell people—especially those guys who are first-generation anything,” he said, “is that you can help those around you but you have to understand where you’re at and to what extent you can help them. And you have to ask, is that help something that’s going to create a line of more handouts down the road, or it is something that’s going to help them grow from that help and produce something from the help?” Otherwise, he said, players can get to a point where they feel like a human ATM.

1987年，哈迪·尼克森在选秀大会第五轮被匹兹堡钢人队选中。当时报纸报道说，他签了一份价值25万美元的合同（以今天的标准来看，这对于一个第五轮新秀来说简直是天价）。他的大家庭都以为他们中了头彩——他们再也不用工作了，哈迪可以帮他们还清车贷，还能补贴一些零零碎碎的开销。但没人算过账——这是一份多年合同，所以他税前年收入只有7.5万美元。不过，他仍然觉得这笔钱不错，而且他尽其所能地帮助家人。后来，他有了自己的孩子，经济重心转移到养家糊口上，情况就发生了变化。“拒绝别人很难，”他说，“你会想，‘他们在我年轻的时候就一直支持我’，这让拒绝变得很困难。但我不得不拒绝我的母亲，我不得不拒绝我的父亲。”他说，这件事当时引起了很多人的不满，但现在他对这件事有了更深刻的理解。他转型成为教练——执教过高中、大学和NFL球队——并指导过数十名年轻球员。“我经常告诉人们——尤其是那些第一代大学生，”他说，“你可以帮助身边的人，但你必须明白自己的处境，以及你能帮到他们的程度。你必须扪心自问，这种帮助是会让他们以后需要更多施舍，还是能帮助他们成长，让他们从中有所收获？”否则，他说，球员们可能会觉得自己就像一台自动取款机。

Although many athletes initially feel good about being in a position to help the people who helped them in some way before they became professional athletes, they will at some point, sooner than later, feel resentful. Why does everyone think that I have endless resources? I feel like they’re taking advantage of this situation. (Incidentally, it’s a positive when they realize it. Sometimes they never do and run into financial challenges as a result.) The players end up removing themselves from relationships instead of just confronting what’s making them uncomfortable. When asked why these relationships have gone sour, they externalize it. “So-and-so was taking advantage of me.” I push back. “Did you ever say no? Did you ever set boundaries?” Others can’t know what we want if we don’t say it, and this is true whether it’s about refilling the coffeepot, being treated badly by a boss, or getting hit up constantly for money.

虽然很多运动员最初都乐于帮助那些在他们成为职业运动员之前帮助过他们的人，但他们迟早都会感到怨恨。为什么每个人都觉得我有用不完的资源？我觉得他们是在占我便宜。（顺便说一句，当他们意识到这一点时，这其实是件好事。但有些人却始终意识不到，结果陷入经济困境。）球员们最终选择疏远这些人，而不是直面让他们感到不舒服的事情。当被问及这些关系为何破裂时，他们会把责任推卸给别人。“某某占我便宜。” 我会反驳。“你有没有说过‘不’？你有没有划清界限？” 如果我们不说出来，别人就无法知道我们想要什么，无论是帮忙续咖啡、被老板苛待，还是被人不停地要钱，都是如此。

I think of what these athletes experience as the “friends and family syndrome,” and I see it all the time with entrepreneurs who have a service business. A proprietor of a coffee shop gives everyone he’s ever met a discount. The graphic designer is asked to make everyone’s websites or business cards and never says no. These entrepreneurs don’t want to hurt their relationship with the person asking. But if they don’t say no, if they don’t draw a boundary, they’re hurting the relationship anyway because they’re chipping away at it with a little hammer called resentment. They don’t see that they can say no and still preserve the relationship.

我认为这些运动员的经历可以称之为“亲友情结”，我在经营服务型企业的创业者身上也经常看到这种情况。比如，咖啡店老板会给所有认识的人打折；平面设计师会被请去做网站或名片，却从不拒绝。这些创业者不想破坏与求助者的关系。但如果他们不说“不”，不划清界限，最终还是会伤害彼此的关系，因为他们就像用一把叫做“怨恨”的小锤子一点点地敲打着这段关系。他们没有意识到，即使拒绝，他们仍然可以维护彼此的关系。

When you set a boundary, you are putting focus on yourself and your needs, but that doesn’t mean you’re not looking out for others’ needs as well. “I would love to design the logo for your daughter’s school auction,” the graphic designer might say to his cousin, “because you’re family and of course I want to help this good cause. There are a lot of causes I want to help with. But if I did that, I wouldn’t have time to finish my paid work and keep a thriving business.” How you explain your position will vary because so will the boundaries. The only hard-and-fast rule: Know what you’re willing to do for others without putting yourself in a bad spot or fostering resentment. What can you afford? What’s your budget? How often will you do it? Is there a particular category you will always cover if you can, versus the never-ending ask? For instance, I’ve advised NFL players to say things to their family and friends such as, “I will cover educational or medical expenses to the point I can, but that’s all I can do.”

当你设定界限时，你是在关注自身需求，但这并不意味着你忽略了他人的需求。“我很想为你女儿学校的拍卖会设计logo，”平面设计师可能会对他的表弟说，“因为你是我的家人，我当然想为这项公益事业出一份力。有很多公益事业我都想参与。但如果我这么做，我就没时间完成我的本职工作，也没时间维持我蓬勃发展的事业了。” 你如何解释你的立场会因人而异，因为界限也会因人而异。唯一不变的原则是：清楚你愿意为他人付出多少，同时又不让自己陷入困境或招致怨恨。你能负担得起什么？你的预算是多少？你会多久做一次？有没有一些你力所能及就会一直承担的领域，而不是没完没了地索要？例如，我曾建议NFL球员对他们的家人和朋友说：“我会尽我所能承担教育或医疗费用，但仅此而已。”

Boundaries like these are hard to set in office settings, too, where, as in the case of the manager who never closes his door, people negotiate against themselves without even recognizing it. Sheryl, for example, is a professor of economics at a university. She is a numbers person, so she is all about the most probable outcomes and labor economics. She is highly accomplished, a sought-after power player, and she knows it. So she negotiated a healthy raise for herself about a year ago. A few months later, she was asked to lead up the department’s administrative team—a two-year, time-consuming extra commitment that did not come with extra compensation. Sheryl figured she should do it—she had just gotten this big raise and wanted to be seen as a team player. Then another professor had to take a leave of absence and asked Sheryl to take over his class. Sheryl was told it would just be five classes, and that he’d return the favor the following year, so she agreed. Again, she wanted to be seen as a team player, and she knew that because of her raise, she was being compensated more than anyone else in the department. As it turned out, her colleague was going to miss ten classes, not five. And Sheryl would also have to do additional office hours and much more grading than she’d originally understood.

在办公室环境中，像这样的界限也很难划定。就像那位从不关门的经理一样，人们在不知不觉中就与自己进行了利益博弈。例如，谢丽尔是一位大学经济学教授。她擅长数字，所以她关注的是最可能的结果和劳动经济学。她成就斐然，是炙手可热的权力人物，而且她也深知这一点。因此，大约一年前，她为自己争取到了一笔可观的加薪。几个月后，她被要求领导系里的行政团队——这是一项为期两年、耗时耗力的额外工作，而且没有额外的报酬。谢丽尔觉得她应该接受——她刚刚获得了大幅加薪，也希望被视为团队的一份子。之后，另一位教授需要休假，并请谢丽尔代他授课。谢丽尔被告知只需要代五节课，而且第二年他会回报她，所以她同意了。她再次强调，她希望被视为团队的一员，而且她知道，由于加薪，她的收入比部门里的任何人都高。结果，她的同事要缺席十节课，而不是五节。谢丽尔还得增加办公时间，批改作业也比她最初预想的要多得多。

Sheryl felt stuck. She swallowed her desire to renegotiate and missed her moment. Even though she has tenure, and her job is in no way at risk, she felt she had to please her department heads and accommodate this professor. Now she is frustrated, and angry at most everyone else in her department. She feels overworked and underappreciated. Her husband isn’t too happy about the situation, either, as she is now away from home teaching most nights, putting more burden on him to take care of the kids. Sheryl had done a great job knowing her worth and telling herself the right story when she negotiated her raise. But then her pleaser instinct kicked in, and she lost most of what she’d gained.

谢丽尔感到进退两难。她压抑住重新谈判的念头，错失了良机。尽管她已获得终身教职，工作也丝毫没有风险，但她还是觉得必须讨好系里的领导，迁就那位教授。现在她感到沮丧，对系里的几乎所有人都感到愤怒。她觉得自己工作过度，却得不到应有的认可。她的丈夫对此也颇有微词，因为她现在几乎每天晚上都要外出授课，这无疑加重了他照顾孩子的负担。谢丽尔在谈判加薪时，对自己价值的认知和自我安慰都做得很好。但随后，她讨好的本能又作祟，让她失去了大部分努力的成果。

The cost of resentment like Sheryl’s is no small matter. She put herself last, thinking it noble, or the right thing to do. I see this pitfall constantly with entrepreneurs who don’t see the trade-offs they’re really making. In some cases, it leads to burnout, or divorce, or family feuds. It leads to leaving a job you might love. The pleaser isn’t likely to think about these costs, believing she can handle it. That’s what makes this habit so dangerous. And so ironic, because it’s a desire to avoid making waves that causes pleasers to say yes in the first place.

像谢丽尔那样心怀怨恨的代价可不小。她总是把自己的利益放在最后，还以为这样做很崇高，或者是正确的。我经常看到创业者陷入这种陷阱，他们看不到自己真正需要权衡的利弊。在某些情况下，这会导致精疲力竭、离婚或家庭不和。它甚至会导致你放弃一份自己可能热爱的工作。讨好型人格的人不太可能考虑这些代价，他们相信自己能够承受。这正是这种习惯如此危险的原因。而且非常讽刺的是，正是出于避免惹麻烦的心理，讨好型人格的人才会一开始就说“是”。

Although these are all professional examples, personal examples are everywhere. When my friend Maria’s second child was an infant and she was tired more often than not, whenever her husband asked if she’d be solo with the kids so he could meet friends or go on a camping trip, she automatically said yes. She wanted him to be happy, and she’d always said “Go for it” whenever he’d asked before. But then she found herself more and more resentful every time he came home. It wasn’t his fault he’d gone—she’d told him to. But she’d done so reflexively. In time, she learned not to respond right away when he asked. She still wanted to say yes—and she often would—but she knew she needed to take a moment to really think through whether she had the bandwidth to handle the kids by herself. She would ask herself, “If I say yes, am I going to resent him when he comes home?” If the answer was yes, then they would think of another option together, whether it was getting a babysitter or making sure that she had part of that day to herself, too.

虽然这些都是职业方面的例子，但个人经历中的例子比比皆是。我的朋友玛丽亚的第二个孩子还是婴儿的时候，她常常感到疲惫不堪。每当她丈夫问她是否愿意独自带孩子，好让他去见朋友或去露营时，她总是下意识地答应。她希望他开心，以前每次他提出这样的要求，她也总是说“去吧”。但后来，她发现自己每次他回家后都会越来越怨恨他。他出门并不是他的错——是她让他去的。但她当时只是出于本能地答应了。渐渐地，她学会了不要在他提出要求时立刻答应。她仍然想答应——而且她也常常会答应——但她知道自己需要冷静下来，认真思考一下自己是否有能力独自照顾孩子。她会问自己：“如果我答应了，他回家后我会不会怨恨他？”如果答案是肯定的，那么他们会一起想出其他办法，比如找个保姆，或者确保她那天也能有一部分时间属于自己。

When we care about people, we can feel like saying no will hurt them. We don’t want them to feel belittled or rejected, and in Maria’s case, she also wanted to maintain the job description she’d set up for herself as an accommodating, easygoing wife. But there’s no way around the buildup of anger that happens when you instinctually overpromise.

当我们关心别人时，会觉得说“不”会伤害他们。我们不想让他们感到被轻视或被拒绝，而玛丽亚的情况是，她也想继续扮演她自己设定的那个善解人意、随和的妻子角色。但是，当你本能地过度承诺时，积压的怒气是无法避免的。

The fear of no

对无的恐惧

Just as much as they fear saying no, pleasers are afraid of hearing no. This fear takes up so much room in our psyche that we don’t want to put ourselves in the position where we hear it at all. We either don’t ask for what we should, or we rush to fill up a silence that we fear will lead to a negative response. Think of how often we end conversations or emails that contain an ask with “If it doesn’t work for you, I understand,” or “This is of course negotiable.” Why? Why do we immediately offer an easy out? Because we’ve already told ourselves they’ll come back and say no, and we’re so afraid of that word that cushioning it makes it less scary. When people recognize how often they do this unthinkingly, it’s jarring. A friend of mine told me she didn’t realize she had this tendency until she was helping her young daughter craft an email “ask” for a school fund-raiser and encouraged her to end it with, “I totally understand if this doesn’t work.” We coach backing off before we coach for courage.

就像他们害怕说“不”一样，讨好型人格的人也害怕听到“不”。这种恐惧占据了我们内心如此巨大的空间，以至于我们根本不想让自己陷入听到“不”的境地。我们要么不去提出我们应该提出的要求，要么急于填补沉默，因为我们害怕沉默会导致负面的回应。想想看，我们有多少次在提出请求后，以“如果你不方便，我理解”或“当然，这可以商量”来结束对话或邮件？为什么？为什么我们总是立刻提供一个容易脱身的借口？因为我们已经告诉自己，他们最终会说“不”，而我们如此害怕“不”这个字眼，所以用一些委婉的说法来减轻恐惧。当人们意识到自己如此频繁地不假思索地这样做时，会感到非常震惊。我的一个朋友告诉我，直到她帮助年幼的女儿撰写一封学校筹款邮件时，她才意识到自己有这种倾向。她鼓励女儿在邮件结尾加上一句：“如果这行不通，我完全理解。”我们先教导学员退缩，然后再教导他们勇敢。

One average guy, a freelance IT specialist named Jason Comely, made a game out of hearing no when he realized that his fear of it was holding him back. He decided that he needed to get used to hearing it. He aimed to get rejected every single day, so he would ask strangers for things he pretty much knew they’d reject—like a ride across town, or a discount on something he hadn’t yet purchased. The desensitization was so empowering for him that he made a card game out of it called Rejection Therapy. “You’re going to feel great afterward,” he told NPR about getting intentionally rejected. “You’re going to feel like, ‘Wow. I disobeyed fear.’” I really like the idea of this game, though dramatic immersion like that isn’t for everyone. I’m deathly afraid of snakes, but the last thing that would help me get over it would be to be surrounded by the nasty creatures. Just the image is enough to give me a heart attack. The point, though, isn’t whether desensitization is the most effective way to get over a fear of no, but that the word no is so frightening and paralyzing for so many people that they are driven to somehow, some way loosen its power over them.

一个名叫杰森·科姆利（Jason Comely）的普通人，一位自由职业IT专家，意识到自己对拒绝的恐惧阻碍了自己前进，于是他把“拒绝”变成了一种游戏。他决定要学会习惯被拒绝。他的目标是每天都被拒绝，所以他会向陌生人提出一些他几乎肯定会被拒绝的要求——比如搭车穿过市区，或者给还没买的东西打折。这种脱敏训练让他感觉非常棒，于是他以此为灵感，制作了一款名为“拒绝疗法”（Rejection Therapy）的卡牌游戏。“玩完之后你会感觉很棒，”他告诉美国国家公共电台（NPR），“你会觉得，‘哇，我战胜了恐惧。’”我很喜欢这个游戏的创意，不过这种沉浸式体验并不适合所有人。我非常害怕蛇，但最不可能让我克服恐惧的就是被这些可怕的生物包围。光是想象它们的样子就足以让我心脏病发作。然而，重点不在于脱敏疗法是否是克服对“不”的恐惧的最有效方法，而在于“不”这个字对很多人来说是如此可怕和令人麻痹，以至于他们不得不以某种方式、通过某种途径来减轻它对他们的影响。

I spend an inordinate amount of time with my students talking about this fear of hearing no, but my approach is less about desensitization and more about looking at the entire exchange differently. Instead of seeing no as rejection, see it as a piece of information in a larger conversation. What other information can you get from that no ? Where can it take you?

我花了大量时间和学生讨论这种害怕被拒绝的恐惧，但我的方法与其说是脱敏，不如说是换个角度看待整个交流。不要把“不”看作是拒绝，而是把它看作是更大对话中的一个信息点。你还能从这个“不”中获得什么信息？它又会把你引向何方？

Undeniably, some no s just suck. If you get rejected from a grant or a job, for instance, and you get a form letter telling you so, it’s tempting to just turn away from the no because it’s painful. But I coach people to summon the confidence to turn into it instead. It’s still information. If the rejector is willing, you could try to find out why you were rejected, so that you can do better next time. Granted, it’s not comfortable, but in the words of the great Wayne Gretzky, “You’ll always miss 100 percent of the shots you don’t take.”

不可否认，有些拒绝确实令人难受。例如，如果你申请科研基金或工作被拒，收到的是一封千篇一律的拒绝信，你可能会因为这种打击而选择逃避。但我会指导人们鼓起勇气，积极面对拒绝。这仍然是宝贵的信息。如果拒绝者愿意，你可以尝试了解被拒的原因，以便下次做得更好。诚然，这并不容易，但正如伟大的韦恩·格雷茨基所说：“你永远不会错过所有你没有尝试的机会。”

This is very different from the telemarketer’s way of not taking no for an answer. Usually working from a script, they don’t take the conversation further, they don’t ask questions, and they won’t let you off the phone. As a result you feel you haven’t been listened to. That’s enough to make anyone crazy. What I’m recommending is very different and is all about being inquisitive and not being afraid to stay in the conversation.

这和电话推销员不接受拒绝的方式截然不同。他们通常照本宣科，不会深入交谈，不会提问，也不会让你挂断电话。结果就是，你会感觉自己根本没被倾听。这足以让人抓狂。我推荐的方法完全不同，它强调的是保持好奇心，不要害怕继续对话。

Entrepreneurs have their own version of the Rejection Therapy game, as often getting funding and customers requires no after no after no. They have to learn from those no s, or they’ll never get off the ground. Sebastian Jackson was told no three times by Wayne State University before they agreed to let him open a barbershop on campus. “That first no was tough because I did hear it as no,” he said. “But I was encouraged to go back to figure out why I was told no. That was a lightbulb moment for me.” His request for a meeting to learn why he was told no was also rejected, though. So he found someone internally at Wayne State who understood how the university made its business decisions. This person said that the rejection was less about the business model than it was about Sebastian personally, as he’d worked in the previous campus barbershop that had failed. What made Sebastian think he could own a barbershop and succeed? The decision makers weren’t convinced he had an answer.

创业者也有他们自己的一套“拒绝疗法”，因为获得资金和客户往往需要经历一次又一次的拒绝。他们必须从这些拒绝中吸取教训，否则永远无法起步。塞巴斯蒂安·杰克逊在韦恩州立大学同意让他在校园里开一家理发店之前，曾三次遭到拒绝。“第一次被拒绝很痛苦，因为我当时确实听到了‘不’这个字，”他说。“但我被鼓励回去弄清楚被拒绝的原因。那对我来说是一个顿悟的时刻。”然而，他要求会面了解拒绝原因的请求也被拒绝了。于是，他找到了韦恩州立大学内部一位了解学校商业决策流程的人。这个人说，拒绝的原因与其说是商业模式的问题，不如说是塞巴斯蒂安个人的问题，因为他曾在之前那家失败的校园理发店工作过。是什么让塞巴斯蒂安认为自己可以拥有一家成功的理发店呢？决策者们并不相信他能给出答案。

Sebastian set out to solve the problem. He requested letters of recommendation that would bolster what he personally could bring to the business, then submitted them to the university and asked again. Again they said no. This time they told him it was because his business model was shaky. So he went back to the drawing board and made the model more clear. A third time, the university said no, explaining that he didn’t have enough money to execute what he wanted to do. Still Sebastian didn’t give up. And although he might not have had much money, he did have enough to pay rent on the barbershop space—a space that the university was currently losing money on because it didn’t have a tenant. Finally, the university relented. Sebastian had used those no s as data and shown that he had the perseverance to succeed. (As a side note, Sebastian’s barbershop, The Social Club, is wildly successful. Beyond cutting hair, The Social Club is a social connector and community builder in Detroit, and I’ll come back to it later.)

塞巴斯蒂安着手解决这个问题。他请求推荐信来佐证自己能为企业带来的价值，然后将推荐信提交给大学，再次提出申请。结果再次被拒。这次，他们告诉他，原因是他的商业模式不够稳固。于是，他重新审视自己的商业模式，使其更加清晰。第三次，大学还是拒绝了他，解释说他没有足够的资金来实施他的计划。但塞巴斯蒂安并没有放弃。虽然他可能资金不多，但他至少有足够的钱支付理发店的租金——而这间店面当时正因为没有租户而亏损。最终，大学妥协了。塞巴斯蒂安把这些拒绝都当作数据，证明了他拥有成功的毅力。（顺便一提，塞巴斯蒂安的理发店“社交俱乐部”非常成功。除了理发之外，“社交俱乐部”还是底特律的社交纽带和社区建设中心，我稍后会详细介绍。）

Believe it or not, when you begin to see no as a piece of data in a conversation, then when you get an immediate yes it doesn’t feel as gratifying anymore. No gives you the opportunity to go deeper into a conversation, and to know each other better. In fact, a good no that gives you more information is more valuable than a bad yes .

信不信由你，当你开始把“不”看作是对话中的一条信息时，即使对方立刻答应，也不会再感到那么欣喜。“不”给了你深入对话、更好地了解彼此的机会。事实上，一个好的“不”比一个糟糕的“是”更有价值，因为它能提供更多信息。

Discomfort with silence

对沉默感到不适

As Francis Bacon said, “Silence is the sleep that nourishes wisdom.” The pleaser should take note, as pleasers tend not to let things just sit when they need to, not to let them breathe. “I hate silence,” said my student James. “I feel this angst poke at me, like I need to fill up some empty space because it’s uncomfortable. If I give someone a cost and they cringe, my past reaction would be to try to find a way to make them feel better.” When you jump in too soon, though, you don’t give yourself time to think through a response, and you don’t give your counterpart time to let things settle. It takes a lot of confidence to just sit in silence, particularly for entrepreneurs who, one way or another, are always selling. They frequently go to a story of doubt: Oh no, was it too expensive? Oh no, did I lose this deal?

正如弗朗西斯·培根所说，“沉默是滋养智慧的睡眠。” 那些总是讨好别人的人应该注意这一点，因为他们往往不会在需要的时候让事情静下来，不给它们喘息的空间。“我讨厌沉默，”我的学生詹姆斯说，“我感觉内心一阵焦虑，好像需要填补某种空白，因为它让我感到不舒服。如果我告诉别人价格，而他们却畏缩不前，我过去会想方设法让他们感觉好一些。” 然而，如果你过早地介入，你既没有时间思考如何回应，也没有时间让对方冷静下来。保持沉默需要很大的勇气，尤其是对于那些总是以各种方式推销的企业家来说。他们常常会陷入怀疑：糟糕，是不是太贵了？糟糕，我是不是丢了这笔生意？

“Sometimes things have to take their course,” James said. “It can’t be solved right away. Sometimes the person on the other side needs time to process things. But trying to come up with a solution, immediately trying to solve the problem, is not always solving the problem.” James struggled to put this into practice in his career and had to dig deep to understand why it was so hard for him. “I have this personal thing where I struggle when something is hanging out there and is unresolved. It’s hard for me to move on to the next issue. I need to solve it right away if I have a perception that a customer would be angry with me or disappointed with me.”

“有时候事情必须顺其自然，”詹姆斯说。“问题不可能立刻解决。有时候对方需要时间来消化。但试图立刻找到解决方案，试图立即解决问题，并不总是能解决问题。”詹姆斯在工作中很难将这一点付诸实践，他不得不深入挖掘自己，才能明白为什么这对他来说如此困难。“我个人有个毛病，就是如果事情悬而未决，我会很难受。我很难继续处理下一个问题。如果我预感到客户会对我生气或失望，我就必须立刻解决问题。”

James has made being comfortable with silence a goal, and he actively practices it, just as he actively practices not jumping in to “fix” things right away. “Not reacting quickly . . . has more beneficial outcomes in whatever business scenario I’m in. . . . Maybe instead of lowering the cost I come up with an idea to make the product in a less expensive way. I don’t have to cut my cost. I’m giving the customer something at a better price or a better price point. I’ve found that to be very beneficial in my business life.” It’s one thing to know that comfort with silence is important, and another matter altogether to actually be comfortable with it. Practicing, as James does, helps—but so does feeling confident in your ask. If you know you are on solid ground in whatever it is you’re proposing, it’s much easier to just let it sit there instead of rushing in to compensate somehow for the fact that you’ve asked at all.

詹姆斯把学会坦然面对沉默作为一项目标，并且积极实践，就像他积极练习不急于“解决”问题一样。“不急于反应……在任何商业环境中都能带来更有利的结果……也许我不会直接降低成本，而是会想出一个更经济的方法来生产产品。我不需要削减成本，而是以更优惠的价格或更合适的价位为客户提供产品。我发现这在我的商业生活中非常有益。” 知道坦然面对沉默很重要是一回事，真正做到坦然面对沉默则是另一回事。像詹姆斯那样练习固然有帮助，但对自己提出的要求充满信心也同样重要。如果你确信自己提出的建议站得住脚，那么就很容易让它保持原样，而不是急于弥补自己提出要求的不足。

I personally find that I’m comfortable with silence when I’m sitting in the presence of my counterpart. There’s still so much information I’m able to glean—about his posture, the tilt of his head, the subtle expressions on his face. I begin feeling less comfortable with silence as physical distance grows. I don’t do well with silence on the phone, but I try not to focus on the dead space. I often try to just kill time on my end by sending an email or looking through my in-box while I wait. Email silence is the most distant, and, for me, the most uncomfortable. If I send a potential client a proposal and suggested fee structure, for instance, and don’t hear back right away, I go a little nuts. That’s when my storytelling factory starts up big-time, and I start thinking they’re stunned by my high fees; I start fearing I’m an imposter and that I most certainly overbid. I squirm and doubt and am generally not a happy person. I do not, however, write back: “Haven’t heard from you. Just wanted to check in. I want to make sure you know that what I proposed is completely negotiable.” Instead, I have a friend I go to, who knows me well and is very familiar with the ways that my confidence can spin when faced with email silence. He tells me I’m overreacting and assures me that my bid was reasonable. More important, he reminds me of my success and my value to the organization. He brings me back to the place of confidence and authority. It’s because of those reminders that I find patience and feel grounded. I sit tight. I wait and trust the process.

我个人觉得，当和对方面对面坐着时，我能坦然面对沉默。我仍然能从中获取很多信息——比如他的姿势、头部倾斜的角度、脸上的细微表情。但随着物理距离的拉长，我开始对沉默感到不自在。我不喜欢电话里的沉默，但我尽量不去关注那段空白。我通常会通过发邮件或浏览收件箱来打发时间。邮件里的沉默是最疏远的，对我来说也是最难受的。比如，如果我给潜在客户发了一份提案和建议的收费方案，却没有立即收到回复，我就会有点抓狂。这时，我的“编故事机器”就会疯狂运转，我会想他们是不是被我的高价吓到了；我会开始怀疑自己是不是冒牌货，是不是报价太高了。我会坐立不安，疑神疑鬼，心情很不好。然而，我不会回复：“一直没收到你的回复。只是想确认一下。我想让你知道，我提出的方案完全可以商量。”相反，我会去找一位了解我的朋友，他很清楚，面对邮件杳无音信，我的自信心会如何动摇。他会告诉我，我反应过度了，并向我保证，我的报价是合理的。更重要的是，他会提醒我，我取得的成就以及我对组织的价值。他让我重拾自信和权威。正是这些提醒，让我找到了耐心，也让我感到踏实。我静观其变，耐心等待，相信事情会水到渠成。

Not everyone has a friend perfectly suited for this job, just as not everyone will struggle with email silence. It’s hard to give purely prescriptive guidelines because it’s all so personal. You have to figure out where your own weak spots are—whether email, in person, or phone, and work on shoring them up in the way that keeps your inner doubter at bay.

并非每个人都能找到完美胜任这项工作的朋友，就像并非每个人都会因为收不到邮件而感到困扰一样。很难给出完全固定的指导原则，因为这完全取决于个人情况。你必须找出自己的弱点——无论是在邮件、面对面交流还是电话沟通中——并努力弥补这些弱点，从而消除你内心的疑虑。

You can’t please everyone

你不可能让每个人都满意。

Now that I’m grown, I can vividly imagine what it must have been like for my parents to leave their home in Iran, to leave their family, and to start over again with a new language and culture. It was undoubtedly terrifying, lonely, and alienating, but what drove them was what drives so many immigrants: the hope for a better future for their children.

现在我长大了，能够清晰地想象父母当年离开伊朗的家，离开亲人，重新开始学习新的语言、融入新的文化，是怎样一番景象。那无疑是恐惧、孤独和疏离的，但驱使他们前行的，也是许多移民的共同动力：对子女美好未来的期盼。

As a kid growing up in Massachusetts and New Jersey, I didn’t really understand this, or perhaps I didn’t want to. What I did understand was that I was two different people. I was Morvarid at home, dutiful and compliant. I spoke Farsi. I was fascinated by sports, by the energy surrounding athletic competition, but was never encouraged to play sports—instead, I did what was expected of me . . . I studied.

在马萨诸塞州和新泽西州长大的我，小时候并不真正理解这一点，或许是我不想理解。我所理解的是，我是两个人。在家，我是莫瓦里德，乖巧听话。我会说波斯语。我热爱运动，热爱体育竞技带来的激情，但从未有人鼓励我参加体育运动——相反，我只能做别人期望我做的事……学习。

Outside of home, I was Mori, spoke English, and wore and did pretty much what I pleased.
