I’d wait until I got to school to put makeup on, not necessarily because I thought my mom would say I couldn’t wear it, but it wouldn’t feel right to do at home. As I got older, I partied, I dated, and did what every other American kid did. I lived a double life, but that doesn’t mean I was rebellious. I never did anything to spite my parents—in fact, I often hid signs of my assimilation from them because I understood that it would disappoint them. I didn’t want to cause anyone pain.

在家里以外的地方，我就是森家的孩子，说英语，穿衣打扮，做事也几乎随心所欲。我会等到学校才化妆，倒不是因为怕妈妈不让我化，而是因为在家化妆总觉得不自在。长大后，我开始参加派对，谈恋爱，做着其他美国孩子都会做的事。我过着双重生活，但这并不意味着我叛逆。我从来没有故意做任何事来惹父母生气——事实上，我常常刻意隐藏自己融入主流社会的迹象，因为我知道这会让他们失望。我不想让任何人伤心。

When I went away to college, my father expected me to study medicine. And in order to make him happy, I did. I went through college preparing for a medical career, and never once enjoyed the ride. I perpetually swam upstream, trying to excel in courses that I didn’t find even remotely interesting. I wanted to take classes in history, economics, and politics and instead took biology, organic chemistry, and physics to meet the requirements of my major. I was living out my father’s dream, not mine. When I found the courage to tell him I was conflicted, that I didn’t think I wanted to study medicine, we didn’t speak again for months. I took the MCAT before I was ready to turn my back on medical school for good. I felt like I had betrayed my parents, who had risked everything by leaving their country so that I could have opportunities. Even now, I still wonder if I’m a disappointment to my parents because I didn’t fulfill their dreams for me. But I had to stop living my life to please others, fearing that I would never find personal fulfillment—whatever that meant.

我上大学时，父亲希望我学医。为了让他高兴，我照做了。大学期间，我一直为未来的医学事业做准备，却从未真正享受过这段时光。我总是逆流而上，努力在那些我根本不感兴趣的课程中取得好成绩。我本想学习历史、经济学和政治学，却为了满足专业要求而选择了生物、有机化学和物理。我活在父亲的梦想里，而不是我自己的梦想里。当我鼓起勇气告诉他我内心挣扎，不想再学医时，我们几个月都没再说话。我还没准备好彻底放弃医学院，就参加了医学院入学考试（MCAT）。我觉得自己背叛了父母，他们为了让我拥有机会，不惜一切代价离开祖国。即使到了现在，我仍然会想，我是否让父母失望了，因为我没有实现他们对我的期望。但我不得不停止为了取悦他人而生活，因为我害怕我永远无法获得个人满足感——无论那意味着什么。

My mom had her own fears, particularly surrounding my personal life. She began to worry as I went through my twenties and thirties without bringing home a nice Iranian boy. Every now and then, she pressured me about getting married and having kids. Meanwhile, unbeknownst to her, I was dating, and even became serious about one or two men. But I never let the relationships progress. If a guy wasn’t Iranian, I knew that being with him meant risking my relationship with my family. For him to be worth that risk, he had to be perfect. If you’ve seen The Big Sick , you know exactly what I’m talking about. Comedian Kumail Nanjiani complies—on the surface—with his Pakistani parents’ wishes but falls in love with a white girl. When she gets sick with a mysterious illness that leaves her in a coma, his double life comes to a head.

我妈妈也有她自己的担忧，尤其是在我的个人生活方面。我二十多岁、三十多岁了，却一直没能带个好伊朗男孩回家，她开始为此焦虑。她时不时地催我结婚生子。与此同时，她不知道的是，我一直在约会，甚至对一两个男人认真交往过。但我从未让这些关系发展下去。如果对方不是伊朗人，我知道和他在一起就意味着要冒着失去家人的风险。只有完美无缺的人，才值得我冒这个险。如果你看过电影《大病》（The Big Sick），你肯定明白我的意思。喜剧演员库梅尔·南贾尼表面上顺从了巴基斯坦父母的意愿，但实际上却爱上了一个白人女孩。当女孩患上一种神秘疾病陷入昏迷时，他的双重生活也随之暴露无遗。

My situation came to a head, too, but over something much less dramatic. One particular visit to my parents’ house, my mom had a friend over for thinly veiled reasons. This friend had another friend who had an eligible son, and she wanted me to meet him. I was thirty-three, and much too old, by Iranian standards, to be single and childless. But I was too old by my standards to have my parents interfere with my love life. I didn’t want to even meet this guy, because in my mind, I equated Iranian men with machismo and traditions I wanted to separate myself from. If my parents were setting me up, I knew it would be with a vision of what they wanted, and nothing of what I wanted. I was furious. I turned from the more compliant Dr. Jekyll they were used to into a crazy Mr. Hyde, right in front of my mother’s eyes. My family had seen my anger before, but never like that. This is the pleaser’s trap: I didn’t set boundaries, I wanted to please, and then I flipped out.

我的情况也到了崩溃的边缘，但起因却远没有那么戏剧化。有一次回父母家，我妈出于某种隐晦的原因带了个朋友过来。这位朋友有个朋友，有个条件不错的儿子，她想介绍我认识。我当时33岁，按伊朗的标准来说，单身无子女已经算是“大器晚成”了。但按我自己的标准，我也不想让父母干涉我的感情生活。我甚至都不想见这个人，因为在我看来，伊朗男人代表着大男子主义和那些我想摆脱的传统观念。如果父母真的要给我安排相亲，我知道那一定是他们自己的想法，而不是我的。我当时气疯了。就在我妈眼前，我从他们熟悉的那个温顺听话的“杰基尔博士”变成了疯狂的“海德先生”。家人以前也见过我生气，但从来没见过这么厉害的。这就是讨好型人格的陷阱：我没有划清界限，一心只想讨好他们，结果就彻底失控了。

I flew back to my home in D.C. and waited a day or two before calling my mom. And as I’d done with my father when I stopped studying medicine, I set a boundary. “Listen,” I said, “I have accepted our heritage, and I’ve done much of what you have wanted me to do. But love? I’m not going to let you guys decide that one for me. That decision is not yours but only mine to make.”

我飞回了华盛顿特区的家，等了一两天后才给妈妈打电话。就像我当初放弃医学学业时对父亲做的那样，我划清了界限。“听着，”我说，“我已经接受了我们的传统，也做了很多你们希望我做的事。但是爱情？我不会让你们替我做决定。这个决定不是你们的，只能由我自己来做。”

My mother was quiet, so I continued. “I’ll never say never, but chances are good that whoever I marry is probably not going to be Iranian. I know that’s pulling your heart out right now. But I can’t bear having these fights anymore. Let me not hurt you with my anger. You need to leave it alone. I will be okay. The man I marry will be wonderful, he just won’t be someone you probably expect him to be.”

母亲沉默不语，于是我继续说道：“我不会把话说死，但我未来的丈夫很可能不是伊朗人。我知道这话现在肯定让你很难过。但我真的受够了这样的争吵。我不想让我的怒气伤害你，你别再想这件事了。我会没事的。我未来的丈夫会很棒，只是他可能不是你想象中的那种人。”

I knew she was upset when we hung up, but I could suddenly breathe more easily—it was like my lungs had found a whole new compartment. I had found the courage to express my authentic self to my mom.

挂断电话时我知道她很生气，但我突然感觉轻松多了——就像我的肺找到了一个全新的空间。我终于鼓起勇气向妈妈表达真实的自己。

I can’t say the fights stopped when my parents accepted that I wasn’t going to be a doctor, or when they understood that I would not agree to their setting me up with men. But something very powerful happened. I stopped being angry with my parents. When I found the courage to stop pleasing them, when I gave myself permission to prioritize my integrity and values above all else, I realized that I was living as my authentic self. I just wished I’d done it earlier and during some critical junctures in my life—maybe when I was taking all of those chemistry classes instead of political science, maybe when I was dating a nice guy whom I could have made a future with.

我不能说父母接受我不会成为医生，或者理解我不会同意他们给我安排相亲之后，争吵就停止了。但确实发生了一件非常重要的事情。我不再生父母的气了。当我鼓起勇气不再取悦他们，当我允许自己把正直和价值观放在首位时，我意识到我终于活出了真正的自己。我只是希望自己能更早地做到这一点，尤其是在人生的一些关键时刻——也许是在我选修化学课而不是政治学的时候，也许是在我和一个可以共创未来的好男人交往的时候。

But instead of the continued burden of looking back, teaching has become the opportunity for me to help others, to give them the permission to be who they are and ask for what they want. Their wants and needs are important, and even if they still strive to make others happy (which isn’t in and of itself a bad goal!), they first have to find their own satisfaction and negotiate for themselves.

但教学不再让我背负回顾过去的重担，反而成为我帮助他人的机会，让我能够鼓励他们做真实的自己，并勇敢地表达自己的需求。他们的需求和愿望都很重要，即使他们仍然努力让别人开心（这本身并不是坏事！），他们首先也必须找到自己的满足感，并为自己争取权益。

#↩

CHAPTER 3

第三章

letting scars define us

让伤疤定义我们

I never became the doctor my father hoped I would, but I did find public health education and prevention fascinating, which is what led me to HIV outreach work. The business of health care and finding ways to provide access to those in need was something I loved. I decided to apply to business schools and pursue a career in the health care business. As luck would have it, not long after beginning my business school applications, I was offered funding to grow an HIV education program I’d developed. Just like that, I cofounded a health care consulting practice and became one of legions of entrepreneurs struggling to appease doubtful voices—from within and without. My family thought I was crazy. It was one thing not to go to medical school, but to start a company, give up full-time employment, and defer an MBA? What was I thinking? Medicine or a master’s degree had appealed to my parents because they were stable professional paths. Entrepreneurship was the polar opposite.

我最终没能成为父亲期望的那种医生，但我发现公共卫生教育和预防工作非常吸引人，这也促使我投身于艾滋病防治宣传工作。我热爱医疗保健行业，也热爱寻找各种途径来帮助有需要的人。于是，我决定申请商学院，在医疗保健行业发展。幸运的是，在我申请商学院不久，我就获得了一笔资金，用于发展我开发的艾滋病教育项目。就这样，我与人合伙创办了一家医疗保健咨询公司，并加入了众多创业者的行列，努力消除来自内部和外部的质疑声。我的家人觉得我疯了。不去医学院是一回事，但创办公司、放弃全职工作、推迟攻读MBA？我到底是怎么想的？我的父母之所以支持医学或硕士学位，是因为它们是稳定的职业道路。而创业则截然相反。

I went for it anyway. Although the company, which I cofounded with my mentor, was initially successful, we ran into trouble when our biggest client didn’t renew a contract that we thought was a sure thing. We had counted on that contract and became financially overextended. Our debt appeared insurmountable and the economy simultaneously took a major downturn. My partner felt we needed to let most of our staff go to avoid potential bankruptcy.

我还是决定放手一搏。虽然我和我的导师共同创立的公司最初发展顺利，但后来我们遇到了麻烦：我们最大的客户没有续签一份我们原本认为稳赚不赔的合同。我们一直指望着这份合同，结果导致财务状况过度扩张。我们的债务似乎难以偿还，与此同时，经济也出现了严重的下滑。我的合伙人认为，为了避免破产，我们必须裁掉大部分员工。

I felt very differently. I wanted to continue to keep staff on and worried about their job prospects given the state of the economy. Even with our vendors, I felt a great sense of responsibility to ensure that we stayed on track with our payments; it wasn’t their fault that we’d overcommitted. Even if I had to pull money out of my personal accounts, in my mind, we had an obligation to settle our debt. For my partner, who was much older than I was and had decades of business experience, this was just business and not personal. “This is why we are an S corp,” he said. “This is why bankruptcy is an option—to protect us in just such a situation.”

我的想法截然不同。鉴于当前的经济形势，我希望继续留住员工，并为他们的工作前景感到担忧。即使是对供应商，我也深感责任重大，必须确保我们按时付款；我们超支并非他们的错。即便需要动用个人账户，在我看来，我们也有义务偿还债务。而我的合伙人比我年长许多，拥有数十年的商业经验，对他而言，这只是生意，而非私事。“这就是我们选择S型公司的原因，”他说，“这也是为什么破产是一种选择——为了在这样的情况下保护我们。”

To me, bankruptcy was synonymous with failure, and I could not tell my family, or others who had been so worried about my starting a business, that the company had failed. Although our business ultimately survived the downturn and we found new clients and large projects, we continued to service our debt for years. Even on more sound financial footing, I found less joy and professional satisfaction from the business—and yet still I felt I had to keep it going.

对我而言，破产就等同于失败，我无法告诉家人，也无法告诉那些一直为我创业而担忧的人，公司已经倒闭了。尽管我们的公司最终挺过了经济低迷期，也找到了新的客户和大型项目，但我们仍然背负了多年的债务。即便财务状况更加稳健，我从公司获得的快乐和职业满足感也大不如前——然而，我仍然觉得我必须坚持下去。

Nelson Mandela said, “May your choices reflect your hopes, not your fears.” It took me a long time to recognize I was letting myself be defined by the scars of my childhood, by this outsized fear of failing. My parents had sacrificed so much in order for me to grow up in the United States, and I did not want to disappoint them.

纳尔逊·曼德拉曾说：“愿你的选择反映你的希望，而非你的恐惧。” 我花了很长时间才意识到，我一直被童年的伤痕和对失败的过度恐惧所定义。我的父母为了让我在美国长大付出了太多，我不想让他们失望。

No one gets through life without scars of one type or another. And most of us let ourselves be defined by them at some point. We have a bad relationship and instead of taking lessons from it and marching onward, we swear off relationships or we become convinced we’re only suited for those bad relationships. Or we lose a job we love, and somehow believe it’s our doing, so we’d better take what we can get from now on. Or we grow up with a particular set of values that, even though they don’t serve us, we can’t break free of. Everyone has scars, and when not seen for what they are, they hamper our ability to think clearly and negotiate effectively.

人生在世，谁都难免留下各种各样的伤痕。而我们大多数人，都曾在某个时刻被这些伤痕所定义。我们经历了一段糟糕的感情，却非但没有从中吸取教训、继续前行，反而从此对感情彻底失望，或者认定自己只适合糟糕的感情。又或者，我们失去了热爱的工作，却莫名其妙地认为这是自己的错，于是决定以后只能接受现状。再或者，我们从小就被灌输了一套特定的价值观，即便这些价值观对我们毫无益处，我们也难以摆脱。每个人都有伤痕，如果我们不正视它们，它们就会阻碍我们清晰思考和有效沟通的能力。

A fighting mind-set

战斗心态

Growing up, Song-I understood a narrow definition of negotiation. In her Korean family, negotiating meant there were winners and there were losers. If you won, the other party went down. Period. “I used to see my family’s terms as very black and white—like there’s one metric and that’s all there is. I would either subvert my desires so as not to fight or get super defensive or angry and go head-to-head. We wouldn’t talk, but we’d yell at each other.”

宋伊从小就对谈判有着狭隘的理解。在她的韩国家庭里，谈判意味着有赢家也有输家。赢了，输的就输。就这么简单。“我以前觉得家里的规矩非黑即白——好像只有一种衡量标准，仅此而已。为了避免争吵，我要么压抑自己的意愿，要么就变得特别防备或愤怒，然后正面冲突。我们不说话，只会互相吼叫。”

As newly arrived immigrants to the United States, she said, they were surrounded by a fighting mind-set all the time. “A lot of people in the immigrant community around me came because they’re running away from something like debt or a bad spouse,” she said. “There’s a lot of pain and stomping over other people to try to win—what, I don’t know. Maybe some self-respect or feeling you’re better than other people.” Her family slept in people’s closets for their first months in the States, and Song-I’s father worked as a janitor while going to school and also studying to be a pastor. He was generous with people and keen on helping others—and ended up being taken advantage of by others, leaving him with a sinking amount of bad credit, strained family circumstances, and fighting. “I would watch my parents fight about the strain my dad’s generosity caused us and think, You can’t be a good person and not get trampled . That informed what I believed a negotiation can be,” she said. “One person benefits and then the other one gets quashed or eliminated or ends up with a sinkhole of debt. . . . I was scared of negotiation. I saw it as a conflict-heavy fight.”

她说，作为新移民，他们身处一个充满争斗的环境中。“我周围的移民社区里，很多人来这里是为了逃避债务或糟糕的伴侣，”她说，“他们承受着巨大的痛苦，为了赢——我也不知道是为了什么。也许是为了维护自尊，或者觉得自己高人一等。” 宋怡一家在美国的头几个月只能借宿在别人家的衣橱里。她的父亲一边做清洁工，一边上学，同时还在攻读牧师学位。他为人慷慨，乐于助人，却最终被人利用，导致信用记录一落千丈，家庭关系紧张，争吵不断。“我看着父母因为父亲的慷慨给我们带来的压力而争吵，心想，好人难免被人践踏。这让我对谈判有了新的认识，”她说。 “一方获益，另一方则被压制、淘汰，或者最终背负巨额债务……我害怕谈判。我把它看作是一场充满冲突的斗争。”

When she was an undergrad at Penn, Song-I enrolled in my negotiations class. “My ultimate goal wasn’t to be a hard-ass—the reason I wanted to take it was because negotiation made me uncomfortable. I knew I was unhappy and not good at asking for what I wanted. I wanted to face it.”

宋伊在宾夕法尼亚大学读本科时，选修了我的谈判课。“我的最终目标并不是成为一个强硬的人——我选这门课的原因是谈判让我感到不自在。我知道自己不快乐，也不擅长表达自己的需求。我想直面这个问题。”

In my class, she had to push against her scars—a message, and a way of being, that she had internalized for twenty years. Instead of a black-and-white framework, she came to see negotiation as problem solving with endless complexities and nuances. And she found she loved it—she loved the process of learning information about other people, and figuring out where their interests overlapped. She also learned that she was naturally very good at it. She was a skilled listener and her classmates respected her.

在我的课堂上，她不得不克服内心的伤痕——这种观念和处事方式，她已经内化了二十年。她不再用非黑即白的框架看待谈判，而是将其视为一个充满无限复杂性和细微差别的解决问题的过程。她发现自己爱上了谈判——她喜欢了解他人、找出彼此利益交集的过程。她也发现自己在这方面很有天赋。她善于倾听，同学们都很尊重她。

Song-I had long been taught that Korean women were not expected to ask for what they wanted, let alone fight for it. They should serve others first, themselves last. Intellectually she did not believe that her wants and needs didn’t matter, but when it came to the moment of the “ask” it was hard for her to speak up. This became really evident in class. She struggled to advocate for her own needs, but when given the exercise of being a real estate agent for a buyer, she could argue confidently for her client all night long. “That I had the ability to be assertive and fight for things was shocking,” she said. “Why couldn’t I do that for myself?” Once she saw this, it began to change everything for her. She strove to be informed by her past but not let it dictate her habits.

宋伊从小就被灌输韩国女性不应该主动提出自己的需求，更别提争取了。她们应该先服务他人，最后才考虑自己。理智上，她并不认为自己的需求不重要，但真到要开口“提出”的时候，她却很难开口。这一点在课堂上表现得尤为明显。她很难为自己争取权益，但当被安排扮演房产经纪人，为买家争取利益时，她却能自信地为客户据理力争一整晚。“我竟然有能力坚持己见，争取自己想要的东西，这让我很震惊，”她说，“为什么我不能为自己做到这一点呢？” 意识到这一点后，她的人生开始发生改变。她努力从过去的经历中汲取教训，但又不让过去束缚自己的行为习惯。

After the class she went on a trip to Thailand, where she took a baby step into her new mind-set. “As I was setting up a reservation for an airport transfer, the company notified me that it would charge 300 THB (baht). However, the original price that a third party had posted was 250 THB. Now, I realize this may be a no-brainer to some people to claim the original 250, but given my past behavior I’d normally avoid the potential conflict/confrontation and just go with the 300. In the grand scheme of things, a 50-baht difference amounts to ~$1.50 and it wouldn’t kill me to stimulate Thailand’s economy for the opportunity cost of a pack of gum. However, I decided that I should try growing somewhat of a backbone and at least put it out there that the third party had promised 250 . . . and I got an email saying that 250 would be fine! I know it’s not much from an objective point of view, but I had to go through a lot of psychological hurdles to be able to do that.”

下课后，她去泰国旅行，在那里她迈出了适应新思维方式的一小步。 “我在预订机场接送服务时，对方公司通知我费用是300泰铢。然而，第三方平台最初公布的价格是250泰铢。我知道对有些人来说，坚持要回250泰铢是理所当然的，但以我以往的习惯，我通常会避免潜在的冲突，直接接受300泰铢。毕竟，50泰铢的差价也就相当于1.5美元左右，为了省下一包口香糖的机会成本，刺激一下泰国经济又何妨呢？不过，我决定还是应该稍微强硬一点，至少要指出第三方平台承诺的是250泰铢……结果我收到了一封邮件，说250泰铢没问题！我知道客观来说这不算什么，但我为了做到这一点，克服了很多心理障碍。”

Song-I’s early experiences with negotiation had huge implications, all made through small habits and microdecisions. As she said, the discrepancy involved in the airport transfer was just $1.50. Plenty of people would have let it go, and that would be fine, too. But Song-I was right to notice that her compliance had become a habit, a way of being in the world. In order to change that habit, she needed to break herself of her unconscious behaviors. She needed to start replacing some of her bad negotiation experiences with good ones.

宋伊早期的谈判经历影响深远，而这一切都源于她一些微小的习惯和决定。正如她所说，机场接送的差价只有1.5美元。很多人可能就此作罢，这也没什么问题。但宋伊敏锐地意识到，顺从已经成为一种习惯，一种处世之道。为了改变这种习惯，她需要打破无意识的行为模式。她需要用一些成功的谈判经历来取代那些糟糕的谈判经历。

Zappos offered Song-I her first job out of college, an exciting moment for her. But she was disappointed by the compensation offered. “I thought, this doesn’t feel good. I know the job’s located in Vegas and Vegas is cheap, but really? I was scared, though, and I thought, if I ask for more I’m going to be seen as needy. I’m going to be seen as demanding. I should just cut my losses and take the job. But then I challenged myself.” She put a toe in the water, where she wouldn’t have before. “I said, ‘I’m excited to work with you guys, but the base salary is a bit low.’ I was apologetic.” Zappos responded with a higher base salary.

Zappos 为宋伊提供了她大学毕业后的第一份工作，这让她兴奋不已。但她对提供的薪酬感到失望。“我当时想，这感觉不太好。我知道工作地点在拉斯维加斯，拉斯维加斯物价低，但真的这么低吗？我当时很害怕，心想如果我要求更高的薪水，别人会觉得我太贪婪，太苛求。我应该及时止损，接受这份工作。但后来我决定挑战一下自己。” 她试探性地提出了自己的要求，这在以前是她不敢尝试的。“我说，‘我很期待加入你们，但是基本工资有点低。’我表达了我的歉意。” Zappos 随后提高了基本工资。

By her next job negotiation, she had dropped the need to apologize. And the negotiation after that—for the job she still has—went better still. “They had a good base salary offering,” she said, but she understood there were three components at play: base salary, sign-on bonus, and stock. She dug into researching all three areas and asked detailed questions about tax exemptions before she prepared a counter-ask. “I started asking myself, Do I really care about the base salary? What is the need I’m trying to fill? And what I wanted changed.” She realized that what she wanted was to make up what she’d lost from breaking her employment contract with her previous employer. She thought, too, of what need her prospective employer wanted to fulfill, and what would feel comfortable for them. They worked together to figure out a solution for all parties.

到了下一次求职谈判，她已经不再需要道歉了。而之后的那次谈判——也就是她现在这份工作的谈判——进行得更加顺利。“他们提供的基本工资很不错，”她说，但她明白这其中包含三个方面：基本工资、签约奖金和股票。她深入研究了这三个方面，并在准备还价之前详细询问了税收减免的相关问题。“我开始问自己，我真的在乎基本工资吗？我想要满足的是什么需求？我想要的又是什么？”她意识到，她想要的是弥补之前违约造成的损失。她也思考了未来雇主想要满足的需求，以及什么对他们来说才是合适的。最终，双方共同努力，找到了一个对各方都有利的解决方案。

Her approach couldn’t be further than the “fight to the win” mentality she grew up with. But the greatest test of Song-I’s new approach to negotiation came when she was in conflict with her dad. Her family eventually moved back to South Korea, while Song-I remains in the United States. Commonly, she receives emails from her dad telling her about men he would like her to date. “At first I found it to be irritating and offensive,” she said. Like me, Song-I has no interest in being set up on dates by her parents. “Then I started shifting and thinking, how do I help him see my worldview? That what he thinks is the right answer is not necessarily what I think is the right answer, and that that’s okay?” They have a shared goal, she sees, which is that they both want Song-I to be happy and to live a fulfilling life. “We might have different viewpoints on what that life looks like, but we’re in agreement that we both want me to be happy.” Now instead of bristling and shutting down the conversation, she’ll show him when she takes his advice into consideration. She’s also started sharing more of her life with him, showing the ways that she is happy and fulfilled even without marriage. She’s bringing him into her world a bit more and, in doing so, they are coming closer together.

她的方法与她从小接受的“不达目的誓不罢休”的心态截然不同。但宋伊这种新的谈判方式面临的最大考验，是她与父亲发生冲突的时候。她的家人最终搬回了韩国，而宋伊则留在了美国。她经常收到父亲的邮件，告诉她有哪些男人适合她约会。“一开始我觉得很烦，也很冒犯，”她说。和我一样，宋伊对父母安排的相亲毫无兴趣。“后来我开始转变思路，思考如何让他理解我的世界观？他认为的正确答案未必是我认为的正确答案，而这也没关系？”她意识到，他们有一个共同的目标，那就是都希望宋伊幸福，过上充实的生活。“我们对这种生活的定义可能不同，但我们都同意，我们都希望我幸福。”现在，她不再像以前那样生气地拒绝他，而是会认真考虑他的建议。她也开始更多地与他分享自己的生活，让他看到即使没有婚姻，她也能拥有快乐和满足的生活。她让他更多地走进她的世界，在这个过程中，他们之间的关系也越来越亲密。

When you don’t ask for help

当你不寻求帮助时

The first thing to know about Linda Schlesinger-Wagner is that she is impressive. She started the Michigan-based Internet retailer Skinnytees with a thousand-dollar loan from her friend. At the time, Linda was broke, working multiple jobs, and recently divorced. Now Skinnytees is regularly featured on Good Morning America and in O magazine and averages $4 million in sales per year. Skinnytees is heavily involved in philanthropy, and Linda is a humanitarian who has traveled the world interviewing Holocaust survivors. To look at her, you would never know just how low she has been, and how very close her life was to working out differently.

了解琳达·施莱辛格-瓦格纳 (Linda Schlesinger-Wagner) 的第一件事就是：她令人钦佩。她用朋友借给她的一千美元创办了位于密歇根州的互联网零售商 Skinnytees。当时，琳达身无分文，同时兼职好几份工作，而且刚刚离婚。如今，Skinnytees 已成为《早安美国》和《O》杂志的常客，年销售额平均高达 400 万美元。Skinnytees 积极投身慈善事业，琳达本人也是一位人道主义者，她曾周游世界采访大屠杀幸存者。从外表上看，你根本无法想象她曾经多么落魄，她的人生差点就彻底改变了。

Linda grew up watching her parents run a manufacturing company, and so she was no stranger to the ups and downs of entrepreneurship. She observed everything about their tool and die company, learning all about factory and business relationships, and the ins and outs of following through on contracts. Her parents lost everything they owned when they were in their forties, and Linda watched as they picked themselves up. “They had the guts to go back in there and do it a different way,” she said. Linda would follow in their footsteps in more ways than one.

琳达从小就看着父母经营一家制造公司，因此她对创业的起起落落并不陌生。她观察着父母的模具公司的一切，学习工厂和商业关系的运作，以及如何履行合同的方方面面。她的父母在四十多岁时失去了所有财产，琳达亲眼见证了他们如何重新振作。“他们有勇气重整旗鼓，另辟蹊径，”她说。琳达在很多方面都追随了他们的脚步。

As an adult, Linda was unhappily married, but, like many, stayed in her marriage to keep the family together. She opened a children’s store, and shortly thereafter became a knitwear manufacturer. Her sweaters were all hand-loomed, and inspired by an antique button collection. As she was building her businesses, Linda was also her family’s primary caregiver and took care of her ailing father-in-law. After her children were grown and her father-in-law had passed away, Linda told her husband that there was no longer a reason to stay together.

成年后的琳达婚姻不幸，但和许多人一样，为了维系家庭，她选择维持婚姻。她开了一家童装店，不久后又成为针织品制造商。她的毛衣全部手工织造，灵感源自她收藏的古董纽扣。在经营事业的同时，琳达也是家里的主要照顾者，悉心照料着体弱多病的公公。孩子们长大成人，公公也去世后，琳达告诉丈夫，他们已经没有理由继续在一起了。

The divorce happened quickly, but fully separating her life from the person she’d been married to for decades was anything but easy. Though the divorce had been her idea, she found herself going back to her ex-husband, but she was so ashamed she didn’t tell anyone. She was struggling with the divorce and struggling with her ex’s treatment of her. As her sense of worth dipped lower and lower, she didn’t want friends and family to know how bad it really was. Linda had always struggled to ask for help. Her worldview was that she should be able to handle by herself whatever life threw her way.

离婚来得很快，但要彻底与相伴数十年的伴侣断绝关系却并非易事。尽管离婚是她自己的主意，她却发现自己又回到了前夫身边，但她羞愧难当，谁也没告诉。她既要承受离婚的痛苦，又要面对前夫对她的冷漠。随着自尊心不断下降，她不愿让亲朋好友知道她的真实处境有多糟糕。琳达一直难以开口求助。她总觉得自己应该能够独自应对生活中的一切挑战。

“My ex was emotionally and mentally abusive to me,” Linda said. “I was a strong woman, and yet I thought I deserved it. The things he said to me were things that no one should say.”

“我的前夫在情感和精神上虐待我，”琳达说。“我是一个坚强的女人，但我却觉得这是我应得的。他对我说的那些话，任何人都不应该说。”

On one fateful day, Linda was at her former home outside Detroit, where her ex still lived. He offered her money to go buy plants and do some gardening around the house while he was out on a date. “I screamed and cried and told him how awful he was, reminding him that I was the mother of his children.” Linda was inconsolable when she left the house. But she didn’t want to burden anyone; she wanted to handle things on her own. She felt she should be able to handle things on her own. “I kept thinking that I wanted no part of this world where the person I shared my life with would treat me this way.”

在一个注定悲剧的日子，琳达回到了她位于底特律郊外的老家，她的前夫还住在那里。他出去约会的时候，给了她一些钱让她去买些植物，帮她打理一下房子周围的花园。“我又哭又叫，告诉他他有多糟糕，提醒他我是他孩子的母亲。”琳达离开家时，悲痛欲绝。但她不想给任何人添麻烦；她想自己处理一切。她觉得自己应该能够独自面对这一切。“我一直在想，我不想再和这样一个与我共度一生的人继续待在这个世界上，他竟然这样对待我。”

Linda got her hands on a bottle of Ambien. She knew a friend was out of town and drove her car near the friend’s house, then ditched it and walked the rest of the way. She let herself into the empty house and laid a blanket down in a downstairs guest bathroom. She planned to slit her wrists there, but first she decided to take the Ambien. Linda was so ashamed, so low, and felt so small, that even though no one was home and no one was looking for her, she hid in an upstairs closet with a flashlight as she swallowed the pills. She was walking to the bathroom to carry out the final part of her plan when she lost consciousness. She woke up forty-eight hours later in a hospital.

琳达弄到了一瓶安眠药。她知道一个朋友不在家，便开车到朋友家附近，然后弃车步行前往。她走进空荡荡的房子，在楼下的客用卫生间铺了一条毯子。她原本打算在那里割腕，但决定先服用安眠药。琳达感到无比羞愧、无比沮丧、无比渺小，尽管家里没人，也没人找她，她还是躲在楼上的衣橱里，拿着手电筒吞下了药片。当她走向卫生间准备执行计划的最后一步时，她失去了意识。四十八小时后，她在医院里醒来。

That Linda survived the suicide attempt is more a factor of fortune than anything else—which is why this story is part cautionary tale. At the same time that Linda was searching for Ambien, her twenty-five-year-old daughter, halfway across the country in San Francisco, felt that something was wrong. Her mother wasn’t answering her phone, which was unusual. She called Linda’s cell carrier and said, “I’m worried about my mom. Can you find out where her phone is?” The carrier located the home of Linda’s friend, and Linda’s daughter called the police. They broke into the house, found Linda, and called an ambulance. Even then, Linda wasn’t out of danger. The emergency room doctor told Linda’s daughter that she was probably going to die.

琳达自杀未遂更多是出于运气而非其他原因——正因如此，这个故事也带有警示意味。琳达四处寻找安眠药的同时，她25岁的女儿远在旧金山，感觉到了不对劲。她母亲的电话一直无人接听，这很不寻常。她打电话给琳达的手机运营商，说：“我担心我妈妈。你们能帮我查一下她的手机在哪儿吗？”运营商找到了琳达朋友的家，琳达的女儿随即报警。警察破门而入，找到了琳达，并叫了救护车。即便如此，琳达仍然没有脱离危险。急诊室医生告诉琳达的女儿，她可能活不了了。

But Linda did come through, and when she woke up, she remembered the emergency room nurse tending to her. The nurse told Linda, “I’ve been exactly where you are. Five years ago. Don’t you ever let someone bring you down.”

但琳达最终挺了过来。当她醒来时，她记得急诊室的护士照顾她。护士告诉琳达：“我五年前也经历过你现在的处境。永远不要让任何人打倒你。”

The aftermath of Linda’s suicide attempt was bleak, as she had to stay in the psych ward before being released to a regular hospital room. Ultimately her daughter got her into The Canyon, a tony rehabilitation center in Malibu for addiction and mental health issues. It was all paid for by a friend of Linda’s who knew that she would pay her back one day. “My friend picked me up and took me there,” Linda said. Like it or not, Linda was being helped.

琳达自杀未遂后的境况十分糟糕，她先是在精神病房待了一段时间，才被转到普通病房。最终，她的女儿把她送进了位于马里布的高档康复中心“峡谷”（The Canyon），该中心专门治疗成瘾和心理健康问题。所有费用都由琳达的一位朋友支付，这位朋友知道琳达总有一天会报答她。“我的朋友开车来接我，然后送我去的，”琳达说。不管琳达是否愿意，她确实得到了帮助。

“You go down this canyon road, and there’s nothing else there—it’s lush and green and hot.” There were only twenty-one patients, and no one gave their last name unless they chose to.

“你沿着这条峡谷路走下去，后面什么也没有——到处都是郁郁葱葱的绿色植物，天气炎热。” 只有二十一名病人，除非他们自愿，否则没有人透露自己的姓氏。

“On my first day, the facilitators separated the women and men, and they said, ‘Okay, ladies, we’re going to blindfold you with a bandana. Hold the shoulders of the person in front of you. We’ll lead the first person.” It was slow walking for fifteen minutes, Linda said, as everyone, blindfolded, carefully stepped on what felt like a rocky path. Then the facilitators told them to hold on to a rope and to leave their blindfolds on. The facilitators explained that they were in a maze, and their task was to find the exit. “We’ll make sure you don’t get hurt. And if you need help, raise your hand.” “In thirty seconds,” Linda recounted, “they said, ‘Okay, the first one has found the entrance.’ Over the next minutes a bunch of others did, but I was still holding the rope. I couldn’t figure out how they’d figured their way out of the maze. Then the facilitators said, ‘There’s two of you left. If you need help, raise your hand.’ All of a sudden I understood. I said, ‘Wait! I get it. If I need anything, ask for help.’” Linda had cracked the code. “I’m in the f-ing forest with people I don’t know. I can’t find an entrance. There wasn’t an exit. The whole thing was set up to show us to ask for help. I never asked for help in my life. I always thought, ‘I’m going to do this on my own.’ It was like a giant lightbulb went off on me. I was the person who never asked for help, and who never gave up, until I tried to kill myself.” That pattern, Linda understood, had held her back for much of her life.

“第一天，组织者把男女分开，然后说：‘好了，女士们，我们要用头巾蒙住你们的眼睛。抓住前面那人的肩膀。我们先带第一个人。’”琳达说，接下来的十五分钟走得很慢，每个人都蒙着眼睛，小心翼翼地走在一条感觉像碎石路的小路上。然后组织者告诉他们抓住一根绳子，不要摘下眼罩。组织者解释说，他们身处一个迷宫，任务是找到出口。“我们会确保你们不会受伤。如果需要帮助，请举手。” “三十秒后，”琳达回忆道，“他们说，‘好了，第一个人找到了入口。’接下来的几分钟里，其他人也都找到了，但我仍然抓着绳子。我百思不得其解，他们是怎么走出迷宫的。然后组织者说，‘你们还剩两个人。如果需要帮助，请举手。’我突然明白了。我说，‘等等！我懂了。如果我需要什么，就开口求助。’”琳达终于明白了其中的奥秘。“我和一群陌生人待在森林里。我找不到入口。也没有出口。这一切都是为了告诉我们要寻求帮助。我这辈子从来没求过人。我总是想，‘我要靠自己。’那一刻，我就像醍醐灌顶。我一直是个从不求助、从不放弃的人，直到我试图自杀。”琳达明白，这种模式在她的人生中大部分时间里都阻碍了她的发展。

Linda spent a month at The Canyon, then returned home to her little yellow house in Michigan to put her life back together. After her hospitalization, Linda no longer made choices that reflected her fears. “After I got out of The Canyon, I said, I’m not going to sit in my house and have a pity party —I put myself on JDate, on Match.com,” she said, something she never would have done previously. “I met people for coffee dates.” She cut off ties with her ex and started thinking of what she wanted to do instead of what she should do. She was set up with a friend of a friend, Paul, who had lost his wife not long before. The two had an instant connection and are now married.

琳达在峡谷疗养院待了一个月，然后回到密歇根州她那栋黄色的小房子里，重新开始生活。出院后，琳达不再受恐惧驱使而做出选择。“出院后，我说，我不能再待在家里自怨自艾了——我开始在JDate和Match.com上注册，”她说，这是她以前想都不敢想的事情。“我开始和人约会喝咖啡。”她和前夫断绝了关系，开始思考自己想做什么，而不是应该做什么。她经朋友介绍认识了保罗，保罗不久前失去了妻子。两人一见如故，现在已经结婚了。

Most significantly, Linda no longer delayed asking for help—from her friends and from her family. She cobbled together different jobs for a time, and then her retailer and manufacturing past gave her the inspiration for Skinnytees. She accepted a loan from a friend, something she never would have felt herself worthy of before, and started selling soft, seamless tanks that worked for all women regardless of their size.

最重要的是，琳达不再拖延寻求帮助——无论是向朋友还是家人。她曾拼凑各种零工，后来，她过去在零售和制造业的经验给了她创办Skinnytees的灵感。她接受了朋友的贷款——这在以前是她想都不敢想的——开始销售柔软、无缝的背心，这种背心适合所有身材的女性。

“What happens in your personal life really spills over to your professional life,” Linda said. “My personality really changed. I didn’t hold back anymore. I learned to ask for help, and I ask for help all the time now.” She attended the Goldman Sachs 10,000 Small Businesses program, where I met her. Linda and several others from her cohort continue to meet, years after the class has ended, to offer one another support and assistance. “Because I learned how to ask for help, that’s why I think I’m eager to give help to other people,” Linda said, whether it’s her former classmates or the charities that she’s so involved in. “We all ask each other for help. How powerful is that?”

“个人生活中发生的事情真的会波及到职业生涯，”琳达说。“我的性格真的改变了。我不再有所保留。我学会了寻求帮助，现在我总是会寻求帮助。”她参加了高盛的“万家小企业”项目，我就是在那里认识她的。琳达和她的几位同学在课程结束后多年仍然保持联系，互相支持和帮助。“因为我学会了如何寻求帮助，所以我才如此渴望帮助别人，”琳达说，无论是她的老同学，还是她积极参与的慈善机构。“我们都会互相寻求帮助。这难道不是一种强大的力量吗？”

Many people consider the negotiation process something that they have to tackle by themselves. You don’t have to be the accountant who knows the financial data inside and out and the attorney who can put together comprehensive and secure contracts. We can seek professionals to help us prepare. We can talk to friends or mentors ahead of the negotiation to run through our plan and ask for critical feedback so that we have another perspective. I find that the older I get, the more comfortable I am in accepting what I don’t know and asking for help. My goal is not to be the smartest person in the room. It’s to be the most open to learning so that I can be wiser by the end of the conversation. I am so privileged to be surrounded by smart students, accomplished entrepreneurs, and brilliant friends and mentors. I’d be foolish not to choose access to their wisdom in order to massage my ego. When my students say, “I’m not a good negotiator because I’m so bad with numbers,” my immediate response is, “Thank goodness there are so many accountants and finance professionals for you to hire!”

很多人认为谈判必须独自应对。其实你不必是精通财务数据的会计师，也不必是能起草全面可靠合同的律师。我们可以寻求专业人士的帮助。我们可以在谈判前与朋友或导师交流，梳理计划，并征求他们的宝贵意见，从而获得不同的视角。我发现，随着年龄的增长，我越来越能坦然接受自己的不足，并乐于寻求帮助。我的目标不是成为房间里最聪明的人，而是保持开放的心态去学习，这样在对话结束时才能更加睿智。我非常荣幸能与众多才华横溢的学生、成功的企业家以及杰出的朋友和导师为伍。如果我为了满足自己的虚荣心而放弃汲取他们的智慧，那就太愚蠢了。当我的学生说：“我不擅长谈判，因为我对数字很不敏感。”我的第一反应总是：“幸好有那么多会计师和财务专业人士可以聘请！”

Always in survival mode

始终处于生存模式

My student Pam was intensely competitive, sometimes to a fault, of which she was well aware. Her whole life, she had felt she had to be. She was an African American woman working in construction services—a white man’s industry—in Detroit, a storied city with a long history of racial strife. She did not get to her position of success by tossing flowers to everyone who crossed her path—she had to roll up her sleeves and fight.

我的学生帕姆极具竞争心，有时甚至到了过分的地步，她对此心知肚明。她一生都觉得自己必须如此。她是一位非裔美国女性，在底特律——一座有着悠久种族冲突历史的城市——从事建筑服务工作，而建筑服务业历来是白人的天下。她并非靠着对遇到的每个人都献上鲜花才获得成功——她必须撸起袖子，奋力拼搏。

When I met Pam in 2014, she and her classmates were still recovering from the recession. When I gave her class a scenario to negotiate, she recognized it as one she’d done before. In the same way that Linda’s blindfolded maze exercise was designed to give people an “aha” moment (that they needed to ask for help), this case study was designed to show people they needed to recognize that cooperation—not competition—is key.

2014年我认识帕姆的时候，她和她的同学们还在从经济衰退中恢复过来。当我给她班布置一个谈判情景时，她认出这是她以前做过的。就像琳达的蒙眼迷宫练习旨在让人们“恍然大悟”（意识到他们需要寻求帮助）一样，这个案例研究旨在向人们展示，合作而非竞争才是关键。

Pam asked me if she could be excused from the exercise. She said it wouldn’t be fair to the others since she knew the answer and they didn’t, and she wasn’t likely to get much out of it. Something told me to ask her to do it anyway, even though I usually excuse students who have done it before. What she gained from it humbled her.

帕姆问我她能不能免做这道题。她说这对其他人不公平，因为她知道答案而其他人不知道，而且她觉得做完也学不到什么。但我总觉得应该让她做一下，尽管我通常会免除已经做过的学生的作业。结果她从中得到的收获让她谦逊了许多。

“I knew the key. I knew we could all win if we had the right secret sauce. And still I couldn’t make it happen. It went totally wrong.” She explained that she was so deeply competitive, as were the others in her group, that the competition, guarding, and posturing overpowered collaboration. “The fact that I still couldn’t manipulate the outcome when I knew the answer was profound to me,” she said.

“我知道关键所在。我知道只要掌握了秘诀，我们就能赢。可我还是做不到。一切都彻底搞砸了。”她解释说，她和组里的其他人一样，都极具竞争心，以至于竞争、戒备和虚张声势压倒了合作。“明明知道答案，却还是无法左右结果，这对我来说意义重大。”她说。

The intensity of Pam’s competitiveness—formed over decades of being in survival mode—made her reluctant to appear cooperative. She feared signaling vulnerability, and this fear hobbled communication and prevented Pam from creating the win-win outcome she knew was possible.

帕姆数十年来一直处于生存模式，这种强烈的竞争意识使她不愿表现出合作的态度。她害怕示弱，而这种恐惧阻碍了沟通，使她无法达成她明明知道是可能的双赢局面。

The gift Pam got from this exercise was self-awareness—she was able to see her scars clearly. In the future, she could use that self-awareness to be more deliberate and proactive. Knowing her inclination to be hypercompetitive, she could be intentional; she could create a plan that took her triggers into account. This plan might include slowing down and taking more time at the outset of a negotiation to get to know her negotiating partner, which would soften her more competitive inclinations. It might include waiting a few beats before responding, checking in with herself. It might be as simple as writing herself a note not to take any of the negotiation personally. I don’t mean to suggest that there is anything easy about checking your strongest inclinations. There isn’t. It’s subtle, and it’s emotionally draining. But it can also be enormously empowering.

帕姆从这次练习中获得的礼物是自我认知——她能够清晰地看到自己的伤痕。未来，她可以利用这种自我认知，更加深思熟虑、积极主动。她了解自己好胜心强的倾向，因此可以有意识地制定计划，考虑到自己的触发因素。这个计划可能包括在谈判初期放慢节奏，花更多时间了解谈判伙伴，从而缓和自己好胜的倾向。也可能包括在回应之前稍作停顿，反思一下自己的感受。甚至可能像给自己写个便条，提醒自己不要把谈判中的任何事都当成针对自己。我并不是说控制自己最强烈的倾向很容易。事实并非如此。这很微妙，也很耗费精力。但它也能带来巨大的力量。

Haunted by an economic downturn

受经济衰退的困扰

We are not where we are from, but our geographical reality is a deeply embedded part of our psyche, and we need to recognize it as such. I’ve taught in New Orleans, for instance, where during hurricane season the weather report takes on huge significance. In New Orleans, it’s easy to feel powerless, that your destiny is not dictated by your goals or the strength of your endeavors, because Mother Nature is there to remind you she’s stronger. Through storm damage and resulting economic damage, my students in New Orleans have gotten back up again and again, but know that though they’re back on their feet, any day now their doors and windows could be shuttered against a gathering hurricane. These wounds then infect the asks my students are willing to make.

我们并非生于何处，但我们的地理现实却深深植根于我们的心灵，我们必须认识到这一点。例如，我曾在新奥尔良教书，那里每逢飓风季，天气预报都至关重要。在新奥尔良，人们很容易感到无力，觉得自己的命运并非由目标或努力决定，因为大自然母亲会提醒你，她的力量远胜于一切。我的学生们在新奥尔良经历了风暴的破坏和由此造成的经济损失，一次又一次地重新站起来，但他们也明白，即便他们重新站了起来，也随时可能再次面临飓风来袭，不得不紧闭门窗。这些创伤会影响我的学生们提出的要求。

“I’m a Louisiana native, so I have heavy doses of the fatalism that we’re known for,” said my Goldman Sachs 10,000 Small Businesses student Mary Ellen, who runs a content marketing company. “People think we like to party, but I think mostly we just figure every day could be our last, because we could be wiped off the map any minute.” But she said living in Washington, D.C., for her twenties and half of her thirties helped her break out of the psychology of the region. Now that she’s back in New Orleans, she’ll tell her fellow New Orleanians, “Come on now, have some self-esteem! This really could work—you can do this, you can ask for that.”

“我是路易斯安那州本地人，所以身上也带着我们这里出了名的宿命论，”我的高盛“万家小企业”项目学员玛丽·艾伦说道，她经营着一家内容营销公司。“人们以为我们喜欢聚会，但我觉得我们更多的是觉得每一天都可能是最后一天，因为我们随时都可能从地图上消失。”不过她说，在华盛顿特区生活了二十多岁和三十多岁的前半段，帮助她摆脱了路易斯安那州的这种心态。现在她回到了新奥尔良，她会告诉她的老乡们：“振作起来，有点自信！一切皆有可能——你们可以做到，你们可以提出要求。”

I’ve recently started teaching in Iowa and was struck by a sentiment echoed by many of my students there. There’s a sense of pride and esteem, from growing up and living in “God’s country.” And yet there’s also a lingering sense of insecurity, of imposter syndrome. It makes sense. We inhabit an economy where high tech is everything, and yet the industry has largely been centered on the coasts, while the middle of America has been skipped over, breeding uncertainty and resentment.

我最近开始在爱荷华州教书，很多学生都表达了类似的感受，这让我印象深刻。他们为自己成长于“上帝之乡”而感到自豪和自尊。然而，他们心中也始终萦绕着一种挥之不去的不安感，一种冒名顶替综合症。这也不难理解。我们生活在一个高科技至上的经济时代，但科技产业却主要集中在沿海地区，而美国中部地区却被忽略了，这滋生了不确定性和不满情绪。

In the Detroit of 2014, the struggle was palpable. They were the forgotten people. As a country, we had decided that it was okay for them to fail, until it wasn’t. That took a toll. Those who are still living and working in Detroit are fiercely proud, but that pride is intertwined with the vulnerabilities of their economic environment. “For many people in Detroit,” said my student Pam, “there were these holes in our hearts because no matter what we tried to do, we were ridiculed. And for so many decades Detroit had been the butt of a national joke—and still is for people who don’t know better.” They had struggled for so long that self-doubt had infected them. Detroiters are fighters, but they had learned to expect less. Even when encouraged to request investment for their growth plans, they consistently set lower “asks.” The perspectives they shared revealed a weariness, a dearth of hope.

2014年的底特律，困境显而易见。他们是被遗忘的人们。作为一个国家，我们曾认为他们的失败是可以接受的，直到有一天，这种观念被打破了。这给他们带来了沉重的打击。那些仍然在底特律生活和工作的人们无比自豪，但这种自豪感与他们脆弱的经济环境交织在一起。“对许多底特律人来说，”我的学生帕姆说，“我们的心中仿佛有一块块空洞，因为无论我们做什么，都会遭到嘲笑。几十年来，底特律一直是全国的笑柄——对于那些不了解情况的人来说，现在依然如此。”他们长期挣扎，以至于自我怀疑侵蚀了他们的内心。底特律人是斗士，但他们已经学会了降低期望。即使被鼓励为他们的发展计划申请投资，他们也总是压低“要求”。他们分享的感受中流露出疲惫和绝望。

The reasons why are clear: Say that an entrepreneur runs a small business in Detroit that supplies parts to big auto manufacturers. This entrepreneur gets an email from GM or Ford that says that because of the economy, the entrepreneur will need to cut costs by 25 percent if they’re to continue to get the business. For these small Detroit-based businesses, who don’t have a diverse client base, a 25 percent reduction is enormous. But they can’t say no. They feel they’re handcuffed, and they’ve felt that way for a long time. They fear the consequences of asking for more because they fear hearing no. They don’t try to find a solution that may work for both parties. They think, How can I possibly do well negotiating with someone who has so much leverage? Although certainly there are other company towns, and big corporations often employ bullying tactics with those they work with, it’s different in Detroit. Chicago and Pittsburgh had troubles, too, and after Boeing cut jobs in Seattle in the 1970s, someone erected a soon-to-be famous billboard that read: Will the last person leaving Seattle—Turn out the lights . But Chicago, Pittsburgh, and Seattle diversified—they were not solely dependent on the industries that put them on the map. These cities also didn’t suffer as much from the deeply ingrained racial issues that plagued Detroit. These cities didn’t stay beaten down and poor for decades or suffer from a consistent lack of leadership. These cities were wounded but not scarred like Detroit. If a human being becomes depressed from being tired and stressed for a long period of time, it only makes sense that the same conditions would apply for a region that’s had bad news for years.

原因显而易见：假设一位企业家在底特律经营一家小型企业，为大型汽车制造商供应零部件。这位企业家收到通用汽车或福特汽车的邮件，称由于经济形势不佳，如果想继续获得业务，就必须削减25%的成本。对于这些客户群体单一的底特律小型企业来说，25%的降幅是巨大的。但他们无法拒绝。他们感到束手无策，而且这种感觉已经持续了很长时间。他们害怕提出更高要求的后果，因为他们害怕被拒绝。他们不去尝试寻找对双方都有利的解决方案。他们心想：我怎么可能和拥有如此强大谈判筹码的人谈判成功呢？当然，其他一些“企业城”也存在这种情况，大型企业也经常对合作伙伴采取胁迫手段，但在底特律，情况却有所不同。芝加哥和匹兹堡也曾遭遇困境。上世纪70年代，波音公司在西雅图裁员后，有人竖起了一块后来名声大噪的广告牌，上面写着：“离开西雅图的最后一个人——请关灯。” 但芝加哥、匹兹堡和西雅图实现了多元化发展——它们不再仅仅依赖于那些使它们声名鹊起的产业。这些城市也没有像底特律那样深受根深蒂固的种族问题的困扰。这些城市没有像底特律那样长期处于衰败和贫困之中，也没有长期缺乏领导。这些城市虽然也曾受过伤，但并没有像底特律那样伤痕累累。如果一个人长期处于疲惫和压力之下会患上抑郁症，那么一个地区如果多年来一直饱受坏消息的困扰，出现同样的症状也就不足为奇了。

To really understand the impact of these economic scars, it’s illuminating to look at someone from Detroit who doesn’t have them, and the ways the world looks different. Andrew Chmielewski grew up in a suburb of Detroit and was still in school during the worst of the economic downturn. He was passionate about business, though, and noticed a great opportunity when his dad, Dave—a retired Detroit firefighter—started getting more requests for his homemade toffee than he could handle. Dave was a great cook and often baked for his old engine house, but the demand for the toffee was unlike anything he’d encountered before. Andrew left school to grow the toffee into a business, and ten years later, Dave’s Sweet Tooth Toffee is in five thousand stores.

要真正理解这些经济创伤的影响，不妨看看一个来自底特律却未受其影响的人，以及他们眼中的世界截然不同的景象。安德鲁·奇米列夫斯基在底特律郊区长大，经济衰退最严重的时候他还在上学。但他对商业充满热情，并敏锐地察觉到父亲戴夫——一位退休的底特律消防员——自制太妃糖的需求量远超他所能承受的范围。戴夫厨艺精湛，经常为他以前的消防站烘焙点心，但太妃糖的需求量之大，却是他前所未见的。安德鲁辍学，将太妃糖生意发展成一项事业。十年后，戴夫的“甜牙太妃糖”已遍布五千家商店。

“I’m thirty,” Andrew said, “so ten years ago, I wasn’t involved in the economy in any meaningful way. I didn’t have a mortgage or a business.” Having grown up amid the downtimes, he came of age aware but not scarred. He was pleasantly surprised that it wasn’t difficult to convince people to give him money. He saw his Detroit roots not as a weight but as a plus: He didn’t have to compete with all of the stylish indie brands coming out of Brooklyn or San Francisco, where Dave’s Sweet Tooth might have gotten lost. He could experiment with flavors in a home kitchen, try and fail different recipes, and just generally be creative, all without being under anyone’s thumb.

“我三十岁了，”安德鲁说，“所以十年前，我几乎没有参与任何经济活动。我没有房贷，也没有自己的生意。” 在经济低迷时期长大，他虽然有所了解，但并没有留下心理阴影。令他惊喜的是，说服别人给他钱并不难。他并不把底特律的出身视为负担，而是优势：他不必与布鲁克林或旧金山那些时尚的独立品牌竞争，否则戴夫的甜品店可能会被埋没。他可以在家里的厨房里尝试各种口味，尝试不同的食谱，即使失败也没关系，总之，他可以尽情发挥创意，而不用受任何人的束缚。

His confidence in his product and in the market built on itself. At thirty, he’s comfortable walking away from big corporate accounts if they won’t come to a reasonable agreement, and he pointed out, “You can’t lose what you don’t have, right?” He knows, of course, that the potential with those accounts is massive. But that’s just the point—Andrew sees potential everywhere.

他对产品和市场的信心与日俱增。三十岁的他，如果大公司客户不愿达成合理的协议，他也会毫不犹豫地放弃。他指出：“你不可能失去你没有的东西，对吧？” 当然，他也明白这些客户的潜力巨大。但关键就在于此——安德鲁总能看到事物的潜力。

Few of us get through life unscarred, of course, and Andrew will surely have his share of trials. The key, though, is to be aware of how those trials are shaping your outlook and your decisions. The key is to let them inform you but not hurt you.

当然，我们当中很少有人能一帆风顺地度过一生，安德鲁也肯定会经历不少磨难。关键在于，要意识到这些磨难是如何影响你的世界观和决策的。关键是要让它们启发你，而不是伤害你。

*   *   *

My fear of failure, I learned, was my scar, and it could be debilitating. My fear of calling it quits on my company led me to make some terrible financial decisions and to stay in a job that didn’t make me happy. I was letting it define me.

我后来才明白，我对失败的恐惧就像一道伤疤，它会让我痛苦不堪。我害怕离开公司，这导致我做出了一些糟糕的财务决定，也让我继续待在一份并不让我快乐的工作中。我让这份工作定义了我。

But there’s another side of my scar, too. Even as I limped on with the company, I enrolled in business school at Wharton. I loved it, and I thrived, earning accolades from my peers and professors. During my second semester of business school I was in a horrible car accident when another car hit me going fifty miles per hour. I broke my ribs and all of my metatarsals, but when I was released from the emergency room I still stayed up to study cost accounting all night because I was terrified of flunking out. I was in a cast for four months, and somehow through my recovery, I kept up my grades. I would not skip classes, I would not fail at school. My fear of failure, I learned, could be motivating.

但我的伤疤还有另一面。即便我当时还在勉强维持公司运营，我还是进入了沃顿商学院学习。我热爱商学院，并且学业有成，赢得了同学和教授的赞誉。在商学院的第二个学期，我遭遇了一场可怕的车祸，另一辆车以每小时五十英里的速度撞上了我。我的肋骨和所有跖骨都断了，但出院后，我仍然熬夜学习成本会计，因为我害怕挂科。我打了四个月的石膏，但不知怎的，在康复期间，我的成绩一直保持良好。我不会逃课，也不会挂科。我意识到，对失败的恐惧也可以成为一种动力。

I ended up giving the graduation address for my class at Wharton. I remember standing pridefully before my family in the audience, and before my classmates and professors, and thinking that I had done it, that I had earned this. I could let the scars of my business define me, or I could let this moment define me. I chose the latter and have never looked back.

我最终在沃顿商学院的毕业典礼上发表了演讲。我记得当时我自豪地站在台下，面对着坐在台下的家人、同学和教授们，心想我做到了，这是我应得的。我可以让创业的伤痕定义我，也可以让这一刻定义我。我选择了后者，并且从未后悔过。

I’m much more mindful about my scars now. I catch myself when I’m up against a decision and my fear of failure rears its head. I can tell when my judgment is affected by imposter syndrome, or when the words in my head are my parents’, not mine. I know this is a struggle for me, and that likely it always will be. But now I can look at it more objectively. I can tell if I’m stewing in the midst of old baggage, which doesn’t serve me, or looking to a future with the lessons of my past relegated to their rightful place on the sidelines. And I feel fortunate to have caught myself out. The real danger is when you don’t even realize that your scars are there at all.

我现在更加在意自己的伤疤了。每当面临抉择，害怕失败的情绪涌上心头时，我都会及时察觉。我能分辨出自己的判断是否受到了冒名顶替综合症的影响，或者脑海中浮现的那些话语是否并非出自自己，而是父母的。我知道这对我来说一直是个难题，而且很可能永远如此。但现在我可以更客观地看待它。我能分辨出自己是否还在为过去的包袱而苦恼，这对我毫无益处；或者，我是否已经将过去的教训抛诸脑后，满怀希望地展望未来。我很庆幸自己能够及时察觉到这一点。真正的危险在于，你甚至根本意识不到自己身上的伤疤。

#↩

CHAPTER 4

第四章

getting the how wrong

搞错了

Nelson Mandela may well have been the best negotiator of the twentieth century. What he wanted—equal citizenship for blacks, an end to South African apartheid—was nothing short of monumental. As he served a life sentence in prison, he had every right and reason to scream his demands. But what made Mandela so brilliant, and ultimately so effective, was his ability to separate his powerful feelings and to empathize with his jailers, as well as with all of those who would love nothing more than to see apartheid thrive. He was a pragmatist. He patiently considered what approach would resonate not only with the South African government but also with the African National Congress. From prison, he was able to bring these two sides together by gently leading from behind, understanding what each side needed to hear and how each needed to approach talking to the other. He had grown up watching his father, a tribal chief, build consensus, and noted how the chief “stays behind the flock, letting the most nimble go ahead, whereupon the others follow, not realizing they are being led from behind.”

纳尔逊·曼德拉或许是二十世纪最杰出的谈判者。他所追求的——黑人的平等公民权，以及结束南非种族隔离制度——堪称意义非凡。身陷囹圄、被判终身监禁的他，完全有理由大声疾呼自己的诉求。然而，曼德拉的过人之处，以及他最终取得如此显著成效的原因，在于他能够将自己强烈的情感与狱卒的处境以及那些一心希望种族隔离制度继续存在的人的处境区分开来。他是一位务实主义者。他耐心地思考着，什么样的方法才能既能引起南非政府的共鸣，又能引起非洲人国民大会的共鸣。即使身陷囹圄，他也能巧妙地从幕后引导双方，理解彼此的需求以及沟通的方式，从而促成双方走到一起。他从小就看着身为部落首领的父亲凝聚共识，并注意到首领是如何“留在羊群后面，让最敏捷的羊走在前面，然后其他羊跟着走，却没有意识到自己被后面的人带领着”。

Abraham Lincoln used a similar patient, empathetic approach, once claiming: “When I get ready to talk to people, I spend two thirds of the time thinking what they want to hear and one third thinking about what I want to say.”

亚伯拉罕·林肯也采用了类似的耐心、同理心的方法，他曾说过：“当我准备与人交谈时，我会花三分之二的时间思考他们想听什么，再花三分之一的时间思考我想说什么。”

The average person may not be as skilled at communication as Mandela or Lincoln, but we do carefully calculate how to present information to a particular audience all the time, starting from when we were kids and knew to wait until Mom and Dad were in a good mood to ask if we could have dessert. Despite this, when an exchange is framed as a negotiation, we often forget the soft skills—that we are dealing, first and foremost, with another human being.

普通人或许不像曼德拉或林肯那样擅长沟通，但我们总是会精心考虑如何向特定受众传递信息，这可以追溯到我们小时候，那时我们就知道要等到父母心情好的时候再问他们能不能给我们吃甜点。尽管如此，当交流被视为谈判时，我们往往会忘记一些软技能——我们首先是在与另一个人打交道。

Whenever you negotiate—whether it’s about changing risky behavior, closing a complex business deal, or deciding who is going to take the garbage out—you need to know two things: what you’re going to ask for, and how. Most people spend considerable time and energy worrying about what to ask for, whether their ask is justified, and whether they’re asking for too much or too little. But they spend little if any time thinking about how to frame their argument. They don’t stop to consider, “How will my counterpart receive the information if I ask this way? What about if I ask it another way?”

无论何时谈判——无论是为了改变冒险行为、达成复杂的商业交易，还是决定谁来倒垃圾——你都需要知道两件事：你要提出什么要求，以及如何提出。大多数人花费大量时间和精力去思考该提出什么要求，他们的要求是否合理，以及他们提出的要求是太多还是太少。但他们很少甚至根本不会花时间思考如何构建自己的论点。他们不会停下来思考：“如果我这样问，对方会如何理解？如果我换一种方式问呢？”

For years, my friend Clay worked in diplomatic protocol. He was the guy prepping politicians and government officials on what they needed to know before multicultural events. He would brief them on where the country flags should be placed, how—or whether!—to shake someone’s hand, and even why the color of their clothing mattered. Each year, I bring him in to speak to my negotiation classes, not because they need to know the finer points of gift giving in a business meeting with bilateral partners, but because they do need to understand how much the details matter and how much they can signal.

多年来，我的朋友克莱一直从事外交礼宾工作。他负责为政客和政府官员准备多元文化活动前的礼仪须知。他会告诉他们国旗应该放在哪里，如何握手（或者是否应该握手！），甚至包括服装颜色的重要性。每年，我都会邀请他来给我的谈判课授课，这并非因为学生们需要了解与双边伙伴进行商务会谈时送礼的技巧，而是因为他们确实需要明白细节的重要性以及它们所传递的信息。

This chapter is about communication. When the how of our communication gets rushed, when you don’t put the thought into it that’s required, it creates a lot of unnecessary problems and unfavorable results. In this chapter, I look at the ways we get the how of the ask so wrong, and why.

本章探讨的是沟通。当我们在沟通中操之过急，没有进行必要的思考时，就会造成许多不必要的麻烦和不利后果。在本章中，我将分析我们在提出请求的方式上经常犯的错误，以及造成这些错误的原因。

You can’t rush a good deal

好交易急不得。

Most of us follow rules that we feel are “truisms”—which, by definition, are statements so obvious they aren’t even worth mentioning. We avoid dairy if we have a cold, thinking that it increases mucus production (it doesn’t). We drop our sandwich on the floor but then pick it up quickly, thinking, “ five-second rule”—when, in actuality, time has nothing to do with bacteria’s ability to infect our food. And of course, everybody knows that it’s always better to be efficient than not. Wrong again.

我们大多数人遵循的规则都是我们认为的“老生常谈”——顾名思义，这些道理显而易见，根本不值得一提。比如，感冒时我们会避免吃乳制品，认为它会增加黏液分泌（其实不然）。我们把三明治掉在地上，但会迅速捡起来，心想“五秒法则”——而实际上，时间与细菌污染食物的能力毫无关系。当然，人人都知道，效率永远比效率低好。然而，这又是错误的。

Let’s get right to the point, shall we? Americans are nothing if not efficient. Why just drive when you can drive, eat, and make a work call at the same time? Why wait in a line at the grocery store when you can order delivery from Instacart? People are able to accomplish more in a day than ever before, and as to-do lists grow, social niceties are seen as a waste of precious time. “I should be able to close this deal and go home in a day or so” is a common refrain from American businesspeople. They imagine flying to Tokyo, meeting their client in person for the first time, signing the deal, then flying home the next day. They’ll be able to order groceries on the plane, and maybe even get caught up on email.

咱们就直奔主题吧。美国人效率极高。既然可以边开车边吃饭边打工作电话，何必还要开车呢？既然可以用Instacart订购送货上门，何必还要在超市排队呢？人们一天之内能完成的事情比以往任何时候都多，待办事项清单越列越长，社交礼节被视为浪费宝贵时间。“我应该能在一两天内完成这笔交易然后回家”是美国商人的口头禅。他们设想飞往东京，与客户首次见面，签下合同，然后第二天就飞回家。他们可以在飞机上订购杂货，甚至可能还能处理一下积压的邮件。

Regardless of whether that’s the way business should be done (and I would argue it isn’t), quick transactions aren’t realistic and rarely make for the most ideal outcomes. Particularly in cultures that put an emphasis on relationships—like those in Asia, Latin America, and the Middle East—people want to know who they’re doing business with. Dinners, drinks, and conversation all take place before broaching business. Relationships mean more than the transaction. It’s a courting process, and even in more task-oriented cultures like Germany and the United States, relationships matter. Robert Iger, who was the CEO of Disney, met in person with George Lucas over a period of two years when negotiating the purchase of Lucasfilm, and he told the New York Times of the deal with the Star Wars visionary, “There was a lot of trust there.” Simply put, negotiation requires patience. People are still people and want to see and be seen by whoever they’re negotiating with.

无论这是否是理想的商业模式（我认为并非如此），快速交易既不现实，也鲜少能带来最理想的结果。尤其是在重视人际关系的文化中——例如亚洲、拉丁美洲和中东地区——人们都希望了解自己的商业伙伴。在正式洽谈业务之前，通常会先进行晚餐、饮酒和交谈。人际关系的重要性远超交易本身。这更像是一个建立关系的过程，即使在像德国和美国这样更注重任务的文化中，人际关系也同样重要。迪士尼前首席执行官罗伯特·艾格在与乔治·卢卡斯洽谈收购卢卡斯影业的过程中，曾与卢卡斯进行了长达两年的会面。他告诉《纽约时报》，与这位《星球大战》的缔造者达成交易时，“我们之间建立了高度的信任”。简而言之，谈判需要耐心。人终究是人，他们希望与谈判对象见面，也希望被对方看到。

Glen Cutrona has worked in real estate development in New York for decades. He says many of the people he deals with for permitting at government agencies are “disgruntled, not happy about what they do.” His job, he’s come to see, “is to get them to feel comfortable enough to drop their guard . . . I can’t walk into scenarios thinking ‘I must get this done.’ Everything you do is a negotiation. Everybody wants something faster than you can deliver it. But it takes time, and I’ve learned to be involved with people. I have to consider the fact that I’m going to be involved with these people in five years.”

格伦·库特罗纳在纽约从事房地产开发几十年了。他说，他经常和政府机构的审批人员打交道，这些人“心怀不满，对自己的工作很不满意”。他逐渐意识到，他的工作“是让他们感到足够放松，放下戒备……我不能抱着‘我必须完成这件事’的想法去处理各种情况。你做的每一件事都是一场谈判。每个人都想要比你更快得到的东西。但这需要时间，我已经学会了如何与人沟通。我必须考虑到，五年后我还要和这些人打交道。”

Perhaps the most stereotypically efficient environment is that of a financial trading floor, which is where Anthony Chiarito got his start. He went straight from high school to a job at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. “Not a place,” he said, “where you show emotion. It was a very testosterone-filled environment.” He spent a decade there before moving on to the insurance field, and he now runs his own insurance agency. He felt that some of what he learned at the exchange, such as where to take risks, has helped, but some elements of the culture have hindered him. “I get too quickly to the point,” he said, “and don’t let my personality come out.” Though a naturally friendly and outgoing guy, Anthony always thought he should shut that side of himself off in negotiation. “I could build a rapport, I just didn’t allow myself to. If I’m pursuing something I’m more reserved. I thought that was the way to be, to keep it to business.”

或许最典型的高效环境莫过于金融交易大厅，安东尼·基亚里托的职业生涯正是从那里起步的。高中毕业后，他直接进入芝加哥商品交易所工作。“那可不是个能让你流露情感的地方，”他说，“那里充满了雄性荷尔蒙。”他在那里工作了十年，之后转行进入保险行业，现在经营着自己的保险代理公司。他觉得在交易所学到的一些东西，比如何时承担风险，对他有所帮助，但交易所的一些文化因素也阻碍了他。“我说话太直奔主题，”他说，“不让自己的个性显露出来。”虽然安东尼天性友善外向，但他总觉得在谈判中应该收敛这一面。“我其实可以建立融洽的关系，但我就是不允许自己这么做。如果我在追求什么，我就会更加内敛。我当时觉得就应该这样，专注于生意。”

When Anthony realized his formal approach wasn’t serving him well, he adjusted. He recently opened up a second location for his insurance business, which required him to find an office space. “Originally the price was right but the square footage wasn’t,” he said of a place he liked. “What I wanted to do was hurry up, get it wrapped up, and move on to the next thing.” But he slowed down. He built a rapport with the building owners. He brought his wife to tour the space. “They got to know me, to see that I was responsible,” he said. “So they allowed me to go in at a month-to-month, and for the rent to be at a lower square footage unit.”

当安东尼意识到自己一成不变的方式行不通时，他做出了调整。最近，他为自己的保险公司开设了第二家分店，这需要他寻找办公场所。“起初价格合适，但面积不够，”他谈到自己看中的一处地方时说道，“我当时想的是赶紧完工，然后去做下一件事。”但他放慢了脚步。他与房东建立了良好的关系。他还带妻子去参观了办公场所。“他们了解了我，看到了我的责任心，”他说，“所以他们允许我按月租赁，而且租金也比原先的面积要低。”

If you don’t take the time to build connection but go straight into the bargaining, then if you reach an impasse regarding your numbers, there’s nothing else to talk about. There’s no context, no building of affiliation. Organizations that write grants for government jobs consistently say that the hardest ones to write are those based only on pricing. If you’re not offering to do the job for the least amount, you’re out. There are no other data points, no other information exchange. In contrast, consider what happens in a hot housing market: Buyers write personal notes to the sellers, often including a photo of themselves or their family. Under the rules of game theory, the highest bidder would win, end of story. That still does happen, and yet when offers are close, it makes a difference to remind people they’re doing business with a human being, not a number.

如果你不花时间建立联系，而是直接进入讨价还价，那么一旦在价格上陷入僵局，就无话可说了。没有背景信息，也无法建立联系。为政府项目撰写拨款申请的机构经常表示，最难写的就是那些只基于价格的申请。如果你提供的报价不是最低的，你就出局了。没有其他数据点，也没有其他信息交流。相比之下，想想在火热的房地产市场中会发生什么：买家会给卖家写一些个人留言，通常还会附上自己或家人的照片。根据博弈论的规则，出价最高者胜出，故事就此结束。这种情况仍然会发生，但当报价接近时，提醒人们他们是在和人而不是数字做生意就显得尤为重要。

When you build rapport, when you take time to have conversations and learn about one another, it does make the process longer. It might even increase the duration by an entire sales cycle. But now your counterpart has other pieces of information that he can use to make a decision or further build the relationship. The exchange has become more than just a transaction. We’ll dig deeper into building relationships in Part II.

当你建立融洽的关系，花时间交谈并了解彼此时，确实会延长整个流程。它甚至可能延长整个销售周期。但此时，你的对方会掌握更多信息，可以用来做出决定或进一步发展关系。交流已不再仅仅是交易。我们将在第二部分深入探讨如何建立关系。

“Nice guys finish last”

“好人没好报”

In the 1975 book Anatomy of a Merger , superlawyer James C. Freund wrote, “Everyone has his [or her] own negotiating style, and the worst thing you can do is to adopt a negotiating technique that does not feel comfortable [because] credibility, based on an evident sincerity, is the most important single asset of a good negotiator.” Nearly fifty years later, legions of young negotiators still struggle to take this advice to heart.

在1975年出版的《并购剖析》一书中，超级律师詹姆斯·C·弗罗因德写道：“每个人都有自己独特的谈判风格，最糟糕的做法就是采用一种让你感到不自在的谈判技巧，因为基于真诚的信誉是优秀谈判者最重要的资产。” 近五十年过去了，无数年轻的谈判者仍然难以真正理解并践行这一建议。

Jennifer, the graphic designer I introduced in Chapter 1, was one of these negotiators. After years of work and friendship with her business partners, Jennifer decided to leave the company she’d cofounded. The buyout process made her extremely nervous; not only was she a pleaser, but conversations about money at her company had been very morally loaded.

我在第一章中介绍的平面设计师詹妮弗就是这些谈判者之一。在与商业伙伴共事多年并建立起深厚友谊后，詹妮弗决定离开她共同创立的公司。收购过程让她非常紧张；她不仅一向讨好别人，而且公司里关于金钱的讨论也充满了道德争议。

As a result, Jennifer turned to her husband for help settling her buyout. He was an attorney and had long rolled his eyes when Jennifer expressed her reluctance to talk money with her partners. His culture was the polar opposite: Any reference to feelings or moralizing about negotiation was scoffed at. This was business, not personal.

因此，詹妮弗只好向丈夫寻求帮助，以解决她的收购事宜。丈夫是一名律师，一直以来，每当詹妮弗表示不愿与合伙人谈钱时，他都会翻白眼。他的文化截然相反：任何提及情感或对谈判进行道德评判的做法都会遭到嘲笑。这是生意，不是私人恩怨。

Jennifer’s husband drafted all of the correspondence she wrote to her partners about the buyout. Once they got a number from a third-party appraiser, Jennifer’s husband ghostwrote an email that listed all the reasons they should agree to the number and do so immediately. It was formal and filled with legalese meant to get the deal agreed to quickly. Jennifer added a line of her own at the end of it, indicating her great affection for her partners, and sent it.

珍妮弗的丈夫代她起草了所有关于收购事宜的信函。一旦他们从第三方评估机构获得估价，珍妮弗的丈夫就代笔写了一封电子邮件，列举了他们应该立即接受该价格的所有理由。这封邮件措辞正式，充满了法律术语，旨在促成交易的快速达成。珍妮弗在邮件末尾添加了一行，表达了她对合伙人的深切情谊，然后发送了出去。

Jennifer’s partners, though they agreed to the number, were upset with her. They felt her approach was overly formal and confrontational. They felt she hadn’t honored the close and personal nature of their decadelong relationship. Only much later, when she had a heart-to-heart with one of her former partners, Carrie, did she learn the extent of their hurt.

尽管詹妮弗的合伙人同意了她的提议，但他们对她很不满意。他们觉得她的做法过于正式和咄咄逼人，没有尊重他们长达十年的亲密关系。直到很久以后，当她与其中一位前合伙人凯莉进行了一次推心置腹的谈话后，她才了解到他们受到的伤害有多深。

“I don’t know that you realized what it was like to get that email,” Carrie said. “We’d been having a really tough year financially, which I thought you understood, and here we were hit with this demanding, honestly kind of mean, email. And then the way you ended it with all this affection was just weird. It was like, Does she really not have a clue how she came across here? ” What’s particularly ironic about this story is that Jennifer was emotionally intelligent—it was one of her strongest traits. But she was so panicked by negotiation and so sure that her emotional intelligence would only serve to harm her that she shut off what could have been her greatest asset. She explained all of this to Carrie, Carrie owned up to her own mistakes in the process, and the two have resumed a close friendship. Still, it was a messy process that was unnecessary, and Jennifer is still not on speaking terms with one of her other partners.

“我不知道你是否意识到收到那封邮件是什么感觉，”凯莉说。“我们这一年经济状况非常艰难，我以为你能理解，结果却收到这样一封咄咄逼人、说实话有点刻薄的邮件。而且你最后还用那么浓浓的爱意结尾，真是太奇怪了。我当时就想，她难道真的不知道自己给人的感觉有多糟糕吗？” 这件事最讽刺的地方在于，詹妮弗情商很高——这是她最突出的优点之一。但她在谈判中惊慌失措，又认定自己的情商只会害了自己，结果反而关闭了自己本可以发挥的最大优势。她把这一切都告诉了凯莉，凯莉也承认了自己的错误，两人重新建立了亲密的友谊。尽管如此，这仍然是一个混乱且不必要的过程，詹妮弗至今仍与她的另一位合伙人断绝了联系。

Jennifer and I debriefed the experience together because though she knew where she’d messed up, she wanted to know how she could have done it differently. The answer was all in the communication, all in the how. “You might have thought through how your partners would receive your ask, knowing that they put a moral judgment on it,” I said. “Didn’t they once tell you that when you lead conversations by talking about money, it makes them distrust you?”

我和詹妮弗一起回顾了这件事，因为虽然她知道自己错在哪里，但她想知道怎样才能做得更好。答案全在于沟通，全在于沟通的方式。“你可能考虑过你的合作伙伴会如何看待你的请求，因为他们会从道德层面来评判这件事，”我说。“他们不是曾经告诉过你，如果你总是谈论金钱，会让他们对你产生不信任感吗？”

Jennifer reddened. “They’re wrong to do that. They shouldn’t—it’s business.” She was echoing the logic of her lawyer husband and his culture.

詹妮弗脸红了。“他们这样做不对。他们不应该这样做——这是生意。”她这番话正是她律师丈夫及其文化背景的逻辑。

“But they do,” I reminded her, pointing out the importance of being pragmatic. We talked through how she might have couched her ask in a way that would speak to her partners. They valued relationship. She could have started there. They adored their brand. She could have gone there next. Instead of leading with formality and numbers, she could have simply met them where they were, and made the ask make sense to them in language they could relate to.

“但他们的确如此，”我提醒她，并强调务实的重要性。我们讨论了她应该如何措辞才能更好地与合作伙伴沟通。他们重视人际关系，她可以从这一点入手。他们热爱自己的品牌，她可以接着谈这一点。她不必一开始就摆出一副正式的姿态，抛出一堆数字，而是应该设身处地地理解他们的想法，用他们能够理解的语言来解释她的请求。

“Gender doesn’t matter” (but emotional intelligence does)

“性别并不重要”（但情商很重要）

Although this section also relates to men, it’s undeniable that the bias here swings more one way than the other. You’re right. Like her or not, never was gender bias more evident than with the presidential candidacy of Hillary Clinton. Everything she said, did, and wore was filtered through the lens of her sex. Gender stereotypes are real. Study after study shows that the achievements of women are viewed more critically than the same achievements of men.

虽然这一部分也涉及男性，但不可否认的是，这里的偏见明显偏向女性。你说得对。不管你喜不喜欢她，希拉里·克林顿的总统竞选都充分体现了性别偏见。她的一言一行、一举一动、一身穿着都被贴上了性别的标签。性别刻板印象是真实存在的。一项又一项的研究表明，女性的成就往往比男性的成就更容易受到批判。

When women make an ask, they often face consequences that men wouldn’t. Women who are not afraid to initiate negotiations and who will ask for more may be seen as demanding and aggressive. They are seen as less likable and pushy, whereas their male counterparts are viewed as goal-oriented and skilled negotiators for doing the same things.

当女性提出要求时，她们往往会面临男性不会面临的后果。那些敢于发起谈判、勇于争取更多权益的女性，可能会被视为要求过多、咄咄逼人。她们会被认为不太讨人喜欢、过于强势，而男性如果做同样的事情，则会被视为目标明确、谈判技巧娴熟。

Female business owners, particularly in male-dominated industries, are highly cognizant of this dilemma and double standard. Likability is important, and they can’t afford to be seen as pushy, greedy, or aggressive. (They likely aren’t any of these things, but in negotiation, perception is reality.) So what to do?

女性企业主，尤其是在男性主导的行业中，对这种困境和双重标准有着深刻的认识。讨人喜欢很重要，她们不能给人留下咄咄逼人、贪婪或好斗的印象。（她们可能并非如此，但在谈判中，感知即现实。）那么，她们该怎么办呢？

For starters, women don’t have to ask for less. What they do have to do is focus on making the ask appeal to their counterpart. Their preparation requires them not only to understand their own interests, set high goals, and identify information that supports those goals, but to take into consideration their counterpart’s perspective and interests. Emotional intelligence is everything. If you have your pulse on the emotions, reactions, and receptivity of your counterpart, you can navigate the conversation with precision. This isn’t true just for women—it’s true for everyone, and in every negotiation.

首先，女性不必降低自己的要求。她们需要做的是，让对方觉得她们的要求合情合理。为此，她们不仅要了解自身利益、设定远大目标并找到支持这些目标的信息，还要考虑对方的视角和利益。情商至关重要。如果你能敏锐地察觉对方的情绪、反应和接受程度，就能精准地掌控对话。这不仅适用于女性，也适用于所有人，在任何谈判中都适用。

Even as they make the ask, women think we can frame it less as an extra battle we need to fight and more as a celebration of our skill. When my former student Eszter, a fantastic businesswoman, successfully negotiated for a table at a full restaurant, the men she was with teased her that she used the fact that she’s a young woman to get her way. This irked her, because she knew she used her intelligence and her savvy, and she felt they were shortchanging her skill. She hadn’t just batted her eyelashes and magically secured a table—she had made a point of connecting with the maître d’, casting herself as his partner to come up with creative solutions. When she asked my take on it, I told her that her femininity was wrapped up in her keen emotional intelligence, so yes, she had used it, and—by the way—it was effective. Instead of seeing it as demeaning, she could see it as a compliment. She had used her warmth and her compassion as sources of power. It’s the same sentiment Ava DuVernay, who directed the Oscar-nominated film Selma as well as the female-strong A Wrinkle in Time , expressed when she told the New York Times , “When you say ‘feminizing,’ people think of softness in certain places, but I think of strength in other places.” That’s what Eszter had exhibited.

即使在提出要求时，女性也认为我们可以把这看作是对自己能力的赞扬，而不是一场需要额外战斗的挑战。我的学生埃斯特是一位出色的女商人，她成功地在一家爆满的餐厅里订到了一张桌子。和她在一起的男士们却取笑她，说她利用了自己年轻貌美的优势。这让她很生气，因为她知道自己运用了智慧和精明，她觉得他们低估了她的能力。她可不是眨眨眼就凭空弄到一张桌子——她特意与餐厅领班建立了联系，把自己塑造成他的合作伙伴，共同想出创造性的解决方案。当她问我的看法时，我告诉她，她的女性魅力体现在她敏锐的情商上，所以没错，她确实运用了这一点，而且——顺便说一句——这很有效。她不应该把这看作是贬低，而应该把它看作是一种赞美。她将自己的热情和同情心转化为了力量的源泉。这与执导过奥斯卡提名影片《塞尔玛》以及展现女性力量的影片《时间的皱褶》的导演艾娃·杜威内（Ava DuVernay）的观点不谋而合。她告诉《纽约时报》：“当你提到‘女性化’时，人们会想到某些方面的柔弱，但我想到的是其他方面的坚强。” 这正是埃斯特所展现的。

In my work in the sports industry, my femininity is always there as subtext. I could go into a meeting as the only woman and think, “Oh, you’re expecting Jane? Well, too bad, guys, I’m Tarzan!” Plenty of women use that strategy. But that wouldn’t be being true to who I am. I might play up or play down certain characteristics based on my audience, but I’m always authentically myself. I will compliment certain people because I’m paying attention and I can tell that it will help set the tone I want. That’s not kissing up—it’s having emotional intelligence. I wouldn’t give a compliment I couldn’t stand behind, or ask a question I didn’t genuinely want to know the answer to.

在我的体育行业工作中，我的女性特质总是以一种潜台词的形式存在。我可能会走进一个只有我一个女性的会议室，然后心想：“哦，你们期待的是简·奥斯汀？那可就糟了，伙计们，我是泰山！”很多女性都用过这种策略。但这并非我真实的自我。我会根据不同的场合，适度地展现或淡化某些特质，但我始终保持真我。我会赞美某些人，因为我会留意观察，并且知道这样做有助于营造我想要的氛围。这并非阿谀奉承，而是情商的体现。我不会给出自己无法认同的赞美，也不会问自己并不真正想知道答案的问题。

When my female students explain, “I’m working in a male-dominated industry and never know how to handle it. I’m so worried about appearing like I’m flirting, or being too nice,” I tell them never to apologize for being a woman. Use all of your weapons, including the emotional intelligence that many women are so good at. Giving someone a compliment is fair game, so long as you mean it. Wearing a low-cut blouse or a short skirt to attract attention is not.

当我的女学生解释说：“我身处一个男性主导的行业，总是不知道该如何应对。我太担心自己看起来像是在调情，或者表现得太热情了。”我会告诉她们，永远不要为自己是女性而道歉。要善用你的一切优势，包括许多女性都非常擅长的情商。真诚地赞美他人是完全可以的。但为了吸引眼球而穿低胸上衣或短裙则不然。

Importantly, using emotional intelligence does not mean rolling over, and the minute I feel disrespected I will call it out. My boundaries are clear and I set a high standard for how I expect to be treated—not as a woman but as a human being. I no longer have trouble speaking up for myself, and I always tell women to do so. But I’m also not going to play the angry woman because I feel like men have marginalized me my whole life. That won’t get me anywhere either. It may not be fair that we constantly have to think about these nuances, but it’s the way it is . . . for now.

重要的是，运用情商并不意味着逆来顺受。一旦我感到不被尊重，我会毫不犹豫地指出来。我的底线很明确，我对别人如何对待我有着很高的要求——不是作为女人，而是作为一个人。我现在不再害怕为自己发声，而且我总是鼓励女性也这样做。但我也不会因为觉得自己一生都被男性边缘化就扮演愤怒的女人。那样做也于事无补。我们不得不时刻考虑这些细微差别，这或许并不公平，但这就是现实……至少目前是这样。

Business is personal

商业与个人息息相关

My student Pam, the owner of the construction services company in Detroit, learned this lesson—as she’s learned most—the hard way. “I didn’t understand the necessity of relationship,” Pam said, then elaborated that she meant, “people who want the best for you, who aren’t related to you, but there’s something in you they want to engage with long-term. People willing to spend their social capital on you. I differentiated ‘this is business’ and ‘this is personal.’” In 2012, Pam lost an order that would have changed her life. It took her two years to realize why she had lost it, given that she had been advised by the purchaser that she had the best price and the best technical offer. “The other company received the order on the strength of their relationship,” Pam said simply.

我的学生帕姆是底特律一家建筑服务公司的老板，她吸取了这个教训——就像她吸取的大多数教训一样——付出了惨痛的代价。“我以前不明白人际关系的重要性，”帕姆说，然后她进一步解释说，她指的是“那些真心希望你好的人，他们和你没有任何关系，但他们想和你建立长期的合作关系。他们愿意在你身上投入他们的社会资本。我以前把‘这是生意’和‘这是私人关系’区分开来。” 2012年，帕姆错失了一份本可以改变她一生的订单。她花了两年时间才明白自己为什么会失去这份订单，因为采购方曾告诉她，她的报价和技术方案都是最优的。“另一家公司凭借的是他们之间的关系，”帕姆简单地说。

“Before I lost the order, I knew intellectually that people do business with people they know. But I truly believed that if I worked hard, and did great work, I would win.” It took some time for Pam to get past the loss. “After I lost the order, I was hurt and angry, but I really got it . I had underestimated the strength of comfort and camaraderie or relationships in business. In the past, I would have viewed the loss as racist and sexist. But I realized that it was less intentional than that. White men still control contracts. Because their primary relationships are with other white men, they’re purchasing from a pool of business owned and operated by white men. Typically, they’re not intentional about meeting other people. They don’t necessarily know African American women and Latina women. And if they don’t know us, then we’re not in the pool, and we don’t have access to relationships or the opportunities. I had to change that.”

“在丢掉订单之前，我理智上知道人们会和熟人做生意。但我真心相信，只要我努力工作，做出出色的成绩，就一定能成功。”帕姆花了些时间才从失利的打击中走出来。“丢掉订单后，我既伤心又愤怒，但我真正明白了。我低估了人际关系在商业中的重要性。过去，我会把这次失利看作是种族歧视和性别歧视。但我意识到，事情远没有那么简单。白人男性仍然掌控着合同。因为他们的主要关系网是其他白人男性，所以他们只能从白人男性拥有和经营的企业中采购。通常情况下，他们不会刻意去结识其他人。他们未必认识非裔美国女性和拉丁裔女性。如果他们不认识我们，我们就不在客户名单上，也就无法获得人脉和机会。我必须改变这种状况。”

Once she understood this, Pam changed her approach. Her new business plan? “Y’all gonna know me.” Pam has spent the last four years stepping out of everything that’s comfortable to her. She’s on panels, she does keynotes, she gets her name out every chance she can. Putting herself out there was the missing link. She and her business are now known entities. “It has worked remarkably well,” she said. “But it was the hardest and most important lesson that I’ve learned.”

一旦明白这一点，帕姆就改变了策略。她的新商业计划是什么？“你们都会认识我。”过去四年，帕姆一直在努力走出舒适区。她参加各种研讨会，发表主题演讲，抓住一切机会宣传自己。勇于展现自我正是她成功的关键。如今，她和她的公司都已小有名气。“效果非常好，”她说，“但这却是我学到的最艰难也最重要的一课。”

The problem of overconfidence

过度自信的问题

When you are overconfident, you mess up the how . And when I say overconfident , don’t immediately exclude yourself because you’re a modest sort of person. Overconfidence is an easy trap to fall into. Many people spend years working on their confidence and are right to do so, as it’s critical for their negotiation. I’m all for confidence. (See Chapter 1!) But it’s a very slippery slope before it turns into overconfidence, and overconfidence can affect the most humble of us. When it does, it keeps us from preparing to the extent we should.

过度自信会搞砸事情。我说“过度自信”的时候，别因为你谦虚就觉得自己不属于这一类。过度自信很容易让人掉进陷阱。很多人花数年时间培养自信，这样做是对的，因为自信对谈判至关重要。我非常支持自信（参见第一章！）。但是，自信很容易滑向过度自信，而过度自信甚至会影响到最谦逊的人。一旦陷入过度自信，就会让我们无法做好充分的准备。

Anthony Chiarito’s experience at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, as well as in business afterward, made him feel pretty confident about his negotiation ability. Negotiation was not something that scared him when he arrived in his cohort’s negotiation class for Goldman Sachs’s 10,000 Small Businesses. “I wasn’t arrogant coming into the class,” he said, “but I was really confident.”

安东尼·基亚里托在芝加哥商品交易所的经历，以及之后的商业经验，让他对自己的谈判能力充满信心。因此，当他参加高盛“万家小企业”项目的谈判培训班时，谈判并没有让他感到畏惧。“我来上课时并不傲慢，”他说，“但我确实非常自信。”

Overconfident, as it turned out.

结果证明，我过于自信了。

In a class exercise, Anthony’s role was to sell a rare piece of jewelry. The amount that he’d charged for jewelry from this designer, and this particular line, had gone up consistently year over year. He also had made one special-occasion sale, but it was an off-market deal between him and a friend, and the price point they’d agreed on was significantly lower than his public sales.

在一次课堂练习中，安东尼的任务是出售一件稀有珠宝。他出售的这位设计师的同系列珠宝价格逐年上涨。他还做过一笔特殊场合的销售，但那是一笔他和朋友之间的非公开交易，他们商定的价格远低于他的公开售价。

When Anthony planned his negotiation strategy, he used that off-market sale as a data point, which brought his year-over-year growth curve down. As a result, he didn’t set his goal high enough. This first mistake was a problem of preparation, because in reality that data point did not need to be factored in—it was an outlier.

安东尼在制定谈判策略时，将那笔场外交易作为参考数据，这拉低了他同比增速的预期。结果，他的目标设定得不够高。第一个错误是准备不足造成的，因为实际上那笔交易的数据点根本无需考虑——它只是个异常值。

Second, he shared the information about the off-market sale freely, which hurt the case about the rate of rising value for the jewelry.

其次，他随意泄露了场外交易的信息，这不利于证明珠宝价值上涨的速度。

I’m generally a supporter of sharing information. People tend to hold information too close, which cuts off creative thinking and hinders openly exploring areas of mutual gain. (This is the subject of Chapter 8!) But before going into a negotiation, you have to think about whether each piece of information at your disposal works to your advantage if you share it or puts you at a disadvantage. Anthony should share information about his past public sales and how the value of the jewelry had consistently and dramatically gone up (as rare objects often do). This information was freely available anyway, and by sharing it, Anthony would establish the tone of the conversation as one of openness and explain why he was justified in his ask. The information about the off-market sale, in contrast, didn’t help Anthony. It shouldn’t have hurt him, since there were good reasons why that amount was lower, but he hadn’t really thought that part through.

我通常支持信息共享。人们往往把信息藏得太深，这会扼杀创造性思维，阻碍公开探索互利共赢的领域。（这正是第八章的主题！）但在谈判之前，你必须思考，你掌握的每一条信息，如果分享出去，是会对你有利，还是会让你处于劣势。安东尼应该分享他过去公开销售的信息，以及珠宝价值如何持续大幅上涨（稀有物品通常如此）。这些信息本来就是公开的，分享这些信息可以让安东尼营造一种开放的对话氛围，并解释他提出要求的合理性。相比之下，关于场外交易的信息对安东尼并没有帮助。这本来不应该对他不利，因为价格较低是有原因的，但他并没有真正考虑清楚这一点。

If Anthony had not been overconfident, he would have prepared more. And if he had prepared more, he would have known not to share the information about the off-market sale but to be ready—if asked—to provide that information along with an explanation of why that sale was lower in order to diminish the information’s influence.

如果安东尼没有那么自负，他就会准备得更充分。如果他准备得更充分，他就会知道不应该透露场外交易的信息，而是应该做好准备——如果有人问起——提供这些信息，并解释为什么那笔交易的价格较低，以降低该信息的影响。
