He was surprised when he and his partner finished negotiating before most of the others. “I was in a rush to get at it. I was one of the first people done. That was eye-opening to me.”

他和搭档比大多数人更早完成谈判，这让他感到惊讶。“我当时急于求成，我是最早完成的人之一。这让我大开眼界。”

He was even more surprised when I displayed the results of the first negotiation. (Remember, everybody sees everybody else’s results on a screen, and then we debrief them.) Not only was Anthony’s deal one of the first ones completed, but he came out near the bottom. “In real-life negotiations, you don’t have the chance to figure out what the other side was willing to pay,” Anthony said. “You get a deal and think you did a great job.

当我展示第一次谈判的结果时，他更加惊讶了。（记住，每个人都能在屏幕上看到其他人的结果，然后我们会进行总结。）安东尼的交易不仅是最早完成的交易之一，而且他的出价还接近最低。“在现实谈判中，你没有机会弄清楚对方愿意支付多少钱，”安东尼说。“你达成了协议，然后就觉得自己做得很好。”

“It was an awakening to me,” he said, “that my confidence was not well placed. I made my notes, I made my plan. The failure was right there in the planning. I didn’t understand what my position should have been, but I thought I knew it. I should have given more thought to it. I lost the negotiation before I opened my mouth. That exercise showed me that there was a better process. That I needed to slow down.”

“这让我幡然醒悟，”他说，“我意识到自己的自信是错误的。我做了笔记，制定了计划。失败就出在计划阶段。我当时并不明白自己的立场应该是什么，但我自以为知道。我应该更仔细地思考。谈判还没开始我就已经输了。那次经历让我明白，还有更好的方法。我需要放慢脚步。”

Beware of overconfidence, because it can trap you into shorting your preparation. There is someone out there who is concerned they’re not prepared enough, and they’re preparing more than you. They are crossing every t and dotting every i , and unless you have, too, and have a solid explanation for your ask that you believe in, they will get a better deal.

切勿过度自信，因为它会让你准备不足。总有人担心自己准备不够充分，所以他们比你准备得更充分。他们事无巨细，一丝不苟。除非你也如此，并且对你的诉求有充分且令人信服的理由，否则他们很可能会得到更好的结果。

I want my students to be confident, but I want them to come to their confidence organically rather than coming in and saying, “I know this stuff cold” without an appropriate level of preparation.

我希望我的学生充满自信，但我希望他们的自信是自然而然形成的，而不是在没有进行适当准备的情况下就说“我对这些东西了如指掌”。

Another by-product of overconfidence is that the overconfident negotiator will try to sell something for more than they can justify. Remember from Chapter 1 that you tell a story that’s favorable to you, but that’s based in data. That story can’t be a fairy tale. I’ve watched numerous businesses that are acquisition targets seek unrealistic sales goals. They never get what they want and sacrifice their credibility in the process.

过度自信的另一个副作用是，过于自信的谈判者会试图以超出自身能力范围的价格出售产品或服务。请记住第一章的内容：你要讲述一个对你有利的故事，但这个故事必须基于数据。这个故事不能是童话故事。我曾目睹许多被收购的目标企业设定不切实际的销售目标。他们最终不仅未能如愿，还损害了自己的信誉。

I see similar dynamics in almost every single class I teach. In just one recent example, when a student named Jane was selling a tonic, she set her price at $4 an ounce when the data could really only support a sale of $2.

我几乎在教的每一门课上都能看到类似的现象。举个最近的例子，一个名叫简的学生在卖一种滋补品，她把价格定在每盎司4美元，但根据数据，这种滋补品实际上只能卖到每盎司2美元。

When I asked her why she did this, she said, “The buyer represented a pharmaceutical company.”

当我问她为什么这样做时，她说：“买家是一家制药公司。”

That didn’t clear it up for me, so I asked her to explain.

这并没有让我明白，所以我请她解释一下。

“I work in pharma,” she said. “They have tons of money.”

“我在制药行业工作，”她说。“他们有很多钱。”

I hear similar and very dangerous assumptions like this one all the time, from every gender and age of student. It will come as no surprise that Jane’s strategy didn’t work. In fact, when her price was so far above what the buyer could (or expected to) pay, she almost got left out of the deal completely. Although she ultimately sold her tonic for $1.50 an ounce, she had hurt her credibility by anchoring so high.

我经常听到类似且非常危险的假设，而且这种假设来自各个年龄段、不同性别的学生。简的策略失败并不令人意外。事实上，当她的定价远远高于买家能够（或预期）支付的价格时，她几乎完全失去了这笔交易。尽管她最终以每盎司1.5美元的价格卖掉了她的滋补品，但她过高的定价策略损害了自己的信誉。

The problem was that Jane hadn’t thought through the how of the ask. She knew what she wanted but couldn’t verbalize why in a way that made sense. If the buyer asked, “How did you arrive at $4?” Jane would have nothing to say other than, “Because I think you can afford it,” which would not have gone over well. You don’t offend people by making rational, justifiable asks, but you do offend them when the ask doesn’t make sense.

问题在于简没有仔细考虑如何提出要求。她知道自己想要什么，但却无法用一种合情合理的方式表达出来。如果买家问：“你是怎么得出4美元这个价格的？”简除了说“因为我觉得你买得起”之外，什么也说不出来，而这句话显然行不通。提出合理、正当的要求不会冒犯别人，但如果要求不合逻辑，就会冒犯别人。

Again, I have a similar conversation in almost every class. The specifics of the exercise may be different, the experience of the student may be different, but what’s always consistent is that when I push them to explain why they came up with the price they asked for, their answer is a variation of “Because I thought I could get it.” They’ve compromised the how .

几乎每节课我都会遇到类似的对话。练习的具体内容可能不同，学生的经历也可能不同，但始终不变的是，当我追问他们为什么会提出这样的价格时，他们的回答总是类似“因为我觉得我能拿到”。他们在“如何”达成交易的问题上做出了妥协。

Moving beyond our traps

走出我们的陷阱

The chapters in this book have thus far only covered half of the issue: what gets in our way. There’s still much work to be done though. What do you know about your negotiation partner? How will you learn more? How can you see your differences as a problem to be solved rather than a battle to win? How can you claim and maintain leverage? You can ask these questions, and others that make up Part II, once you have a handle on who you are and where you’re coming from—and then and only then can you look across the table.

本书各章节目前只探讨了问题的一半：阻碍我们前进的因素。但还有很多工作要做。你对谈判伙伴了解多少？你如何才能了解更多信息？你如何才能将分歧视为需要解决的问题，而不是一场必须取胜的战斗？你如何才能获得并保持谈判优势？只有当你真正了解自己是谁、你的立场是什么之后，你才能提出这些问题，以及构成第二部分的其他问题——也只有那时，你才能真正审视谈判桌对面的对手。

In the way that I view negotiation, coming to an agreement with your counterpart is an important step, but it’s not the end of the exchange. Because once you’ve done the work together to come to a mutual solution, you have—first of all—a doorway to other mutual solutions in the future. You have a relationship, shared equity, and a shared vision. Every conversation thereafter is easier, because there is trust. From this vantage, you can then say, “Let’s take a step back. Can we do even better than this deal?” And from there, you get beyond just yes.

在我看来，谈判中，与对方达成协议固然重要，但这并非交易的终点。因为一旦双方共同努力找到一个互惠互利的解决方案，首先，你们就拥有了未来寻求其他互惠解决方案的大门。你们建立了关系，共享了权益，并拥有了共同的愿景。此后的每一次对话都会更加顺畅，因为彼此之间建立了信任。基于此，你们可以提出这样的问题：“让我们退一步，看看能否达成比这更好的协议？” 而由此，你们的合作就超越了简单的“是”。

#↩

part II

第二部分

what gets us beyond yes

是什么让我们超越了“是”

I HAVE DISCOVERED IN LIFE THAT THERE ARE WAYS OF GETTING ALMOST ANYWHERE YOU WANT TO GO, IF YOU REALLY WANT TO GO.

—LANGSTON HUGHES

我发现，只要你真心想去，几乎任何地方都有办法到达。——兰斯顿·休斯
#↩

CHAPTER 5

第五章

the power of an open mind

开放心态的力量

We all pay lip service to the notion that understanding both sides of an issue is important, as is keeping an open mind. Many of us grew up with the moralizing of Atticus Finch in our heads: “You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view.” And yet we don’t do it—not really. In a recent study, 202 Americans were asked their views on same-sex marriage, then given a choice: Read several statements supporting that position, answer some questions about it, and make $7. Or they could read several statements supporting the opposing view, answer some questions about it, and make $10. No one was asking them to change their view in any way, the time requirement was the same, and yet 64 percent of people who supported same-sex marriage chose to take less money so as not to have to read the opposing view, and 61 percent of same-sex marriage opponents felt the same way. It seems we just don’t want to hear the other side of the story.

我们都口头上认同理解问题的正反两面很重要，保持开放的心态也很重要。许多人从小就听着阿提克斯·芬奇的这句格言长大：“你只有站在别人的角度思考问题，才能真正了解他。”然而，我们却很少真正做到这一点。最近一项研究询问了202名美国人对同性婚姻的看法，并让他们选择：阅读几篇支持同性婚姻的陈述，回答一些相关问题，然后获得7美元；或者阅读几篇支持反对同性婚姻的陈述，回答一些相关问题，然后获得10美元。没有人要求他们改变观点，所需时间也相同，但64%的同性婚姻支持者为了避免阅读反对意见，选择了少拿钱，而61%的反对者也持相同观点。看来我们只是不想听听不同的声音。

Having an open mind means, first and foremost, being curious. You have to ask questions—not just of your counterpart but of yourself. It requires being authentic, of really and truly wanting to know more. It requires asking the “why” questions and being disciplined and patient enough to learn the answers. It doesn’t matter if that question is “Why is my dad so controlling?” or “Why does she want to buy this particular car?” It requires being sensitive to your biases, acknowledging that of course you have them. It requires skills in the art of conversation and a willingness to employ them, even if you’re an introvert who really dreads these kinds of interactions. So although knowing that you should bring an open mind into a negotiation is one thing, actually doing so is far more difficult.

保持开放的心态，首先意味着要有好奇心。你必须提出问题——不仅要问对方，也要问自己。这需要真诚，需要你真心实意地想要了解更多。这需要你不断追问“为什么”，并且要有足够的自律和耐心去寻找答案。问题可以是“为什么我爸爸这么控制欲强？”或者“为什么她想买这辆车？”。这需要你对自身的偏见保持敏感，承认自己当然会有偏见。这需要你掌握沟通的技巧，并且愿意运用这些技巧，即使你是一个非常害怕这类交流的内向者。所以，虽然知道在谈判中应该保持开放的心态是一回事，但真正做到这一点却要困难得多。

An introspective mind is an open mind

内省的心灵也是一种开放的心灵

Before you can engage with your counterpart in a negotiation, you first have to be introspective, and that involves asking more questions. What do you really want? What is your interest ? Don’t just assume that you know.

在与对方展开谈判之前，你首先需要进行自我反思，这意味着要多问问题。你真正想要的是什么？你的利益所在是什么？不要想当然地认为自己知道答案。

Critical to every negotiation is the issue of interest and positions, and the difference between them. It’s a pretty nuanced topic, but here’s how I think of it: When you use Google Maps (or any other navigation app), you first input your desired destination and then the point from which you’re starting out. Google Maps in turn gives you a variety of routes based on whether you’re driving, taking public transportation, or walking. All these routes or modes of transport get you to your destination. In negotiation, your interest is your destination (desired outcome) and all the different routes you could possibly take to get to your destination are your positions.

在所有谈判中，利益和立场的问题及其区别都至关重要。这是一个相当微妙的话题，但我是这样理解的：当你使用谷歌地图（或其他任何导航应用）时，你首先输入目的地，然后输入出发地。谷歌地图会根据你是驾车、乘坐公共交通还是步行，为你提供不同的路线。所有这些路线或交通方式最终都能到达目的地。在谈判中，你的利益就是你的目的地（期望的结果），而所有可能到达目的地的不同路线就是你的立场。

Put another way, your interest is the reason you’re engaged in a negotiation in the first place and what motivates you to come to the table. Your interest is your underlying need, want, fear, or desire, and it doesn’t have to be mutually exclusive from that of your counterpart. Your positions are all the possible options you have to achieve your interest. Positions are often confused with interest because they’re easier to grasp and communicate. For instance, let’s say that you’re negotiating a new contract with a long-standing, highly valued client. The cost of doing business has increased over the years, and so you would love to somehow get a larger contract. Going into the meeting with your client, you may think that your interest in the negotiation is to get more money for that new contract. But rarely is money what brought you to the bargaining table. You want to secure a larger contract, certainly, but what you really want and need is to maintain the relationship with the client. This is a major account and one you can’t afford to lose. It’s steady work, they pay on time, and they offer a sense of security in your income projections. Therefore, more funding is not what matters most—it’s the relationship and, once you spend the time preparing, you’re well aware of that.

换句话说，你的利益才是你参与谈判的根本原因，也是你走到谈判桌前的动力。你的利益是你潜在的需求、愿望、恐惧或渴望，它并不一定与对方的利益相冲突。你的立场则是你为实现自身利益所拥有的所有可能选择。立场常常与利益混淆，因为立场更容易理解和表达。例如，假设你正在与一位长期合作且非常重要的客户谈判一份新合同。多年来，业务成本不断上涨，因此你很想争取到一份更大的合同。在与客户会面之前，你可能认为谈判的目的是为了获得更高的合同金额。但实际上，促使你走到谈判桌前的并非金钱。你当然希望获得一份更大的合同，但你真正想要和需要的是维护与客户的关系。这是一个重要的客户，你输不起。这是一份稳定的工作，他们按时支付工资，而且收入预期也让人感到安心。因此，资金投入并非最重要的——重要的是合作关系。一旦你花时间做好准备，你就会明白这一点。

If you drill deep to understand your interest prior to the conversation, thinking carefully about what’s bringing you to the negotiation in the first place, you know that although you would like to get paid more for your work, there are many ways to get you to what you really want—that long-standing, stable relationship with a great client. In your preparation, you’d think about various scenarios that would meet your interest. Perhaps you could suggest that the client sign a multiyear contract, which would give you more stability, or better payment terms, which would give you a healthier cash flow. These options fulfill your interest, meet your immediate funding needs, and provide you with a variety of possibilities to present to the client that could work for them as well.

如果你在谈判前深入思考自己的利益所在，仔细想想是什么促使你参与谈判，你就会明白，虽然你希望获得更高的报酬，但有很多方法可以让你实现真正的目标——与一位优秀的客户建立长期稳定的合作关系。在准备阶段，你可以设想各种符合自身利益的方案。例如，你可以建议客户签订多年合同，这将为你带来更稳定的收入；或者提出更优惠的付款条件，这将为你带来更健康的现金流。这些方案既能满足你的利益，又能满足你眼前的资金需求，同时还能为你提供多种方案，供客户参考，这些方案也可能对他们有利。

Alternatively, let’s say that you only scratched the surface in your thinking and approached the meeting focused on obtaining a larger contract, with a specific amount in mind. When you sit down together, you ask for more money for the work. The client says no. Where do you go from there? You have not considered any alternatives to offer them when they don’t concur with a larger contract. They tell you that they haven’t budgeted for it. Their no sticks because you can’t move on to another potential solution that could be mutually acceptable. Your thinking is limited, and the negotiation comes to a dead stop.

或者，假设你只是浅尝辄止，带着明确的金额目标去参加会议，一心想着争取一份更大的合同。坐下来后，你提出增加工作费用，客户却拒绝了。接下来该怎么办？你没有考虑过在客户不同意增加合同金额的情况下，可以提出哪些替代方案。他们告诉你，他们没有为此做预算。他们的拒绝让你无法接受，因为你找不到其他双方都能接受的解决方案。你的思维局限，谈判陷入僵局。

Song-I went through this process in her job negotiation that I wrote about in Chapter 3. Initially she thought she would just ask for a higher salary, but she stopped herself to question her true desires and see the 360 view. There were three factors in play—salary, sign-on bonus, and benefits. Which mattered most to her, and why? Only after reflecting more deeply on her needs and wants was she able to recognize her true interest: She wanted to make up what she lost by leaving her previous company before her contract was up. That gave her a lot of room to negotiate—she could get to this interest in numerous ways, and work with her new would-be employer to do it.

宋伊在第三章中描述的求职谈判过程中就经历了类似的过程。起初，她只想要求更高的薪水，但她很快停下来，开始审视自己的真实需求，并从更全面的角度思考问题。她考虑的因素有三个：薪水、签约奖金和福利。对她来说，哪个最重要？为什么？只有在深入思考了自己的需求和愿望之后，她才意识到自己真正的诉求：她想弥补在合同到期前离开前一家公司所造成的损失。这给了她很大的谈判空间——她可以通过多种方式来实现这个目标，并与未来的新雇主合作。

Let’s consider a more personal example, one that most couples with children encounter at some point. Two parents are negotiating who will pick their daughter up from camp at rush hour. The mom thinks, Dammit, it’s his turn, he has to do it. I don’t have enough time, I’m doing everything around here, I’ve got a million things to do that don’t involve sitting in traffic. Let’s imagine the dad’s thought process is similar. If they go into their negotiation without questioning and understanding their own underlying interest fully, chances are excellent they’ll battle.

让我们来看一个更贴近生活的例子，大多数有孩子的夫妇都会遇到这种情况。一对父母正在商量谁在高峰期去接女儿放学。妈妈心想：糟了，该他了，他得去。我时间不够，家里所有的事情我都要做，我有一大堆事情要做，哪有时间堵在路上。假设爸爸的想法也差不多。如果他们在协商时没有认真思考和充分理解自己的实际利益，那么他们很可能会争执不下。

The mom’s position is that she wants to be free of driving duty that day. But her interest is more nuanced. What she really wants is to feel less tired and overwhelmed. She wants to feel more supported by her husband. The dad has a big deadline at the end of the day that’s going to be difficult to complete if he has to leave early. His position is that he wants to be free of driving duty that day, but his interest is that he wants enough time to get his work done. If the mom and dad aren’t thinking through their interests, they can’t see the many positions actually available to them. The mom could agree to pick up their daughter since her husband has a deadline but, in order to honor her feelings of being overwhelmed, ask that he take something else off her plate, or perhaps that he offer to do pickup every other day that week. The dad might think of a friend he could call who also has a child at that camp, and they could sort out a car-pool. But the parents can’t get to that place without uncovering their true interest.

妈妈的立场是她那天不想开车。但她的真正需求远不止于此。她真正想要的是减轻疲惫和压力，希望得到丈夫更多的支持。爸爸当天有个重要的截止日期，如果他不得不提前离开，就很难完成。他的立场是他也不想开车，但他真正想要的是有足够的时间完成工作。如果父母没有认真思考自己的需求，就无法发现其实有很多选择。妈妈可以同意去接女儿，因为她丈夫有截止日期，但为了体谅她感到压力过大的心情，可以请他帮忙分担一些其他的事情，或者提出这周隔天接送孩子。爸爸或许可以想到一位朋友，他的孩子也在那个夏令营，可以打电话联系他，安排拼车。但如果父母不弄清楚自己的真正需求，就无法找到合适的方案。

When you’re clear about what’s truly driving you, you can turn your curiosity toward the person you’re negotiating with. What are their interests? You may not know—and you’ll want to carefully make some assumptions. You’ll pressure-test these assumptions in conversation, but first you need to make some educated guesses.

当你明确了自己的真正动机之后，就可以将好奇心转向谈判对象。他们的利益是什么？你可能并不了解——所以你需要谨慎地做出一些假设。你可以在对话中检验这些假设，但首先你需要做出一些有根据的猜测。

Gather information. Be a detective. You want to discover everything you possibly can about your counterpart. Revenue at my student Mary Ellen Slayter’s marketing company is up 40 percent in the last couple of years, and she credits the rise in part to the fact that she now takes much more time gathering information about her counterpart’s possible interests. She explained that although there are many details about a meeting she can’t control, “I can control what I know about the people I’m meeting with and what they need,” she said. “That doesn’t require me to be smart or have some exotic skill, that literally just requires me to go read the LinkedIn profiles of people before I talk to them, try to ask if there’s a deck they want me to review before we meet, to Google to see whatever initiatives they’ve had. That’s not some secret skill. That just takes time.”

收集信息，像侦探一样。你要尽可能多地了解你的对方。我的学生玛丽·艾伦·斯莱特（Mary Ellen Slayter）的营销公司在过去几年里收入增长了40%，她认为部分原因在于她现在会花更多时间收集对方的潜在兴趣信息。她解释说，虽然会议中有很多细节她无法控制，但“我可以控制我对会见对象以及他们需求的了解，”她说。“这并不需要我多么聪明或拥有什么特殊技能，这实际上只需要我在与对方交谈之前查看他们的LinkedIn个人资料，询问他们是否希望我在会见前审阅他们的演示文稿，以及在谷歌上搜索他们参与过的项目。这并非什么秘密技能，只是需要时间而已。”

But here’s where curiosity about your counterpart gets particularly tricky, because as you prepare, and as you negotiate, you have to watch out for bias. Bias can take many forms and can lead you to faulty thinking that hurts your negotiation. And lest you think you’re free of bias, let me assure you that you’re not.

但正是在这里，对对方的好奇心会变得格外棘手，因为在准备和谈判过程中，你必须警惕偏见。偏见可以以多种形式出现，并可能导致错误的思维方式，从而损害你的谈判。别以为你完全没有偏见，我可以肯定地告诉你，你并非如此。

Confronting your biases

直面你的偏见

We often think that people with whom we interact, manage, befriend, hire, and do business with think similarly to us. As we prepare to negotiate, we consider information that we feel is important, and presume that it will be important to our counterpart. To negotiate effectively, though, you need to question any biases you may have. This means that you can’t take the starting point for granted.

我们常常认为，与我们互动、管理、交友、雇佣和做生意的人，他们的想法与我们相似。在准备谈判时，我们会考虑我们认为重要的信息，并假定这些信息对对方也很重要。然而，要想进行有效的谈判，你需要质疑自己可能存在的任何偏见。这意味着你不能想当然地认为对方的想法与我们一致。

Consider the use of the word fair . I constantly have students tell me that they just wanted to be fair, or that so-and-so wasn’t playing fair. But fair means something different to everyone. It can be very hard to get on the same page as others because we make assumptions based on our own values, experiences, and—importantly—our culture. Americans may think it’s only fair to get complimentary tap water when dining out, but in many European countries that’s an unreasonable presumption. In some families it’s expected that whoever is hosting a dinner will do all of the dishes afterward, whereas in others such a scenario would seem wrong. Our values are very personal to each of us and are derived from a variety of factors (age, race, gender, education, socioeconomic status). This is why the word fair can be fraught. Fair to who? Fair by what standards? If your values are different, then the way you evaluate fairness must be different. If you want to appeal to someone’s sense of fairness, it’s important to put yourself in their shoes to really understand what they would consider fair—it’s all about perspective.

想想“公平”这个词的用法。我经常听到学生说他们只是想公平行事，或者某某人没有公平竞争。但公平对每个人来说意义都不同。我们很难与他人达成共识，因为我们会根据自身的价值观、经验，以及——非常重要的——文化背景做出假设。美国人可能认为外出就餐时免费提供自来水是理所当然的，但在许多欧洲国家，这是一种不合理的假设。在一些家庭里，宴请主人的人应该负责餐后的所有洗碗工作，而在另一些家庭里，这种做法则显得不妥。我们的价值观因人而异，并受到多种因素的影响（年龄、种族、性别、教育程度、社会经济地位）。这就是为什么“公平”这个词会充满争议。对谁公平？以什么标准来衡量公平？如果你的价值观不同，那么你评判公平的方式也必然不同。如果你想唤起某人的公平感，重要的是要设身处地地为他们着想，真正理解他们认为什么是公平的——这完全取决于视角。

In an exercise my classes do, each group has access to a lifesaving dialysis machine but must choose who from a select list of candidates will receive it. Should it go to the mother charged with taking care of a large family? To the doctor whose work saves lives? To the employer whose role providing jobs in the community is critical? Or to a child who has so much life left to live? This is almost always a heated negotiation, and was especially so for one of my recent classes. The discussion and outrage over what was fair and what wasn’t was so intense that it took up the better part of two classes. The problem was, there were forty-eight students and thus forty-eight different perspectives on what the word fair meant. The groups that were the most successful had decided on a metric—criteria for making the choice. How were they evaluating who they chose? The value the person would have on society? How they would provide for the people they took care of? Age? When they could establish these norms, they could then apply them to every one of the people being considered for the machine. It was still hard to come up with a metric everyone could agree on, but it was the only way to get even close to a solution.

在我教课时，每个小组都有一台救命的透析机，但必须从一份候选名单中选择谁来使用。这台机器应该给那位肩负重任、照顾大家庭的母亲吗？给那位救死扶伤的医生？给那位在社区提供就业机会至关重要的雇主？还是给那位还有很长生命要走的孩子？这几乎总是一场激烈的争论，我最近的一节课尤其如此。关于公平与否的讨论和愤怒如此之深，以至于占据了近两节课的时间。问题在于，有48名学生，因此对“公平”一词的理解也各不相同。最成功的几个小组都制定了一套衡量标准——选择依据。他们是如何评估最终选择的？这个人对社会的价值？他/她能如何照顾他/她所照顾的人？年龄？当他们能够建立起这些标准时，就可以将其应用于所有候选透析机使用者。尽管很难找到每个人都能接受的衡量标准，但这却是接近解决方案的唯一途径。

I’ve no intention of boycotting the word fair but encourage using it wisely by asking a question: “What does fair mean to you?” Words matter in a negotiation. You have to be discerning and methodical. The word fair is neither.

我无意抵制“公平”这个词，而是鼓励大家明智地使用它，可以问问自己：“对你来说，公平意味着什么？”谈判中，措辞至关重要。你必须明辨是非，并且做事有条不紊。“公平”这个词恰恰缺乏这两点。

“It’s not fair that she got X and I didn’t,” said every little brother or sister ever . But what does that mean, really? My sister often bemoaned the fact that since I was the youngest, I was spoiled, that it wasn’t “fair” when my parents did (fill in the blank). In my view, she’d had it much easier, because she only had my mom and dad to parent her, whereas I had my parents, my sister, and my older brother. I effectively had four parents, and that felt unfair. But how was she supposed to understand my reasoning? Her experience was hers and mine was mine. If all we did was argue about what was fair, we’d get nowhere.

“她得到了X，我却没有，这不公平！”每个弟弟妹妹都这么说过。但这话到底是什么意思呢？我姐姐经常抱怨，因为我是最小的，所以被宠坏了，父母得到（此处可自行填空）的时候，她觉得“不公平”。在我看来，她过得轻松多了，因为她只有爸爸妈妈管教，而我除了爸爸妈妈，还有姐姐和哥哥。我实际上有四个“父母”，这让我觉得很不公平。但她又怎么能理解我的想法呢？她的经历是她的，我的经历是我的。如果我们总是争论什么才算公平，那我们永远也解决不了任何问题。

We all have false preconceptions like these. A false bias can be based on racial stereotypes, a theme played with in both the films BlacKkKlansman and Sorry to Bother You , wherein an African American character adopts a “white” telephone voice. The words are just words, but the perception of the person on the other end of the line is vastly different. A false bias is assuming a pilot is a “he,” or that a nurse is a “she.” We base our ideas on artificial information, and then we’re surprised when we find our assumptions to be wrong. I teach this stuff, and still I’m guilty of it! Once just recently I was checking out an investment property and had arranged to meet the owner there. This guy showed up, looking unshowered and disheveled, wearing raggedy clothes and with his hair looking like Albert Einstein’s. I was thinking I should offer him some money, but then he reached out his hand to shake mine. “Hi, I’m Jack,” he said, and explained that he was the building owner. I thought, Wait, what? You own this building? I recovered my powers of speech but vowed to check myself more closely for bias.

我们都有类似的错误观念。错误的偏见可能源于种族刻板印象，电影《黑色党徒》和《抱歉打扰》都运用了这一主题，片中非裔美国角色模仿“白人”的电话腔。话语本身只是语言，但电话另一端的人的感知却截然不同。错误的偏见还包括假定飞行员是“他”，或者护士是“她”。我们基于人为信息形成观念，然后发现自己的假设是错误的，并对此感到惊讶。我教的就是这些，但我自己也犯过同样的错误！就在不久前，我去看了一处投资房产，并约好和房主见面。结果来了一个人，看起来没洗澡，衣衫褴褛，头发乱得像爱因斯坦。我当时想，要不要给他点钱，但他却伸出手和我握手。“你好，我是杰克，”他说，并解释说他是这栋楼的房主。我心想，等等，什么？这栋楼是你的？我恢复了说话的能力，但暗自发誓要更加注意自己的言行，避免带有偏见。

Jennifer Eberhardt has spent years studying bias, won a MacArthur Genius Grant for her work, and published a brilliant book on the subject. She spent the first few years of her life living in an African American neighborhood, and she noticed when her family moved to a white neighborhood that the school was nicer, that the resources were better. She also noticed that all of her new white friends looked the same. So much so, in fact, that she had a hard time telling them apart. So began a lifelong fascination with the way that biases affect us and what we can do about it. As she learned, her childhood reaction was normal. “That cringeworthy expression ‘They all look alike’ has long been considered the province of the bigot,” she wrote. “But it is actually a function of biology and exposure. Our brains are better at processing faces that evoke a sense of familiarity.”

詹妮弗·埃伯哈特多年来致力于研究偏见，并因此荣获麦克阿瑟天才奖，还出版了一本关于此主题的杰作。她童年最初几年生活在非裔美国人社区，后来全家搬到白人社区后，她注意到学校更好，资源也更丰富。她还发现，所有新认识的白人朋友看起来都一样。事实上，他们长得如此相像，以至于她很难分辨彼此。由此，她开始对偏见如何影响我们以及我们能做些什么产生了终生浓厚的兴趣。后来她发现，自己童年时的反应其实很正常。“‘他们都长得一样’这种令人尴尬的说法长期以来都被认为是偏执者的专属，”她写道，“但实际上，这是一种生物本能和环境影响的结果。我们的大脑更擅长处理那些能唤起熟悉感的面孔。”

Eberhardt has studied the ways that bias is triggered by stress, an issue she looked at closely with police departments with whom she’s worked. Even if officers are aware of their biases, she said, biases can still be triggered in situations where the officer is stressed, is threatened, or has to make decisions fast. “We cannot possibly take in all of the stimuli with which we are constantly bombarded. Based on our goals and our expectations, we make choices—often unconsciously—about what we attend to and what we do not.” One way to gird against bias, then, is to slow everything down to the extent you can. She told NPR of her work with the Oakland, California, police department. “They decided to change their foot pursuit policies. And so instead of chasing someone, you know, they were told to step back and set up a perimeter and call for backup.”

埃伯哈特研究了压力如何引发偏见，她曾与多个警察部门密切合作，深入探讨了这个问题。她说，即使警员意识到自身的偏见，在压力过大、受到威胁或需要快速决策的情况下，偏见仍然可能被触发。“我们不可能接收所有不断涌入的信息。基于我们的目标和预期，我们会做出选择——通常是无意识的——决定关注什么，忽略什么。” 因此，对抗偏见的一个方法就是尽可能放慢节奏。她向美国国家公共电台（NPR）讲述了她与加州奥克兰警察局的合作。“他们决定改变徒步追捕的政策。他们不再追捕嫌疑人，而是被告知后退，设置警戒线，并呼叫支援。”

So what does this look like in the far less consequential area of a business negotiation? Researchers distinguish between two types of thinking: System 1 thinking, which is quick and grounded in intuition; and System 2 thinking, which is slower and more conscious. (Daniel Kahnemann’s Thinking, Fast and Slow is great for reading more on the subject.) The key with stripping bias out of your negotiation—particularly those that are more consequential than whether your child gets a second cookie—is to make sure you’re working from System 2. Be mindful, and slow it way down. Think about time-share pitches—there’s a reason the salespeople insist they get an answer that very day in order to make the deal; they know that it puts the buyer in their System 1 mind. Finally, Eberhardt cautions to be aware that bias is a state, not a trait. Be on the lookout for the state you’re in.

那么，在无关紧要的商业谈判领域，这又意味着什么呢？研究人员区分了两种思维模式：系统1思维，快速且基于直觉；以及系统2思维，速度较慢且更具意识性。（丹尼尔·卡尼曼的《思考，快与慢》是深入了解这一主题的绝佳读物。）消除谈判中的偏见——尤其是在那些比孩子能否得到第二块饼干更重要的谈判中——关键在于确保你运用的是系统2思维。保持觉察，并大幅放慢速度。想想分时度假的推销——销售人员坚持当天就给出答复以促成交易是有原因的；他们知道这样做会让买家进入系统1思维模式。最后，埃伯哈特提醒我们，偏见是一种状态，而非一种特质。时刻留意自己所处的状态。

If you’re trying to imagine your counterpart’s interest before a difficult conversation or negotiation, you might seek advice and counsel from others so that you can anticipate reactions that you may not have considered. But if you just ask those who agree with you, you’re vulnerable to confirmation bias . You’re at risk for becoming more cemented in your ideas and are thrown when, during the negotiation, a perspective is raised that you hadn’t thought of before. You have to intentionally seek opinions from people who will challenge your thinking. Get other points of view and fight any inclination not to be open to them. Kai Ryssdal, the host of Marketplace on NPR, asked a group of adoring progressives how many of them listened to conservative Rush Limbaugh’s show or watched Fox News occasionally. No one raised a hand, and he chastised the crowd, saying that it was their responsibility to listen to and understand the other side, not just to talk to others who felt just as they did. This is obviously uncomfortable to do but imperative for any negotiation.

如果你在进行艰难的对话或谈判之前，试图设身处地地为对方着想，你可能会向他人寻求建议和意见，以便预判你可能没有考虑到的反应。但如果你只问那些与你观点一致的人，你就很容易陷入确认偏误。你可能会更加固执己见，一旦在谈判过程中有人提出你之前从未想过的观点，你就会感到措手不及。你必须有意识地去征求那些会挑战你固有思维的人的意见。要了解不同的观点，并克服任何不愿接受新观点的倾向。美国国家公共广播电台（NPR）《市场》（Marketplace）节目的主持人凯·里斯戴尔（Kai Ryssdal）曾问一群崇拜进步派的听众，有多少人会收听保守派主持人拉什·林博（Rush Limbaugh）的节目或偶尔观看福克斯新闻。没有人举手，于是他斥责了在场的听众，说倾听和理解对方的观点是他们的责任，而不仅仅是与那些和自己想法相同的人交谈。这样做显然会让人感到不舒服，但对任何谈判都至关重要。

Some of my consulting projects involve talking to organizations about how to create more diverse and inclusive organizations to retain top talent, promote greater engagement, drive innovation, and improve overall business outcomes. The connection between this work and negotiation may not be obvious, but I talk about the same characteristics and encourage people to use the same skills. Foremost among them is countering confirmation bias. You cannot have an effective organization if you have only one type of person making decisions.

我的一些咨询项目涉及与企业探讨如何创建更加多元化和包容性的组织，以留住顶尖人才、提升员工敬业度、推动创新并改善整体业务成果。这项工作与谈判之间的联系或许并不明显，但我所探讨的特质相同，并且鼓励人们运用相同的技巧。其中最重要的是克服确认偏误。如果只有一种类型的人来做决策，那么组织就无法高效运作。

The need to diversify does not come from an altruistic or politically correct place—though those are nice benefits. It comes from a place of smart strategy, from understanding that diversity of thought is required for a company to remain competitive. The research shows that teams outperform individual decision makers 66 percent of the time. And if you make that team more diverse, if it includes different ages, genders, and geographic locations, that percentage rises to 87 percent. A 2015 report by the management consultancy firm McKinsey & Company found that the companies who had the most ethnic and racial diversity in management were 35 percent more likely to have higher financial returns. A Harvard Business Review piece said, “In recent years a body of research has revealed another, more nuanced benefit of workplace diversity: nonhomogenous teams are simply smarter.”

多元化的必要性并非源于利他主义或政治正确——尽管这些也是不错的益处。它源于明智的战略考量，源于对思维多样性的理解，即企业保持竞争力的必要条件。研究表明，团队在66%的情况下表现优于个人决策者。如果团队更加多元化，涵盖不同年龄、性别和地域的人员，这一比例将上升至87%。管理咨询公司麦肯锡2015年的一份报告发现，管理层种族和民族多样性最高的公司，其财务回报高出35%。《哈佛商业评论》的一篇文章指出：“近年来，大量研究揭示了职场多元化的另一个更为微妙的益处：多元化的团队往往更聪明。”

Diversity and inclusion are highly valued by organizations such as Deloitte and the NFL. The wisdom of having different voices at the table makes great sense when you look at what happened with a now-infamous Pepsi commercial. In the commercial, model and reality star Kendall Jenner spontaneously joins a protest march, grabbing a Pepsi from a well-stocked cooler as she engages in what seems more like merriment than activism. Then she hands a Pepsi to a police officer at the front of the barrier. The public outcry about the ad was immediate, as it was, simply, tone-deaf. It didn’t reflect or honor the real nature and sacrifice of protest in America. Pepsi took down the ad and wrote in a public apology that “Pepsi was trying to project a global message of unity, peace, and understanding. Clearly we missed the mark, and we apologize.” Gucci and H&M both recently made racially insensitive blunders: the former when it marketed a wool sweater that pulls up over the bottom of the wearer’s face and looks a whole lot like blackface, and the latter when it featured a photo of an African American kid wearing a sweatshirt that read Coolest monkey in the jungle . Diversity and inclusion problems are everywhere—universities, entertainment, banking, the arts. Lack of representation at the decision-making levels plagues these industries, thus allowing biases to be carried through to the end. In the case of the fashion industry, the items weren’t vetted, and the right people weren’t in the room to point out how offensive the clothing designs were.

德勤和美国国家橄榄球联盟（NFL）等机构高度重视多元化和包容性。百事可乐一则如今臭名昭著的广告就充分说明了让不同声音参与决策的重要性。广告中，模特兼真人秀明星肯达尔·詹娜（Kendall Jenner）突然加入抗议游行，从一个摆满饮料的冰柜里拿出一瓶百事可乐，她的举动与其说是参与社会活动，不如说是享受乐趣。随后，她将一瓶百事可乐递给了路障前的一名警察。这则广告立即引发公众强烈抗议，因为它实在太不合时宜了。它既没有反映也没有尊重美国抗议活动的真实性质和参与者所做出的牺牲。百事可乐随后撤下了这则广告，并在公开道歉声明中写道：“百事可乐原本想传递一个关于团结、和平与理解的全球信息。显然，我们未能达到预期效果，对此我们深表歉意。” Gucci和H&M最近都犯下了种族歧视的错误：前者推出了一款羊毛衫，其拉袢会遮住穿着者的下半张脸，看起来很像“黑脸”表演；后者则刊登了一张非裔美国儿童穿着印有“丛林中最酷的猴子”字样卫衣的照片。多元化和包容性问题无处不在——大学、娱乐业、银行业、艺术界。决策层缺乏代表性是这些行业的通病，导致偏见得以延续到最终环节。就时尚行业而言，这些产品未经审核，也没有合适的人在场指出这些服装设计的冒犯性。

How does this happen? Remember again the study I cited at the beginning of this chapter, of people who would rather earn less money than read about another point of view. Participants didn’t want to hear the opposing position and felt that doing so “‘would create cognitive dissonance’—the psychological discomfort that arises from simultaneously holding two opposing beliefs.” But the fact is that we cannot be strong negotiators unless we stretch ourselves.

这是怎么回事呢？再想想我在本章开头引用的那项研究，研究对象是那些宁愿少挣点钱也不愿了解其他观点的人。参与者不想听到相反的立场，他们认为这样做“会造成认知失调——即同时持有两种对立信念所产生的心理不适”。但事实是，如果我们不挑战自我，就无法成为优秀的谈判者。

The more you learn, the more you know

学得越多，懂得就越多。

After all of the preparation before a negotiation comes the encounter itself, the phase where you will exchange information with your counterpart. You’re not jumping right into bargaining, even if the encounter is over the phone. Instead, exchanging information requires that you take your time to get to know each other. It could be that something you learn about the person affects how you will approach the negotiation—you have to be prepared to waver from whatever script you’ve come with. It’s the same principle as a science experiment: Make a hypothesis, test it, and adjust. If you find that your assumptions are wrong, you don’t need to abandon your goals. But you may need to find a different way to get there or modify your goal to reflect the new information that was introduced in the conversation. Perhaps you learn that a toy you wanted to buy for your child is in higher demand than you anticipated before you went into a store. Your interest is still the same—you want that toy—but you have to look at your budget more creatively, or look at the used market, now that you know more about the toy’s limited supply. It’s akin to driving down the highway to find that your exit’s been closed. You still want to be committed to your desired outcome, but you remain flexible about other ways of arriving there. You may even be surprised to find a better way.

谈判前的准备工作完成后，就到了正式会面阶段，也就是与对方交换信息的阶段。即使是通过电话，你也不能一开始就急于讨价还价。相反，信息交换需要你花时间了解彼此。你了解到的关于对方的信息可能会影响你的谈判策略——你必须做好准备，随时调整你预先设定的谈判策略。这与科学实验的原理相同：提出假设，验证假设，并进行调整。如果你发现你的假设是错误的，你不需要放弃你的目标。但你可能需要找到不同的方法来实现目标，或者根据谈话中引入的新信息来修改你的目标。也许你得知，你原本想给孩子买的玩具比你进店前预想的更抢手。你仍然想要那个玩具——但既然你现在知道了玩具供应有限，你就必须更灵活地调整预算，或者考虑二手市场。这就像开车行驶在高速公路上，却发现出口被封闭了。你仍然想要达成目标，但同时也对其他实现目标的方式保持开放的态度。你甚至可能会惊喜地发现更好的方法。

Always stay in fact-finding mode instead of feeling beholden to a script. Choose curiosity over certainty. As Leo Tolstoy wrote in The Kingdom of God Is Within You , “The most difficult subjects can be explained to the most slow-witted man if he has not formed any idea of them already; but the simplest thing cannot be made clear to the most intelligent man if he is firmly persuaded that he knows already, without a shadow of a doubt, what is laid before him.”

始终保持探求事实的态度，而不是拘泥于既定的剧本。选择好奇心而非确定性。正如列夫·托尔斯泰在《上帝的国就在你们心中》中所写：“即使是最迟钝的人，只要对最难懂的事情没有形成任何概念，也能理解；但即使是最聪明的人，如果坚信自己对摆在面前的事情已经了如指掌，也无法弄明白。”

Information exchange involves asking questions, showing authentic interest in your counterpart, and creating a natural rapport that puts both sides at ease. I always think of the information exchange that happens before an opening offer as “pure”—you’re curious about your counterpart and want to know more about them and everything that may affect the deal in some way. Information exchange takes time—but take the time you need. The more you learn before initiating the actual bargaining process, the more likely you are to engage in a negotiation that is thoughtful, consensus-driven (because you have successfully established an understanding of your mutual interests), and void of derailing surprises. In other words, by the time of the opening offer, you’ve already done most of the work. But information exchange does not stop once someone has thrown out an opening offer—you never close the door to learning more. Once the opening offer is made, though, the learning isn’t as pure. You’re learning with the opening offer firmly ingrained in the back of your mind, offering a backdrop to the discussion.

信息交流包括提问、对对方表现出真诚的兴趣，以及建立一种让双方都感到自在的自然融洽关系。我总是把首次报价之前的信息交流看作是“纯粹的”——你对对方充满好奇，想要了解更多关于他们以及所有可能影响交易的因素。信息交流需要时间——但要确保你有足够的时间。在正式谈判开始前了解得越多，你就越有可能进行一场深思熟虑、以共识为导向（因为你已经成功地了解了彼此的共同利益）且避免意外情况的谈判。换句话说，在对方提出首次报价时，你已经完成了大部分工作。但是，信息交流并不会随着对方提出首次报价而停止——你永远不会关闭了解更多信息的大门。然而，一旦对方提出首次报价，这种了解就不再那么纯粹了。你会带着对方的报价进行学习，这就像是在给讨论设定了一个背景。

Even if you agree, in theory, that spending time exchanging information is worth the time, the work has just begun. This is the art of conversation, and it’s not easy. If you do it incorrectly, your counterpart may feel like they’re being interrogated or interviewed for a job. But the more you engage in conversations and ask open-ended questions, the better you become at making authentic connections—which is very different from thinking, Okay, I need to get through a few minutes of frivolous small talk and then we can get to business . The better you become at conversation, the more you see it’s not frivolous at all. Fresh Air host Terry Gross—who has made a brilliant career out of being a skilled conversationalist—told the New York Times that “Tell me about yourself” is possibly the most powerful way to open any conversation. It doesn’t make presumptions, the way “What do you do for work?” does, and it lets your companion begin the conversation where they want to. Plus, people on the whole like talking about themselves!

即使你理论上认同花时间交换信息是值得的，真正的工作才刚刚开始。这就是谈话的艺术，它并不容易。如果你做得不好，对方可能会感觉像是在接受审问或面试。但是，你越是积极参与对话，提出开放式问题，就越能建立真正的联系——这与“好吧，我得先聊几分钟无关紧要的闲话，然后我们才能谈正事”的想法截然不同。你的谈话技巧越精湛，就越会发现它一点也不无关紧要。《新鲜空气》节目主持人特里·格罗斯（Terry Gross）——他凭借出色的谈话技巧在业内取得了辉煌的成就——告诉《纽约时报》，“跟我说说你自己吧”可能是开启任何对话最有效的方式。它不像“你是做什么工作的？”那样带有预设，而是让对方从他们想谈的话题开始。而且，人们普遍都喜欢谈论自己！

You don’t want your counterpart to feel you’re asking questions in order to manipulate them; your curiosity must be genuine. If you ask a question, even one as basic as, “Where did you go on vacation last summer?” you have to care to listen to the answer. Don’t ask questions about a subject that’s not meaningful to you. Dale Carnegie wrote: “ The difference between appreciation and flattery? That is simple. One is sincere and the other insincere. One comes from the heart out; the other from the teeth out. One is unselfish; the other selfish. One is universally admired; the other universally condemned.”

你不想让对方觉得你提问是为了操纵他们；你的好奇心必须是真诚的。如果你问了一个问题，哪怕是像“你去年夏天去哪儿度假了？”这样简单的问题，你也必须认真倾听答案。不要问那些对你来说无关紧要的问题。戴尔·卡耐基写道：“欣赏和奉承的区别？很简单。一个是真诚的，一个是虚伪的。一个发自内心，一个是虚伪的。一个是无私的，一个是自私的。一个是人人称赞的，一个是人人谴责的。”

If this whole line of reasoning is making you squirm because you hate small talk, know that I get it. So do I. I’m an introvert who goes to receptions all the time and my first thought, when looking around the room of mostly strangers, is that I want to pull out my phone and check emails, sports scores, or the news. I don’t want to chat with someone just because.

如果你因为讨厌闲聊而对这种说法感到不自在，别担心，我完全理解。我也一样。我是一个内向的人，经常参加各种招待会，每次环顾四周，看到房间里几乎全是陌生人时，我的第一反应就是想拿出手机看看邮件、体育比分或者新闻。我不想无缘无故地跟人聊天。

I’m not suggesting, then, that you force yourself to become an extrovert. It would feel disingenuous if I suddenly strived to be the center of attention at a party of strangers. Instead, I channel the part of myself that is genuinely curious about other people. I’ve noticed that the most amazing thing happens when I decide I’m going to be curious for just a little while before I go back to my cave of sports scores and news. Let’s say I see a woman who it doesn’t look like I have a lot in common with, but she’s wearing shoes that are to die for. I admit that I’m a shoeaholic, so when I say something to her about them, it’s genuine. I can find an angle where I’m authentically interested, and, paired with an intent to be curious, it’s remarkable how the conversation flows and how much I learn.

所以，我并不是建议你强迫自己变成外向的人。如果我突然在一个陌生人聚会上努力成为众人瞩目的焦点，那会显得很虚伪。相反，我会引导自己内心真正对他人充满好奇的那一部分。我发现，当我决定在回到我的“体育比分和新闻洞穴”之前，先让自己保持一点好奇心时，最神奇的事情就会发生。比如说，我看到一个女人，看起来我们之间没什么共同点，但她穿着一双美得让人窒息的鞋子。我承认我是个鞋控，所以当我跟她聊起鞋子时，我是发自内心的。我可以找到一个真正感兴趣的切入点，再加上我本身就带着好奇心，你会发现谈话进行得非常顺利，而且我能学到很多东西。

A study out of the University of Rochester showed just how much curiosity like this matters in personal relationships. The study paired participants up and, before putting them into conversation with one another, measured their level of curiosity. The couples were assigned either a small-talk conversation or an intimate conversation. Those who had lower levels of curiosity going into the experiment experienced greater closeness in the intimacy-producing situation but not the small-talk situation. Those who had been judged to have high levels of curiosity, on the other hand, experienced greater closeness with their partner, regardless of the nature of the conversation. In simple terms, they connect with people better. As highly curious individuals have more closeness with their conversation partner, they naturally acquire more knowledge about that individual, which leads to more creative solutions.

罗切斯特大学的一项研究表明，好奇心在人际关系中扮演着至关重要的角色。该研究将参与者两两配对，并在让他们交谈之前测量了他们的好奇心水平。随后，研究人员将每对参与者分别安排进行闲聊或深入的对话。结果发现，那些在实验前好奇心水平较低的参与者，在深入对话的情境下体验到了更高的亲密感，但在闲聊情境下则没有这种效果。相反，那些被评定为好奇心较高的参与者，无论对话内容如何，都能与伴侣建立更亲密的关系。简而言之，他们更容易与人建立联系。由于好奇心强的人与对话对象之间的亲密感更强，他们自然而然地会更多地了解对方，从而能够提出更具创造性的解决方案。

Sarah Farzam, founder of Bilingual Birdies, used to dread meetings that involved negotiation. Then she realized that she loved meeting people and she loved hearing their stories. If she made this her focus, she looked forward to it. You may recall that Sarah is Jewish, Mexican, and Iranian. She speaks four languages and the entire point of her business is to help children appreciate other cultures.

双语小鸟（Bilingual Birdies）的创始人莎拉·法扎姆（Sarah Farzam）过去最害怕的就是需要谈判的会议。后来她意识到，她喜欢结识新朋友，也喜欢倾听他们的故事。如果她把这作为工作的重心，她就会充满期待。你可能知道，莎拉拥有犹太、墨西哥和伊朗血统。她会说四种语言，而她创办这家机构的宗旨就是帮助孩子们了解和欣赏其他文化。

“I’m genuinely interested in people,” Sarah said, so it’s natural for her to ask questions. “I’ll ask, ‘So how long have you been working here? I see your last name is Martinez—do you speak Spanish? Tell me about that.’ They tell me their stories and all about their family and where they come from. Everyone is at some point an immigrant.”

“我真心对人感兴趣，”莎拉说，所以她很自然地会问问题。“我会问，‘你在这里工作多久了？我看到你姓马丁内斯——你会说西班牙语吗？跟我说说吧。’他们会跟我讲述他们的故事，他们的家庭，以及他们的来历。每个人在人生的某个阶段都曾是移民。”

How Sarah enters those conversations depends on what she knows about her counterpart’s culture. When she is negotiating with someone from a Middle Eastern culture, for example, she makes it all about the relationship. “I try to make the conversation an experience. In Iranian culture, for instance, people come to your house and they roll out the red carpet for you. They’re not going to give you three pieces of food and that’s it. They’re going to bring people to sing for you. So I try to re-create that. I say, ‘Let’s get the chai. Let’s talk.’” She plays up the part of her own personality that will show she relates.

萨拉如何展开对话取决于她对对方文化的了解程度。例如，当她与来自中东文化背景的人谈判时，她会着重营造一种关系感。“我努力让对话成为一种体验。比如在伊朗文化中，人们会热情款待你，铺上红毯。他们不会只给你三道菜就完事，还会请人来为你唱歌。所以我努力重现那种氛围。我会说，‘我们去喝茶吧，聊聊。’”她会展现出自己能够与对方产生共鸣的一面。

“It makes sense to do,” she said of the information-gathering she prioritizes, “because (a) it’s genuine, (b) people like it, and (c) I like it. Even if I don’t get a deal, I feel like I’ve learned so much.”

“这样做很有意义，”她谈到自己重视的信息收集工作时说，“因为（a）这是真实的，（b）人们喜欢这样做，（c）我也喜欢这样做。即使我最终没有达成交易，我也觉得我学到了很多东西。”

Sarah is unabashedly curious. Curious negotiators notice everything and treat negotiation just as sommeliers approach wine. You don’t use just a single sense as a sommelier; you don’t ask, “White or red?” You take your time, you think about smell and food pairings and the process that went into making the wine you recommend. You listen for understanding, not for validation of what you already have assumed. As the Dalai Lama said, “When you talk, you are only repeating what you already know. But if you listen, you may learn something new.”

萨拉毫不掩饰自己的好奇心。好奇的谈判者会注意到一切，他们对待谈判的态度就像侍酒师品酒一样。侍酒师不会只用一种感官；你不会问“白葡萄酒还是红葡萄酒？”你会花时间思考，思考香气、食物搭配以及你推荐的葡萄酒的酿造过程。你倾听是为了理解，而不是为了验证你已有的假设。正如达赖喇嘛所说：“当你说话时，你只是在重复你已经知道的东西。但如果你倾听，你可能会学到新的东西。”

Becoming genuinely interested in people

对人产生真正的兴趣

Information exchange is particularly easy to skip over with family members, because we think we know everything there is to know about them. But that’s not always the case—in fact, it’s usually not the case. My friend Emma told me that information exchange had dramatically improved her marriage. She and her husband continuously argued about how to discipline their children. She felt her husband was too lenient, and he thought she was too strict. It panicked him whenever she raised her voice to one of the kids, and he grew frantic if she even suggested the prospect of spanking. She’d been brought up in a household where spanking was acceptable. Her parents hadn’t done it a lot, but for offenses that were alarming—like disrespect—they had felt it was an appropriate way to send a message, and she agreed. She and her husband constantly butted heads until she decided to apply the concepts of curiosity to their next negotiation about discipline. Instead of fighting about the fact that they felt differently, she wanted to understand why they felt differently. What values had her husband grown up with that made him feel so strongly? She asked him question after question. Only after they had been talking about it for some time did he reveal that he had been physically abused as a child. She had been with her husband for over a decade and had never known. Now that she did, it changed everything, brought them closer, and offered a new framing for some of their most perpetual arguments.

在与家人相处时，信息交流尤其容易被忽略，因为我们总觉得自己对他们了如指掌。但事实并非总是如此——实际上，通常并非如此。我的朋友艾玛告诉我，信息交流极大地改善了她的婚姻。她和丈夫经常因为如何管教孩子而争吵。她觉得丈夫太宽容，而丈夫则认为她太严厉。每当她对孩子提高嗓门，丈夫都会惊慌失措；如果她哪怕只是提出要打孩子屁股，他都会变得非常激动。艾玛成长在一个打孩子屁股是可以接受的家庭。她的父母虽然不常这样做，但对于一些严重的过错——比如不尊重——他们觉得这是传递信息的一种恰当方式，她也认同这一点。她和丈夫一直争执不休，直到她决定在下一次关于管教问题的协商中运用好奇心。她不再纠结于彼此感受不同，而是想要了解他们感受不同的原因。她的丈夫从小接受的价值观是什么，才会让他如此坚定？她问了他一个又一个问题。在他们谈论了一段时间后，他才透露自己童年时期曾遭受过身体虐待。她和丈夫在一起十多年，却一直毫不知情。如今得知真相，一切都改变了，他们的关系更加亲密，也为他们之间一些由来已久的争吵提供了新的视角。

My friend Joan called me seething after she got home from a morning workout to find a sink full of dishes and an unemptied but clean dishwasher while her husband was on the computer upstairs. She and her husband were in a rush to get out of town and had a dogsitter staying. Joan figured her husband had probably just expected her to do the dishes. And he was also being passive-aggressive, she thought, mad that she’d gone to work out. She called me as she angrily put dishes away. She was ready to bite her husband’s head off. This was a negotiation in the making, and it had the potential to go very badly. So I encouraged Joan to think of it the way she would any professional negotiation. The first thing she needed to do was show curiosity. She should ask her husband—and not in an accusatory way—why he hadn’t done the dishes. She should be genuine in her desire to know his thought process without judgment.

我的朋友琼早上锻炼完回家，发现水槽里堆满了碗碟，洗碗机虽然干净却没洗，而她丈夫却在楼上用电脑，她气得给我打了个电话。她和丈夫急着出城，还请了保姆帮忙照看狗狗。琼心想，她丈夫大概是觉得她应该洗碗。她还觉得，丈夫这是在暗地里发脾气，因为她去锻炼了。她一边生气地把碗碟放回原位，一边给我打电话。她恨不得把丈夫的脑袋拧下来。这简直就是一场即将爆发的谈判，而且很有可能以失败告终。所以我鼓励琼像对待任何一场职业谈判一样去思考这件事。她首先需要做的就是表现出好奇心。她应该问问丈夫——语气不要带有指责——为什么他没洗碗。她应该真诚地想要了解他的想法，而不是带着评判的眼光去问。

Joan took my advice and, instead of launching into accusations, asked her husband nonconfrontational questions and committed to listening. What had he been doing? Had he been in the kitchen? As it turned out, he’d been working on a home loan for them that had a tight turnaround. He had seen the dishes, but he hadn’t expected Joan to do them. Rather, he thought it was fair for them to expect the dogsitter to do them since there were only a few and, from his point of view, they were paying her an excellent rate to basically snuggle their dog for a couple of days.

琼听从了我的建议，没有立刻指责丈夫，而是问了一些不带冲突的问题，并认真倾听。他到底在干什么？是不是在厨房？结果发现，他一直在忙着帮他们办理一笔房贷，时间很紧。他看到了碗碟，但并没有指望琼去洗。他觉得既然碗碟不多，让他们请遛狗员洗也合情合理，而且在他看来，他们付给遛狗员的报酬很丰厚，她基本上就是陪他们的狗玩几天而已。

There was still a conflict here—Joan felt the dishes should be done before they left, and her husband didn’t. But now that they’d worked out each of their interests, the couple could focus the conversation on the question that was really at hand: What is a reasonable expectation for a dogsitter?

这里仍然存在分歧——琼觉得他们离开前应该把碗筷洗干净，而她丈夫不这么认为。但现在他们已经解决了各自的顾虑，这对夫妇可以将谈话的重点放在真正重要的问题上：对遛狗员来说，合理的期望是什么？

Similarly, James and his wife were looking for a family home to buy and couldn’t agree on a place to make an offer. What’s more, when they discussed different houses, they’d start to argue. “I travel a lot,” James explained, “so the house is not as important to me. I was looking at the bottom line.” His wife, who stayed home with the kids, was looking for what would be best for them, where they would play, which neighborhoods made sense. “She kept finding places that were over budget, and I found places that weren’t considerate of her needs. We were being dismissive of each other.” When James decided to focus on being curious, the conversation went much better. “We had a discussion about another house. And instead of dismissing it, I became more specific about why I didn’t like it. Then [my wife] said that she cared a lot about the neighborhood for all of these reasons, but that she’s willing to sacrifice something else. Because we were explaining what we really wanted instead of just saying, ‘I want this and she wants that,’ we were willing to bend. We understood where the other one was coming from, and we both wanted to please the other because we love each other.” When they were going to bed that night, James’s wife said, “That is the best conversation we have had in some time.”

同样，詹姆斯和妻子也想买一套适合全家居住的房子，却始终无法就出价达成一致。更糟糕的是，每次讨论不同的房子，他们都会争吵起来。“我经常出差，”詹姆斯解释说，“所以房子对我来说没那么重要。我只考虑价格。”他的妻子在家照顾孩子，她更看重的是孩子们的福祉，比如哪里适合玩耍，以及哪些社区环境好。“她总是找到超出预算的房子，而我找到的房子又都不符合她的需求。我们彼此都忽略了对方。”后来，詹姆斯决定换个角度，用更开放的心态去思考，双方的讨论才开始顺利起来。 “我们讨论过另一套房子。我没有直接否定它，而是更具体地解释了我不喜欢它的原因。然后（我妻子）说，她很在意这个社区，原因有很多，但她愿意做出一些妥协。因为我们解释了我们真正想要的是什么，而不是简单地说‘我想要这个，她想要那个’，所以我们都愿意做出让步。我们理解了对方的想法，而且我们都想让对方满意，因为我们彼此相爱。”那天晚上睡觉前，詹姆斯的妻子说：“这是我们最近一段时间以来最棒的一次谈话。”

In my final (and probably favorite) story of how families can practice open-mindedness with one another, my former student Michael was in a really awkward place. His wife asked him to talk to her father about a complicated family negotiation that had reached deadlock. “I’m a chiropractor who took a negotiations class,” Michael reminded her. “I’m not sure I have a lot to offer here.” But he agreed to try.

在我讲述的最后一个（也可能是我最喜欢的）关于家庭成员如何彼此保持开放心态的故事中，我的前学生迈克尔陷入了非常尴尬的境地。他的妻子请他去和她父亲谈谈一个陷入僵局的复杂家庭谈判。“我是一名脊椎按摩师，上过谈判课，”迈克尔提醒她，“我不确定我能帮上什么忙。”但他还是同意试一试。

Their predicament was fraught, to say the least. It all started when Michael and his wife, Susan, wanted to buy a home in San Francisco, and Michael’s father-in-law, Jack, agreed to pay half, on the condition that the house would be put in a trust for the grandchildren. Michael and Susan agreed, and after the purchase of the home, they hired an attorney who specialized in trusts to draw it up. Jack asked to see the trust and was not happy that he wasn’t the sole trustee. How was he to be 100 percent confident that Michael wouldn’t run off with the money? Now, keep in mind that Jack had known Michael since the latter was a little boy. Michael had been married to Jack’s daughter for fifteen years, he had three children with her, and their marriage was strong, as was Jack’s personal relationship with Michael. Jack’s request was unreasonable and insulting. If Michael and Susan ever did divorce, Jack’s demand would require Michael to continue paying the mortgage on the home without living there. Because the mortgage was so high, Michael wouldn’t have been able to afford another place to live. Jack and Susan had screaming matches over the issue, and because father and daughter were getting nowhere, Michael got involved.

他们的处境可谓十分棘手。事情的起因是迈克尔和妻子苏珊想在旧金山买房，迈克尔的岳父杰克同意支付一半的房款，条件是房子要放入信托基金，留给孙辈。迈克尔和苏珊同意了，买房后，他们聘请了一位专门从事信托业务的律师来起草信托文件。杰克要求查看信托文件，却发现自己并非唯一的受托人，这让他很不高兴。他怎么能百分之百确定迈克尔不会卷款潜逃呢？要知道，杰克认识迈克尔很久了，从他还是个小男孩的时候就认识他了。迈克尔和杰克的女儿结婚十五年，育有三个孩子，他们的婚姻非常牢固，杰克和迈克尔的私人关系也很好。杰克的要求既不合理又令人愤慨。如果迈克尔和苏珊真的离婚了，按照杰克的要求，迈克尔就得继续偿还房贷，即使他自己不住在那里。由于房贷太高，迈克尔根本负担不起另一处住所。杰克和苏珊为此事大吵了一架，父女俩争论不休，毫无进展，迈克尔也介入了此事。

“I knew I couldn’t approach it as ‘This is my father-in-law giving me a gift,’” he said, nor could he look at it as his father-in-law wishing him harm. “I had to approach it as ‘This is someone going in on buying a property with me. How can we make it work?’” When Michael and Jack finally talked about it—in front of Susan and Michael’s mother-in-law—Jack expected Michael to be as emotional as Susan had been. “I think Jack was prepared to say, ‘I love you like a son, but this is business,’” Michael said, but Jack never needed to say it because Michael didn’t get upset. He was calm, and he was focused on being curious about what drove his father-in-law to do the things he did. What was the man’s interest?

“我知道我不能把这件事看作是‘这是我岳父送我的礼物’，”他说，也不能把它看作是岳父想害他。“我必须把它看作是‘这是有人要和我合伙买房。我们该怎么解决这个问题？’”当迈克尔和杰克最终在苏珊和迈克尔的岳母面前谈起这件事时，杰克以为迈克尔会像苏珊一样情绪激动。“我想杰克当时已经准备好说，‘我爱你像爱儿子一样，但这是生意，’”迈克尔说，但杰克根本没必要说出口，因为迈克尔并没有生气。他很冷静，一心想弄明白是什么驱使他的岳父去做这些事。这个人究竟有什么目的？

“Was Jack wanting to be a terrible person?” Michael asked himself. “No. He had a certain interest and wasn’t going about getting it in the right way. To this man, the dollar is king. Money is everything. It’s very different than in my family, where my mother gave me a check on my wedding day and asked no questions. She wanted to give me a gift, so she gave me a gift. Jack was different. So I had to approach it from a point of view of ‘Why do you want this? What is your concern here? What are you worried about me doing?’”

“杰克是想当个坏人吗？”迈克尔问自己。“不。他只是有某种目的，但方式不对。对他来说，金钱至上。钱就是一切。这和我家很不一样，我母亲在我结婚那天给了我一张支票，什么也没问。她想送我礼物，所以就送了。杰克不一样。所以我必须换个角度去问他：‘你为什么想要这个？你到底在担心什么？你担心我做什么？’”

When asked these questions, Jack responded, “I’m worried that if you get divorced and the house gets sold, you’d buy something for yourself with the money.”

当被问及这些问题时，杰克回答说：“我担心如果你离婚，房子被卖掉，你会用这笔钱给自己买些东西。”

“Okay,” Michael said, still unaffected by the insinuation of this statement. “What if we were to say that if the house gets sold because of divorce, the money still goes to the kids?”

“好吧，”迈克尔说道，似乎并未受到这句话的暗示影响。“如果我们规定，如果房子因为离婚而被卖掉，钱仍然归孩子所有，那又会怎样呢？”

Jack had to agree that this resolved his fear, mostly. But Jack said he was still worried about Michael running off. Then Michael pointed out that there was risk in everything, that they would never get to a place of zero percent risk. “Can I steal the money? Yes, but then the trust would have to come after me. You can’t prevent someone from murdering someone else, you can only come after them.” Michael helped his father-in-law see how he was overreaching, and they found common ground and, ultimately, an agreement.

杰克不得不承认，这基本消除了他的恐惧。但他仍然担心迈克尔会逃跑。这时，迈克尔指出凡事都有风险，他们永远无法达到零风险。“我可以偷钱吗？可以，但那样的话，信托基金就得追究我的责任。你无法阻止别人杀人，你只能追究他们的责任。”迈克尔帮助岳父意识到自己有些操之过急，他们找到了共同点，最终达成了一致。

It all worked out, but the tension leading up to it could have been avoided. We’re not as curious with family members as we should be. We assume we know not only what they think but why they think that way. Susan and Jack clashed for this very reason. But this dynamic keeps us from fact-finding mode, a mode from which we can either validate or dismiss our assumptions.

事情最终解决了，但之前的紧张气氛本可以避免。我们对家人的好奇心不够强。我们总是想当然地认为自己不仅知道他们的想法，还知道他们为什么这么想。苏珊和杰克正是因为这个原因发生了冲突。但这种心态让我们无法进入事实调查模式，而这种模式恰恰能让我们验证或推翻自己的假设。

The impact of perspective

视角的影响

There’s a haunting series on Showtime called The Affair that begins by exploring an extramarital affair from multiple viewpoints, showing how the same interactions are viewed differently depending on the character. None of the characters are lying, but they are subject to memory bias. Their experience is their experience. You see, for instance, how the married father of four, Noah, sees the younger Alison as flirty and the instigator of their affair. The viewers also see how Alison sees herself very differently and views Noah as the one who came on to her. It’s fascinating, from an audience perspective, to see how starkly people “miss” one another as they pass. What’s true in this television drama is also true in negotiation. Your perspective and that of your counterpart can be vastly different, while each of you views the same perceived facts. A few years ago, the issue of perspective elevated to an international frenzy and captivated millions when a wedding guest posted a photo of the mother of the bride wearing a dress that some viewers swore was white and gold while others said it was clearly black and blue. Scientists disagreed about what accounted for the discrepancy, but perspective was clearly at the heart of it. Dr. Duje Tadin, an associate professor of brain and cognitive sciences at the University of Rochester, pointed to variations of photoreceptors in our retinas, and told the New York Times , “This clearly has to do with individual differences in how we perceive the world. There’s something about this particular image that just captures those differences in a remarkable way.”

Showtime电视台有一部名为《婚外情事》（The Affair）的剧集，引人入胜。该剧以多视角探讨婚外情，展现了同一事件在不同角色眼中的不同解读。剧中人物都没有说谎，但他们都受到记忆偏差的影响。他们的经历就是他们的经历。例如，已婚并育有四个孩子的父亲诺亚，认为年轻的艾莉森轻佻放荡，是她挑起了这段婚外情。而观众则看到艾莉森对自己的看法截然不同，她认为诺亚才是主动追求她的人。从观众的角度来看，人们擦肩而过时彼此“错过”的程度令人着迷。这部电视剧所揭示的现象，在谈判中也同样适用。即使双方都认为事实相同，但彼此的视角也可能大相径庭。几年前，透视问题一度引发国际热议，吸引了数百万人的关注。起因是一位婚礼宾客发布了一张新娘母亲身穿礼服的照片，一些人坚称礼服是白金色的，而另一些人则认为它是黑蓝色的。科学家们对造成这种差异的原因莫衷一是，但透视显然是关键所在。罗切斯特大学脑与认知科学副教授杜耶·塔丁博士指出，我们视网膜中的感光细胞存在差异，并告诉《纽约时报》：“这显然与我们感知世界的个体差异有关。这张照片恰好以一种非凡的方式捕捉到了这些差异。”

TV dramas and social media may have a way of creatively capturing these perspective shifts, but it’s nothing new. Consider this from nineteenth-century philosopher William James: “Whenever two people meet there are really six people present. There is each man as he sees himself, each man as the other sees him, and each man as he really is.” The storylines are endless.

电视剧和社交媒体或许能以富有创意的方式捕捉到这些视角转变，但这并非什么新鲜事。不妨想想十九世纪哲学家威廉·詹姆斯的话：“每当两个人相遇，实际上就有六个人在场。每个人都有自己眼中的自己，对方眼中的自己，以及真实的自己。” 故事情节可谓无穷无尽。

Imagine, then, the power you would have if you didn’t insist the dress was blue and black but had the ability to also see it as white and gold. You could make an argument for one perspective while also clearly seeing the other. With this power in hand, you enter another league of negotiator, one where you can more easily broker deals, resolve arguments, and even usher in peace. With this power in hand, you can see new solutions, and tap into generosity. But it isn’t easy.

试想一下，如果你不坚持认为那件裙子是蓝黑色的，而是能够同时看到它是白金色的，你将拥有多么强大的力量。你可以为一种观点辩护，同时也能清晰地看到另一种观点。拥有这种力量，你就进入了谈判者的另一个境界，在这个境界里，你可以更轻松地促成交易、化解争端，甚至带来和平。拥有这种力量，你就能发现新的解决方案，并激发他人的慷慨。但这并非易事。

#↩

CHAPTER 6

第六章

the power of empathy

同理心的力量

Once you’ve learned everything you possibly can about your counterpart and opened yourself up to their point of view, you have to go a step further yet. You can’t just read about and ask questions of the other side—you have to actually be able to see things from their perspective, to empathize. You have to be like a Method actor, figuratively walking in their shoes so that you can not only see where they’re coming from but respect it, even if you disagree.

当你尽可能地了解了对方的一切，并敞开心扉接受他们的观点之后，你还需要更进一步。你不能只是阅读资料和提问——你必须真正地从他们的角度看待问题，感同身受。你必须像方法派演员一样，设身处地地去体验他们的经历，这样你不仅能够理解他们的出发点，还能尊重他们的观点，即使你并不认同。

Nelson Mandela is perhaps the best modern example of an empathetic negotiator. When he was imprisoned, he learned Afrikaans, the language of his jailers, so as to better understand them. When he was released and elected president, his predecessor, the Afrikaner F. W. de Klerk, served as his vice president. And once when he was berated on the radio by an angry Afrikaner, he said, “Well, Eddie, I regard you as a worthy South African, and I have no doubt that if we were to sit down and exchange views I will come closer to you and you will come closer to me. Let’s talk, Eddie.” Mandela was considered a “giant of empathy,” which was critical to his effective diplomacy.

纳尔逊·曼德拉或许是现代最具同理心的谈判者典范。他被囚禁期间，为了更好地理解狱卒，学习了他们的语言——南非荷兰语。获释后，他当选总统，他的前任、同样是南非荷兰人的弗雷德里克·威廉·德克勒克担任了他的副总统。有一次，一位愤怒的南非荷兰人在电台对他破口大骂，曼德拉回应道：“埃迪，我认为你是一位值得尊敬的南非人，我毫不怀疑，如果我们坐下来交流意见，我们彼此都会更加亲近。来谈谈吧，埃迪。”曼德拉被誉为“同理心的巨人”，这对他卓有成效的外交至关重要。

Empathy isn’t a “nice-to-have” for an effective negotiator; it’s a must-have. Empathy is a strategic way for you to understand your counterpart that allows you to communicate well. Further, if you don’t truly understand where your counterpart is coming from, how do you know how to compromise? How do you know where to make concessions that will really matter to them? Empathy allows for conflict mitigation—that easing of tension, that turning down of the temperature in a potentially heated discussion.

对于高效的谈判者而言，同理心并非“锦上添花”，而是必不可少。同理心是一种策略性的方法，能帮助你理解对方，从而进行有效的沟通。此外，如果你不真正理解对方的立场，又如何知道如何做出妥协？又如何知道哪些让步对他们来说真正重要？同理心能够化解冲突——缓解紧张气氛，缓和可能激烈的讨论。

The celebrated hostage negotiator Lt. Jack Cambria prizes empathy as a critical negotiation tool. Now retired from the New York Police Department, he has also trained other negotiators and is considered a bit of a godfather in the business. He told the Wall Street Journal that when he is looking for someone to be a hostage negotiator, he thinks they must “experience the emotion of love at one point in their life, to know what it means to have been hurt in love at one point in their life, to know success and perhaps, most important, to know what it means to know failure.” The hostage takers have demands—but the demands are less important than your having empathy, understanding their emotional state, and connecting with them on that level. Their demands are their wants, but their needs are more emotional and deeper. Former FBI chief negotiator Gary Noesner reflected, “When I used to interview people when they had surrendered after an incident and ask them what one thing I said to make them change their mind, they would invariably reply, ‘I don’t know what you said but I liked the way you said it.’ Our genuine, sincere, and concerned tone and demeanor are the most powerful tools of influence that we know.”

著名人质谈判专家杰克·坎布里亚中尉将同理心视为谈判的关键工具。他现已从纽约警察局退休，曾培训过其他谈判专家，被誉为业内泰斗。他告诉《华尔街日报》，在寻找人质谈判专家时，他认为候选人必须“在人生中体验过爱情，懂得在爱情中受伤的滋味，体验过成功，或许最重要的是，懂得失败的滋味。”劫持者会提出要求——但这些要求远不如你的同理心重要，你需要理解他们的情绪状态，并与他们建立情感联系。他们的要求是他们的欲望，但他们的需求则更为深层，也更感性。前联邦调查局首席谈判专家加里·诺斯纳回忆道：“过去，当我采访那些在事件后投降的人，问他们我说了什么让他们改变主意时，他们总是回答说：‘我不知道你说了什么，但我喜欢你说话的方式。’我们真诚、诚恳和关心的语气和举止是我们所知的最有力的影响力工具。”

Noesner says that when the FBI was working out how to positively influence people they were negotiating with, they looked to the writing and research of Robert Cialdini, particularly his book Influence: The Psychology of Persuasion , which has also been a seminal text for me. They learned that influence “is all about relationship building, earning trust and demonstrating a genuine interest in their issues and concerns. We learned that negotiators needed to come across as being non-threatening and non-judgmental.”

诺斯纳说，联邦调查局在研究如何积极影响谈判对象时，参考了罗伯特·西奥迪尼的著作和研究，特别是他的《影响力：说服心理学》一书，这本书对我来说也是一本影响深远的著作。他们了解到，影响力“关键在于建立关系、赢得信任，并展现出对对方问题和关切的真诚关注。我们了解到，谈判者需要表现得不具威胁性，也不带有评判性。”

When we seek to empathize, we get closer to resolution . . . even if it’s just marginally so. On a trip to the Middle East during his presidency, Barack Obama met with a group of Palestinian youth. According to Obama aide Ben Rhodes, the Palestinians told stories of having friends imprisoned and the freedom of their movements restricted. One of the speakers told Obama, “Mr. President, we are treated the same way the black people were treated in your country. Here, in this century. Funded by your government, Mr. President.”

当我们努力去理解他人时，我们就能更接近解决问题……哪怕只是略微接近。巴拉克·奥巴马在担任总统期间访问中东时，会见了一群巴勒斯坦青年。据奥巴马的助手本·罗兹说，这些巴勒斯坦青年讲述了他们的朋友被监禁、行动自由受到限制的故事。其中一位青年对奥巴马说：“总统先生，我们在这里受到的待遇，和你们国家对待黑人的方式如出一辙。就在本世纪，而且是由你们的政府资助的，总统先生。”

Shortly afterward, Obama spoke at a conference in Jerusalem. Although Obama had prepared remarks, at one point he stopped and said, “I’m going to go off script here for a second, but before I came here I met with a group of young Palestinians from the age of fifteen to twenty-two. And talking to them, they weren’t that different from my daughters. They weren’t that different from your daughters or sons. I honestly believe that if any Israeli parent sat down with those kids, they’d say I want these kids to succeed; I want them to prosper. I want them to have opportunities just like my kids do. I believe that’s what Israeli parents would want for these kids if they had a chance to listen to them and talk to them. I believe that.” Although Obama could not fix the deep fissures between Israel and Palestine, he could encourage empathy, just as the Palestinian speaker had done with Obama.

不久之后，奥巴马在耶路撒冷的一个会议上发表了讲话。尽管奥巴马事先准备了讲稿，但他中途停下来说道：“我先偏离一下讲稿，但在来这里之前，我与一群15岁到22岁的巴勒斯坦年轻人会面。与他们交谈后，我发现他们和我的女儿们并没有什么不同。他们和你们的子女也没有什么不同。我真心相信，如果任何一位以色列父母能和这些孩子坐下来谈谈，他们都会说：我希望这些孩子成功；我希望他们幸福。我希望他们能像我的孩子一样拥有各种机会。我相信，如果以色列父母有机会倾听这些孩子的心声，与他们交谈，他们也会有同样的愿望。我坚信这一点。”尽管奥巴马无法弥合以色列和巴勒斯坦之间根深蒂固的裂痕，但他可以像那位巴勒斯坦演讲者对奥巴马所做的那样，激发人们的同理心。

How empathy translates

如何转化同理心

Empathy is invaluable in politics and world affairs, and it’s also imperative on the smallest scale: that between two family members. Parents, for instance, can turn to empathy when locked in battle with their kids. I remember when one of my nephews was obsessed with gaming. Most of the adults in his life spent most of their energy fighting with him to stop “wasting” so much time instead of stopping to understand why he felt so compelled to spend so many hours gaming in the first place. What was it about gaming that he found so exciting and engaging? The adults in his life, including me, should have put ourselves in his shoes and tried to understand why he felt it was worth so much of his time and energy. We might have learned that he loved gaming because he played with his best friends, and it was the connection to his friends that he most valued. Or we might have learned that it was something he felt he could excel in and master, thus giving him a sense of accomplishment. The truth is I don’t know if we ever really understood his motives; we spent so much time being worried about him that every time it came up, we appeared unreasonably protective or judgmental.

同理心在政治和国际事务中至关重要，在最细微的层面上也同样不可或缺：比如在两个家庭成员之间。例如，父母在与孩子发生冲突时，可以运用同理心。我记得我的一个侄子曾经沉迷于游戏。他身边的大多数成年人都把精力放在劝他不要“浪费”那么多时间上，而不是停下来思考他为什么会如此痴迷于游戏。游戏究竟有什么魔力让他如此兴奋和投入？他身边的成年人，包括我，本应该设身处地地为他着想，努力理解他为什么觉得游戏值得投入这么多时间和精力。我们或许会发现，他喜欢游戏是因为他可以和最好的朋友一起玩，而与朋友之间的这种联系是他最珍视的。又或许我们会发现，他觉得游戏是他能够精通并掌握的领域，这能给他带来成就感。事实上，我不知道我们是否真正理解过他的动机；我们花了太多时间担心他，以至于每次谈到他，我们都会显得过度保护或妄加评判。

Nothing about this conflict is unique to my family. Parents worry about their kids and often feel they just know better, so why not just attempt to stop the activity? This approach rarely works because it doesn’t allow for true empathy, for the chance to understand the decisions or actions from the perspective of your child. Without empathy, you appear judgmental, punitive, and unjust. You form barriers to communication and perpetuate misunderstandings.

这种冲突并非我家独有。父母总是担心孩子，常常觉得自己比孩子更懂，所以干脆阻止他们做某件事。但这种方法很少奏效，因为它缺乏真正的同理心，无法从孩子的角度去理解他们的决定或行为。缺乏同理心，你会显得带有评判性、惩罚性和不公正。你会阻碍沟通，加剧误解。

Many a parent has been in conflict with a surly child who, for whatever reason, is demanding something. Before the parent refuses, they would do well to stop a moment and imagine what’s going on with their child. What was their day like that day? How might they be feeling? Is the issue really whatever it is they’re demanding, or is it something else?

许多父母都曾遇到过孩子无理取闹、提出各种要求的情况。在拒绝之前，父母不妨停下来想一想孩子的情况。他们那天过得怎么样？他们可能感觉如何？问题真的出在他们提出的要求上，还是另有隐情？

This tactic isn’t only confined to parents, by the way, and I’ve found it enormously useful as a daughter. In Chapter 2, I wrote about my relationship with my parents, focusing on how it took me a long time to separate their wishes for me from what I authentically wanted. (I suspect I’m not the first child of immigrants to experience this dynamic.) I was angry with them, particularly my father, for insisting that I study medicine instead of seeing that I had no interest in being a doctor. For many years I could not see his perspective. But I eventually came to understand where he was coming from, in a genuine, empathetic way, and not because he told me explicitly but because I worked hard at putting myself in his shoes. When we left Iran, we left everything we knew, everything that defined us. He had been stable and grounded—when he moved us to the United States, the rug was pulled out from under him and stability was no more. He went from being an engineer and managing thousands of people at sugar refineries to running a small convenience store.

顺便说一句，这种策略并非父母专属，作为女儿，我也发现它非常有效。在第二章中，我写到了我和父母的关系，重点讲述了我花了很长时间才将他们对我的期望和我的真实想法区分开来。（我猜想，经历这种情感纠葛的移民子女肯定不止我一个。）我曾对他们，尤其是我的父亲，感到愤怒，因为他们坚持让我学医，却不肯承认我对当医生毫无兴趣。多年来，我一直无法理解他的想法。但最终，我以一种真诚而感同身受的方式理解了他的处境，这并非因为他直白地告诉我，而是因为我努力设身处地地为他着想。离开伊朗时，我们离开了所有熟悉的一切，所有定义我们身份的事物。他原本是一个稳定而脚踏实地的人——但当他带着我们来到美国时，一切都变了，稳定不复存在。他从一名管理着糖厂数千名员工的工程师，变成了一家小型便利店的老板。

When people come to the United States from other countries, there are a million ideas in their heads about what America is like. Just to mention a few, Americans have a different way of raising kids, an incredible freedom of choice, a mantra that says, “Live your dreams! Be what you want to be!” For someone like my dad, this was confusing, undoubtedly scary, and yet he felt he must keep a sense of balance. But how? How could he ensure that the person he was betting the farm on (me!) was successful? How could he make sure I stayed on the right course when there were so many unknowns, including language, culture, and social values? All he felt he could do to protect me was to write the script for my life and tell me to follow it.

当人们从其他国家来到美国时，他们脑海中会浮现出无数关于美国的想法。举几个例子来说，美国人有着不同的育儿方式，拥有令人难以置信的选择自由，以及一句口号：“活出你的梦想！做你想成为的人！”对于像我父亲这样的人来说，这一切无疑令人困惑，甚至有些可怕，但他觉得自己必须保持平衡。可是该怎么做呢？他如何才能确保他寄予厚望的人（我！）能够成功？面对语言、文化和社会价值观等诸多未知因素，他如何才能确保我走在正确的道路上？他觉得唯一能做的，就是为我的人生写好剧本，然后告诉我按部就班地走下去。

The way that my dad pressured me to follow a career path he felt sure to be successful was the way he showed his love for me. Everybody loves differently, and everybody accepts love differently. I wanted a different kind of love from my dad—a kind that was more tactile, unconditional, and nonjudgmental. But because I didn’t get it in that way didn’t mean it wasn’t there. I didn’t agree with my father’s approach, but working hard to see the world the way he does has been crucial to my capacity to forgive him.

父亲逼我走他认为肯定会成功的职业道路，这其实是他表达爱的方式。每个人爱的方式都不同，每个人接受爱的方式也不同。我想要的是父亲另一种爱——一种更直接、更无条件、更不带评判的爱。但我没能得到那种爱，并不代表它不存在。我并不认同父亲的做法，但努力从他的角度看待世界，对我最终能够原谅他至关重要。

My student Dom told me that the evening after one of our classes where we discussed the importance of empathy in bargaining, he got a chance to try it out. The negotiation, in this case, was with his wife. A group of Dom’s friends were getting together, and Dom wanted to go. But he had been out the previous two evenings because of work engagements, and his wife had been left home as the sole parent to their kids. Their discussion about how he would spend his evening was not going well. He kept repeating that he really wanted to go and she kept saying no.

我的学生多姆告诉我，在我们上完一堂课，讨论了同理心在谈判中的重要性之后，第二天晚上他就有机会实践了一下。这次谈判的对象是他的妻子。多姆的一群朋友要聚会，多姆也想去。但他前两个晚上都因为工作安排外出，妻子独自在家照顾孩子。他们讨论他晚上该怎么安排，结果并不顺利。他反复强调自己真的很想去，而妻子却一直拒绝。

Then he took a step back and tried to empathize. His wife was tired of solo parenting, which he respected. She also was in need of a little love and attention from her husband. Dom owned three businesses and was constantly working—and that clearly made her feel overlooked sometimes. Dom understood then that his wife would respond better to whatever he asked—whether it was that night or the next week—if he could fill up her emotional bank account. So that was what he decided to do.

然后他退后一步，试着去理解妻子。他明白妻子已经厌倦了独自抚养孩子，他对此表示尊重。但她也需要丈夫多一些关爱和关注。多姆拥有三家公司，工作繁忙——这显然让她有时感到被忽视。多姆这才意识到，如果他能满足妻子的情感需求，无论他提出什么要求——无论是当晚还是下周——妻子都会更容易接受。于是，他决定这么做。

“You’re right,” he said. “Let’s spend time together this evening. What do you want to do? Do you want to watch a movie or something?” He told her how much he loved and appreciated her and that it was really wonderful to spend time with her. Importantly, all of these statements were true! He felt them all the time, he just was hyperaware that she needed to hear them. He knew it was a possibility that once her “bank account” was filled up, she might change her mind and suggest that he go out with his friends, but he also knew that might not happen and he was perfectly happy in that case to be at home.

“你说得对，”他说。“我们今晚一起待着吧。你想做什么？想看电影什么的吗？”他告诉她他有多爱她、多感激她，和她在一起真的非常美好。重要的是，这些话都是真心的！他一直都有这种感觉，只是他格外清楚她需要听到这些话。他知道，一旦她的“银行账户”满了，她可能会改变主意，提议和他的朋友出去玩，但他同时也知道这种情况可能不会发生，如果真是那样，他也很乐意待在家里。

After a while, though, she turned to him and said, “You know what? I think you should go out with your friends.”

但过了一会儿，她转向他说：“你知道吗？我觉得你应该和朋友们出去玩。”

Dom was pretty excited about how effective empathy was, and so he used it in his next work negotiation. One of his companies is an auto body shop, and a large part of the work he does is negotiating estimates with insurance adjusters. The very purpose of an insurance adjuster is not to give way to companies like Dom’s. In other words, if ever there was a place where the tactic of empathy would fall short, this was it.

多姆对同理心的有效性感到非常兴奋，于是他在下一次工作谈判中运用了它。他所在的公司是一家汽车修理厂，他工作的大部分内容就是与保险理赔员协商估价。保险理赔员的职责就是不向像多姆这样的公司让步。换句话说，如果说同理心这种策略有什么失效的地方，那就是这里了。

Dom worked with one adjuster with whom he habitually clashed. When the adjuster came in to Dom’s shop, he was frowning and just generally looked antagonistic. Okay , thought Dom, here goes . Dom put his arm around him and said, “Listen, dude. I don’t want to go on like this anymore. We’re here together for the benefit of our customer. We should be able to work together better.”

多姆和一位理赔员共事，两人总是意见不合。那天，理赔员来到多姆的店里，眉头紧锁，一副充满敌意的样子。多姆心想，好吧，那就试试吧。他搂住理赔员的肩膀说：“听着，伙计。我不想再这样下去了。我们一起工作是为了客户的利益，我们应该更好地合作。”

The adjuster shook his head and said, “No, it’s nothing about you. I’m just having a bad day.”

理赔员摇了摇头说：“不，这跟你没关系。我只是今天心情不好。”

“Why?” Dom asked. “What’s up?”

“为什么？”多姆问道，“出什么事了？”

The adjuster took out a picture of his son and explained that he’d just had an ugly accident.

理赔员拿出他儿子的照片，解释说他儿子刚刚遭遇了一场严重的事故。

“Then what are you doing here?” Dom said. “Go home. Go be with your family. We’ll talk tomorrow, don’t worry.”

“那你来这儿干什么？”多姆说。“回家去。回家陪陪家人。我们明天再谈，别担心。”

When the adjuster came in the next day he said, “I really appreciate what you did for me yesterday.”

第二天理赔员来的时候说：“我非常感谢你昨天为我所做的一切。”

“I have a little boy too,” Dom said. “I would do the same thing.”

“我也有个小男孩，”多姆说。“我也会这么做。”

The two spent the next few hours going over the estimate, and as empathy allowed them to be shoulder-to-shoulder, they came to an agreement they both felt good about.

接下来的几个小时里，两人仔细研究了估价，在同理心的驱使下，他们肩并肩站在一起，最终达成了一项双方都满意的协议。

My student John went through a process that closely mirrored Dom’s. He’d recently left the military when he took my class at Wharton, and although the military had given him a code of ethics in his negotiation style that was well defined, he hadn’t given much thought to the role of empathy in negotiation. He began using some of what we discussed at class at home with his wife, and at graduation his wife came up to me to tell me how much the class had strengthened their marriage. As John explained, they focus a lot more in their conversations on “understanding the why.” “Even if we still end up on opposite ends,” he said, “we’ll say, at least I understand how you got to your why, even though I don’t agree with you. It’s opened up another layer of communication in our marriage.”

我的学生约翰的经历与多姆的经历非常相似。他刚从军队退役不久，就来沃顿商学院上我的课。虽然军队给他制定了一套明确的谈判道德准则，但他并没有过多地思考同理心在谈判中的作用。他开始把课堂上讨论的一些内容运用到与妻子的沟通中。毕业时，他的妻子找到我，告诉我这门课如何极大地巩固了他们的婚姻。正如约翰解释的那样，他们现在在谈话中更加注重“理解背后的原因”。“即使我们最终还是意见相左，”他说，“我们也会说，至少我理解你得出这个结论的过程，即使我不同意你的观点。这为我们的婚姻沟通开辟了新的层面。”

He’s taken these skills into his work at a private equity firm, where he deals exclusively with distressed debt. “If we’re a lender on someone’s business loan, and the business deteriorates, we know the collateral that we can come after.” With his earlier mind-set, he was more likely to focus on the quantitative data without much thought to the humans behind them. He’s seen that mind-set used often by his colleagues who have been in the field a long time and who have become jaded. “It’s easy to take the approach, ‘Hey, pay me this or we’re taking that.’” But employing empathy, he said, while harder, leads to better outcomes. “You actually start looking at the people behind the business, and families. These are just business owners who were trying to make a living and then it ended up going south and they can’t pay their debt.” He said when you show compassion, you end up working together and discovering variables—like a health crisis—that had an impact on their ability to pay a loan. “We’ll find out after the fact that somebody just got ill, and the business kind of just fell away. You can’t discern this from financial statements and hundreds of pages of documents. When you’re able to understand the why and how they ended up in these situations, it often can drive a better outcome because you have them on board and working with you. No one necessarily has to be right.”

他将这些技能运用到他在一家私募股权公司的工作中，专门负责不良债务。“如果我们是某人商业贷款的贷款方，而该企业经营状况恶化，我们就知道可以追讨哪些抵押品。” 以前，他更倾向于关注量化数据，而很少考虑数据背后的人。他发现，许多在这个领域工作多年的同事仍然抱有这种思维模式，变得麻木不仁。“很容易采取‘嘿，要么还我这个，要么我们就收那个’的态度。” 但他表示，运用同理心虽然更难，却能带来更好的结果。“你会开始关注企业背后的人，以及他们的家庭。他们只是努力维持生计的企业主，但最终生意失败，无力偿还债务。” 他说，当你展现出同情心时，你们最终会携手合作，发现影响他们还款能力的各种因素——比如健康危机。 “事后我们才会发现，原来是有人生病了，然后公司就垮掉了。你不可能从财务报表和几百页的文件里看出这一点。当你能够理解他们为什么会陷入这种境地，以及事情是如何发生的，往往能带来更好的结果，因为你让他们参与进来，与你并肩作战。其实，谁也不一定是对的。”

Empathy has a bad rap

同理心名声不好。

Many feel that having too much empathy is a weakness—not an asset—in a negotiation. They argue that you have to be emotionless to be effective; otherwise you are apt to concede too much. My students constantly apologize for their empathy, thinking it gets in the way of effective negotiation. But this is dead wrong. Empathetic people are, in fact, some of the best negotiators out there. Empathetic people are the most able to put themselves in their counterparts’ position and assess what they might want.
