Empathetic people are the ultimate information gatherers.

许多人认为，在谈判中，同理心过强是一种弱点，而非优势。他们认为，要想高效谈判，就必须保持冷静，否则很容易做出过多让步。我的学生经常为自己的同理心感到抱歉，认为它会妨碍有效的谈判。但这完全是错误的。事实上，富有同理心的人往往是最优秀的谈判者之一。他们最能设身处地地为对方着想，评估对方的需求。他们也是最擅长收集信息的。

Empathetic negotiators run into problems only when they get so involved in the feelings of others that they cross over to taking on those challenges as their own. As Dom put it, “Empathy is working with others the best you can. Stupidity is giving away the house.” I wouldn’t call it stupid, but we do get into trouble when we can’t separate ourselves emotionally. This is what Emily, the pleaser who was buying a used car in Chapter 2, struggled with when she thought, “Oh, this poor car salesman is going to be late for dinner with his girlfriend and I can’t let that happen.” These empathetic people aren’t able to draw a line, and their decision making is impacted to their detriment. Deeply intertwined with this tendency is that they are not turning their empathy on themselves . These negotiators are focused on other people’s needs and wants and mistakenly think they can’t also focus on their own, that the two are mutually exclusive. What they don’t understand is that without taking care of themselves, too, they can’t be effective.

只有当富有同理心的谈判者过于投入他人的感受，以至于将这些挑战视为己任时，才会遇到问题。正如多姆所说：“同理心是尽你所能与他人合作，而愚蠢则是拱手让人。” 我不会称之为愚蠢，但当我们无法将自身情感抽离出来时，确实会陷入困境。第二章中，讨好型人格的艾米丽在购买二手车时就遇到了这样的问题：她心想，“哦，这个可怜的汽车销售员要和女朋友吃晚饭迟到了，我不能让他得逞。” 这些富有同理心的人无法划清界限，他们的决策也因此受到损害。与这种倾向密切相关的是，他们没有将同理心运用到自身。这些谈判者专注于他人的需求和愿望，却错误地认为他们无法同时关注自身的需求和愿望，认为两者是互斥的。他们不明白的是，如果不照顾好自己，就无法取得成效。

I learned this lesson the hard way with my health care consulting practice. When we had to lay people off, it was awful. I empathized with their disappointment and lost many nights of sleep worrying about them. Although I firmly believe this empathy was essential to the collaborative culture that I was trying to establish, I took it too far. I made it my responsibility to fix it by delaying the downsizing, putting unnecessary strain on our already dwindling budget. I took on their strain and internalized it.

我在医疗咨询业务中为此付出了惨痛的代价。裁员时，我感到非常难过。我能体会到他们的失望，为此彻夜难眠。虽然我坚信这种同理心对于我努力建立的协作文化至关重要，但我却做得过火了。我把解决问题的责任推给了自己，拖延裁员，给本已捉襟见肘的预算增加了不必要的压力。我承担了他们的压力，并将之内化于心。

Many leaders find themselves walking the same line I walked, struggling with the same question I did: How do I care about my employees without caring so much that it affects my ability to run the business? My student Saudia is one such leader. She founded a cleaning service, and most of her employees come from the same demographic as her mother and grandmother: single moms, immigrants, not formally educated, economically vulnerable. Saudia feels a great sense of responsibility to these employees. She remembers how the first time she gave out paychecks, one of her employees literally ran to the Western Union to send money to her mother in Columbia, who would now be able to afford surgery. The benefits and consequences of Saudia’s business success feel very personal because they are.

许多领导者都和我一样，面临着同样的困境：如何在关心员工的同时，又不至于过度关心而影响到公司的运营？我的学生萨蒂亚就是这样一位领导者。她创办了一家清洁服务公司，她的大部分员工都和她的母亲、祖母一样，来自类似的群体：单身母亲、移民、没有接受过正规教育、经济状况脆弱。萨蒂亚对这些员工深感责任重大。她记得第一次发放工资时，一位员工甚至跑到西联汇款公司，给远在哥伦比亚的母亲汇款，这样她的母亲就能负担得起手术费用了。萨蒂亚的商业成功所带来的益处和后果，对她而言都意义非凡，因为它们确实与她息息相关。

When Saudia realized she had a seriously underperforming employee, she was in a hard spot and went through a grueling negotiation within herself. Letting this employee go would have real consequences. This employee would undoubtedly not go quietly—there would be a conflict. This employee had a family. It was the holidays. Saudia could track the ripple effects of the act. Simply put, no matter what she did, people were going to be pissed. Saudia had to get herself to a place where she could see all the ripples through to their natural ending and still fire the employee. She had to do it, because there were financial consequences to not doing it. She had to do it, because other employees were relying on Saudia to steer the ship. She had to do it, because as much as she wanted to take care of everyone, sometimes as the boss, you can’t.

当沙蒂娅意识到自己手下有个严重表现不佳的员工时，她陷入了进退两难的境地，内心经历了一场艰难的挣扎。解雇这个员工会带来切实的后果。这个员工肯定不会默默离开——肯定会引发冲突。这个员工有家庭要照顾。而且正值假期。沙蒂娅预感到解雇的连锁反应。简而言之，无论她做什么，大家都会不高兴。沙蒂娅必须让自己能够预见到所有后果，并最终解雇这个员工。她必须这么做，因为如果不这么做，将会面临经济上的损失。她必须这么做，因为其他员工都指望着她来掌舵。她必须这么做，因为尽管她很想照顾到每个人，但作为老板，有时候她也做不到。

“The internal negotiations [with myself] are the ones that are hardest,” Saudia said. She had to give herself permission to use her empathy but not be hobbled by it. She knew she could do it because she’d just had a similar internal negotiation about her nanny.

“最难的是和自己进行内心的斗争，”萨迪娅说。她必须允许自己运用同理心，但又不能被同理心束缚。她知道自己能做到，因为她刚刚就保姆的问题进行过类似的内心斗争。

“I knew my first one wasn’t right,” she said. “I saw the ripple effect. I knew my child was attached to her. I knew there would be a transition period where I’d need to be at home. I was negotiating the repercussions instead of negotiating the action I needed to do. My significant other will say, ‘You have to think about it this way: How much better is it going to be with someone new who is going to be able to do this job effectively?’ There are so many plusses that you can’t worry about the minuses.”

“我知道我第一个孩子的情况不对，”她说。“我看到了连锁反应。我知道我的孩子很依赖她。我知道会有一段过渡期，我需要待在家里。我当时一直在考虑后果，而不是思考我需要采取的行动。我的伴侣会说，‘你得这样想：换个能胜任这份工作的新人，情况会好多少？’好处那么多，你根本没必要去想那些坏处。”

Letting each person go was uncomfortable, as expected, but Saudia knew it was the right call. “I have to constantly remind myself that in all of my thirteen years in business, I have never regretted firing someone. However, I have constantly and consistently regretted not firing someone sooner.”

解雇每个人都让人感到不舒服，这不出所料，但沙特航空知道这是正确的决定。“我必须不断提醒自己，在我十三年的从业经历中，我从未后悔解雇过任何人。然而，我一直后悔没有早点解雇某些人。”

John Lynch, former star NFL safety, works in a very different field, but like Saudia, he uses empathy daily in his work. He knows what it’s like to be a young player worried about proving himself. He also knows what it’s like to be a veteran player coming to terms with the idea that perhaps it’s time to move on. Now he’s the general manager of the San Francisco 49ers and sits on the other side of the table. He has to make dozens of fast decisions daily, he said, decisions that affect people’s livelihoods and families. A naturally empathetic human being, he has had to work hard at using that trait for the good of the organization.

前NFL明星安全卫约翰·林奇如今从事着截然不同的工作，但和沙特亚一样，他也每天都在工作中运用同理心。他深知年轻球员渴望证明自己的感受，也了解老将不得不接受或许该退役的现实时的心情。如今，他是旧金山49人队的总经理，坐在决策桌的另一边。他说，他每天都要迅速做出几十个决定，这些决定会影响到人们的生计和家庭。他天生富有同理心，因此必须努力将这种特质运用到球队的运营中。

“A couple of weeks ago,” he told me, “we were talking to players who were drafted, and I realize the impact that has on their achieving a dream. I think, I’ve been there before. I’ve been a player early in a career where you’re drafted, but gosh, do you really believe you can make it? I understand how that feels.” When he has to make the tough calls about personnel—which he must do constantly—he uses empathy to inform him how. He or head coach Kyle Shanahan try to meet personally with every player who is let go. “It comes from having been there myself and knowing what I appreciated, someone looking you in the eye. I think it’s also important to tell people the truth, saying, ‘Hey. Here’s why we cut you.’ In particular, if they ask questions—‘Why me instead of this guy?’—I say, ‘Well, I’m not going to get into talking about this guy, but for you, here’s what our mind-set was.’” The same approach applies when players ask, as they sometimes will, if he thinks it’s time for them to move on. “I’m willing to say, ‘Hey, I don’t know everything, but yeah. I think it might be that time,’ because I think that’s what I would want to hear and I think having been there helps me in those situations.”

“几周前，”他告诉我，“我们和一些被选中的球员聊过，我意识到这对他们实现梦想的影响有多大。我想，我以前也经历过这种感觉。我职业生涯早期也被选中过，但天哪，你真的相信自己能成功吗？我理解那种感受。” 当他不得不做出艰难的人员决定时——而他必须经常这样做——他会运用同理心来指导自己。他和主教练凯尔·沙纳汉会尽量亲自与每一位被裁球员见面。 “这源于我自己的亲身经历，让我明白我真正感激的是什么——有人看着你的眼睛。我觉得坦诚相待也很重要，我会说：‘嘿，这就是我们裁掉你的原因。’特别是如果他们问问题——‘为什么是我而不是那个人？’——我会说：‘好吧，我不想谈论那个人，但对你来说，这就是我们当时的想法。’”当球员问他是否认为他们该离开了时（这种情况时有发生），他也会采取同样的态度。“我愿意说：‘嘿，我并不了解所有情况，但是，是的，我想也许是时候了。’因为我觉得这正是我想要听到的，而且我认为我的亲身经历能帮助我更好地应对这种情况。”

Now John is also involved in front-office negotiation, and he uses his experience as a player in that context as well. His ability to understand the players gives him better insight into their interests, their struggles, their fears, and their decision making as a whole. This gives him great advantages when negotiating with agents. He knows their clients and can be better at anticipating their needs and wants. He can also be more effective in framing things for the players from the perspective of the organization so that they can understand the dynamics. In this sense, his empathy can make him more persuasive.

如今，约翰也参与到俱乐部管理层的谈判工作中，并将他作为球员的经验运用到其中。他对球员的理解使他能够更深入地洞察他们的兴趣、困境、担忧以及整体决策过程。这让他与经纪人谈判时拥有巨大的优势。他了解他们的客户，因此能够更好地预判他们的需求和愿望。他也能更有效地从俱乐部的角度出发，向球员解释情况，帮助他们理解其中的运作机制。从这个意义上讲，他的同理心使他更具说服力。

Leaving something on the table

桌上留点东西

For weeks in 2015, various governments of the world met in Switzerland to solve a stubborn, decadelong stalemate over Iran’s nuclear weapons program wherein they ultimately agreed to lift sanctions in return for Iran making concessions to their nuclear program. Many Americans criticized the agreement, feeling that the United States hadn’t been tough enough, that we hadn’t gotten enough for ourselves out of the deal. Years later, Mohammad Javad Zarif, foreign minister of Iran, made the point that no one was entirely happy with the deal—that’s how they knew it was a good deal. “I never believed in zero-sum games,” Zarif told CNN’s Fareed Zakaria. “We reached a deal that nobody likes. And it’s good. Because no good deal is a perfect deal. Because you cannot have a perfect deal for both sides. You need to have a deal that is less than perfect so that both sides can reach an understanding . . . it doesn’t have all the things that we wanted in the deal. It doesn’t have everything that the U.S. wanted in the deal.”

2015年，世界各国政府在瑞士举行了数周会谈，试图解决伊朗核武器计划长达十年的僵局。最终，各方同意解除对伊朗的制裁，以换取伊朗对其核计划做出让步。许多美国人批评这项协议，认为美国不够强硬，没有从中获得足够的利益。多年后，伊朗外交部长穆罕默德·贾瓦德·扎里夫指出，没有人对这项协议完全满意——正因如此，他们才知道这是一项好协议。“我从不相信零和博弈，”扎里夫在接受CNN记者法里德·扎卡利亚采访时说道。 “我们达成了一项谁都不满意的协议。但这很好。因为没有完美的协议，就谈不上好协议。你不可能达成一项对双方都完美的协议。你需要达成一项不完美的协议，这样双方才能达成共识……它并没有包含我们想要的所有内容，也没有包含美国想要的所有内容。”

According to a BBC documentary, the environment of the negotiations was more like a dormitory than a summit, where everyone stayed in the same hotel and worked all hours of the day and night against deadlines that came and went. The lead U.S. negotiator, Wendy Sherman, talked about how they sometimes dined with the Iranians, and how important it was to build the relationships. She also talked of how she and Iran’s lead negotiator both became grandparents during the course of the negotiations and showed each other videos of their grandchildren. They were human beings to each other, but that didn’t mean they weren’t tough, too. “He had a responsibility to the national interests of his country, and I had a responsibility to the national interest of my country,” she said.

据BBC纪录片报道，谈判环境与其说是峰会，不如说更像宿舍，所有人都住在同一家酒店，日夜不停地工作，应对那些一去不复返的最后期限。美国首席谈判代表温迪·舍曼谈到，他们有时会与伊朗人共进晚餐，并强调建立关系的重要性。她还提到，在谈判期间，她和伊朗首席谈判代表都荣升祖父母，并互相分享孙辈的视频。他们彼此之间展现出人性的一面，但这并不意味着他们不强硬。“他要对国家利益负责，我也要对国家利益负责，”她说。

Harnessing the power of empathy often means leaving something on the table, because you try to understand what the other side is dealing with as best you can, and you know what they can sell and what they can’t. You make concessions, which isn’t about giving ground but more about problem solving: You give up something that’s less important to you in order to get something that’s more important to you. Making concessions well requires knowing your interest well, as well as really understanding your counterpart’s, so that you know what to offer as a concession that will be meaningful.

运用同理心往往意味着有所取舍，因为你需要尽力理解对方的处境，了解他们能提供什么，不能提供什么。你需要做出让步，但这并非意味着退让，而是为了解决问题：放弃对你而言不那么重要的东西，以换取对你而言更重要的东西。要想做出有效的让步，你需要充分了解自身的利益，同时也要真正理解对方的利益，这样才能做出真正有意义的让步。

The practice of leaving something on the table is also known as win-win negotiating, but I’ve always been wary of that moniker because it can be misleading: win-win implies that everyone gets their way, and that’s not the case. Rather, win-win means that both parties leave the negotiation feeling better off than they were before they started talking. It may not mean they both got everything they wanted, but they are now more likely to have met their most important interests while conceding things that were not as relevant.

这种有所保留的做法也被称为双赢谈判，但我一直对这个说法持谨慎态度，因为它容易产生误导：双赢意味着每个人都能如愿以偿，但事实并非如此。更确切地说，双赢意味着双方在谈判结束后都感觉比谈判前更有利。这可能并不意味着双方都得到了所有想要的东西，但他们现在更有可能在满足自身最重要利益的同时，做出一些不那么重要的让步。

In addition, they feel that the negotiation has gone as well as it could have for both parties. Expectations have been managed, such that neither party feels they have come out the loser. Note the use of the word feel . Win-win negotiation relies heavily on emotional intelligence, because you have to be aware of how your counterpart interprets and reacts to whatever twists and turns the negotiation takes—and to how your counterpart interprets even a seemingly “easy” negotiation. When a group of researchers studied reactions to opening offers, they found that when those opening offers were accepted right away, the party who offered it felt less satisfied with the agreement. Could they have done better? Did they not ask for enough?

此外，他们认为谈判对双方来说都进行得相当顺利。双方的预期都得到了有效控制，因此没有一方觉得自己吃了亏。请注意这里使用了“感觉”这个词。双赢谈判非常依赖情商，因为你必须了解对方如何解读和应对谈判过程中出现的各种曲折变化——甚至包括对方如何看待看似“轻松”的谈判。一组研究人员研究了人们对初始报价的反应，他们发现，如果初始报价被立即接受，提出报价的一方会对协议感到不太满意。他们本可以做得更好吗？他们是不是要求得不够？

Years ago, sports agent Bob Woolf told Inc. that he made it a regular practice to leave money on the table. “It’s possible to push the price so far, create such antagonism, that the extra 10% isn’t really worth it. If someone feels you held them up, they’re going to take it out on your business or—if it’s an employee—on you. In my case, they’ll take it out on my client, make him miserable, trade him. Obviously, a negotiation isn’t about only money.” Put another way, you cannot have a satisfying negotiation without empathy, because then how could you know that the other side truly feels like they’ve won too?

多年前，体育经纪人鲍勃·伍尔夫告诉《Inc.》杂志，他经常会故意让出一些钱。“价格可能会被压得太高，激起对方的敌意，以至于多出来的10%其实并不值得。如果有人觉得你占了他们的便宜，他们就会迁怒于你的公司，或者——如果是你的雇员——迁怒于你。就我而言，他们会迁怒于我的客户，让他痛苦不堪，甚至把他交易出去。显然，谈判不仅仅是关于钱。”换句话说，如果没有同理心，谈判就无法令人满意，因为那样你又怎么能确定对方也真心觉得他们赢了呢？

Amy Voloshin, cofounder of Printfresh Studio and the Voloshin clothing line, is a rising star in the world of fashion and textiles. In the course of growing her business, she said she realized that “your best-case scenario is where everyone walks away happy.” When she is doing salary negotiations, she said, “I can’t just send [the candidate] an email. Knowing more about where they’re coming from makes it so much easier. Maybe there’s a cap to the salary we’re offering, but maybe being paid 50k instead of 49k is huge.” They’re going to be part of her team, she said, and she wants them to walk away feeling like their wants were met and that they’re valued. Similarly, Amy has noticed that when they get bids in from vendors, the male-owned firms tend to price themselves higher than female-owned firms. So if they get a quote in from a female-owned firm that’s reasonable, while Amy’s husband and cofounder would say “always negotiate,” Amy disagrees. “His natural tendency is to ask for a better price whereas I’m more apt to say it’s a reasonable price.” She knows, in her ability to relate to their perspective, that the women are offering what they can do the job for without being squeezed. She doesn’t want them to feel underpaid for the job, because then no one wins.

Amy Voloshin是Printfresh Studio和Voloshin服装品牌的联合创始人，也是时尚和纺织界冉冉升起的新星。在发展业务的过程中，她意识到“最好的结果就是每个人都满意而归”。她说，在进行薪资谈判时，“我不能只是给候选人发一封邮件。了解他们的背景会让谈判变得容易得多。也许我们提供的薪资有上限，但5万美元而不是4.9万美元对他们来说意义重大。” 她说，他们将成为她团队的一员，她希望他们离开时感到自己的需求得到了满足，并且自己受到了重视。同样，Amy注意到，当收到供应商的报价时，男性拥有的公司往往比女性拥有的公司定价更高。因此，如果收到一家女性拥有的公司的合理报价，尽管Amy的丈夫兼联合创始人会说“一定要谈判”，但Amy并不认同。 “他总是倾向于要价更高，而我则更倾向于说这个价格很合理。”她能理解她们的处境，知道这些女性给出的价格是她们在不被压榨的情况下所能接受的。她不希望她们觉得自己的报酬过低，因为那样对谁都没有好处。

You haven’t really succeeded if you get the most money out of the negotiation but your counterpart leaves feeling angry, or cheated, or bitter. What about your future working relationship? What about your reputation? There are real costs here, and even if you did exceptionally well in a negotiation, you want to leave your partner feeling that she did, too.

如果你在谈判中争取到了最多的钱，但对方却感到愤怒、被欺骗或心怀怨恨，那么你并没有真正成功。你们未来的工作关系会怎样？你的声誉又会如何？谈判是有代价的，即使你在谈判中表现出色，你也希望对方同样感到满意。

Concessions, made with empathy, not only are good for the long term but can have immediate impact. Charalambos Vlachoutsicos, a professor in Athens, Greece, believes that the use of empathy saved his business. As he tells it in an article for the Harvard Business Review , his company, which was in the business of reselling electrical fixtures, got a quote for the fixtures from a company in India. They then offered the fixtures to their customers for a good price based on that quote. The problem was, the Indian company then said they couldn’t honor the quote—in fact, the actual cost was 40 percent higher . Vlachoutsicos’s company was in a terrible position. Purchasing the fixtures at the price from the Indian company would be a huge loss for them; on the other hand, telling their customers “Sorry, it’s actually a lot more than we originally told you” would ruin their credibility.

以同理心做出的让步不仅有利于长远发展，还能产生立竿见影的效果。希腊雅典的教授查拉兰博斯·弗拉乔西科斯 (Charalambos Vlachoutsicos) 认为，正是同理心挽救了他的公司。正如他在《哈佛商业评论》的一篇文章中所述，他的公司从事电器设备转售业务，并从一家印度公司获得了报价。随后，他们根据该报价以优惠价格向客户提供了这些设备。然而，问题在于，这家印度公司随后表示无法兑现报价——实际上，实际成本要高出40%。弗拉乔西科斯的公司陷入了进退两难的境地。如果按印度公司的价格购买这些设备，将会造成巨大的损失；而如果告诉客户“抱歉，实际价格比我们最初告知的要高得多”，则会严重损害公司的信誉。

What were the options? Obviously, one was to scream and shout at the Indian company, which happened. (And got them nowhere.) A lawsuit could have been another option, but international litigation is rarely desirable. Vlachoutsicos chose to pursue a course of understanding and empathy, which he believed would help them work toward a solution they could all live with. He flew to meet with the Indian company in person and used all of the open-minded approaches I covered in the last chapter. He asked them what had happened to make them change their quote, and when they told him that it was an error in their accounting department about the cost of the materials, he realized that they really didn’t have any room to budge. He also realized the Indian company didn’t recognize what a big loss this screwed-up quote represented for Vlachoutsicos’s company. Together, they talked through all of the ramifications, and also the possibilities if they could make the deal work somehow. Not only would this Indian company be able to stay in the Greek market—something that surely would not happen were the whole deal to fall apart—but it was an opportunity for expansion into other European markets. They could look at the deal differently, less as a one-off and more as an investment. Ultimately they came to an arrangement where Vlachoutsicos’s company would pay 10 percent more than the quoted price and thereby break even. According to Vlachoutsicos, “the main factor for this successful outcome was the fact that we had genuinely tried to put ourselves in their shoes and realized the big financial loss they would suffer. Our arguments for reducing the price back to where it had been were not based on our interests but rather on an objective analysis of the risks and opportunities they faced.” In other words, Vlachoutsicos framed the negotiation based on the Indian company’s interests. “Moreover,” he wrote, “the fact that we did not actually make a profit at the new price was a face-saver for the Indian company as it further demonstrated that both sides were making a sacrifice.”

有哪些选择？显然，其中之一是对着那家印度公司大吼大叫，而他们也确实这么做了。（但毫无效果。）提起诉讼或许是另一个选择，但国际诉讼通常并非理想之选。弗拉赫茨科斯选择采取理解和同理心的方式，他相信这有助于双方找到一个都能接受的解决方案。他亲自飞往印度与那家公司会面，并运用了我在上一章中提到的所有开放心态的方法。他询问对方更改报价的原因，当对方告诉他，是会计部门在材料成本上出了错时，他意识到对方确实没有让步的余地。他也意识到，那家印度公司并没有意识到这份错误的报价对弗拉赫茨科斯的公司来说意味着什么巨大的损失。他们一起探讨了所有可能的影响，以及如果能设法促成这笔交易的可能性。这家印度公司不仅能够继续留在希腊市场——如果交易彻底失败，这肯定是不可能的——而且还有机会拓展到其他欧洲市场。他们可以换个角度看待这笔交易，不再将其视为一次性交易，而是将其视为一项投资。最终，双方达成协议，Vlachoutsicos 的公司支付的价格比报价高出 10%，从而实现收支平衡。Vlachoutsicos 表示：“促成这一成功的关键因素在于，我们真正设身处地地为他们着想，意识到他们将遭受巨大的经济损失。我们要求将价格降回原价的理由并非出于自身利益，而是基于对他们面临的风险和机遇的客观分析。”换句话说，Vlachoutsicos 从印度公司的利益出发构建了谈判框架。他写道：“此外，我们最终没有在新价格下盈利，这实际上也为印度公司挽回了颜面，因为它进一步表明双方都做出了牺牲。”

Empathy is simply too valuable to the toolbox of a negotiator—be it a hostage negotiator or a politician like President Obama—to keep its bad rap. My hope is that I never again have a student say, “Professor, I’m not cut out for negotiation because I’m too empathetic.” Nope. As long as you are turning your empathy on yourself, too, and looking out for your interests, you should own that empathy for all you can. Better still, use it.

同理心对于谈判者来说至关重要——无论是人质谈判专家还是像奥巴马总统那样的政治家——它不应该继续背负恶名。我希望以后再也不会有学生说：“教授，我不适合谈判，因为我太有同理心了。” 不，绝对不行。只要你也能善待自己，维护自身利益，就应该充分利用你的同理心。更重要的是，要善用它。

#↩

CHAPTER 7

第七章

wherever you are, be there fully

无论身在何处，都要全身心投入。

When I first started teaching, I didn’t think as much about how I would get my points across because my brain was fully occupied with what I needed to say. I also had my fair share of lesson plans from which I was not willing to deviate. Now that I’ve been teaching for fifteen years, I’ve let go of all of the rigid rules I set for myself in favor of just being in the moment with my class, and it’s shocking to me what it’s opened up. I notice everything about my students. In a class of thirty-six or forty-eight students, I notice if someone who is usually smiling isn’t. I notice if someone is checking their phone (which they shouldn’t be—more on that later). I notice if a student feels uncomfortable or anxious. I find that I’m now able to be incredibly present, curious, and laser-focused on my students at any given moment. I walk into a classroom and immediately take inventory of the mood and energy in the room. I can sense where my students are, mentally and emotionally. For the next three hours, I am only there, in the presence of my students, and give little thought to anything outside the classroom no matter what baggage I was carrying prior to walking in. I leave it all at the door. And I’ve been told again and again that this presence—some would say intensity—is what makes my classes impactful.

刚开始教书的时候，我没怎么考虑如何把观点表达清楚，因为我的脑子里全是需要讲的内容。我也有很多教案，而且不愿意随意更改。现在教了十五年书，我放弃了所有给自己设定的死板规则，转而全身心地投入到课堂中，这让我大吃一惊。我能注意到学生的一切。在一个三十六或四十八人的班级里，我会注意到平时总是面带微笑的学生是否突然不笑了。我会注意到有人在看手机（他们不应该这样做——稍后会详细解释）。我会注意到学生是否感到不自在或焦虑。我发现自己现在能够全神贯注、充满好奇心，并且时刻关注着我的学生。我走进教室，立刻就能感受到教室里的气氛和能量。我能感受到学生们的心理和情绪状态。接下来的三个小时，我全身心投入到课堂中，与学生们在一起，几乎不去想任何与课堂之外的事情，无论走进教室前我背负着怎样的包袱。我把一切都留在门外。我一次又一次地听到人们说，正是这种专注——有些人甚至会说是投入——让我的课如此精彩。

I’m not a meditation expert or a yogi by any stretch (no pun intended) and can more likely be found taking a SoulCycle class or sprinting through a busy airport than sitting on a yoga mat. But I firmly believe that cultivating presence is one of the best things we can do to find satisfaction in our day-to-day experiences, improve our relationships, and succeed in negotiations. You cannot be open-minded or empathetic without presence, because the three are so closely intertwined. When we are distracted, we are unable to notice people, emotions, reactions, and our surroundings. When we’re distracted we get our information not in totality but through a filter. This is detrimental in negotiation, because negotiation relies on the art of noticing everything .

我绝非冥想专家或瑜伽修行者（绝非双关），比起坐在瑜伽垫上，我更可能出现在动感单车课上或在熙熙攘攘的机场里奔跑。但我坚信，培养专注力是我们获得日常满足感、改善人际关系以及在谈判中取得成功的最佳途径之一。没有专注力，你就无法做到开放包容或感同身受，因为这三者密不可分。当我们分心时，我们就无法注意到他人、情绪、反应以及周围环境。当我们分心时，我们获取的信息并非全然完整，而是经过了过滤。这在谈判中尤其不利，因为谈判依赖于对一切事物的敏锐观察。

Without being present, you are unable to tap into your emotional intelligence, or EQ, as it’s often called, and truly understand the state of mind of your counterpart. This emotional intelligence is a superpower in a negotiation, and distraction is like kryptonite. Sometimes the most important information someone tells you is what they aren’t saying at all. A smile, a frown, shifting uncomfortably in their seat, nodding yes when they are saying no: You have to be fully present to capture these nuanced cues as part of the big picture.

如果你无法全神贯注，就无法运用情商（EQ），也无法真正理解对方的心理状态。情商在谈判中至关重要，而分心则如同氪星石一般致命。有时，对方传递的最重要信息恰恰是他们没有说出口的那些。一个微笑、一个皱眉、在座位上不安地挪动身子、明明说了“不”却点头同意：你必须全神贯注才能捕捉到这些细微的信号，从而把握全局。

Without being present, you cannot recognize when you’re becoming tense, or nervous, or angry. Without being present you don’t know when to take that break to calm your nervous system so that you don’t say something you regret and possibly blow the deal. Without being present, you may not be aware of signals that your body is bringing into the conversation of its own accord . . . that you’re nervously tapping your pen, that your voice is sharp, that your face is flushed.

如果你无法全神贯注，就无法察觉自己何时变得紧张、焦虑或愤怒。如果你无法全神贯注，就不知道何时该停下来，平复一下自己的情绪，以免说出让自己后悔的话，甚至搞砸交易。如果你无法全神贯注，就可能无法意识到身体在对话中自发发出的信号……比如你紧张地敲着笔，你的声音变得尖锐，你的脸颊泛红。

Ambassador Wendy Sherman negotiated on behalf of the United States at the highest levels, and says she noticed everything about her counterpart, Iranian foreign minister Javad Zarif. “Over time I learned to tell which of Zarif’s dramatic turns were for effect and which meant he was truly upset,” she wrote in her book about the experience, “and thus whether I should strike a conciliatory tone by addressing him as ‘Javad’ or call him ‘Minister,’ by which he would know that I was ticked off and not buying his dramatics.”

温迪·舍曼大使曾代表美国与伊朗最高层进行谈判，她说她注意到了伊朗外长扎里夫的一切。“随着时间的推移，我学会了分辨扎里夫哪些夸张的举动是为了博取眼球，哪些是真的生气了，”她在回忆这段经历的书中写道，“因此，我才能判断我应该用‘贾瓦德’来缓和语气，还是应该称呼他‘部长’，让他知道我生气了，不相信他的表演。”

It’s powerful to notice that glance, that smile, that uncomfortable movement. As negotiation scholar Max Bazerman put it, “What’s in front of you is rarely all there is.” So you have to learn to truly see . My students who are distracted lose information, so they can’t gain leverage. But to focus takes concentration and stamina. Most people have an attention span of approximately eight seconds, illustrating that we’re more distractible than goldfish. We don’t give enough credence to the notion that being present is hard .

注意到那个眼神、那个微笑、那个不自在的动作，意义非凡。正如谈判学者马克斯·巴泽曼所说：“你眼前所见的，往往并非全部。” 所以你必须学会真正地观察。我的学生如果注意力不集中，就会丢失信息，也就无法获得优势。但集中注意力需要专注力和耐力。大多数人的注意力持续时间大约只有八秒，这说明我们比金鱼更容易分心。我们往往低估了“全神贯注”的难度。

It’s only gotten harder, thanks to a hyperconnected world where multitasking is the de facto way of being. We don’t connect as meaningfully with one another when we’re texting over a meal or doing two things at once in any context. We miss the cues from our friends and loved ones that might tell us more about their state of mind.

如今，在高度互联的世界里，一心多用已成为常态，这让沟通变得更加困难。当我们一边吃饭一边发短信，或者在任何情况下同时做两件事时，我们很难与他人建立真正有意义的联系。我们会错过来自朋友和爱人的蛛丝马迹，而这些线索本可以让我们更深入地了解他们的内心状态。

As with so many other companies, Mary Ellen Slayter’s marketing company does a lot of its business over email. She said, “A lot of what I do is based on having to read people over the phone and reading intent in emails. Any chance I get to see someone in person, especially the higher the stakes it is, I go. I try to get as much information and I don’t look at my phone and I don’t do other things. I need to take it in . . . because most of the decisions [my clients make], even though they’re big corporate decisions, they’re ultimately personal decisions and I need the best read on their emotional state as I can get.”

和许多其他公司一样，玛丽·艾伦·斯莱特的营销公司也主要通过电子邮件开展业务。她说：“我的很多工作都依赖于通过电话和电子邮件来了解客户的意图。只要有机会与客户见面，尤其是在事关重大的情况下，我都会去。我会尽可能多地收集信息，期间不看手机，也不做其他事情。我需要全神贯注……因为我的客户做出的大多数决定，即使是重大的企业决策，最终也是个人决策，我需要尽可能准确地了解他们的情绪状态。”

Teaching this in my classes has reinforced presence for me, and I work at it every day. When I teach, I try to send a message to my students that there is no place more important than where I am at that moment and no conversation more critical than the one I am having. I’ve noticed that as a result, I’m better able to meet my students where they are, to respond to them, and to couch the information in a way that I know they will hear it. I believe that level of presence is the ultimate sign of respect and allows me to demand the same in return.

在课堂上教授这一点，让我更加注重临场感，我每天都在努力践行。教学时，我试图向学生传达这样的信息：此刻我身处何处，没有什么比这更重要；此刻我正在进行的对话，也没有什么比这更重要。我发现，这样做能让我更好地理解学生的处境，回应他们的提问，并以他们能够理解的方式传递信息。我相信，这种临场感是对学生最高的尊重，也让我有理由要求他们给予同样的尊重。

I’ve also made a point of practicing presence on the journey to and from the classroom. I ride in Ubers and taxis all the time, and one goal I’ve set is to keep my phone in my bag, and my mind and body in the present for the duration of the journey. In full disclosure, this goal actually began because I wanted to raise my rating from Uber drivers, and I learned they hate it when riders spend the whole time either talking on or looking at their phones. I know, the competitive side of me rears its head more often than not. But what started as a game turned into a breakthrough. I found I love my time on the road. I’ll chat with the drivers about where they’re from and what their lives are like. I’ll look out the window, and often notice buildings I’ve never noticed before. I once asked my driver if a building in my neighborhood was new. Turns out I’d just not looked at it before. I’ve started asking the drivers to take a scenic route to get to the train station, so that in between rushing to get out of the house and rushing through the train station, I have time to process, transition, and just stare out the window. Should someone try to reach me during this time, I won’t answer my phone, or I’ll tell them I can’t talk because I’m rushing to catch my train. It’s partly true—I am en route to Union Station. But the full truth is that I treasure this period of just being.

我也特意练习在上下学的路上保持专注。我经常乘坐优步和出租车，我给自己定下的一个目标就是把手机放在包里，让身心在整个旅程中都专注于当下。坦白说，这个目标最初是为了提高优步司机的评分，我了解到他们很讨厌乘客在车上一直打电话或看手机。我知道，我好胜的一面总是时不时地冒出来。但这个最初只是个小游戏的事情，却意外地带来了突破。我发现我很享受这段旅程。我会和司机们聊聊他们来自哪里，他们的生活是什么样的。我会看看窗外，经常会注意到一些以前从未注意过的建筑。有一次，我问司机我家附近的一栋楼是不是新建的。结果发现，原来是我以前没注意到它。我开始要求司机们绕道风景优美的路线去火车站，这样，在匆忙出门和匆匆穿过火车站的间隙，我就可以有时间思考、调整状态，然后静静地望着窗外。如果有人在这段时间联系我，我不会接电话，或者我会告诉他们我没空说话，因为我正赶着去搭火车。这部分是真的——我确实在去联合车站的路上。但真正的原因是，我珍惜这段独处的时光。

I’ve adopted a similar practice on airplanes. Instead of immediately opening my computer or taking out my book, I look out the window whenever there’s a sunrise or a sunset. The fact that I fly all the time has gone from being an annoyance to being a gift. When I look out the window of an airplane, I appreciate it, I find peace in it, and I find gratitude in it. People around me must think it’s my first time flying, because I’m so captured by the scenery outside. Little do they know I’ve got elite status on three different airlines and Amtrak. I’m just captivated because I’ve learned to cultivate presence and gratitude for the moments of stillness in an otherwise crazy busy life.

我在飞机上也养成了类似的习惯。与其立刻打开电脑或拿出书，不如在日出日落时分欣赏窗外的景色。频繁飞行这件事，曾经让我感到烦恼，如今却成了一种恩赐。当我望向飞机窗外时，我心生感激，从中找到平静，并心怀感恩。周围的人一定以为我是第一次坐飞机，因为我完全沉浸在窗外的风景中。他们不知道的是，我可是三家航空公司和美国铁路公司（Amtrak）的高级会员。我之所以如此着迷，是因为我学会了在忙碌不堪的生活中，培养对静谧时刻的觉察和感恩之心。

I was so grateful for this habit when, after a recent week of rushing around nonstop, I boarded a flight to teach a class in Providence. When the plane doors shut and I collected myself and took a breath, I almost immediately realized that I wasn’t supposed to teach in Providence that day. Had I not stopped to take that breath but immediately plowed into emails, I might not have recognized my mistake at all and would have gone all the way to the class site.

最近一周我忙得不可开交，登机去普罗维登斯上课。飞机舱门关上后，我深吸一口气，才意识到自己那天不应该去普罗维登斯。幸亏我养成了这个习惯。如果我当时没有停下来喘口气，而是立刻埋头处理邮件，可能根本不会意识到自己的错误，就真的到了上课地点。

What could have been a day filled with frustration and self-blaming was, in actuality, a really nice day. I chalked it up to a lesson—an expensive one, but still—about how I need to get off the hamster wheel more often and slow down. I considered the time a gift to myself. I realized that being angry and frustrated wouldn’t help. I let the mistake go and calmly talked to the gate agents in Providence, who immediately put me on the next flight out without hesitation and gave me an upgraded seat as well. I didn’t even try to access the flights’ wireless service. Instead I spent the time to and from Providence reading magazines that I never get a chance to read, planning my week, sipping drinks, and enjoying a few hours to reset. It was a beautiful day to fly, and I spent a good part of the time just looking out the window.

原本可能充满挫败感和自责的一天，实际上却过得非常愉快。我把它当作一次教训——虽然代价不菲，但总算吸取了教训——让我明白自己需要更频繁地从忙碌的生活中抽身出来，放慢脚步。我把这段时间当作送给自己的礼物。我意识到生气和沮丧于事无补。我放下了之前的失误，冷静地与普罗维登斯机场的登机口工作人员交谈，他们毫不犹豫地帮我安排了下一班航班，还给我升了座位。我甚至都没尝试使用飞机上的无线网络。相反，在往返普罗维登斯的这段时间里，我读着平时没时间看的杂志，计划着接下来的一周，啜饮着饮料，享受着几个小时的放松时光。那天天气晴朗，非常适合飞行，我花了很多时间欣赏窗外的风景。

In this chapter, I cover why it’s hard to be present, and why it’s so important. Yes, technology is a huge distractor, and I’ll get into that, but the smartphone is not the only difficulty we face. It turns out that it is very difficult to listen—and I mean really listen—without thinking about what you are going to say next, or without any sort of agenda, and yet true presence requires this mindful listening. It’s also difficult to be mindful about not just what your words are communicating but what your body language is projecting and what story your facial expressions are revealing. Often they are not in sync. Finally, I’ll cover ways to plan for and manage your emotions in a negotiation, whether it’s a heated discussion with a family member or a business deal that keeps you up at night.

在本章中，我将探讨为什么保持专注如此困难，以及它为何如此重要。没错，科技是一个巨大的干扰因素，这一点我稍后会详细阐述，但智能手机并非我们面临的唯一难题。事实证明，真正做到倾听——我指的是全神贯注地倾听——而不去思考自己接下来要说什么，或者不带任何预设，是非常困难的。然而，真正的专注恰恰需要这种用心倾听。此外，我们不仅要关注言语传递的信息，还要关注肢体语言和面部表情所展现的信息，这同样很难做到。通常情况下，这些信息并不一致。最后，我将探讨如何在谈判中规划和管理自己的情绪，无论是与家人激烈的争论，还是让你夜不能寐的商业交易。

Free to be phone-free

可以自由自在地摆脱手机的束缚

When the Obamas hosted their final party at the White House, I was fortunate enough to get an invitation, and I brought my oldest nephew as my plus-one. When we got to the security check-in, my nephew learned that we would have to leave our phones before we entered. My nephew was distraught, to say the least. “This is the worst thing ever,” he said. “No one will believe I was here.” Ever the realist, I pointed out there wasn’t really anything he could do about it. So we took a quick photo where we stood outside, left our phones behind, and went in.

奥巴马夫妇在白宫举办最后一次派对时，我有幸受邀参加，并带上了我的大侄子。到了安检处，侄子才知道我们必须在进入白宫前寄存手机。他当时非常沮丧，简直难以置信。“这太糟糕了，”他说，“没人会相信我来过这里。” 我一向很现实，就告诉他，他对此也无能为力。于是，我们在外面拍了张合影，寄存了手机，然后就进去了。

It was a spectacular, star-studded evening. The evening started with performances from Usher, the Roots, De La Soul, Jill Scott, and others. The afterparty felt otherworldly, where the likes of Dave Chappelle and Bradley Cooper were just hanging out in the comfort of their peers and free from cell phones and paparazzi. Even though my nephew fought it at first because he was being uncharacteristically shy, I introduced him to Dave Chappelle and they had the chance to share their mutual admiration for the Golden State Warriors. I was for sure up for the Aunt of the Year Award. Music blasted in the background, food and drink were abundant, and we all enjoyed what we knew was one of the highlights of our lives. We didn’t leave until after two a.m. On the way home, my nephew said, “I’m so glad I couldn’t use my phone. I just had one of the best nights of my life and I actually got to experience it.”

那是一个精彩绝伦、星光熠熠的夜晚。当晚以亚瑟小子、The Roots乐队、De La Soul乐队、吉尔·斯科特等人的精彩表演拉开序幕。派对结束后，气氛更是如同另一个世界，像戴夫·查普尔和布莱德利·库珀这样的明星们与朋友们轻松自在地聚会，远离手机和狗仔队的干扰。虽然我侄子一开始有些抗拒，因为他一反常态地害羞，但我还是把他介绍给了戴夫·查普尔，他们有机会分享了对金州勇士队的共同热爱。我肯定要角逐年度最佳姑姑奖了。现场音乐震耳欲聋，美食美酒应有尽有，我们都尽情享受着这注定是我们人生中最美好的回忆之一。我们一直玩到凌晨两点多才离开。回家的路上，我侄子说：“我真庆幸没用手机。我刚刚度过了人生中最棒的夜晚之一，而且我真的亲身经历了这一切。”

We’re so caught up in Instagram that we’re pulled away from the actual moment. We think we’re experiencing it, but we’re somewhere else, viewing it through a filter. Because my nephew didn’t have his phone, he got to see the performances, hear the music, and really take in that once-in-a-lifetime event. For the first time in a long time, he felt what it was like to be fully present. Although I’m an avid social media user as well, I much prefer “post-a-gram” to Instagram, where I take a few pictures to capture a moment and, later, when I have time and am reliving the memory, I post on Instagram or Facebook. It’s a walk down memory lane as opposed to robbing myself of the joy of that memory in that moment.

我们太沉迷于Instagram，以至于错过了当下。我们以为自己身临其境，其实心不在焉，透过滤镜观看。因为我侄子没带手机，他才能看到演出，听到音乐，真正地感受这千载难逢的盛事。他很久以来第一次体会到全然投入当下的感觉。虽然我也是社交媒体的忠实用户，但我更喜欢“post-a-gram”（在Instagram上发布照片），而不是Instagram。我会先拍几张照片记录瞬间，之后等有时间重温这段回忆时，再发布到Instagram或Facebook上。这就像一次重温旧时光的旅程，而不是在当下就剥夺自己享受回忆的乐趣。

My classes are technology-free zones. No laptops, no phones, no tablets, and even no smart watches. I think of my classroom as a laboratory where we emulate the behaviors that we should practice in any negotiation outside the classroom. Therefore, I want my students to experience being present. If your phone is in your line of sight, vibrating in your pocket, or even if you’re immersed in typing notes on what the other party is saying, you’re probably missing cues that being more aware would provide you. Research backs me up on this: A 2017 study showed that the mere presence of your phone is distracting—even if you’re not paying attention to it, even if it’s in airplane mode, even if it’s powered off. Because we now rely on our phones for so much, it’s like they’re calling to us: “Pick me up! Just one quick look!” You may be listening with your ears, but you’re not really hearing. Or maybe you’re hearing, but you’re not gaining valuable information by watching. Worse yet, you might be signaling to the other party that you don’t care what they’re saying.

我的课堂是无科技区域。不准使用笔记本电脑、手机、平板电脑，甚至连智能手表也不行。我把课堂看作一个实验室，在这里我们可以模拟在课堂外任何谈判中都应该练习的行为。因此，我希望我的学生体验到专注当下。如果你的手机在你视线范围内，在口袋里震动，或者你正忙着记笔记，记录对方的发言，你很可能会错过一些原本可以通过更专注的观察获得的线索。研究也支持我的观点：2017年的一项研究表明，手机的存在本身就会分散注意力——即使你没有在看它，即使它处于飞行模式，即使它已经关机。因为我们现在太依赖手机了，它们就像在召唤我们：“拿起我！就看一眼！”你可能在用耳朵听，但你并没有真正听进去。或者你可能听到了，但你并没有通过观察获得有价值的信息。更糟糕的是，你可能是在向对方发出信号：你根本不在乎他们说什么。

Some of my students push back. Those in the Goldman Sachs 10,000 Small Businesses classes are accustomed to being glued to their phones 24/7. Since they are running a business while attending the program, they multitask all the time—they feel they have to. Some students will be surreptitious, checking their phones when they think I’m not looking. But in part because I’ve completely separated myself from all of my devices, I notice everything , so they always get caught. It doesn’t matter how many times I say it, there’s rarely a time when a student doesn’t reach for their phone or forgets to put it away. Sometimes I feel like this is the hardest thing I teach!

有些学生会反抗。参加高盛“万家小企业”课程的学生已经习惯了24小时不离手机。因为他们一边经营自己的生意一边上课，所以总是同时处理多项任务——他们觉得必须这样做。有些学生会偷偷摸摸地查看手机，以为我没注意。但部分原因是我自己完全远离了所有电子设备，所以我能注意到他们的一举一动，所以他们总是会被抓到。不管我讲多少遍，几乎没有学生能忍住不去拿手机或者忘记收起来。有时候我觉得这是我教过的最难的东西！

Other students nod when I make the request and say they get it. They’ve heard a lot about mindfulness, maybe even read some articles and studies. But they are as plugged in to their phones as everyone else. A 2018 study of two thousand Americans showed that they checked their phones an average of every twelve minutes while on vacation . Feel the sun, hear the surf, breathe in the wind, then check your email. There’s something wrong with this picture, and we all know it. My students are willing to give putting their phones down a try, though, because intellectually they buy in. But they don’t fully buy in until they see what a difference presence makes for themselves.

当我提出这个要求时，其他学生点头表示理解。他们听说过很多关于正念的知识，甚至可能读过一些文章和研究。但他们和其他人一样，都离不开手机。2018 年一项针对两千名美国人的研究表明，他们在度假期间平均每十二分钟就会查看一次手机。感受阳光，聆听海浪声，呼吸微风，然后查看邮件。这显然有问题，我们都知道。我的学生们愿意尝试放下手机，因为他们在理智上认同正念。但只有当他们亲身感受到专注当下带来的改变时，他们才会真正接受它。

“I have such a major problem with my phone,” said my student James, for whom the no-cell-phone rule was challenging. He feels he needs to always be in contact with his office. “It causes me anxiety because I’m so super connected. It makes me half-present in connections with human beings.” He has two children, ages three and six, and he said that when he takes them to the park, “They’ll play on the playground and I’m checking my phone and sending emails. And I’m checking things that could wait an hour or two. It’s just such an addiction.” He felt what a difference it made in class when he was forbidden to use his phone, and how he had a different level of engagement with whomever he was talking with. At the same time, maintaining that level of engagement with others was tiring and led him to recognize how his attention span has gone down. “I’m used to being on the phone and bouncing from one thing to the other,” he said, noting that he doesn’t even read anymore.

“我的手机问题太严重了，”我的学生詹姆斯说道，对他来说，禁止使用手机的规定是个挑战。他觉得必须时刻和办公室保持联系。“这让我很焦虑，因为我太依赖手机了。这让我在与人交流时心不在焉。”他有两个孩子，一个三岁，一个六岁。他说，带他们去公园的时候，“他们在游乐场玩耍，而我却在查看手机、回复邮件。有些事情其实可以等一两个小时再处理。这简直是一种瘾。”他感受到，禁止使用手机后，课堂上的变化让他与他人交流时更加专注。但与此同时，保持这种专注度也让他感到疲惫，并意识到自己的注意力持续时间越来越短。“我习惯了玩手机，习惯了在各种事情之间来回切换，”他说道，并指出自己现在甚至都不看书了。

He’s not unusual. Maryanne Wolf is a scientist who has researched reading and the brain and documented her findings first in the book Proust and the Squid , then in Reader, Come Home: The Reading Brain in a Digital World . In the latter she writes, “Perhaps you have already noticed how the quality of your attention has changed the more you read on screens and digital devices. Perhaps you have felt a pang of something subtle that is missing when you seek to immerse yourself in a once favorite book. Like a phantom limb, you remember who you were as a reader, but cannot summon that ‘attentive ghost’ with the joy you once felt in being transported somewhere outside the self to that interior space.”

他并非特例。玛丽安·沃尔夫是一位研究阅读与大脑关系的科学家，她最初在《普鲁斯特与乌贼》一书中记录了她的研究成果，后来又在《读者，回家吧：数字世界的阅读大脑》一书中进行了阐述。在后一本书中，她写道：“或许你已经注意到，随着你在屏幕和电子设备上阅读的时间越来越长，你的注意力质量发生了变化。或许当你试图沉浸在曾经挚爱的书中时，你会感到一种微妙的缺失。就像幻肢一样，你记得自己曾经的阅读状态，但却无法唤起那种‘专注的幽灵’，也无法再像以前那样，带着那种被带离自我、进入内心世界的喜悦，重新体验阅读的乐趣。”

I’ve noticed that it takes me all day to read the newspaper on Sundays. It didn’t use to be that way—I used to read the paper edition of the Sunday New York Times cover to cover in just a couple of hours. I’d be done in plenty of time to watch football for the rest of the day. Now I find that my attention won’t hold for the two hours it used to take—my mind bounces around all over the place—and I’m still reading parts of the paper during the Sunday-night game. It’s not ideal, but I’m grateful that I’m at least aware of it.

我发现现在周日读报纸要花我一整天的时间。以前可不是这样——我以前几个小时就能把《纽约时报》周日版从头到尾读完。读完之后，我还有充足的时间看剩下的足球比赛。现在我发现自己无法像以前那样集中注意力两个小时——我的思绪总是飘忽不定——以至于在周日晚上看球赛的时候，我还在断断续续地读报纸。这当然不是理想的情况，但至少我意识到了这一点，这让我很欣慰。

When it comes to negotiation, the implications of our loss of attention are huge. In an exchange that is so common I can’t even attach it to a specific class or exercise, I’ll debrief a negotiation with my students and it will become clear that some missed key information in the printed case study. There’s a famous negotiation exercise, for instance, that revolves around an orange. There are different adaptations of the exercise—in Roger Fisher’s classic book Getting to Yes , it involves two kids who both want the last orange in the fruit bowl, whereas in other adaptations it involves two companies who want a rare orange to develop lifesaving products. But one party needs only the rind (in the case of the kids, for baking), whereas the other party needs only the pulp. If you read the description of a case too quickly, you can miss this key information.

在谈判中，注意力分散的后果极其严重。有些情况非常普遍，我甚至无法将其与某个具体的课程或练习联系起来。例如，在与学生讨论谈判案例时，我常常会发现他们忽略了书面案例研究中的关键信息。有一个著名的谈判练习，围绕着一个橙子展开。这个练习有不同的版本——在罗杰·费舍尔的经典著作《谈判力》中，是两个孩子都想要果盘里最后一个橙子；而在其他版本中，则是两家公司想要一个稀有橙子来开发救命产品。但其中一方只需要橙皮（在孩子们的例子中，是为了烘焙），而另一方只需要果肉。如果你阅读案例描述的速度太快，就可能错过这些关键信息。

I tell my students who make this mistake: “Why didn’t you just negotiate for the rind? You didn’t need the rest,” to which they argue, “I needed the whole thing. Not just the rind.”

我会告诉犯这种错误的学生：“你为什么不只争取果皮呢？你不需要其他部分。”他们会争辩说：“我需要的是整个东西，不仅仅是果皮。”

“Fourteen years later,” I tease, reminding them how many times I have seen this exercise, “I think I know.”

“十四年后，”我打趣道，提醒他们我已经看过多少次这个练习了，“我想我知道了。”

“No,” they say with complete certainty, “it doesn’t say that on my sheet.” Sometimes, it’s not until I physically circle it for them in pen on their sheet that they see what they missed.

“不，”他们斩钉截铁地说，“我的表格上没写。” 有时候，直到我用笔在他们的表格上圈出来，他们才意识到自己漏掉了什么。

Whatever I say from there on out about presence is taken much more seriously. Little by little, negotiation by negotiation, they see how much being distracted hurts them. And how being distracted is likely the norm, and being present is an exception.

从那以后，我再说什么关于专注的事情，他们都更加认真对待。一点一点地，通过一次次的协商，他们逐渐明白分心对他们的伤害有多大。他们也意识到，分心很可能才是常态，而专注反而是一种例外。

Negotiations are all about relationships and connection. If you believe that’s important and then simultaneously you’re on your phone, or you’re distracted, you’re negating that connection. In Chapter 6, I wrote about how empathy is critical to negotiation. But technology may actually lower empathy, according to research. Sherry Turkle is a research psychologist at MIT and author of Reclaiming Conversation . She says that we learn intimacy and empathy through conversation and through face-to-face interaction. When we’re on our screens instead, we miss out on that. It makes sense. How can we recognize the slight crinkle in a forehead that signals concern if we stop learning to read facial expressions and only read emoticons?

谈判的核心在于关系和联结。如果你认为这一点很重要，却同时还在玩手机或分心，那么你就是在破坏这种联结。我在第六章中写到，同理心对谈判至关重要。但研究表明，科技实际上可能会降低同理心。雪莉·特克尔是麻省理工学院的研究心理学家，也是《重拾对话》一书的作者。她说，我们通过对话和面对面的交流来学习亲密感和同理心。当我们沉迷于屏幕时，就错过了这些。这不难理解。如果我们不再学习解读面部表情，而只关注表情符号，又如何能识别出额头上细微的皱纹所代表的担忧呢？

Mary Ellen Slayter, my Goldman Sachs 10,000 Small Businesses program student whose content marketing company is on fire, took these lessons to heart and felt a huge shift in her negotiations. Although in her preparation she learns as much about who she will be talking to as she can, inevitably there are times when we all have to call an audible and make quick decisions based on the information at hand. Her focus on being present has made her more adept at this. She said she can tell when someone comes into a meeting whether they’re genuinely excited about a project. “I can see in their eyes and in their faces. I can see it in the way they take notes, how they’re shifting . . . is there excitement and joy in the way they’re talking about the project?” In contrast, though, she can tell if someone’s primary emotions are fear and anxiety, and her strategy changes accordingly. “If I get the joy version, we start brainstorming. . . . What is often negotiated out of that are things that were never on the table whatsoever. They haven’t even thought of that, and I can tell they’re game for it so I throw that at them. When I get the anxious person, I actually try to do less. I’ll say, ‘You know, I hear that you’re overwhelmed by all of this. What if we break it down into these pieces?’ I can see when they start to relax a little. The ultimate goal in this conversation is to get to a negotiated agreement on what work we’re going to do and at what price.”

玛丽·艾伦·斯莱特是我在高盛“万家小企业”项目中的学员，她的内容营销公司发展迅猛。她将这些经验铭记于心，并在谈判中取得了巨大的进步。虽然她在准备阶段会尽可能多地了解谈话对象，但不可避免地，我们有时都需要根据手头的信息随机应变，迅速做出决定。她专注于当下，这使她在这方面更加得心应手。她说，她能从一个人走进会议室的那一刻就看出他们是否真的对某个项目充满热情。“我能从他们的眼神和表情中看出端倪。我能从他们记笔记的方式、他们的神态变化中看出……他们谈论项目时是否充满兴奋和喜悦？” 相反，她也能察觉到对方的主要情绪是恐惧和焦虑，并据此调整策略。 “如果对方比较乐观，我们就开始集思广益……通常，我们会从中挖掘出一些之前从未考虑过的内容。他们甚至都没想过这些，但我看得出来他们很乐意接受，所以我就会提出来。如果对方比较焦虑，我反而会尽量少说。我会说：‘我知道你觉得这些事情让你压力很大。要不我们把事情分解成几个部分？’我能看出他们什么时候开始放松下来。这次谈话的最终目标是就我们要做什么工作以及价格达成一致。”

The illusion of transparency

透明的错觉

My friend Samantha worked for a company that was hiring a new manager. Part of the protocol for the interviews was that a team of six employees would sit with the candidate and ask questions, then confer afterward. When Samantha and her colleagues convened to debrief after one such interview, everyone asked Samantha why she disliked the candidate so much.

我的朋友萨曼莎在一家招聘新经理的公司工作。面试流程之一是，由六名员工组成的小组会与候选人面谈，提出问题，然后进行讨论。在一次面试结束后，萨曼莎和同事们聚在一起进行总结时，每个人都问萨曼莎为什么那么不喜欢那位候选人。

“What are you talking about?” she said. “I thought he was fine.”

“你在说什么？”她问道，“我以为他没事。”

“Then why were you glaring at him?”

“那你为什么一直怒视着他？”

“What?” Samantha said. “I wasn’t glaring.”

“什么？”萨曼莎说，“我没有怒视你。”

Her colleagues assured her that yes, she was glaring. They even mimicked her expression. Samantha was horrified.

她的同事们向她保证，没错，她当时确实在怒视别人。他们甚至还模仿了她的表情。萨曼莎感到十分震惊。

“I looked like that ?” she asked. “I was just focusing. That was my listening face.”

“我当时是那个表情吗？”她问。“我当时只是在集中注意力。那是我在认真听的表情。”

As Samantha now saw, her listening face looked much more like a scowl. As leadership author and speaker Carol Kinsey Goman said, “Body language is in the eye of the beholder. It has less to do with your intention and everything to do with its interpretation.” Samantha was caught in what’s called the illusion of transparency : the belief that what someone feels, desires, and intends is crystal clear to others, even though they have done very little to communicate it. There is reality, and then there is perception, and the two are not the same.

萨曼莎这才意识到，她刚才认真倾听的表情，现在看起来更像是怒容。正如领导力作家兼演讲家卡罗尔·金西·戈曼所说：“肢体语言取决于观察者的视角。它与你的意图关系不大，而与你的意图的解读息息相关。”萨曼莎陷入了所谓的“透明错觉”：她误以为一个人的感受、愿望和意图对其他人来说都一目了然，即使他们几乎没有做出任何表达。现实和感知是两回事，二者并不相同。

Some are uncommonly skilled at communicating just what they want to, but for most of us, getting better at it is a lifelong process. There are a few tricks to it, and none are easy.

有些人天生擅长准确表达自己的想法，但对我们大多数人来说，提高沟通能力是一个终身的过程。这其中有一些技巧，但没有一个是容易的。

The first is to be present. You have to be completely aware of your own emotions. You have to be aware of your facial expressions. You have to be aware not just of your words but of the tenor of the other person’s words, the slight changes on their face, so that you know how they are receiving your message.

首先，要全神贯注。你必须完全觉察自己的情绪，觉察自己的面部表情。你不仅要关注自己的言辞，还要关注对方话语的语气，以及他们面部细微的变化，这样你才能知道他们是如何理解你的信息的。

We can also ask for feedback. Samantha’s colleagues teased her about her scowl-face, but she could have asked them for feedback before they had to—and the next time, she did. As soon as she left the next interview she said, “Hey, I was trying to communicate that this is an intense job but without seeming like I’m scary. Do you think I accomplished it? Do you think so-and-so actually understood what I was saying? I want to be better at this. What do you think I might do better next time?” This feedback was relevant for interviews but also for more quotidian meetings she had with her colleagues.

我们也可以寻求反馈。萨曼莎的同事们曾取笑她总是板着脸，但她本可以在他们开口之前就主动征求他们的意见——而下次，她就这么做了。面试结束后，她立刻说道：“嗨，我当时是想表达这份工作压力很大，但又不想显得自己很吓人。你觉得我表达清楚了吗？你觉得某某真的理解我的意思了吗？我想在这方面做得更好。你觉得我下次可以改进哪些方面？”这样的反馈不仅适用于面试，也适用于她与同事的日常会议。

Samantha had a lot of work to do on her communication. If she made a scowl-face when she was in an inconsequential interview, her intensity was much more pronounced when she was in meetings where she really didn’t like someone she was meeting with, or when she felt impatient because the meeting was going on for too long. She was known to tap her pencil on the desk quickly when she felt that someone was speaking unnecessarily, or when she felt the meeting should be over. She was commonly criticized for it and felt frustrated and misunderstood. When a consultant came in to help the entire team with communication, he helped Samantha practice body language that was relaxed, that signaled openness, and that employed even and deep breathing. The consultant had her focus on the speed and volume of her voice and the reception she was getting with others. Samantha began to ask specifically and deliberately for feedback.

萨曼莎在沟通方面还有很多需要改进的地方。如果说在无关紧要的面试中她只是皱着眉头，那么在会议上，当她遇到自己不喜欢的人，或者会议时间过长让她感到不耐烦时，她的情绪就会更加激动。她常常会在觉得有人说话多余，或者觉得会议应该结束的时候，用铅笔快速敲击桌面。她因此经常受到批评，也常常感到沮丧和不被理解。后来，一位顾问来帮助整个团队提升沟通技巧，他指导萨曼莎练习放松的肢体语言，展现开放的态度，并配合均匀深长的呼吸。顾问让她关注自己的语速和音量，以及他人对她说话的反应。萨曼莎开始有针对性地主动寻求反馈。

This kind of nonverbal communication is practiced all the time in the grand national negotiation of politics. In her memoir Becoming , Michelle Obama writes about being called to meet with David Axelrod and Valerie Jarrett during Barack Obama’s first campaign for the presidency. Michelle had been taking a lot of heat from the opposition, who tried to paint Michelle as an angry anarchist. It seemed to be working, and Michelle didn’t get it. She’d been giving the same talk for months and it had seemed to resonate with her crowds. She was bringing authentic emotion and heart into her talk, she felt, but she wasn’t angry . Then Axelrod and Jarrett muted the volume of the recording so they could examine her body language, her facial expressions. “What did I see?” she wrote. “I saw myself speaking with intensity and conviction and never letting up. I always address the tough times many Americans were facing as well as the inequities within our schools and our healthcare system. My face reflected the seriousness of what I believed was at stake, how important the choice that lay before our nation really was. But it was too serious. Too severe, at least given what people were conditioned to expect from a woman. I saw my expression as a stranger might perceive it, especially if it was framed with an unflattering message.”

这种非语言沟通在宏大的国家政治博弈中无处不在。米歇尔·奥巴马在她的回忆录《成为》中写道，在巴拉克·奥巴马第一次竞选总统期间，她被叫去见大卫·阿克塞尔罗德和瓦莱丽·贾勒特。当时，反对派对米歇尔的攻击非常猛烈，他们试图把她描绘成一个愤怒的无政府主义者。这种攻击似乎奏效了，但米歇尔却不明白。几个月来，她一直在重复同样的演讲，而且似乎引起了听众的共鸣。她觉得自己在演讲中倾注了真情实感，但她并不愤怒。然后，阿克塞尔罗德和贾勒特调低了录音音量，以便观察她的肢体语言和面部表情。“我看到了什么？”她写道。 “我看到自己语气坚定、充满激情地讲话，一刻不停。我总是谈到许多美国人面临的困境，以及我们学校和医疗体系中存在的不平等现象。我的表情反映了我认为事关重大的严肃性，以及我们国家面临的选择是多么重要。但这太严肃了。至少考虑到人们对女性的固有印象，我的表情显得过于严厉。我设想，如果换作陌生人，我的表情会是怎样的，尤其是在这种表情被赋予了某种贬损的信息之后。”

A consultant who joined the team advised Michelle Obama to “play to my strengths, and the things I most loved talking about, which was my love for my husband and kids, my connection to working mothers, and my proud Chicago roots,” she said. The consultant recognized, too, that Michelle liked to joke around and insisted that was fine. “ It was okay, in other words, to be myself.”

一位加入团队的顾问建议米歇尔·奥巴马“发挥我的优势，谈论我最喜欢谈论的话题，比如我对丈夫和孩子的爱，我与职业母亲的共鸣，以及我引以为傲的芝加哥根基，”她说。这位顾问也注意到米歇尔喜欢开玩笑，并坚持认为这完全没问题。“换句话说，做我自己就好。”

Passion is powerful. To show others what drives you and motivates you can be very persuasive if it’s well placed in a speech or a negotiation. Passion can be contagious, but it can also be misconstrued. If not well communicated, it can appear overbearing, aggressive, and unreasonable. This doesn’t mean that women don’t have the right to act angry; of course they do, and in other speeches when Michelle Obama wanted to convey her anger, she did. Rather, we all just need to understand how others perceive our communication, and think hard about whether the audience is getting the message intended. Striking the right balance is an art. I’m typically in favor of showing emotion in a negotiation, especially since I value human connections and honest exchange of information. But channeling our emotions effectively can be the difference between success and failure in communicating your ideas. Perception is everything and you have to understand how your words and expressions are received in order to be able to connect, deliver, influence, and impress.

激情的力量不容小觑。在演讲或谈判中，巧妙地展现你的动力和动机，能起到极强的说服力。激情具有感染力，但也容易被误解。如果表达不当，激情可能会显得专横跋扈、咄咄逼人，甚至不讲道理。但这并不意味着女性没有权利表达愤怒；她们当然有，米歇尔·奥巴马在其他演讲中也曾如此，表达过她的愤怒。关键在于，我们都需要理解他人如何看待我们的沟通方式，并认真思考听众是否真正理解了我们想要传达的信息。把握好分寸是一门艺术。我通常赞成在谈判中展现情感，尤其是我珍视人际关系和坦诚的信息交流。但能否有效地引导情感，往往决定着沟通的成败。感知至关重要，你必须了解自己的言辞和表达方式如何被他人接受，才能真正建立联系、传递信息、影响他人并给人留下深刻印象。

Sometimes being a better communicator has nothing to do with others and everything to do with self-reflection. Self-reflection is not about judgment or about beating yourself up over communications that have gone wrong. It’s about understanding. It’s about taking that curiosity-driven approach you’ve taken to understanding others and turning it inward, so that you can learn more about yourself. It’s about probing how you feel in the presence of others, and what they are doing that’s making you feel that way. For instance, when I spend time with friends who are on their phone when we’re together, I’ve gotten in the habit of doing an internal check of how I feel—which is usually tense and annoyed. I’m able to recall those feelings when I’m in conversation with others, so I’m better able to resist distractions that might have been hard for me otherwise. It’s easier for me to stop my urge to reach for my phone, and to say, “Not right now.”

有时候，提升沟通能力与他人无关，而与自我反思息息相关。自我反思并非评判他人，也并非因沟通不畅而自责。它关乎理解。它意味着将你理解他人时那种好奇心驱动的方式转向自身，从而更深入地了解自己。它意味着探究你在他人面前的感受，以及他们做了什么让你产生这种感受。例如，当我和朋友在一起时，如果他们一直在玩手机，我就会养成习惯，在内心审视自己的感受——通常是紧张和恼怒。当我与他人交谈时，我能够回忆起这些感受，因此我更能抵制那些原本可能让我难以抗拒的干扰。我更容易克制住想要拿起手机的冲动，并对自己说：“现在不行。”

Listening with focus

专注聆听

There’s a popular puzzle among the elementary school set that goes something like this: Someone is found murdered on a school campus at the beginning of the school year. The PE teacher said she couldn’t have been the killer because she was watching students run laps. The principal says it wasn’t her because she was giving a tour of the school. The math teacher says it wasn’t him because he was grading midterms. Who’s lying?

小学生中流传着一个很流行的谜题，大概是这样的：开学初，校园里发现了一具尸体。体育老师说她不可能是凶手，因为她当时正在看学生跑步。校长说她也不可能，因为她当时正在带学生参观校园。数学老师说他也不可能，因为他当时正在批改期中考试卷。到底谁在撒谎？

The answer is the math teacher, because he said he was grading midterms, and yet the murder happened at the beginning of the year. The puzzle tests your listening skills to see what information you’re discarding too readily when it’s actually important. Likewise, a critical piece of any negotiation is to focus on taking in information, and then thoughtfully and methodically analyzing it. You cannot discard any piece of information as unimportant. Everything is important, until it’s not.

答案是数学老师，因为他说他在批改期中考试卷，但谋杀案却发生在学年伊始。这个谜题旨在测试你的倾听能力，看看你是否轻易忽略了真正重要的信息。同样，任何谈判的关键都在于专注于吸收信息，然后进行深思熟虑、条理清晰的分析。你不能轻易忽略任何一条信息。一切信息都可能很重要，直到它不再重要为止。

Listening well is also strategic because when your counterpart feels like they are your focus, they are more likely to open up. You gather more information, and you can better understand the other side’s perspective so that you know better how to frame your argument.

认真倾听也是一种策略，因为当对方感受到你的关注时，他们更愿意敞开心扉。这样你就能收集到更多信息，更好地理解对方的观点，从而更好地组织自己的论点。

With mindful listening, you focus on listening to everything . It sounds so simple, right? But my students report that the mindful listening activity is the hardest part of my class. In an exercise I highly recommend you replicate, I ask them to find a partner and sit across from them. It’s important with mindful listening that both people are at the same level, so they are seeing eye to eye. Then one person speaks for five minutes about whatever it is they want. It could be something that happened that day. It could be what they’re thinking of making for dinner that night. It could be a meaningful, powerful memory they want to share. The listener has to focus on what his partner is saying, and not on what to say in response, or what to say when they swap roles and it’s his turn to speak for three minutes. The listener can ask clarifying or follow-up questions but needs to be careful not to judge—which even includes making affirmative declarations like, “Wow, that must have been hard,” or “Yum, that sounds delicious.” Mindful listening is just taking in. It takes focus, concentration, and patience.

专注聆听的精髓在于认真倾听每一个细节。听起来很简单，对吧？但我的学生反映，专注聆听练习是我课堂上最难的部分。我强烈建议你们也尝试一下这个练习：我让学生们找一个伙伴，面对面坐着。专注聆听的关键在于两人保持同一水平，这样才能目光交流。然后，其中一人可以自由发挥，用五分钟时间讲述任何想说的事情。可以是当天发生的事情，也可以是晚上想吃的菜，或者一段意义非凡、令人难忘的回忆。聆听者必须专注于伙伴的发言，而不是想着如何回应，或者轮到自己发言时该说什么。聆听者可以提出一些澄清或后续的问题，但要注意不要妄加评判——这甚至包括不要说一些肯定的话，比如“哇，那一定很不容易吧”或者“嗯，听起来真好吃”。用心聆听就是全然地吸收。它需要专注、集中和耐心。

In a negotiation, you probably won’t use mindful listening but rather active listening where you do make affirmative declarations. Yet I still recommend practicing mindful listening, because it strengthens those muscles of focus. It’s like lifting weights to help you prepare to run a marathon—every good trainer will tell you that cross-training is essential. There’s much more to listening than we give it credit for, and you have to work hard to control your thoughts and otherwise build the skills required to be good at it. If, when your negotiation partner is speaking to you, you’re focused on what you’ll say in response, you are in danger of missing a key piece of information from them. As Stephen Covey famously put it in his seminal book The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People , “Most people do not listen with the intent to understand; they listen with the intent to reply.” Perhaps you’re worried, though—you don’t want to have your counterpart turn to you when they’re done speaking and say, “Well?” and feel like you’ve been so focused on listening that you haven’t thought of a response. You don’t want the scary silence that follows (see Chapter 2!). Remind yourself it’s okay. Give yourself permission to take information in before thinking about how to respond to it. Don’t let feeling rushed cloud your judgment. It’s fine to say, “Let me think about this for a few minutes.”

在谈判中，你可能不会使用专注聆听，而是会使用积极聆听，并在其中做出肯定的表述。但我仍然建议练习专注聆听，因为它能增强你的专注力。这就像举重来帮助你备战马拉松一样——每个优秀的教练都会告诉你，交叉训练至关重要。聆听远比我们想象的要复杂得多，你需要努力控制自己的想法，并培养其他必要的技能才能做好聆听。如果你的谈判伙伴在和你说话时，你只想着如何回应，那么你很可能会错过他们传递的关键信息。正如史蒂芬·柯维在他那本开创性的著作《高效能人士的七个习惯》中所说：“大多数人聆听的目的不是为了理解，而是为了回应。” 也许你会担心——你不想在对方说完后，对方转过头来问你：“怎么样？”你可能会感觉自己太专注于倾听，以至于忘记了如何回应。你肯定不想面对随之而来的尴尬沉默（参见第二章！）。提醒自己，这没关系。允许自己先消化信息，然后再思考如何回应。不要让匆忙的感觉蒙蔽了你的判断。你可以说：“让我考虑几分钟。”

One of the more natural results of teaching listening skills is that I’ve become more aware of my own. And I’ve noticed that improving my listening has deepened my relationships. I make connections with people more quickly than I used to, which is saying something because I’m an introvert. It appears subtle, but I see the difference. For instance, I have a friend who recently lost her high-level job. Though she had seen the writing on the wall and knew it was coming, she’d received the news much earlier than she expected. We met for drinks, and it was clear she was still reeling from it. My first instinct was to tell her about the experience of losing my job that I recounted in Chapter 2. I had never told her that story before and thought it would be helpful because it would show her how much I understood. But I stopped myself. I needed to hear her—really hear her—before saying anything. There were key differences in our experiences—mine had happened early in my career, whereas she was deeply into hers. It wouldn’t work to say, “I know exactly how you feel because I was there.” Well, that’s not true. I didn’t know how she felt, not really, unless I listened. My experience might not resonate. I needed to listen purely, without thought to what I would say.

教授倾听技巧带来的一个自然而然的结果就是，我更加意识到自己的倾听能力。而且我发现，提高倾听能力加深了我的人际关系。我现在比以前更容易与人建立联系，考虑到我性格内向，这确实意义非凡。这种变化看似细微，但我能感受到。例如，我有个朋友最近失去了她的高薪职位。虽然她早有预感，知道这一天迟早会来，但她收到消息的时间比预期要早得多。我们约了酒，很明显她仍然沉浸在失落之中。我的第一反应是跟她讲讲我在第二章里提到的自己失业的经历。我以前从未跟她讲过这个故事，觉得讲出来或许能帮到她，让她知道我有多理解她的感受。但我克制住了自己。在开口之前，我需要先听她倾诉——真正地倾听。我们的经历有关键的不同——我的失业发生在职业生涯的早期，而她当时正处于事业的巅峰期。如果我说“我完全理解你的感受，因为我曾经经历过”，那肯定行不通。不，并非如此。除非我倾听，否则我根本无法真正了解她的感受。我的经历或许无法引起她的共鸣。我需要全然地倾听，不去想自己会说什么。

Managing emotions

情绪管理

Part of what makes active listening so difficult in negotiation is that people are often anxious about the negotiation to begin with. If you’re infected by fear, if you’re activating your amygdala, the “fight-or-flight” part of your brain, listening well and focusing are virtually impossible. Now, a little bit of anxiety—or rather worry—will make you more motivated for a negotiation, more prepared, and will keep your senses sharp during the negotiation. But too much fear and worry and you can’t think straight. You have to adjust so that you’re in the sweet spot—you have to be a master of managing emotions.

谈判中积极倾听之所以如此困难，部分原因在于人们往往一开始就对谈判感到焦虑。如果你被恐惧所笼罩，激活了大脑中负责“战斗或逃跑”反应的杏仁核，那么认真倾听和集中注意力几乎是不可能的。适度的焦虑——或者更确切地说是担忧——会让你更有动力去谈判，准备更充分，并在谈判过程中保持敏锐的感知。但是，过度的恐惧和担忧会让你无法清晰思考。你必须调整自己，找到最佳状态——你必须成为情绪管理的高手。

There is a famous quote from psychiatrist Viktor Frankl: “Between stimulus and response there is space. In that space is the power to choose our response. In our response lies our growth and our freedom.” The quote is like a battle cry for mindfulness. Mindfulness has long left the realm of yogis and philosophers and permeated the rest of the world. It doesn’t matter whether you’re at the bargaining table or the Thanksgiving dinner table; mindfulness helps you acknowledge and regulate your emotions.

精神分析学家维克多·弗兰克尔有一句名言：“在刺激和反应之间存在着空间。在这个空间里，蕴藏着选择我们反应的力量。我们的成长和自由就蕴藏在我们的反应之中。” 这句话就像是正念的战斗口号。正念早已不再局限于瑜伽士和哲学家的圈子，而是渗透到世界的方方面面。无论你是在谈判桌旁还是感恩节餐桌旁，正念都能帮助你觉察并调节自己的情绪。

The best course of action you can take to manage your emotions during a negotiation is to think through them fully before a negotiation. Most people have had the experience of waking up in the middle of the night, or perhaps not being able to sleep to begin with, because they are in the throes of a heated argument with someone . . . all in their head. Fuming and ruminating are a preparation, of sorts—they signal to you that when you do eventually talk with the other person, you will be bringing some strong feelings into the discussion. Thus, you need to figure out what those strong feelings are, where they’re coming from, and how you can best use them to serve the negotiation. Note that I’m not telling you not to be yourself. Be yourself, just be the best-prepared, most emotionally attuned version of yourself you can be.

在谈判中管理情绪的最佳方法是在谈判前充分思考。大多数人都有过这样的经历：半夜醒来，或者根本无法入睡，因为他们正与某人激烈争论……而这一切都只是在脑海中进行。怒火中烧和反复思考其实是一种准备——它们提醒你，当你最终与对方交谈时，你会将一些强烈的情绪带入讨论中。因此，你需要弄清楚这些强烈的情绪是什么，它们从何而来，以及如何最好地利用它们来服务于谈判。请注意，我并不是要你改变自己。做你自己就好，只是要尽可能地做好充分的准备，并尽可能地调整好自己的情绪。

If the primary feeling you’re bringing into the discussion is anger, beware. Whereas once it was commonly accepted that anger was a useful emotion in a negotiation, that’s not so. Researchers in a seminal 1997 study found that angry negotiators and their counterparts had less desire to work with each other in the future, they achieved fewer joint gains, and the party who was angry did not in fact claim any more value for themselves by virtue of being angry. More recent research shows that when people are faced with an angry negotiator, they’re more likely to walk away.

如果你在谈判中主要情绪是愤怒，那就得小心了。虽然过去人们普遍认为愤怒在谈判中是一种有用的情绪，但事实并非如此。1997 年一项具有里程碑意义的研究发现，愤怒的谈判者及其对手未来合作的意愿更低，双方获得的共同收益更少，而且愤怒的一方实际上并没有因为愤怒而获得更多利益。更新的研究表明，当人们面对愤怒的谈判者时，他们更有可能选择离开。

Anne was in the difficult spot of leading a board wherein one member, Melissa, was often divisive and abrasive. Melissa would frequently begin her emails by attacking someone’s intentions, and, as the board members were all volunteers who gave their time out of goodwill, Anne was protective of her colleagues and frequently furious with Melissa. She could feel her blood pressure rise whenever she saw Melissa’s name in her in-box. After a particularly nasty email fight between Melissa and some of the other board members, Anne decided to take Melissa out for coffee. She really didn’t want to but felt she might be able to appeal to her in a way that would help the group’s dynamic going forward.

安妮领导的理事会处境艰难，其中一位成员梅丽莎经常制造分裂，言辞尖锐。梅丽莎经常在邮件开头就攻击别人的动机，而理事会成员都是出于好意奉献时间的志愿者，安妮很维护她的同事，也常常对梅丽莎感到愤怒。每当她在收件箱里看到梅丽莎的名字，血压都会飙升。在梅丽莎和其他几位理事会成员之间发生了一场特别激烈的邮件争吵后，安妮决定请梅丽莎喝咖啡。她其实并不想这么做，但觉得或许能用某种方式说服梅丽莎，从而改善理事会未来的运作。

Before their meeting, Anne thought through all the ways that Melissa might push her buttons and incite her anger. It had happened before at board meetings, many times. Anne’s de facto response was to shut her down, to take control of the conversation and steer it away from Melissa. Anne had a temper, and not a lot of patience for bullshit when there was a lot of important work to be done. In sum, Anne knew this coffee date had the potential to go very, very badly. But the whole objective was to work toward a better, more collaborative relationship, so Anne couldn’t let the discussion go off the rails. She planned what she would do if Melissa attacked—how she would breathe and touch the table to calm herself, how she would leave a pause before she responded, how she would check the timbre of her voice when she spoke. She thought through how she would absolutely not drink coffee at their meeting, which made her jumpy and sped up her voice, and instead would order herbal tea. If she was really becoming angry, she would imagine that she was taking part in a story told by her favorite satirist, David Sedaris. By focusing on Melissa’s absurdity, she could laugh inwardly and do what she had to do outwardly.

在会面之前，安妮仔细考虑了梅丽莎可能会用哪些方式激怒她，让她生气。这种情况在之前的董事会会议上发生过很多次。安妮的本能反应是阻止她，掌控谈话，把话题从梅丽莎身上引开。安妮脾气暴躁，在有很多重要工作要做的时候，她对胡说八道毫无耐心。总之，安妮知道这次咖啡约会可能会非常糟糕。但最终的目标是建立更好、更协作的关系，所以安妮不能让谈话失控。她计划好了如果梅丽莎发起攻击该怎么办——如何深呼吸，如何轻抚桌子让自己冷静下来，如何在回应前停顿一下，如何注意自己说话时的语气。她想好了在会议上绝对不喝咖啡，因为咖啡会让她紧张，语速加快，所以她会点花草茶。如果她真的生气了，她就会想象自己正身处她最喜欢的讽刺作家大卫·塞达里斯笔下的故事中。通过专注于梅丽莎的荒谬行为，她可以在内心嘲笑自己，同时又能完成她必须做的事情。

Although sometimes the best course for dealing with a difficult person is to keep the meeting as focused and businesslike as possible, Anne sensed that with Melissa, it was all about the small talk—the whole point was to let go of an agenda and let her talk. And indeed, the more rapport you have with your counterpart before and during a negotiation, the more you can keep anger at bay. Anne suspected Melissa needed an audience to say all that she wanted to say without rebuttal. After a half hour of talking, wherein Anne asked friendly questions that she knew would put Melissa at ease and make her feel comfortable, they delved into some of the more loaded issues that had come up with the board. Anne let Melissa talk—and she could talk a lot . Anne reminded herself to stay present, that she didn’t need to cut Melissa off as she often had to during board meetings. She could just listen and watch. What she saw was a great deal of hurt and vulnerability. Melissa didn’t outright say, “I’m hurt and vulnerable,” of course, but there were clear clues. In an offhand way, Melissa offered that she had not attended their last board meeting because she thought everyone hated her. She told the story of how one board member had given her a hug when they’d seen each other randomly. It was clear from her body language when she told the story that the interaction had mattered to her, a lot. Anne learned more by being present at that coffee date than she had in a year of working on the board with Melissa. Seeing Melissa’s insecurity taught Anne that Melissa needed reassurance, to feel safe. And if Melissa felt safe, her actual point of view came through instead of getting lost in divisive language.

虽然有时对付难缠的人最好的办法是尽可能保持会议的专注和公事化，但安妮感觉和梅丽莎的会面更像是闲聊——关键在于放下既定议程，让她畅所欲言。的确，在谈判前后与对方建立的融洽关系越深，就越能控制住怒气。安妮猜想梅丽莎需要一个听众，让她可以毫无顾忌地倾诉所有想说的话。在半小时的交谈中，安妮问了一些她认为能让梅丽莎放松自在的友好问题，之后她们开始深入探讨董事会提出的一些棘手问题。安妮让梅丽莎畅所欲言——而她确实滔滔不绝。安妮提醒自己要保持专注，不必像在董事会会议上那样经常打断梅丽莎。她只需要倾听和观察。她看到的是梅丽莎内心深处的伤痛和脆弱。当然，梅丽莎并没有直接说“我很受伤，很脆弱”，但其中的蛛丝马迹却清晰可见。梅丽莎漫不经心地提到，她没参加上次董事会是因为她觉得大家都讨厌她。她讲了一个故事，说有一次偶然的机会，一位董事会成员给了她一个拥抱。从她讲述这个故事时的肢体语言来看，很明显，那次互动对她意义非凡。安妮在那次咖啡会面中学到的东西，比她和梅丽莎在董事会共事一年所学到的还要多。看到梅丽莎的不安全感，安妮意识到梅丽莎需要的是安慰和鼓励，需要安全感。而如果梅丽莎感到安全，她的真实想法就能清晰地表达出来，而不是被充满争议的言辞所掩盖。

It was worth Anne’s time to engage Melissa because it had the potential to save tons of time at board meetings, so the group could more effectively focus on the agenda at hand. And it did work, for about one meeting. Then Melissa returned to her divisive tactics. Anne could have mentally prepared herself to negotiate with her one-on-one again, but she determined it just wasn’t worth it and that the board needed to seek another way to proceed. (One that involved squeezing Melissa out, unfortunately.) There comes a point in many negotiations where you have to make a call about whether it makes sense to engage at all. (This is a particularly important internal check to do before talking to intractable family members about politics.) In short, just because you’re capable of managing your emotions, it doesn’t mean you always want to. Sometimes, simply walking away from difficult negotiation partners is the smartest thing to do.

安妮花时间与梅丽莎沟通是值得的，因为这有可能节省董事会会议的大量时间，使大家能够更有效地专注于当前议程。而且，这确实奏效了，至少在一次会议上是这样。之后，梅丽莎又开始使用她那分裂性的策略。安妮本可以做好心理准备再次与她一对一谈判，但她认为这样做不值得，董事会需要寻找其他方法。（不幸的是，这种方法意味着要把梅丽莎挤出局。）在许多谈判中，总会遇到这样的时刻：你必须决定是否继续参与。（在与固执的家庭成员谈论政治之前，这是一个特别重要的自我评估。）简而言之，即使你能够控制自己的情绪，也不意味着你总是想这样做。有时，远离难缠的谈判伙伴才是最明智的选择。

Many negotiators go a step beyond managing their emotions for a particular encounter and work to make mindfulness more instinctive by practicing meditation; Ford Motor’s Bill Ford, Salesforce’s Marc Benioff, Amy Schumer, and Arianna Huffington are among those who are committed meditators. Others practice yoga, like my student Julia. “Yoga offers some of the few moments in my everyday life where I unplug,” she said. “At my studio, we literally leave our phones in the other room.” Her yoga practice of focusing on the world of her mat helps her manage the times when she’s distracted at her consulting job. “Sometimes I realize I have a ticker tape going full of the stories I tell myself about what other people think of me. It’s really demotivating, distracting, and unproductive, which is why the focus I am able to cultivate on the yoga mat is so valuable.” Finding ways to quiet her mind is important to her in general, but it also translates directly to who she is as a negotiator. When you’re in the middle of a challenging conversation, she said, “you don’t want to be thinking about the eight other things you have to do for work. Or thinking, ‘Oh, I said this thing and I shouldn’t have and now they probably think I’m an idiot.’”

许多谈判者不仅会针对特定场合控制情绪，还会通过冥想练习，使正念成为一种本能反应；福特汽车公司的比尔·福特、Salesforce公司的马克·贝尼奥夫、艾米·舒默和阿里安娜·赫芬顿都是虔诚的冥想者。还有一些人练习瑜伽，比如我的学生朱莉娅。“瑜伽是我日常生活中为数不多的可以让我彻底放松的时刻，”她说，“在我的瑜伽馆，我们真的会把手机放在另一个房间。”她专注于瑜伽垫上的世界，这帮助她在咨询工作中应对分心的情况。“有时我会意识到，我的脑海里就像有一条滚动播放的电子屏幕，不断涌现出我对自己说的关于别人如何看待我的故事。这真的很打击积极性，让人分心，而且效率低下，所以我在瑜伽垫上培养的专注力才显得如此宝贵。”对她来说，找到让自己平静下来的方法非常重要，而这也会直接影响她作为一名谈判者的表现。她说，当你在进行一场棘手的谈话时，“你不想去想工作上还有八件事要做。或者想，‘哦，我说了那句话，我不该说的，现在他们可能觉得我是个白痴。’”

Despite her regular practice, Julia still struggles with noticing her internal monologue and watching it, as if it’s floating by on a cloud or on a river, but without being swept up in it. It’s a form of detachment, what William Ury has termed “going to the balcony.” You want to see what’s happening, and acknowledge what you’re thinking and feeling but with a little remove. You want to think, Hmm . . . I am having some strong thoughts and feelings right now , but not act on them without giving yourself that blessed space that Frankl wrote about.

尽管朱莉娅经常练习，但她仍然难以觉察到自己的内心独白，并像观察漂浮在云端或河面上的物体一样观察它，而不被其卷入其中。这是一种超脱，威廉·尤里称之为“走到阳台上”。你想看看发生了什么，也想承认自己的想法和感受，但要保持一点距离。你想思考：“嗯……我现在有一些强烈的想法和感受”，但不要付诸行动，而是给自己留出弗兰克尔所描述的那种宝贵空间。

“Last week at work I had a client say something to me that took me off guard,” Julia said. “The client was surprised at a decision one of their counterparts had made to extend the scope of our contract beyond the original end date. . . . We were going to be helping them with another module of work. I sensed a reaction that wasn’t pleasure, excitement, or gratitude at first blush. So it had to do with me, but it didn’t have to do with me. But the way it was phrased, it felt personal.

“上周工作时，一位客户跟我说了些让我措手不及的话，”朱莉娅说。“客户对他们的一位合作伙伴决定将合同范围延长至原定截止日期之后感到惊讶……我们原本要协助他们完成另一个模块的工作。我感觉他的反应并非出于喜悦、兴奋或感激。所以这件事似乎与我有关，但又似乎与我无关。不过，他说话的方式让我感觉像是针对我。”

“My initial reaction was ‘Shit, this is bad, this is really bad. They don’t want our help, we’re not demonstrating enough value.’ My brain starts going. In that moment, the story mill started,” she said. She worried about what the client had said or thought about her, and what she might have done wrong. “Anything I could dream up was running through my head,” she said. “In those moments, it’s very hard to remember that I’m drawing conclusions about what’s happening around me that may not be helpful or true.”

“我的第一反应是‘糟了，这下糟了，真的糟透了。他们不需要我们的帮助，我们没能展现出足够的价值。’我的大脑开始飞速运转。那一刻，各种想法开始涌现，”她说道。她担心客户对她说过什么、想过什么，以及自己可能做错了什么。“我能想到的所有事情都在我脑海里翻腾，”她说道。“在那种情况下，我很难意识到自己正在对周围发生的事情做出一些可能毫无帮助甚至不真实的判断。”

She called forth her practice and noted that when you’re successfully mindful, you recognize the thoughts, observe them, honor them, then let them go. “I thought, Hmm, I see that thought. I’m going to allow it to float away in the sky. I’m going to focus on the present moment, what is real right now and not a concern that I’m fabricating in my head . Because the stories you tell yourself don’t help,” she added. “Unless the story is ‘You’re amazing!,’ it’s usually negative and brings you down.”

她回忆起自己的练习方法，并指出，当你真正做到正念时，你会觉察到念头，观察它们，尊重它们，然后让它们随风飘散。“我当时想，嗯，我看到了那个念头。我要让它飘走。我要专注于当下，专注于此时此刻的真实，而不是我脑海中臆想出来的担忧。因为你告诉自己的那些故事毫无益处，”她补充道。“除非是‘你很棒！’这样的故事，否则通常都是消极的，会让你沮丧。”

Although Julia’s remedy is yoga, you have to do what works for you, with the ultimate goal of noticing that inner critic and getting some distance. I struggle with doubts and negative self-talk all the time, and I turn to the polar opposite of what works for Julia: I go to SoulCycle. That place is a respite for me—there are no phones, it’s a dark room lit only by the glow of candles, and music plays so loudly that you can’t hear yourself think. All you can focus on is the intensity of the required effort as sweat drips down your face, your breathlessness while enjoying the endorphin high. At the end of the class, having had a complete vacation from my thoughts, I’m almost always able to think with more objectivity.

虽然茱莉亚推荐瑜伽，但你必须找到适合自己的方法，最终目标是觉察到内心的批评声音，并与之保持距离。我一直饱受怀疑和消极自我对话的困扰，所以我采取了与茱莉亚截然相反的方法：我去SoulCycle。那里对我来说是一个避风港——没有手机，房间昏暗，只有烛光照明，音乐震耳欲聋，让你根本听不到自己的想法。你只能专注于挥汗如雨的训练强度，感受汗水顺着脸颊滑落，呼吸急促，同时享受内啡肽带来的快感。课程结束后，我的思绪彻底放松下来，几乎总能更客观地思考问题。

*   *   *

There are many ways to think about and practice presence, whether you’re leaving your phone before going to a party, staring at the sunset from an airplane window, or practicing yoga. But one of my favorite ways to frame presence comes from my student Glen. Glen has been playing the guitar since he was five and likens the notion of presence to that of differentiating musical notes. “I think the most incredible thing that I was able to achieve at a certain point,” he said of his music, “was not to play more notes or to play faster but to leave more space between the notes. What makes music music is leaving space,” he said. Otherwise, the notes just blend together and that’s not music—it’s noise. Ever since he shared this with me, I’ve thought of presence as the space between the notes. It could be infinitesimal. It could be subtle. But without it, it’s all just noise.

有很多方法可以思考和练习“临在”，比如在参加聚会前放下手机，在飞机舷窗外凝视日落，或者练习瑜伽。但我最喜欢的诠释方式之一来自我的学生格伦。格伦从五岁就开始弹吉他，他把“临在”比作区分音符。“我觉得我在某个阶段取得的最了不起的成就，”他谈到自己的音乐时说，“不是弹奏更多的音符或更快的速度，而是在音符之间留出更多的空间。音乐之所以是音乐，就在于留出空间。”他说。否则，音符就会混杂在一起，那不是音乐——那是噪音。自从他跟我分享了这一点后，我就把“临在”理解为音符之间的空间。它可以微乎其微，也可以非常微妙。但如果没有它，一切都只是噪音。

#↩

CHAPTER 8

第八章

assume abundance

假设丰度

On a Monday last winter, I reported for jury duty in D.C., where I live, and after waiting around all morning I was one of the potential jurors selected for a panel. The judge gave us the rough outline of the case we’d be hearing—which seemed very simple and sure to wrap up that day.
