Then he asked us to come to the lectern to see him if there was any possibility we wouldn’t be able to serve for four consecutive days. Dammit , I thought. I had to teach a class in New York on Wednesday morning that I could not miss. Despite the judge’s question, I knew the case couldn’t last very long, so if I just stayed quiet I’d be able to finish out my service by the end of the day or the following day. Additionally, since the final jury panel hadn’t been selected, I could actually be dismissed, which would fulfill my jury duty obligations. But I was in a court of law and didn’t feel I could withhold information when the judge requested us to be forthcoming.

去年冬天的一个星期一，我到我居住的华盛顿特区报到参加陪审团。等了一上午后，我被选为候选陪审员之一。法官给我们大致介绍了一下案情——案情似乎很简单，肯定当天就能审完。然后，他问我们是否有可能连续四天无法履行陪审义务，让我们到讲台上跟他谈谈。糟糕，我心想。周三上午我在纽约还有一堂课，不能缺席。尽管法官问了这个问题，但我知道案子不会持续太久，所以只要我保持沉默，就能在当天结束前或者第二天完成陪审义务。而且，由于最终的陪审团成员还没有选出，我其实可以被解职，这样就履行了我的陪审义务。但我身处法庭，法官要求我们坦诚相告，我觉得自己不能隐瞒。

I told the judge about my conflict, so he excused me from the panel and sent me to the schedulers. What followed felt straight out of a Seinfeld episode. The clerk I approached looked grumpy and harassed the moment she turned her attention to me. When I explained the situation, she said I could leave but would need to choose another Monday within ninety days to report back.

我向法官说明了我的利益冲突，他便让我退出了小组，并把我送到了日程安排处。接下来发生的事简直就像《宋飞正传》里的情节。我找到的那位办事员一注意到我，就一副不耐烦又恼火的样子。我解释了情况后，她说我可以离开，但需要在九十天内另选一个星期一回来汇报。

“That’s going to be a problem,” I explained, “because starting next week I teach every Tuesday in Philadelphia and I won’t be able to stay past Mondays. We’d naturally run into the same issue next time around and even worse, since I’d only have the Monday to spare at that point.”

“那将会是个问题，”我解释说，“因为从下周开始，我每周二都要在费城教课，周一之后我就没法待下去了。下次我们自然会遇到同样的问题，而且情况会更糟，因为到那时我就只有周一有空了。”

She shrugged impassively. “You’ll still need to choose a date.”

她面无表情地耸了耸肩。“你还是得选个日子。”

“But then I’ll spend my whole morning waiting around for the same exact thing to happen, and I’ll be standing in front of you again saying the exact same thing. Can’t I be called in for trials that take place on Wednesdays instead?”

“但那样的话，我整个上午就得白白等着同样的事情发生，然后我又得站在你面前说同样的话。能不能把我安排到周三参加庭审呢？”

“No,” she said. “If you’re initially called for a Monday appearance, you have to choose another Monday.”

“不，”她说。“如果你最初被安排在周一出庭，你必须选择另一个周一。”

“Well, then can I come in on a Monday in May, when the semester’s over and I won’t have to teach?”

“那我五月份的星期一可以来吗？那时候学期结束了，我也不用教课了。”

“No,” she said. “That’s outside of the ninety days.” She then went on to lecture me about my duty as a citizen.

“不，”她说，“那超出了九十天的期限。”然后她开始对我进行公民义务方面的说教。

The most frustrating part of this experience was that I wanted to do my duty as a citizen. I even wanted to serve on a jury. I thought it would actually be an interesting process—especially from a perspective of negotiation. I wasn’t making up excuses to get out of it. I’m sure this clerk was so accustomed to being lied to that she couldn’t see that my intentions were good. I’m also sure that there are valid reasons for the many rules regarding a juror’s service, but she never explained them, so I couldn’t rationalize them. But I was trying to present my intent, and I was trying to figure out a way that I could serve and also teach my class. All of my ideas fell on deaf ears, or, rather, prompted lectures about citizenship responsibilities.

这次经历最令人沮丧的地方在于，我本想履行公民义务，甚至想担任陪审员。我觉得这会是一个很有意思的过程——尤其从协商的角度来看。我并没有找借口逃避。我确信这位办事员早已习惯了谎言，所以她看不出我的初衷。我也相信关于陪审员服务的诸多规定自有其合理之处，但她从未解释过，所以我无法理解。我一直在努力阐明我的意图，也在努力寻找既能履行陪审义务又能兼顾教学的方法。然而，我的所有想法都无人理睬，或者更确切地说，反而引发了一场关于公民责任的说教。

The scheduler’s inflexibility reminded me of what my students do in class. They become singularly focused on one thing and one thing only: what slice of the pie they can grab for themselves in a negotiation. It’s like they’re wearing dog cones, unable to see beyond what’s immediately in front of them (dog food!). The problem-solving part of their brain isn’t available to them because they’re entirely focused on fighting for their share.

课程安排的僵化让我想起了我的学生在课堂上的表现。他们一心只想着一件事：在谈判中如何为自己争取到应得的份额。他们就像戴着狗项圈一样，眼里只有眼前的东西（狗粮！）。他们大脑中负责解决问题的部分完全被打乱了，因为他们一心只想争取自己的那份。

We wear dog cones all the time and we don’t even realize it. And the reason we do so is the same as this scheduler’s: We are in a locked mind-set, a state in which no is just so easy to say. And it is often much easier to see only our narrow piece than it is to see our negotiating partner as someone who might have overlapping interests. We enter every negotiation fearful that the other person is out to get us, that we must be cutthroat and competitive instead of kind, honest, and open. I’m sure the scheduler had heard a million excuses. I’m certain her nerves had already been worked by the time I arrived at the counter. I’m sure she had a variety of great reasons for her inflexibility. But it was maddening that there was no room for compromise.

我们总是戴着伊丽莎白圈，却浑然不觉。原因和这位调度员一样：我们陷入了一种思维定势，在这种状态下，说“不”是如此轻易。我们往往更容易只看到自己狭隘的利益，而不是把谈判伙伴看作一个可能与我们利益相符的人。每次谈判，我们都提心吊胆，害怕对方会处处刁难我们，害怕自己必须冷酷无情、争强好胜，而不是友善、诚实、坦率。我相信这位调度员已经听过无数借口。我肯定，当我走到柜台前时，她早已神经紧绷。我相信她对自己的固执己见有各种各样的充分理由。但最令人恼火的是，她根本没有妥协的余地。

No matter the circumstance, in order to get to yes and beyond, we need to be thoughtful about the ways we limit our thinking, and why, and think more expansively about what’s possible. As Winston Churchill said, “The pessimist sees difficulty in every opportunity. The optimist sees opportunity in every difficulty.”

无论情况如何，为了达成目标并超越目标，我们需要认真思考我们限制自身思维的方式及其原因，并更广阔地思考各种可能性。正如温斯顿·丘吉尔所说：“悲观者在每个机会中看到困难，乐观者在每个困难中看到机会。”

In this chapter, you’ll see how assuming that there’s enough for everyone—abundance—can lead to uncovering overlapping interests, create more options for problem solving, and allow you more leverage by giving you the courage to walk away. Most significantly, when we start from a place of abundance and not scarcity, instead of splitting up our pie, we make a bigger one.

在本章中，你会看到，假设资源充足——即“富足”——如何能帮助你发现共同的兴趣点，创造更多解决问题的选择，并赋予你更大的话语权，让你有勇气果断离开。更重要的是，当我们从富足而非匮乏的角度出发时，我们不是去瓜分蛋糕，而是去创造更大的蛋糕。

When you’re sure there’s not enough

当你确定没有足够的

I have seen “scarcity thinking” in classrooms, jury rooms, airport lines, and especially the workplace. For instance, I have worked in the sports industry in many different capacities for almost fifteen years, and although I’ve seen growing gender diversity, it continues to be male-dominated. The scarcity of female executives can breed competition, just as it does with other male-dominated industries like technology, finance, and law. Studies show that women would prefer to work for men than for other women, and in a study comparing attitudes at law firms, the firms where women were less represented, the women who did work there were “ almost universally reviled” by the other women. Women are sadly so much tougher on one another professionally, aggressively jostling to maintain their position at the leadership level. They see it as a battle to succeed in a hypercompetitive environment, where they perceive there are few token females allowed and they need to be one of them. Work collaboratively with another woman when there may be only room for one of us? No way.

我在教室、陪审团、机场候机区，尤其是在职场中都见过“稀缺思维”。例如，我在体育行业工作了近十五年，担任过各种不同的职务。虽然我看到性别多样性有所提高，但这个行业仍然以男性为主导。女性高管的稀缺会滋生竞争，就像科技、金融和法律等其他男性主导的行业一样。研究表明，女性更愿意为男性工作，而不是为其他女性工作。一项比较律师事务所态度的研究发现，在女性人数较少的事务所，女性员工几乎普遍受到其他女性的排斥。令人遗憾的是，女性在职业上彼此之间的竞争更加激烈，为了保住领导地位而展开激烈的角逐。她们把在一个竞争异常激烈的环境中取得成功视为一场战斗，她们认为女性人数寥寥无几，而她们必须成为其中一员。如果一个职位可能只容得下我们其中一人，那么与另一位女性合作？想都别想。

The reality is, we’re all pretty conditioned to think there’s limited room at the top, and just one way to get there. One student, Heather, did better than anyone else in her class on the exercise where she had to sell a tonic, and when I pointed out that she hadn’t been able to justify her outsized ask, it rattled her. “But I got the best deal of anyone in the class.” Although it’s true that she had done well, it was also true that she’d gotten lucky. Heather’s negotiation partner hadn’t questioned why she was asking so much for the tonic. And luck does not make for a sustainable strategy. It’s also likely that her classmates would remember her unjustifiable ask. In the real world, she’d gain a reputation as someone who was unreasonable or greedy. In class, she would put her peers on guard.

事实上，我们都被一种根深蒂固的观念所束缚，认为顶层空间有限，而且只有一条通往顶峰的道路。班里有个学生叫希瑟，她在推销补品的练习中表现得比班上任何人都好。当我指出她无法证明自己开出的高价是合理的时，她很恼火。“但我拿到了班里最好的价格。”虽然她的确做得很好，但她也确实运气不错。希瑟的谈判伙伴没有质疑她为什么要价那么高。而运气并不能成为可持续的策略。她的同学们很可能会记住她那不合理的要价。在现实世界中，她会落得个不讲道理或贪婪的名声。在课堂上，她也会让同学们对她有所防备。

When you look at a negotiation as winner-take-all, you lose out on creative thinking and options that neither party might have considered on their own. You’re unable to see beyond the competition, like the remorseful Aaron Burr from Lin-Manuel Miranda’s Hamilton : “I should’ve known the world was wide enough for both Hamilton and me.”

当你把谈判看作是赢家通吃时，你就会错失创造性思维和双方可能都未曾考虑过的方案。你无法跳出竞争的局限，就像林-曼努埃尔·米兰达的音乐剧《汉密尔顿》中懊悔的亚伦·伯尔一样：“我早该知道，世界足够大，足以容纳我和汉密尔顿。”

My student Eszter was brought up in Communist Hungary, not exactly an ideal environment for nurturing an abundance mind-set, since every resource imaginable was distributed in a careful and restricted way. Her grandfather was jailed for criticizing the government; the family sought refugee status in Canada but was ultimately rejected. After the Berlin Wall fell, they had to return to Hungary. “I know from my grandma that things were hard when I was small,” Eszter said. “We didn’t have money for bread and could only heat one part of our apartment.” Although Eszter’s mom was a doctor and her father was a lawyer, the family earned the same amount as every other family. “In a capitalistic society you have opportunities to think outside the box,” Eszter explained. “But with communism the box is by definition quite limited—you can only get a passport every few years, you don’t get to buy things because you only have a designated amount of money, you can’t get currency. . . . My mom was the mastermind of trying to make something more out of it. How do you take what seems like the same as everyone else and try to transform it into something more?” Eszter says that because of the way her mother operated, she had a great childhood and always considered herself privileged. Her mother’s creative thinking created abundance where there didn’t seem to be any. “We didn’t buy ice cream,” Eszter says, “but [my mom] told us that because we are so good at saving on ice cream, we would be able to have chocolate cake later. I think in the end it was the thought and anticipation of the chocolate cake that made us feel that there was abundance. It was in the reframing. We weren’t a family unable to afford ice cream, we were a family making a conscious choice to save wisely for the future.

我的学生埃斯特在共产主义时期的匈牙利长大，那并非培养富足心态的理想环境，因为所有资源都经过严格分配和限制。她的祖父因批评政府而被监禁；全家曾寻求加拿大的难民身份，但最终被拒。柏林墙倒塌后，他们不得不返回匈牙利。“我从祖母那里得知，我小时候生活很艰难，”埃斯特说，“我们连买面包的钱都没有，只能给公寓的一部分供暖。”尽管埃斯特的母亲是医生，父亲是律师，但他们家的收入与其他家庭并无二致。“在资本主义社会，你有很多机会跳出固有思维模式，”埃斯特解释道。 “但在共产主义制度下，选择余地从定义上来说就非常有限——你只能每隔几年才能拿到护照，你买不了什么东西，因为你的钱只有一定数额，你也拿不到货币……我妈妈是个能人，她想方设法让生活变得更有意义。你如何才能把看似和别人一样的生活，变成更美好的事物呢？”埃斯特说，正是因为母亲的这种处事方式，她拥有一个美好的童年，并且一直觉得自己很幸运。母亲的创造性思维在看似匮乏的地方创造了富足。“我们以前不买冰淇淋，”埃斯特说，“但（我妈妈）告诉我们，因为我们很会省冰淇淋钱，所以以后就能吃巧克力蛋糕了。我想，最终正是对巧克力蛋糕的憧憬和期待，让我们感受到富足。关键在于重新定义。我们不是一个买不起冰淇淋的家庭，而是一个有意识地选择为未来明智储蓄的家庭。”

“When we had enough money for chocolate cake, she said we could have the chocolate cake or we could now buy ice cream and save for something even better than a chocolate cake.”

“当我们攒够钱买巧克力蛋糕的时候，她说我们可以买巧克力蛋糕，或者现在我们可以买冰淇淋，然后把钱省下来买比巧克力蛋糕更好的东西。”

In this way, Eszter learned how to make more from what you’ve got. When she was just seven, she went on an errand to get napkins. Eszter’s mom had given her the precise amount of money needed for two packs of napkins. “I remember bartering my way through the market, asking who would give me a better price or better deal, or something as a gift for the purchase.” The final merchant she spoke with asked Eszter why she was working so hard to get a deal. “I told her that I needed enough money left over to buy flowers for my mom as a surprise. I told her something like ‘There is no deal without it.’” The merchant was not swayed by Eszter’s threat, obviously, but impressed by her precociousness and intent to please. When Eszter came home, she had not only the napkins but also flowers for her mom.

就这样，埃斯特学会了如何物尽其用。在她七岁那年，她出门去买餐巾纸。埃斯特的妈妈给了她刚好够买两包餐巾纸的钱。“我记得当时我在市场上讨价还价，问谁能给我更优惠的价格，或者给我一些小礼物。”她最后遇到的那个商贩问埃斯特为什么这么费劲地讨价还价。“我告诉她，我需要剩下的钱给妈妈买花，给她一个惊喜。我还跟她说‘没有花就没法成交’。”显然，商贩并没有被埃斯特的威胁吓倒，而是被她早熟的头脑和想要讨好别人的愿望所打动。埃斯特回家的时候，不仅买到了餐巾纸，还给妈妈买了花。

When Eszter graduated from Penn she worked as a strategy consultant and (because why not do more ?) she also started an online retailer with her boyfriend, who would become her husband. Their venture was successful and so they started several more, ultimately selling them all in order to focus on a new consulting business they formed together. Eszter negotiates all the time in her work and always tries to view the negotiation as a collaborative, rather than competitive, venture. One of Eszter’s trademark moves after getting to a good deal is to turn to her negotiation partner and say, “Great, we have a good deal. Now, can we make it better?” I recommend this tactic all the time, and although most people agree with it, few actually do it. But Eszter does. It may look like taking a few minutes to go over all of the new information the negotiating partners have learned about one another. Is there another area where they should engage in business together? Anything else they can do, maybe as part of the original deal or maybe outside it, that would be mutually beneficial? Eszter consistently analyzes whether she’s approaching a deal differently based on whether there will be a next one, and she says it’s her moral obligation to treat every deal as if there will be. And, in fact, she has been surprised by the people who have returned to her orbit when she never expected them to.

埃斯特从宾夕法尼亚大学毕业后，先是做了一段时间的战略顾问，然后（为什么不多做一些呢？）她和当时的男友（后来成了她的丈夫）一起创办了一家线上零售店。他们的生意很成功，于是他们又创办了几家，最终全部卖掉，以便专注于他们共同创立的新咨询公司。埃斯特在工作中经常需要谈判，她总是努力把谈判看作是合作而非竞争。埃斯特的一个标志性做法是，在达成一笔不错的交易后，她会转向谈判伙伴说：“太好了，我们达成了一笔不错的交易。现在，我们还能让它更好吗？”我一直都推荐这种策略，虽然大多数人都同意，但真正付诸行动的人却寥寥无几。但埃斯特会这么做。这可能看起来只是花几分钟时间，回顾一下谈判伙伴们了解到的关于彼此的新信息。他们是否应该在其他领域开展业务合作？他们还能做些什么，无论是作为原先交易的一部分，还是在交易之外，对双方都有利？埃斯特尔总是会分析自己是否会根据是否还有下一笔交易而区别对待每一笔交易，她说，认真对待每一笔交易都是她的道德义务，因为她认为会有下一笔交易。事实上，她也曾惊讶地发现，有些人竟然在她意想不到的情况下重新回到了她的圈子。

In one personal investment deal, Eszter negotiated with a large real estate development company—let’s call them ARCO—about the purchase of a flat in Budapest. The deal was pretty complicated, but what it boiled down to was that the property—which was still under construction—was smaller than ARCO would admit. “I knew they were wrong, so I asked for their calculations.” She went over everything with a fine-tooth comb and could show that she was right. Still, no law firm would agree to represent her. “They said it’s impossible to go up against this company, even though they knew I was probably right.”

在一次个人投资交易中，埃斯特与一家大型房地产开发公司——我们姑且称之为ARCO——就购买布达佩斯的一套公寓进行谈判。这笔交易相当复杂，但归根结底，问题在于这套仍在建设中的房产面积比ARCO承认的要小。“我知道他们错了，所以我要求他们提供计算结果。”她仔细审查了所有数据，并证明自己是对的。然而，没有一家律师事务所愿意代理她的案件。“他们说，即使他们知道我可能是对的，也无法与这家公司抗衡。”

So Eszter wrote ARCO a letter instead. She indicated that although the company might not have meant it, its information about the size of the flat was incorrect. She explained that their dispute could be reduced to mathematics, that in this case there was no he said/she said. She said that she would not sign a contract unless an independent third party verified the measurements. ARCO did not respond kindly and went with the strongman approach instead, getting as many as six of its lawyers involved. “They told me we would be in litigation for five years if I didn’t sign. But I wouldn’t. Then [ARCO] said, ‘You have no rights and you have no power. You’re not going to get anywhere. You have to sign this or you lose.’”

于是，埃斯特给ARCO公司写了一封信。她在信中指出，虽然该公司可能并非有意为之，但他们提供的公寓面积信息有误。她解释说，他们的纠纷可以简化为数学问题，不存在各执一词的情况。她表示，除非有独立的第三方机构核实尺寸，否则她不会签署合同。ARCO公司的回应并不友好，反而采取了强硬手段，动用了多达六名律师。“他们告诉我，如果我不签字，我们将面临长达五年的诉讼。但我拒绝了。然后ARCO公司说，‘你没有任何权利，也没有任何权力。你不会有任何结果。你必须签字，否则你就输了。’”

Most people, when faced with such a predicament, would either sign or steel themselves for litigation. And in this case, surely ARCO hadn’t given Eszter any reason to work together or to believe any form of collaboration was possible. It was trying to bully her into compliance. “So I told myself to isolate the negative parts of the negotiation,” she said. When she did, possibilities opened up. Eszter did two things to push once more for a collaborative—versus a strictly competitive—process: First, she reached out to the construction lead on the site. “I talked to everyone kindly and asked about the challenges with the project. I do this normally—I wasn’t on a spy mission to collect information. Being on good terms with the site lead and project engineers allowed me to understand the motivations of certain behaviors during the later negotiations with the lawyers.”

大多数人遇到这种困境，要么会签字，要么会做好诉讼的准备。而在这个案例中，ARCO公司显然没有给埃斯特任何合作的理由，也没有让她相信任何形式的合作是可能的。他们试图胁迫她屈服。“所以我告诉自己，要找出谈判中消极的部分，”她说。当她做到这一点时，机会出现了。埃斯特采取了两项措施，再次推动合作而非纯粹的竞争：首先，她联系了现场的施工负责人。“我友好地与每个人交谈，询问项目遇到的挑战。我平时就会这样做——我并不是在执行间谍任务收集信息。与现场负责人和项目工程师保持良好的关系，使我能够理解他们在之后与律师谈判中某些行为背后的动机。”

Second, she wrote another letter to ARCO. She said she understood that their last encounter had been negative, and that she wanted to change the focus to something more positive. She gave them three different options that she felt comfortable with, including one that involved Eszter buying something else from them. If they agreed to one, she said, they would have a deal.

其次，她给ARCO公司写了另一封信。她在信中表示，她明白上次的会面并不愉快，希望把重点转移到更积极的事情上。她提出了三个她认为合适的方案，其中一个方案是让埃斯特从他们那里购买其他商品。她说，如果他们同意其中一个方案，双方就达成协议了。

Significantly, Eszter had learned from the site engineers that the reason the flat was smaller than promised was due to a construction issue and that all of the flats on that side of the building were smaller. She could easily have included this information in the letter and threatened that if ARCO did not work with her, she would go to the other flat owners and begin a collective campaign to sue. In fact, she actually did include a subtle reference to this information in her first draft but then took it out, reasoning that she couldn’t very well present a positive framing of the deal if she was also threatening ARCO. “If I couldn’t ‘win’ this without the threat, then I wouldn’t feel good about it. That’s the way I now think about negotiations. If you can’t do it the right way, the result is not valuable.” The intent of interest-based negotiation, after all, is “ to bring people to their senses rather than to their knees.” Interest-based negotiation is about problem solving, not winning. It’s about seeing the interests of both parties and figuring out a way to meet them in a way that everyone feels comfortable. Winning takes on a different meaning. It’s not about one-way gains but about shared gains that can set the stage for future opportunities.

值得注意的是，埃斯特从现场工程师那里得知，公寓面积比承诺的要小是因为施工问题，而且楼那一侧的所有公寓都比较小。她本可以轻易地把这些信息写进信里，威胁说如果ARCO公司不配合，她就去找其他业主，发起集体诉讼。事实上，她确实在初稿中巧妙地提到了这一点，但后来又删掉了，理由是如果威胁ARCO公司，就很难对这笔交易做出积极的表述。“如果不用威胁就无法‘赢’这件事，那我就不会觉得满意。我现在就是这样看待谈判的。如果不能用正确的方式去做，结果就毫无价值。”毕竟，基于利益的谈判的目的是“让人们清醒过来，而不是让他们屈服”。基于利益的谈判是为了解决问题，而不是为了赢。关键在于理解双方的利益，并找到一种让各方都感到舒适的平衡方式。胜利的意义也随之改变。它不再是单方面的收益，而是能够为未来机遇奠定基础的共同收益。

ARCO ended up selecting one of the three options Eszter had proposed, and they made a deal. What’s more, when ARCO had an issue come up with another project soon after, they asked Eszter to be a consultant on it because they trusted her.

ARCO最终选择了埃斯特提出的三个方案之一，并达成了协议。不仅如此，不久之后ARCO在开展另一个项目时遇到问题，他们因为信任埃斯特，便邀请她担任顾问。

Perhaps my favorite story of Eszter’s abundance mind-set doesn’t have to do with business at all. She and her husband and brother wanted to take her dad to his favorite restaurant for his birthday, but somehow they had botched the reservation. The maître d’ was kind but firm that there was no table.

也许我最喜欢的关于埃斯特尔富足心态的故事，与生意完全无关。她和丈夫、弟弟想带父亲去他最喜欢的餐厅庆祝生日，但不知怎么的，他们把预订搞砸了。餐厅领班态度友善但很坚定地告诉她，没有空位了。

“I smiled and walked away,” said Eszter, “but then came back to him with a couple of ideas of what we could do. I suggested that they add a table for us in the sun, which we don’t mind (they had a limited number of covered areas, but I saw more tables/chairs in the storage area when I walked around); or that we wait for the fifteen-minute mark (how long they hold no-show reservations) on tables that were reserved.”

“我笑着走开了，”埃斯特说，“但后来又回来找他，提出了一些我们可以采取的措施。我建议他们在阳光下给我们加一张桌子，我们不介意（他们有的遮雨棚数量有限，但我四处走走的时候看到储藏室里有更多的桌椅）；或者我们可以等十五分钟（他们为未到的预订保留时间）再去预订的桌子。”

The maître d’ said no, he was sorry, but there was simply no room for them that evening. Eszter walked away again and thought for a moment. Then she went back to the maître d’ and explained that as the evening was so lovely and the part of town the restaurant was in was so charming, they would take a short walk, and then she would come back to see if either she or the maître d’ had thought of a solution that might work. “I thought that even if there was not a no-show, this would give the staff time to think of a solution without pressure. Sometimes I find that people think of a solution just after one’s walked away—I know this, because sometimes I go back.”

领班说不行，他很抱歉，但当晚实在没有空位了。埃斯特再次走开，想了一会儿。然后她回到领班身边，解释说今晚天气这么好，餐厅所在的街区又这么迷人，他们打算出去散散步，然后再回来看看她和领班有没有想到什么解决办法。“我想，即使最终没有客人爽约，这样也能给员工一些时间，让他们在没有压力的情况下想办法。有时候我发现，人们会在离开之后才想到解决办法——我知道这一点，因为有时候我也会回去。”

Sure enough, when she and her family returned fifteen minutes later, the maître d’ said he now had a table. Would she like it?

果然，十五分钟后她和家人回来时，餐厅领班说现在有张桌子了，问她是否愿意。

Note that Eszter wasn’t obnoxious to the guy. This wasn’t about refusing to hear no, or simply repeating “But I really want a table” again and again. Rather, she was thinking about the lack of a table as a problem to be solved, and one that she and the maître d’ could work on collaboratively. She didn’t have a “locked” mind-set, one where she might have shrugged in defeat in the face of a seemingly intractable problem. She chose to see the situation differently.

值得注意的是，埃斯特并没有对那位男士无礼。她并非不肯接受拒绝，也不是反复念叨“但我真的想要一张桌子”。相反，她把没有桌子这件事看作是一个需要解决的问题，一个她和餐厅经理可以共同解决的问题。她并没有固执己见，面对看似无法解决的问题，她可能只会耸耸肩表示放弃。她选择用不同的视角来看待这个问题。

“After we had a lovely lunch, I went up to personally thank everyone involved in making the table happen and explained how much it meant to my dad to have lunch with his kids (who live abroad) on his birthday. They all felt like heroes by the end,” she said. “We tipped well, but I specifically did not want to give them a tip for the table, because I wanted the interaction to be based on kindness between humans and not based on a monetary transaction.”

“午餐过后，我亲自上前感谢所有参与安排餐桌的人，并解释了能和住在国外的孩子们一起在父亲生日这天共进午餐对他意义有多么重大。最后，他们都觉得自己像英雄一样，”她说。“我们给了不少小费，但我特意没有给餐桌小费，因为我希望这次互动是基于人与人之间的善意，而不是金钱交易。”

It’s so tempting to fall into a locked mind-set because it’s often easier to categorize a problem as impossible to solve, to say “no” and “can’t” than to try to creatively work together. When working with someone with such a mind-set, sometimes it takes several tries to shift them into a problem-solving frame of mind. Recently I went to a department store to return two dresses I’d bought that, once I got them home, I realized didn’t fit me all that well. I’d lost my receipt, but the tags were still on the dresses, so I wasn’t anticipating a problem. I explained the receipt issue to the salesclerk. “Can you look it up through my credit card?” I asked, knowing they often have transaction histories that will show how much someone has paid for the item.

人们很容易陷入思维定势，因为把问题归类为无法解决，说“不”和“不行”往往比尝试创造性地合作更容易。与抱有这种思维定势的人合作时，有时需要多次尝试才能让他们转变到解决问题的思维模式。最近我去百货商店退两条裙子，买回家后才发现不太合身。我把收据弄丢了，但裙子上的标签还在，所以没预料到会有什么问题。我向售货员解释了收据丢失的情况。“你能帮我查一下信用卡上的记录吗？”我问道，因为我知道他们通常会有交易记录，可以显示顾客购买这件商品的付款金额。

“No,” she said, “I can’t, because you bought it from the couture collection. For those areas we need a receipt.”

“不行，”她说，“因为这件衣服是从高级定制系列买的。这类商品需要收据。”

I believed her; I understood that this was their policy. But why? The policy itself made no sense to me, so I asked her to explain. “You pay more so you need a receipt?” I asked.

我相信她；我明白这是他们的规定。但为什么呢？这项规定本身让我百思不得其解，所以我请她解释一下。“你付的钱多，所以需要收据吗？”我问道。

She shrugged. “On the tag,” she said, pointing to a tag on one of the dresses, “it says that you need your receipt for these items.”

她耸了耸肩。“标签上，”她指着其中一件连衣裙上的标签说，“写着购买这些商品需要收据。”

She was right, of course, it did. I said I understood it was the policy (although come on, who really reads the print on a tag?), but the why didn’t make sense to me. “So what can I do here?” I asked her, hoping she’d help me problem-solve.

她说的没错，确实如此。我说我理解这是规定（虽然说实话，谁会真的去看标签上的字呢？），但我搞不懂为什么。“那我该怎么办？”我问她，希望她能帮我解决这个问题。

She said she was sorry—and I know she really was—but that she couldn’t let me return it without a receipt.

她说她很抱歉——我知道她是真心的——但是没有收据她不能让我退货。

At that point I was considering my remaining option, which was to give the dresses away. Why not just offer them to her?

当时我正在考虑剩下的选择，那就是把裙子送人。为什么不直接送给她呢？

“Would these fit you?” I asked. “Because if not, I’m donating them to Goodwill. Consider it a gift from me to you.” I was being serious. Absurd but serious.

“这些衣服你穿得下吗？”我问。“如果不行，我就捐给慈善机构。就当是我送你的礼物吧。”我是认真的。虽然听起来很荒谬，但确实是认真的。

She raised her eyebrows, then peered at me closely. “I’ll tell you what,” she said. “We can find the transaction if you remember which register they were purchased on. So maybe, if you could remember which register rung up the purchase . . .”

她挑了挑眉，然后仔细地打量着我。“这样吧，”她说，“如果你记得是在哪个收银机上买的，我们就能找到这笔交易。所以，如果你能记住是哪个收银机扫的账……”

“I can!” I said, and pointed to what turned out to be Register 5. It took forty-five minutes, all told, from the moment I walked in until she found the receipt. By the end of the time we were really friendly, in the hunt together. Instead of just giving me store credit for the dresses, which was their policy, she ended up refunding the money to my credit card.

“我可以！”我说，并指了指5号收银台。从我进店到她找到收据，总共花了45分钟。最后我们成了朋友，一起寻找收据。按照他们的规定，裙子的钱只能给我代金券，但她最后还是把钱退到了我的信用卡上。

Naturally, this pressing to problem-solving mode doesn’t work all the time. It certainly didn’t work with the jury duty clerk. But it’s worth trying to (nicely) help someone enter that frame of mind.

当然，这种急于解决问题的方法并非总是奏效。对那位陪审团书记员来说，它显然就没用。但尝试（以友好的方式）帮助别人进入这种思维模式是值得的。

What dog cones have to do with ethics

狗脖子上的伊丽莎白圈与伦理道德有何关系？

People tend to see two ways of negotiating: a cutthroat style that assumes there’s not enough to go around, and an abundance style that assumes there is. What so often happens when we take the latter approach, one based in problem-solving and a clear desire to find mutual gains, is that we’re labeled inexperienced or naïve. And what so often happens when we take the cutthroat approach is that we’re labeled competitive and uncompromising. In this section, I get into why the naïve label is misguided, while the other one . . . well, it’s up for debate.

人们通常认为谈判有两种方式：一种是残酷无情的谈判风格，认为资源匮乏；另一种是资源充裕的谈判风格，认为资源充足。当我们采取后一种方式——一种基于解决问题并明确寻求互利共赢的方式——时，我们常常被贴上缺乏经验或天真的标签。而当我们采取残酷无情的谈判风格时，我们常常被贴上好胜心强、不妥协的标签。在本节中，我将探讨为什么“天真”这个标签是误导性的，至于“不天真”……嗯，这还有待商榷。

Stacey started a social mission–driven company in Detroit that does custom screen printing and serves as a community gathering place. Her community-mindedness made her nervous to take a negotiations course when she was enrolled in the Goldman Sachs 10,000 Small Businesses program. “Negotiations sounds so intimidating,” she said. “I always thought of negotiators as people who were good wheelers and dealers. People who got the upper hand and kept it.”

斯泰西在底特律创办了一家以社会使命为导向的公司，该公司提供定制丝网印刷服务，同时也是一个社区聚会场所。正是这种强烈的社区意识，让她在参加高盛“万家小企业”项目时，对谈判课程感到紧张。“谈判听起来太吓人了，”她说，“我一直觉得谈判者都是些精于算计、善于交际的人，他们能掌握主动权并保持优势。”

She was encouraged, then, by my discussions in class about how negotiation is best seen as a conversation, one in which strong relationships are key. She was skilled at building relationships and loved to learn about people, so she thought perhaps the class would resonate with her after all.

课堂上我讲解了谈判最好被视为一场对话，而牢固的关系是对话的关键，这让她很受鼓舞。她擅长建立人际关系，也喜欢了解人，所以她觉得这门课或许能引起她的共鸣。

I broke Stacey’s class into groups to do an exercise in which four different companies try to buy the same object from one seller. The stakes were high: Each party, including the seller, could lose their job if not successful. Although many of the exercises I use in class don’t have a clear wrong or right answer, this particular exercise does. There is a solution for all parties, where everyone can get what they want if they lay their cards on the table. I love showing the various outcomes to the class when we debrief, because it provides the most remarkable “aha” moments. If only we’d been more open about what we were after , they see, we’d have all come away happy . Although egos are sometimes hurt and students become defensive, this reaction is often followed by an awareness that win-win solutions are in fact possible, and that the path to getting there requires curiosity, an open exchange of information, honesty, and respect.

我把斯泰西的班级分成几个小组，做了一个练习：四家不同的公司试图从同一个卖家那里购买同一件商品。风险很高：如果交易失败，包括卖家在内的每一方都可能丢掉饭碗。虽然我课堂上用到的很多练习都没有明确的对错之分，但这个练习却不一样。它有一个对所有参与方都有利的解决方案，只要大家坦诚相待，就能各取所需。我喜欢在总结讨论时向全班展示各种不同的结果，因为这能带来最令人醍醐灌顶的“顿悟”时刻。他们意识到，如果我们当初能更坦诚地表达自己的诉求，大家都会皆大欢喜。虽然有时会伤到学生的自尊心，让他们产生防御心理，但这种反应之后，他们往往会意识到双赢的解决方案其实是存在的，而实现这一目标需要好奇心、开放的信息交流、诚实和尊重。

Stacey didn’t know any of this, of course, when she went into the exercise. But she approached the negotiation as a conversation, asking questions about her negotiating partners’ interests and revealing her own. “The people in my group were looking to win,” she said. “That was hard for me. And they were looking at me as naïve because I wasn’t interested in holding my cards close.” In this exercise, much like all of the other negotiation role-plays, participants react as they would in real life. If they perceive scarcity, their dog cones come out and block open and innovative problem solving. As a result, they can’t find a path to collaborative outcomes.

当然，斯泰西在参加练习时对这一切都一无所知。但她把谈判当作对话，询问谈判伙伴的利益所在，并坦诚地表达了自己的想法。“我组里的人都想赢，”她说，“这让我很难受。他们觉得我很天真，因为我没有把自己的想法藏起来。” 在这个练习中，就像其他所有谈判角色扮演一样，参与者会像在现实生活中一样做出反应。如果他们感到资源匮乏，就会像戴上了警戒线一样，阻碍他们进行开放和创新性的问题解决。结果，他们就找不到达成合作的途径。

By the end of the exercise, Stacey’s group was close to coming to blows and failed to reach their optimal solution. Stacey also didn’t come out of the negotiation as well as some of her counterparts. When we debriefed as a class, Stacey realized that two of her negotiation partners had misled her about what they needed and what they had to spend. They were operating from a cutthroat perspective. “I felt really used and betrayed,” she remembered. “I thought we were negotiating in good faith. I felt like I’d been had.” She asked me in front of the whole class, “What do you do when the people you’re negotiating with don’t negotiate in an ethical way?” I could hear murmurs throughout the room as people realized that we were heading into a difficult conversation. Her classmates had not seen Stacey like this before, but she was angry and hurt.

练习结束时，斯泰西的小组几乎要大打出手，最终也没能达成最佳方案。斯泰西在谈判中的表现也不如其他一些组员。全班进行总结讨论时，斯泰西意识到她的两位谈判伙伴在需求和预算方面误导了她。他们采取的是一种残酷无情的谈判策略。“我感觉自己被利用和背叛了，”她回忆道，“我以为我们是在真诚谈判。我觉得自己被耍了。”她当着全班同学的面问我：“当你的谈判对象不讲道德时，你会怎么做？”我能听到教室里响起一阵低语，大家意识到我们即将展开一场艰难的对话。她的同学们以前从未见过她这副模样，但她既愤怒又伤心。

“Did you get at least the minimum you were supposed to get for your company?” I asked.

我问：“你公司至少拿到了你应得的最低工资吗？”

“Yes,” Stacey said.

“是的，”斯泰西说。

“Did you feel good about the way you personally acted, that you acted with integrity? Did you stay true to yourself?”

“你对自己个人的行为感到满意吗？你觉得自己行事正直吗？你是否忠于自己？”

“Yes.”

“是的。”

“Then you made a good deal.” I wanted to impress on her the advice that’s been handed down for centuries and yet is so hard to internalize: Ultimately, we can only affect what’s within our control. Stacey would be more effective—not to mention more content—if she kept her focus on her actions.

“那你真是做对了。”我想让她明白一个流传了几个世纪却又难以领悟的道理：归根结底，我们只能影响我们力所能及的事情。如果斯泰西能把注意力集中在行动上，她会更有效率，也会更满足。

The class grew heated, with some people saying they had similar experiences to Stacey’s, and criticizing their classmates for their misleading behavior. Other students insisted that their “winner-take-all” approach was the only sensible way. Sure, they argued, in this case there was an outcome that worked for everyone, but their objective was to find and hold on to their leverage at all costs.

课堂气氛变得紧张起来，一些同学表示自己也有过类似的经历，并批评其他同学的误导行为。另一些同学则坚持认为，他们“赢者通吃”的做法才是唯一明智的选择。他们辩称，没错，在这种情况下，确实存在一个对所有人都有利的结果，但他们的目标是不惜一切代价找到并保持自己的优势。

Stacey went home that night still feeling lousy about what had happened. “Then later on,” she said, “I was unpacking it in my mind and I started feeling better. I shifted away from thinking Maybe I should have tried to get a better deal to No, I wouldn’t feel good about screwing someone .”

那天晚上，斯黛西回到家，仍然对发生的事感到难过。“后来，”她说，“我开始反思这件事，感觉好多了。我不再想‘也许我应该争取更好的条件’，而是想‘不，我不会因为和别人上床而感到快乐’。”

When Stacey talked to her group in a later session, one classmate condescendingly reflected on Stacy’s approach, telling her, “You seemed so naïve. I wanted to help you out.” Stacey was understandably frustrated that her approach was seen as amateurish instead of principled. So she told her group “I’m not being naïve, I just don’t want to play a game if I don’t have to. It doesn’t feel good. Even if I were to win, it still wouldn’t feel good.”

在之后的小组讨论中，当斯黛西和她的同学交流时，一位同学居高临下地评价了斯黛西的做法，说：“你看起来太天真了。我本来想帮你的。” 斯黛西感到很沮丧，因为她的做法被认为是业余的而不是有原则的。于是她告诉她的同学：“我不是天真，我只是不想在没有必要的情况下玩游戏。感觉不好。即使我赢了，感觉也不会好。”

Over the long run, an open negotiation style can be rewarding. The reality is that, if you can help it, you’re only going to negotiate once with a person who tries to screw you. And in fact, one of the women from Stacey’s group later needed to have some T-shirts printed and negotiated with Stacey using similar sharp-elbowed tactics that she had used in class. This women made a very big deal about the fact that she was also considering using another classmate’s company for the order. This woman loved to create competition where there was none, a phenomenon I see frequently but that always baffles me. Stacey did the work for her but found the process just as unpleasant as their negotiation in class. So Stacey resolved that she would never work with her again. In contrast, Stacey formed a friendship with another woman in her group who shared Stacey’s point of view that it was senseless to play games if you didn’t have to. They bonded over their shared values and remain close professional supporters.

从长远来看，公开透明的谈判方式会带来丰厚的回报。事实上，如果可以避免，你只会和那些试图坑你的人谈判一次。实际上，斯泰西小组里的一位女生后来需要印制一些T恤，她用了和课堂上类似的咄咄逼人的手段与斯泰西谈判。这位女生大肆宣扬她也在考虑找另一位同学的公司来做这笔订单。她喜欢无中生有地制造竞争，这种现象我经常看到，但总是让我感到困惑。斯泰西最终还是帮她完成了订单，但她发现整个过程和课堂上的谈判一样令人不快。因此，斯泰西决定以后再也不和她合作了。相比之下，斯泰西和小组里的另一位女生建立了友谊，这位女生和斯泰西一样认为，如果没必要，玩弄权术毫无意义。她们因为共同的价值观而结缘，并一直保持着密切的职业支持。

The fundamental argument in Stacey’s group is one I see a lot, as negotiators constantly wrestle with establishing the line between being a savvy negotiator and an unethical counterparty. Not everyone who follows the school of the cutthroat negotiator is unethical, but it can be a slippery slope. There’s a process researchers have described as “ ethical fading,” wherein “the ethical colors of a moral decision fade into bleached hues . . . void of moral implications.” At the heart of this is self-deception, or, essentially, the way we lie to ourselves about our behavior so we can still sleep at night.

斯泰西小组的核心论点我经常看到，因为谈判者们一直在努力厘清精明谈判者和不道德交易对手之间的界限。并非所有奉行“冷酷无情”谈判策略的人都是不道德的，但这确实是一个危险的滑坡。研究人员将这种现象描述为“道德褪色”，即“道德决策的道德色彩逐渐褪成苍白的色调……失去了道德意义”。其核心在于自我欺骗，或者说，本质上是我们为了能够安然入睡而对自己的行为撒谎。

Many people are comfortable with whatever approach achieves their desired outcome. “Who cares if I’m perceived as less than forthright?” they may think. “I got the outcome I wanted, and I’m never going to see this person again. I won!” This was certainly the point of view of many in Stacey’s group. We are programmed to think that all negotiations are competitive, so a transparent approach can only hurt you. In fact, in many negotiations classes, you’re graded solely on the outcome of your negotiations. I think this view of negotiation is shortsighted. And I’m in good company.

许多人对任何能达到预期结果的方法都习以为常。“就算别人觉得我不够坦诚又怎样？”他们可能会想，“反正我已经达到了目的，而且以后也不会再见到这个人了。我赢了！”这无疑是斯泰西小组中许多人的观点。我们被灌输了一种观念：所有谈判都是竞争性的，所以坦诚只会让自己吃亏。事实上，在很多谈判课程中，你的成绩完全取决于谈判的结果。我认为这种谈判观是短视的。而且，我的观点并非孤立。

In 1873, Andrew Carnegie had a problem. The financial market was in panic, and to honor his commitments he needed to liquidate some funds he had invested with J. P. Morgan. He asked Morgan for $60,000, as his original investment was $50,000 and he figured its value had increased $10,000. Morgan could have written him a check for $60,000 and let that be the end of it. But Morgan knew that the value had actually increased by $20,000, so he wrote a check for $70,000. Because of Morgan’s integrity, Carnegie was loyal to him for the rest of his life.

1873年，安德鲁·卡内基遇到了一个难题。当时金融市场一片恐慌，为了履行承诺，他需要变现一些投资于J·P·摩根的资金。他向摩根索要6万美元，因为他最初的投资是5万美元，他估计这笔投资已经增值了1万美元。摩根本可以给他开一张6万美元的支票，事情就此结束。但摩根知道这笔投资的实际增值只有2万美元，所以他开了一张7万美元的支票。由于摩根的诚信，卡内基终生都对他忠心耿耿。

A cynic might find this story quaint. Sure, maybe reputation mattered in 1873 , they might say, but welcome to the present, where the savvy negotiator must be cutthroat in order to win.

愤世嫉俗的人可能会觉得这个故事很古怪。他们可能会说，当然，也许在1873年名声很重要，但欢迎来到今天，精明的谈判者为了获胜必须冷酷无情。

I disagree, but I also believe that each individual must establish her own ethical lines. Some questions of ethics are easily answered: I could never accept, for example, lying to a counterpart about core issues. But there are a lot of gray areas, and questions about honesty come up more often than you might suspect. Some people think there is no harm in a little white lie, so they have no problem making a minor misstatement. Telling a negotiating partner that you were late because of traffic when you actually overslept doesn’t affect the negotiation substance, so no harm, no foul, right? In certain cultures, deceit in a negotiation is seen as standard, so even more substantive lies are not seen as immoral. For others, there is no such thing as an acceptable mistruth—a lie is a lie is a lie.

我不同意这种观点，但我认为每个人都必须建立自己的道德底线。有些道德问题很容易回答：例如，我永远无法接受在核心问题上对对方撒谎。但很多事情都存在灰色地带，关于诚实的问题出现的频率可能比你想象的要高。有些人认为善意的谎言无伤大雅，所以他们觉得说些无关紧要的小谎没什么大不了的。比如，明明睡过头了，却告诉谈判伙伴是因为堵车才迟到，这并不影响谈判的实质内容，所以也无伤大雅，对吧？在某些文化中，谈判中的欺骗被视为常态，因此即使是更实质性的谎言也不被视为不道德。而对另一些文化来说，根本不存在可以接受的谎言——谎言就是谎言。

I’m not prescriptive around what constitutes ethical negotiation, because that would imply that my judgment is correct, and that’s simply not so. Rather, I work with my students to help them understand their values, and how to bring these convictions to their negotiations. Reaching this understanding is an ongoing and lifelong exercise for all of us.

我不会对何为合乎道德的谈判做出具体规定，因为那样就意味着我的判断是正确的，而事实并非如此。相反，我会帮助学生理解自身的价值观，以及如何将这些信念运用到谈判中。对我们所有人来说，达成这种理解都是一项持续终生的修行。

Most critically, negotiators must determine whether their actions would violate their own moral code. As Stacey realized, a onetime favorable outcome cannot come at the cost of your principles. She had to think, if her actions were covered on the front page of the Wall Street Journal , would she be okay with that? Would she still feel she’d taken the right approach? More important, had she been true to herself? Would regret keep her up at night?

最关键的是，谈判者必须判断自己的行为是否会违背自身的道德准则。正如斯泰西所意识到的，一次性的有利结果不能以牺牲原则为代价。她必须思考，如果她的所作所为登上《华尔街日报》头版，她能接受吗？她还会觉得自己采取了正确的做法吗？更重要的是，她是否忠于自己？她会因此夜不能寐吗？

Even if certain negotiating tactics don’t sacrifice your principles, there are important strategic reasons to consider the implications of how you negotiate. First, every negotiator should consider how their counterpart would react to any perceived dishonesty. Some people think, It’s a negotiation and I expect them to lie . But if you’re negotiating with someone who believes that even small mistruths are unforgivable, she may never work with you again if you intentionally mislead her. Some others have even less tolerance and believe that failing to disclose information is tantamount to a lie. With such a broad spectrum of beliefs, you have to make sure you understand your negotiating partner (remember Chapters 5 and 6!) and ensure that your approach is tailored appropriately.

即使某些谈判策略不会违背你的原则，但出于重要的战略原因，你仍然需要考虑谈判方式的潜在影响。首先，每位谈判者都应该考虑对方对任何被认为不诚实的行为会作何反应。有些人认为：“这是谈判，我预料到他们会撒谎。”但如果你与一位认为哪怕是微小的谎言都不可饶恕的人谈判，那么如果你故意误导她，她可能永远不会再与你合作。有些人容忍度更低，认为隐瞒信息等同于撒谎。面对如此广泛的信念差异，你必须确保了解你的谈判伙伴（请记住第五章和第六章的内容！），并确保你的谈判策略能够恰当地适应对方。

Honesty in negotiation is also important because it helps you maintain your credibility throughout the process. The nuance of ethics comes to the forefront with a simple example of stating your final “bottom line.” Let’s say you’re interested in buying a souvenir and, in an effort to drive down the price, you tell the seller that you just can’t pay more than $10. If the vendor responds, “That’s too bad, I can’t sell it for that”—well, now what? Your misstatement has trapped you. You don’t want to walk away—you actually want the keepsake, and the truth is, you were prepared to pay more. So you tell the vendor, “Fine. I’ll give you $11.50.” You’ve lost all credibility. The seller now knows you misstated your true bottom line and is unlikely to believe your future protestations.

谈判中的诚实至关重要，因为它能帮助你在整个过程中保持信誉。一个简单的例子就能凸显道德的微妙之处：说出你的最终“底线”。假设你想买个纪念品，为了压低价格，你告诉卖家你最多只能出10美元。如果卖家回答说：“那太遗憾了，我不能卖这个价。”——那么，接下来该怎么办？你的谎言让你陷入了困境。你不想放弃——你其实想要这个纪念品，而且事实上，你原本愿意出更高的价格。于是你对卖家说：“好吧，我出11.5美元。” 你已经完全失去了信誉。卖家现在知道你谎报了真正的底线，以后不太可能再相信你的任何解释。

Most people shrug when they hear this example, thinking it’s an inconsequential negotiation. And bartering over a vacation trinket is hardly life and death. But credibility in negotiation is critical, and it can be destroyed whether or not your counterpart shares your definition of a white lie. Words matter. And if you blow your credibility on something small, you’ve also blown it on whatever follows. If your counterpart believes that you are not being forthright, he will be on edge and will scrutinize all future claims, if he is even willing to continue negotiating at all.

大多数人听到这个例子都会耸耸肩，认为这只是无关紧要的小谈判。毕竟，为了一个度假纪念品讨价还价，也算不上什么生死攸关的大事。但在谈判中，信誉至关重要，无论对方是否认同你对善意谎言的定义，信誉都可能被摧毁。言辞至关重要。如果你因为一件小事而丧失了信誉，那么接下来的一切谈判都将受到影响。如果你的对方认为你不够坦诚，他就会心存戒备，并且会仔细审查你未来的所有说法，甚至可能根本不愿继续谈判。

Another simply tactical reason to avoid saying anything that’s not completely true is that you don’t have to keep track of possible misstatements. No one wants to spend their time and energy in a negotiation keeping track of little white lies: What was the excuse I gave for being late? What did I say my available funds were? With the truth, you don’t need to remember what you’ve said and to whom.

另一个避免说谎的简单策略原因是，你无需费心去记住可能出现的错误陈述。没人愿意在谈判中浪费时间和精力去记住那些无关紧要的小谎：我迟到的理由是什么？我当时说我的可用资金是多少？说真话，你就无需记住自己说过什么，也无需记住自己对谁说过。

Although I avoid dictating others’ ethical lines in negotiation, I have certainly developed my own views of what constitutes fair—and effective—behavior. Personally, I share the perspective of the late Jon Huntsman Sr., the self-made billionaire who cofounded and ran the massive Huntsman Corporation. “Financial ends never justify unethical means,” he wrote in his book Winners Never Cheat . He understood that it takes years to establish a reputation and only hours to dismantle it. “Once dishonesty is introduced,” he wrote, “distrust becomes the hallmark of future dealings or associations.” Huntsman worked in the Nixon White House, so he saw firsthand how underhanded tactics caused leaders to lose their reputations (and ultimately their jobs). Huntsman also relates how his company’s ethical stand proved time and again to be profitable over the long term. For example, Huntsman Chemical worked in partnership with Mitsubishi in Thailand, but when Jon Huntsman learned that his company was expected to pay bribes, Huntsman Corporation sold its interest at a $3 million loss. Jon Huntsman was playing the long game. “Ethical decisions can be cumbersome and unprofitable in the near term,” he reflected, “but after our refusal to pay ‘fees’ in Thailand became known, we never had a problem over bribes again in that part of the world.”

虽然我避免在谈判中干涉他人的道德底线，但我确实形成了自己对公平有效行为的看法。就我个人而言，我认同已故的乔恩·亨茨曼（Jon Huntsman Sr.）的观点。这位白手起家的亿万富翁是亨茨曼集团的联合创始人兼首席执行官。他在其著作《赢家从不作弊》（Winners Never Cheat）中写道：“经济利益永远不能成为不道德手段的借口。”他深知，建立声誉需要数年时间，而摧毁声誉只需数小时。“一旦出现不诚实的行为，”他写道，“不信任就会成为未来交易或合作的标志。”亨茨曼曾在尼克松的白宫工作，因此他亲眼目睹了不正当手段如何导致领导人失去声誉（最终丢掉工作）。亨茨曼还讲述了他的公司如何一次又一次地证明，其道德立场在长期内能够带来丰厚的利润。例如，亨斯迈化学公司曾与三菱公司在泰国合作，但当乔恩·亨斯迈得知公司被要求行贿后，亨斯迈公司以300万美元的亏损出售了其在三菱公司的股份。乔恩·亨斯迈着长远的眼光。“在短期内，合乎道德的决定可能会很麻烦，而且无利可图，”他反思道，“但自从我们拒绝在泰国支付‘费用’的消息传开后，我们在世界那个地区就再也没有遇到过贿赂问题。”

Jon Huntsman fully acknowledged—indeed, embraced—that competition is central to the entrepreneurial spirit, and negotiations are often tough. But cheating and lying are a step beyond. “If the immoral nature of cheating and lying doesn’t particularly bother you,” he wrote, “think about this: They eventually lead to failure.”

乔恩·亨茨曼完全承认——甚至可以说是欣然接受——竞争是创业精神的核心，谈判也往往十分艰难。但作弊和撒谎则更进一步。“如果作弊和撒谎的不道德本质并没有让你感到特别困扰，”他写道，“那么请想想：它们最终会导致失败。”

Conversely, when you’re known as someone who plays fair, who is honorable and trustworthy, you are rewarded. Every holiday, Linda Schlesinger-Wagner asks her staff at Skinnytees to make a list of their favorite customers. Not their biggest customers, but the ones that they like working with the most. Those customers get 25 percent off their next order. It’s Santa saying, “I’ve been watching, and you’re pretty good.”

反之，如果你为人正直诚实，行事公平，你就会得到回报。每逢节假日，琳达·施莱辛格-瓦格纳都会让她在Skinnytees的员工列出他们最喜欢的顾客名单。不是最大的顾客，而是他们最喜欢合作的顾客。这些顾客下次购物可享受25%的折扣。这就好比圣诞老人说：“我一直在关注你们，你们真不错。”

Honesty and respect reap rewards over and over, and when you project these qualities outward, you get returns. This isn’t just a would-be episode of SuperSoul Sunday —though I love that show—but it makes good business sense. In business, you can’t always offer the best price or the top-performing product. But you do not necessarily have to: Your value proposition can be just that people like working with you. As the legendary sports agent Bob Woolf observed, “Think about it: Why do companies spend millions and millions of dollars on public relations and goodwill advertising to develop a nice relationship with the public? Because they want to do business. They want to create a nice atmosphere. They do it because it works.”

诚实和尊重会带来源源不断的回报，当你将这些品质展现给别人时，你也会获得回报。这不仅仅是《超级灵魂星期日》（SuperSoul Sunday）节目的一集——虽然我很喜欢那个节目——而是具有良好的商业意义。在商业中，你不可能总是提供最优的价格或性能最佳的产品。但你也不一定非要这样做：你的价值主张可以仅仅是人们喜欢与你合作。正如传奇体育经纪人鲍勃·伍尔夫（Bob Woolf）所说：“想想看：为什么公司要花费数百万美元用于公共关系和公益广告，以建立与公众的良好关系？因为他们想做生意。他们想营造良好的氛围。他们这样做是因为这样做有效。”

To share or not to share

分享还是不分享

We can’t uncover common interests if we are too protective of information and think that our only objective is to stand our ground. When people approach negotiation as cutthroat competition, their inclination is to hold all of their information close, as if they’re playing a card game and don’t want to let their opponent in on their strategy. I don’t advocate sharing every thought and number in your head, but this general approach of controlling information is problematic. It creates an environment of hostility and paranoia instead of one of openness. This is also the reason I don’t like silent auctions. Deals are all about conversation and human connection, and a silent auction eliminates that. If you’re not talking, then all you can do is limit the conversation to money and pricing. There are no shades of gray, no room for creative thinking. It goes only in two directions. More or less—up or down. Auctions eliminate innovation and collaboration. This may make for a very efficient process but it hardly makes for one that produces maximum, long-term value.

如果我们过于保守信息，认为我们唯一的目标就是坚守阵地，就无法发现共同利益。当人们把谈判当作残酷的竞争时，他们倾向于将所有信息牢牢掌握，就像玩纸牌游戏一样，不愿让对手了解自己的策略。我并不提倡事无巨细地分享所有想法和数字，但这种控制信息的普遍做法是有问题的。它营造的是一种充满敌意和猜疑的氛围，而不是开放的氛围。这也是我不喜欢无声拍卖的原因。交易的关键在于沟通和人际交往，而无声拍卖恰恰扼杀了这些。如果不进行交流，对话就只能局限于金钱和价格。没有灰色地带，没有创造性思维的空间。结果只有两个方向：要么高，要么低。拍卖扼杀了创新和合作。这或许能使流程非常高效，但却很难创造最大的长期价值。

Similar difficulties apply to negotiation by email, something most of us do all the time. With a global economy where we’re often thousands of miles from the person we’re negotiating with, it makes sense to use technology, but I also feel strongly that if you must negotiate over email, make it a priority to first meet the other party face-to-face to share information and get to know each other. If that isn’t possible, then try Skype or some other means that will allow you to see one another as you glean additional information with face-to-face communication. If given a choice between email and texting, always email. With texting even more information is lost, and the more we cut away human contact, the more we open the doors to miscommunication.

类似的困难也适用于电子邮件谈判，而我们大多数人却经常这样做。在全球经济一体化的今天，我们常常与谈判对象相隔千里，使用科技手段固然合情合理，但我强烈认为，如果必须通过电子邮件谈判，务必优先考虑与对方面对面交流，分享信息，彼此了解。如果无法做到这一点，可以尝试使用Skype或其他能够让你们看到对方的沟通方式，通过面对面交流获取更多信息。如果要在电子邮件和短信之间选择，请务必选择电子邮件。短信会丢失更多信息，而我们越是减少人际接触，就越容易造成沟通误解。

Glean as much information as you can, and all the while, assume abundance, which sets a tone of forthrightness and transparency. You can learn more about the other person’s interests, which gives you more options to work with in a negotiation. You don’t want to give away everything , though, so be thoughtful about what you share and what you don’t.

尽可能多地收集信息，同时保持信息丰富的假设，这有助于营造坦诚透明的氛围。你可以更多地了解对方的兴趣，从而在谈判中拥有更多选择。但你也不想事无巨细地透露所有信息，所以要慎重考虑哪些信息应该分享，哪些信息应该保留。

Before a negotiation, think through what information you have, and ask, “What will happen if I share this? Will this piece of information help me or hurt me?” In more instances than not, people tend to hide information that, even if revealed, wouldn’t hurt them and in fact can help them by buying them goodwill. They just think about things from a limited perspective, assuming that information held close gives them power, and/or that anything they share will somehow be used against them.

谈判前，仔细思考你掌握的信息，并问问自己：“如果我分享这些信息会怎样？这些信息对我有利还是有害？” 大多数情况下，人们倾向于隐瞒一些信息，即使这些信息被公开，也不会对他们造成伤害，反而可能通过赢得好感而对他们有利。他们只是从狭隘的角度思考问题，认为掌握信息就能获得权力，或者担心分享的任何信息都会被用来对付自己。

In 2000, Ursula Burns was not yet CEO of Xerox, but she was integral to turning the struggling company around. In a digital age where a company known for producing and maintaining photocopies could have become obsolete, Ursula and then CEO Anne Mulcahy had a hefty job in front of them. They needed to outsource their manufacturing in order to cut costs, but in order to do so, Ursula needed the buy-in of the Xerox union. Not an easy negotiation, as the outsourcing would mean cutting jobs and lots of them. Burns approached the negotiation with the four-thousand-employee union with transparency. “I told them the truth, in as much detail as I could, about what was happening,” Burns told Fast Company of the meeting. Anne Mulcahy said, “ She literally convinced the union that it was going to be either some jobs or no jobs. For anyone. It was survival. There was no other way.” Burns thought through the information she had, understood it couldn’t hurt her, and used it to garner goodwill.

2000年，乌苏拉·伯恩斯（Ursula Burns）尚未成为施乐公司首席执行官，但她对这家陷入困境的公司扭转颓势起到了至关重要的作用。在数字化时代，一家以生产和维护复印件而闻名的公司本可能被时代淘汰，乌苏拉和当时的首席执行官安妮·穆尔卡希（Anne Mulcahy）面临着一项艰巨的任务。为了削减成本，她们需要将生产外包，但为此，乌苏拉需要获得施乐工会的支持。这并非易事，因为外包意味着裁员，而且裁员人数众多。伯恩斯以透明的方式与拥有四千名员工的工会进行谈判。“我尽可能详细地告诉了他们真相，”伯恩斯在接受《快公司》（Fast Company）采访时谈到那次会面。安妮·穆尔卡希说：“她最终说服了工会，要么裁掉一些工作，要么就全部失业。对每个人来说都是如此。这是生死攸关的问题。别无选择。”伯恩斯仔细思考了她掌握的信息，明白这些信息不会对她造成任何损害，并利用这些信息赢得了工会的信任。

Consider another example, this time a train company negotiating with its passengers for loyalty and for help in keeping the trains clean. A sign in the train bathroom read: “We know you are not happy with the cleanliness of our bathrooms. We are looking for solutions and taking interim steps like having more staff come aboard at various stops to clean them. Meanwhile, we would like to ask for your help in keeping the bathroom clean for the next guest.” I was struck by this sign because it was so honest. The dog-cone inclination would be “Everything is fine here! Our passengers love us, and they even love our bathrooms!” Well, that wasn’t the case. Passengers weren’t happy, the train company knew it, and the passengers knew it. What’s the point in hiding that information? Instead, why not reveal it to strengthen the relationship?

再举一个例子，这次是一家铁路公司为了赢得乘客的忠诚度并让他们帮忙保持列车清洁而与乘客进行谈判。列车洗手间里贴着一张告示：“我们知道您对我们洗手间的清洁状况并不满意。我们正在寻找解决方案，并采取了一些临时措施，例如在各个停靠站安排更多工作人员上车进行清洁。同时，我们也想请您帮忙保持洗手间的清洁，以便下一位乘客使用。” 这张告示让我印象深刻，因为它非常坦诚。如果按照常理，人们可能会想：“一切都很好！我们的乘客喜欢我们，他们甚至喜欢我们的洗手间！” 但事实并非如此。乘客不满意，铁路公司知道，乘客也知道。为什么要隐瞒这些信息呢？为什么不坦诚相告，从而加强彼此的关系呢？

I almost always encourage proactively sharing market information and objective data (i.e., Kelley Blue Book values or Multiple Listing Service [MLS] data). This is information people will be able to find or have before they arrive and confirm when they leave the negotiation. If you neglect to share it—or worse, lie about it—they will recognize that you weren’t forthcoming, or that you weren’t knowledgeable. This will not bode well for either the chance of them negotiating with you again or your reputation generally in the long term. In the short term, it makes you appear ill-informed or shady, making it much harder to navigate the conversation. In contrast, by sharing this data, you’re showing your willingness to educate them and to approach the negotiation as a problem that needs to be solved. You’re encouraging them to put aside their own dog cone and to talk openly. It works: Researchers have shown that people share more when others reveal sensitive information.

我几乎总是鼓励主动分享市场信息和客观数据（例如凯利蓝皮书估价或多重上市服务[MLS]数据）。这些信息人们在谈判开始前就能找到或掌握，并在谈判结束后进行确认。如果你忽略分享这些信息——或者更糟的是，撒谎——他们会意识到你不够坦诚，或者缺乏专业知识。这不仅会影响他们再次与你谈判的可能性，也会损害你长远的声誉。短期来看，这会让你显得信息不足或可疑，使谈判更加难以进行。相反，分享这些数据表明你愿意为他们提供指导，并将谈判视为一个需要解决的问题。你是在鼓励他们放下成见，坦诚交流。这种方法行之有效：研究表明，当其他人透露敏感信息时，人们会更愿意分享。

If nothing else, you are taking the time to educate your counterpart so that the conversation can be informed, and an informed counterpart is so much more enjoyable than an oblivious one. CarMax took this rationale and made itself into a Fortune 500 company. It approached the field of used-car sales—one famously associated with holding critical information close—and reasoned, “We want you, the consumer, to be fully informed, and we want to be completely transparent.” They have computers readily accessible for doing research if you haven’t ahead of time. They want an educated consumer, believing that it saves time and encourages goodwill for everyone. CarMax recognizes that with the widespread availability of information, period, it’s not hard to be an educated consumer—it’s just up to the consumer to be educated.

即便没有其他好处，你也花时间向对方普及信息，让对话更加深入。而一个了解情况的对方远比一个一无所知的对方更令人愉快。CarMax正是秉持着这样的理念，跻身财富500强企业之列。他们进入二手车销售领域——这个领域历来以信息保密著称——并提出这样的理念：“我们希望您，消费者，能够充分了解信息，我们也希望做到完全透明。”他们提供电脑，方便您提前查询相关信息。他们希望消费者具备一定的知识，因为他们相信这既能节省时间，又能增进彼此的友好关系。CarMax深知，在信息如此普及的今天，成为一名有见识的消费者并不难——关键在于消费者是否愿意主动学习。

If there is information you know you don’t want to share, think carefully about how to deflect your counterpart if she asks for it. For instance, if someone asks, “What’s your bottom line?” you can say, “I don’t want to spend more than . . .” Which, as I already covered, is not the same at all as giving your bottom line. Research backs up the idea that if someone is an eloquent sidestepper, the listener doesn’t even notice that they’ve deflected the question. Deflecting unwelcome questions is not something that comes easily to everyone—it’s a learned skill. Just watch any politician being interviewed on a morning news show to see the dance in action. Some can evade questions by sticking to their talking points in such a blatant way that you wonder why the interviewer is even there—the politico is just giving a stump speech. Others softshoe around a firm answer with such deftness that you may have to watch the segment two or three times before recognizing that they haven’t in fact answered the question at all. Jake Tapper made a name for himself because he wouldn’t allow Donald Trump to deflect. “That’s great,” Tapper would say in response to a nonanswer, “but can you answer the question?” If worst comes to worst, and you’re talking with a Jake Tapper who isn’t abiding by your deflection, you can always say, “I’m not ready to answer that right now. Can we come back to it? I’d like to think about it a bit more.” Find what works for you—there’s no one right way to withhold strategic information.

如果你知道有些信息你不想透露，那么当对方追问时，要仔细考虑如何巧妙地回避。例如，如果有人问：“你的底线是多少？”你可以说：“我不想花超过……”正如我之前提到的，这和直接说出你的底线完全是两回事。研究表明，如果一个人能巧妙地回避问题，听者甚至不会注意到他已经避开了。回避不受欢迎的问题并非人人都能做到——这是一种需要学习的技能。只要看看任何一位政客在早间新闻节目中的采访，就能明白这种技巧。有些人会刻意地重复自己的论点来回避问题，以至于你会怀疑采访者存在的意义——政客只不过是在发表竞选演说而已。有些人巧妙地回避正面回答，以至于你可能需要反复观看两三遍才能意识到他们根本没回答问题。杰克·塔珀之所以声名鹊起，是因为他绝不允许唐纳德·特朗普回避问题。“很好，”塔珀在面对特朗普的模棱两可的回答时会说，“但你能回答这个问题吗？” 如果情况变得非常糟糕，你遇到的杰克·塔珀不接受你的回避，你总可以说：“我现在还没准备好回答这个问题。我们能稍后再谈吗？我想再考虑一下。” 找到适合你的方法——没有一种万能的策略可以让你隐瞒战略信息。

When it comes to information sharing, I recommend, at least at first, giving more information than feels wholly comfortable. By overcorrecting those first natural, protective inclinations, you’ll get to a place where you’re more comfortable and feel more in control of the process. Being less afraid will help you think more rationally about what you should share and what you shouldn’t.

在信息分享方面，我建议至少在初期，提供比你感觉完全舒适的信息量要多一些。通过克服最初那些自然的、自我保护的倾向，你会逐渐感到更加自在，也更能掌控整个过程。减少恐惧感能帮助你更理性地思考哪些信息应该分享，哪些信息不应该分享。

Assume abundance to conquer fear

相信富足可以战胜恐惧

The most common refrain I hear when I reconnect with my former students is that assuming abundance gave them the greatest leverage of all, because it let them know they could walk away from a bad deal, a bad client, even a bad relationship. As Benjamin Franklin said, “Necessity never made a good bargain.”

当我与以前的学生重新联系时，我最常听到的一句话是，认为拥有充裕的心态让他们拥有了最大的优势，因为它让他们知道，即使遇到糟糕的交易、糟糕的客户，甚至是糟糕的人际关系，他们也能果断离开。正如本杰明·富兰克林所说：“急需从来都不是好的交易。”

Take Linda Schlesinger-Wagner, the founder of Skinnytees. Critical to her early success was the fact that QVC picked up her product and it sold well for the company. Linda worked with three different buyers during the company’s five years with QVC and generally had similar contracts with all of them. Then a new buyer, whom I will call Stephanie, came in and changed the rules of engagement. Stephanie was hungry and wanted to make a name for herself. She presented a fee structure and return-rate metric to Linda that would have had Skinnytees taking on an inordinate amount of risk, such that there was a good chance Skinnytees would lose money on the deal. Linda tried to work it out with the new buyer, explaining her predicament and that the buyer’s predecessors had all been willing to work with Skinnytees to come up with a deal that worked for everyone. Not so from this buyer. She would not negotiate.

以Skinnytees的创始人琳达·施莱辛格-瓦格纳为例。她早期成功的关键在于QVC选中了她的产品，并且销量很好。在Skinnytees与QVC合作的五年间，琳达与三位不同的买家合作，并且与他们签订的合同大同小异。后来，一位名叫斯蒂芬妮的新买家出现，改变了合作规则。斯蒂芬妮野心勃勃，渴望成名。她向琳达提出了一套费用结构和回报率指标，这套方案会让Skinnytees承担过高的风险，很可能最终亏损。琳达试图与这位新买家协商，解释了自己的困境，并指出之前的买家都愿意与Skinnytees合作，达成一个对双方都有利的协议。但这位买家却并非如此。她拒绝谈判。

So Linda had a decision to make: continue working with the behemoth that was responsible for a large percentage of Skinnytees sales, but at what could be a loss? Or pursue other areas of business? As Linda explains it: “I said, ‘We love you and we’re not happy that we have to part ways. And your customer isn’t going to be happy.’” She walked away. “It was a game changer for us. Scary like I can’t believe. And we were sweating it. But it made us grow in so many ways. Now I’m not dependent on any one buyer. I have to be dependent on lots of different ways of doing business today. In the old days I would have thought, let’s do the deal. But I believe in my line. I can walk away from a deal and I did. And now QVC has come back and renegotiated.”

所以琳达面临着一个抉择：是继续与这家占据Skinnytees大部分销售额的巨头合作，但可能会蒙受损失？还是另辟蹊径？琳达解释说：“我说，‘我们很喜欢你们，但我们不得不分道扬镳，我们很不高兴。你们的顾客也不会高兴。’”说完，她就离开了。“这彻底改变了我们的命运。简直难以置信，太可怕了。我们当时紧张得要命。但这让我们在很多方面都得到了成长。现在我不再依赖任何单一的买家。如今，我必须依靠多种不同的商业模式。以前我会想，那就成交吧。但我相信我的产品线。我可以放弃一笔交易，而我也确实这么做了。现在QVC又回来重新谈判了。”

Linda also had to walk away from Dillard’s, another company she loved working with. Skinnytees was in forty-seven Dillard’s stores nationwide when Linda saw that Dillard’s had started putting the product in the underwear department, hanging between bras and panties. She really didn’t like the look, which suggested Skinnytees was a lower-market brand than it was. “We met with one of the head managers and I said, ‘This looks horrible—what can we do?’ She told me to ask for our own kiosk. But Dillard’s said no. They were great to work with, but we had to pull away—it wasn’t good for our brand to be displayed like that.” Linda left the relationship on good terms, which allowed her to return years later with a new idea for the product presentation that would make sense for everyone.

琳达不得不离开她非常喜欢合作的另一家公司——迪拉德百货。当时，Skinnytees的产品已经入驻了迪拉德百货在全美47家门店，但琳达发现迪拉德百货开始把产品放在内衣区，挂在胸罩和内裤之间。她非常不喜欢这种陈列方式，这让人觉得Skinnytees的定位比实际低端。“我们和一位经理见面，我说：‘这看起来太糟糕了——我们该怎么办？’她建议我们申请一个专属的销售亭。但迪拉德百货拒绝了。他们人很好，合作起来很愉快，但我们不得不退出——这样的陈列方式对我们的品牌形象不利。”琳达最终友好地结束了合作关系，这让她在几年后带着一个全新的产品陈列方案重返迪拉德百货，这个方案对大家都有好处。

Dana Sicko had a similar experience with her juice company, Gundalow. Every juice company tries to be cheaper and cheaper in order to make grocery stores happy. And for a time Dana tried, too. “Then I thought, why am I trying to make these grocery stores happy who aren’t good partners to work with anyway?” She described having a moment of feeling total empowerment, of recognition that she should move in a positive direction that made sense for her . “We can’t apologize for being who we are. So we were like, we’re going to sell to boutique hotels and high-end restaurants.” Gundalow is going to be profitable this year, which is a pretty big accomplishment for the juice industry. “I can negotiate every part of my business,” she said. “We’re going to find good people and negotiate with them .”

达娜·西科 (Dana Sicko) 的果汁公司 Gundalow 也经历过类似的困境。每家果汁公司都想方设法降低价格，以取悦超市。达娜也曾一度尝试这样做。“后来我想，我为什么要费尽心思去讨好这些根本不是好合作伙伴的超市呢？” 她回忆起那一刻，她感到自己获得了力量，意识到应该朝着对她有利的积极方向前进。“我们无需为自己的身份道歉。所以我们决定，要把产品卖给精品酒店和高端餐厅。” Gundalow 今年即将实现盈利，这在果汁行业是一项了不起的成就。“我可以就业务的每一个环节进行谈判，”她说。“我们会找到合适的合作伙伴，并与他们进行谈判。”

Jessica Johnson helms her family’s private security business and was recently in the tough spot of losing one of her company’s largest contracts. “One of the first things I did when I learned this relationship was ending is that I called our bankers. I said, ‘All of our business we projected isn’t going to happen.’” The bank, predictably, said she needed to give them a plan of what lay ahead. “I put pen to paper,” she said, and it allowed her to maintain a mind-set of abundance, even in the wake of this bad news. “Say we lose twenty people. We’ve still got a hundred. When I counted things up I was reminded that there are eight thousand security companies in the United States and ninety-five percent make less than five million a year.” (Johnson Securities is one of the top 5 percent.) She recognized, too, that less than 13 percent of women-owned businesses bring in more than $1 million in revenue. (She is in that 13 percent.) “When I realized that,” she said, “I saw that I am a unicorn. Even when we take all of that business off the table, I’m still up there.” Jessica’s mind-set of abundance allowed her to go back to her bank with confidence and to approach new potential business with that same confidence.

杰西卡·约翰逊掌管着家族的私人安保公司，最近她遭遇了公司最大的一笔合同被砍的困境。“得知合作终止后，我做的第一件事就是给银行打电话。我说：‘我们之前所有的业务预期都落空了。’”不出所料，银行要求她提供一份未来计划。“我把计划写下来，”她说，这让她即使在遭遇坏消息后也能保持乐观的心态。“假设我们失去了20个人，我们还有100个人。当我仔细计算后，我意识到美国有8000家安保公司，其中95%的年收入不足500万美元。”（约翰逊安保公司是排名前5%的公司之一。）她也意识到，只有不到13%的女性企业主的年收入超过100万美元。 （她属于那13%的精英。）“当我意识到这一点时，”她说，“我发现自己简直就是个独角兽。即使我们把所有现有的业务都排除在外，我的业绩依然名列前茅。”杰西卡这种富足的心态让她能够自信地回到银行，并以同样的自信去开拓新的潜在业务。

Negotiation like this can also happen almost completely internally. Consider the negotiation Anna went through in her own mind. Anna was contemplating leaving her job in a marketing department. She hadn’t gotten a raise in three years, nor, according to her boss, was a raise on the horizon. She considered going freelance, but there were many valid reasons to fear making the change. She would not have a guaranteed salary. She might have trouble finding clients. She would have to pay for her own health insurance. All of these reasonable fears prevented her from pushing back on her boss, because she felt she had no leverage. She couldn’t leave.

这样的谈判几乎完全可以在公司内部进行。想想安娜在内心经历的谈判。安娜当时正在考虑离开市场部的工作。她已经三年没涨过工资了，而且据她的老板说，短期内也没有涨薪的可能。她考虑过做自由职业者，但有很多合理的理由让她害怕做出改变。她没有稳定的收入。她可能找不到客户。她还得自己支付医疗保险。所有这些合理的担忧让她不敢和老板据理力争，因为她觉得自己毫无筹码。她走不了。

When she negotiated with a mind-set of abundance, however, she recognized she could indeed leave. There were a dozen people she knew she could contact to seek freelance work. She wouldn’t need as many clients because her hourly rate, working for herself, would be more than her hourly rate as an employee. There were other reasons to feel legitimately confident about the decision to go freelance: Her work quality was higher than that of some of her colleagues, and she’d be able to differentiate herself; she’d be able to go after different sorts of clients, doing things that paid more but that her company didn’t do; and she could always do temp work in case of a workflow rut. And so she did, finally, walk away. And sure enough, though it wasn’t seamless, there was enough work to go around.

然而，当她以更积极的心态去谈判时，她意识到自己确实可以离开。她认识十几个可以联系的自由职业者。她不需要那么多客户，因为自由职业的时薪会比当员工时薪更高。还有其他一些理由让她对成为自由职业者的决定充满信心：她的工作质量比一些同事更高，能够脱颖而出；她可以去争取不同类型的客户，做一些公司不做但报酬更高的工作；而且，如果遇到工作瓶颈，她还可以接一些临时工。于是，她最终离开了公司。果不其然，虽然过程并非一帆风顺，但工作机会还是足够多的。

No one who knows me would describe me as a bubbling well of optimism, and yet I recognize on a very intellectual level that when we believe in possibility, when we believe in abundance, we are rewarded. This is true when we negotiate with others, and it’s an approach that works with the world at large. I believe that it’s assuming abundance that gets us beyond yes.

认识我的人都不会觉得我乐观得像个喷泉，但我理智上明白，当我们相信可能性，相信富足时，我们就会得到回报。这在与人谈判时如此，在整个世界也同样适用。我相信，正是对富足的信念，才能让我们超越“是”。

Years ago, I had a great job with the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID). It was customary for the organization to put on one or two big events at the UN General Assembly meetings in September. Shortly after I started my job as a senior advisor for sport for development there, I attended a meeting where we discussed what kind of megaevent we might orchestrate. I knew very little about such things, but I raised my hand and suggested we throw a sports event. “I can bring in all these big names,” I said. “It could be exciting, and a great way to elevate our platform and reach people in a different kind of way.” Within a week, I had the go-ahead.

多年前，我曾在美国国际开发署（USAID）担任一份很棒的工作。按照惯例，该机构会在每年九月的联合国大会期间举办一到两场大型活动。我刚到那里担任体育促进发展高级顾问不久，就参加了一次会议，会上我们讨论了可以策划什么样的大型活动。我对这类事情知之甚少，但我还是举手建议举办一场体育赛事。“我可以请到很多大牌明星，”我说，“这会非常精彩，也是提升我们平台影响力、以一种全新方式接触公众的绝佳途径。”不到一周，我的提议就得到了批准。

What I didn’t realize was that putting on an event of this magnitude was a huge undertaking. We had only about a month, celebrity guests to confirm, invitations to send, details to coordinate, and logistics to problem-solve for an event that would take place in New York but that we were planning from D.C. The month was exhausting but exhilarating. In the end, it all came together and the attendees raved about it.

我当时没意识到，筹办这样一场盛大的活动是多么艰巨的任务。我们只有大约一个月的时间，要确认明星嘉宾，发出邀请函，协调各项细节，还要解决各种后勤问题。这场活动虽然在纽约举行，但我们却要从华盛顿特区进行策划。这一个月既疲惫又令人兴奋。最终，一切都顺利完成，与会者都赞不绝口。

The longer I worked at USAID, the more I realized what a big accomplishment our sports event was. I hadn’t been afraid because I didn’t know what I should be afraid of. I didn’t know about bureaucratic obstacles, so I didn’t let worrying over them stop me from thinking big. Years later, as I became more and more entrenched in the bureaucracy of the development space, it became harder for me to think expansively as I’d done when I suggested the sports event. To this day, when I realize that I am using a scarcity mind-set, I try to think back to the mind-set I’d had at the beginning of my tenure to recapture the person I’d been. I always want to be that person—the one who doesn’t set limits but rather who thinks, Why not?

我在美国国际开发署工作的时间越长，就越发意识到我们举办的那场体育赛事是多么了不起的成就。我当时并不害怕，因为我不知道自己应该害怕什么。我对官僚主义的阻碍一无所知，所以没有让对这些阻碍的担忧阻碍我大胆设想。几年后，随着我越来越深陷于发展领域的官僚体系之中，我越来越难以像当初提出举办体育赛事时那样，拥有开阔的视野。直到今天，每当我意识到自己陷入匮乏思维时，我都会努力回想刚入职时的心态，重新找回那个自己。我一直想成为那样的人——一个不设限，而是思考“为什么不呢？”的人。

When I catch myself thinking that something can’t be done—be it finding a reasonable price for a hotel or my ability to make a deadline—I often think of that woman at the jury duty scheduling desk. I imagine her impassive shrug and how easy it seemed for her to say no. She did me a favor, really. (Okay, maybe I wouldn’t go that far.) I have an image of what I don’t want to be, of how I don’t want to think, about how I don’t want to operate whether I’m negotiating with myself or anyone else. And then I simply take off my blinders and put my mind to the task of imagining what’s possible.

每当我发现自己觉得某件事做不到——无论是找到价格合理的酒店，还是无法按时完成任务——我常常会想起陪审团调度台的那位女士。我会想象她面无表情地耸耸肩，仿佛轻而易举地说“不”。说真的，她帮了我一个忙。（好吧，也许我不会这么说。）我脑海中浮现出一个画面：我不想成为什么样的人，我不想那样思考，我不想那样行事——无论是在和自己谈判，还是和别人谈判。然后，我只需摘下眼罩，开始想象各种可能性。

#↩

CHAPTER 9

第九章

claiming your power

行使你的力量

In the film Erin Brockovich , a single mom with no law degree (played by Julia Roberts) works with her boss (a lawyer) to go after Pacific Gas and Electric (PG&E) for contaminating water and thereby poisoning its inhabitants. When three polished PG&E attorneys arrive at her small firm to meet with Erin’s boss, Brockovich recruits two office workers to sit in on the meeting, so it will be four against three. The office workers don’t say or do anything, nor do they need to, because their purpose is to show that the small firm will not be outnumbered or intimidated.

在电影《永不妥协》中，一位没有法学学位的单身母亲（朱莉娅·罗伯茨饰演）与她的老板（一位律师）合作，起诉太平洋煤气电力公司（PG&E）污染水源，导致居民中毒。当三位精明干练的PG&E律师来到她的小律师事务所与艾琳的老板会面时，艾琳找来了两名办公室职员旁听，使人数变为四对三。这两名职员什么也没说，也不需要做什么，因为他们的目的是表明这家小律师事务所不会寡不敌众，也不会被吓倒。

Most people think that leverage has everything to do with money or the amount of resources you have. But as this scene suggests, leverage is all about perception. It’s about the way you bring yourself to the table. If you believe in your power, you reflect your power. For this reason, I think of Chapter 9 as the inverse of Chapter 1. In Chapter 1, I wrote about how telling ourselves stories that sell us short can hurt us in negotiation. In this chapter, I write about the opposite phenomenon—how, when we truly understand our power, we have leverage.

大多数人认为，影响力完全取决于金钱或资源的数量。但正如这段文字所暗示的，影响力其实关乎认知。它取决于你如何展现自己。如果你相信自己的力量，你就能展现出这种力量。因此，我认为第九章与第一章正好相反。在第一章中，我讲述了自我贬低的故事如何在谈判中损害我们的利益。而在这一章中，我将探讨相反的现象——当我们真正理解自身的力量时，我们便拥有了影响力。

Sarah Farzam, the Iranian, Mexican, and Jewish founder of Bilingual Birdies, shared in Chapter 1 that she once found negotiation intimidating. Not only was she a minority woman, but she was much younger than many of the people she was doing business with. It wasn’t until she understood her power that she recognized her leverage. “When I negotiate against a white man who might be older, who is representing say ten preschools together, I don’t have this thing I used to have where I would paralyze a bit and do whatever I could to not talk about the money,” she said. Instead, she focuses on how negotiating is in her blood, how she grew up watching her dad negotiate at Rite Aid when he was just buying toiletries, how she comes from a rich Iranian culture of merchants, going back to the beginning of civilization. “I can use that,” she said. She also has the superpower of being able to relate to pretty much anyone, in large part because of her diverse heritage. Now in a negotiation, she tells herself, “Even though I’m Mexican and Iranian and a woman, I have nothing less than you have . . . I might even have more.”

双语小鸟（Bilingual Birdies）的创始人莎拉·法扎姆（Sarah Farzam）拥有伊朗、墨西哥和犹太血统。她在第一章中分享了自己曾经对谈判感到畏惧的经历。她不仅是一位少数族裔女性，而且比许多与她做生意的人年轻得多。直到她意识到自己的优势，才意识到自己拥有谈判筹码。“当我与一位可能年纪较大的白人男性谈判时，比如他代表十家幼儿园，我不会像以前那样畏缩不前，想方设法避免谈钱，”她说。相反，她专注于谈判的本能，她从小就看着父亲在Rite Aid药店购买日用品时讨价还价，她来自伊朗悠久的商人文化，这种文化可以追溯到文明之初。“我可以利用这些，”她说。她还拥有与几乎任何人建立联系的超能力，这很大程度上得益于她多元的文化背景。在谈判中，她告诉自己：“即使我是墨西哥裔伊朗裔女性，但我拥有的并不比你少……我甚至可能拥有更多。”

Mary Ellen Slayter went through the same type of evolution in her outlook. Her small content marketing company counts as its clients some of the biggest companies in the world. “The natural place for me would be to feel like they have all the power and I have none, right?” she said. That mind-set would enable them to kill her margins—and, ultimately, her business. But then she had a realization. “They wouldn’t be calling me if they didn’t need me, and even with the big difference with the size of the companies, it doesn’t mean I don’t have power. I actually have a tremendous amount of power.”

玛丽·艾伦·斯莱特的观念也经历了类似的转变。她经营着一家小型内容营销公司，客户中不乏一些全球最大的公司。“我自然而然会觉得他们掌握着所有权力，而我却毫无权力，对吧？”她说道。这种想法会让他们蚕食她的利润，最终导致她的公司倒闭。但后来她意识到：“如果他们不需要我，就不会联系我。即使公司规模差异巨大，也不代表我没有权力。事实上，我拥有巨大的权力。”

Mary Ellen’s company does a lot of writing, a notoriously low-paid skill. She said sometimes she’ll encounter people who think that writers are a dime a dozen, and she’ll get that niggling feeling in the back of her brain that she is so lucky to be a well-paid writer. “But I’m not a writer,” she said, “I’m actually a business strategist who uses content to solve business problems.”

玛丽·艾伦的公司从事大量的写作工作，而写作这项技能的收入向来不高。她说，有时她会遇到一些人，认为作家遍地都是，这时她心里就会隐隐觉得，自己能成为一名高薪作家是多么幸运。“但我不是作家，”她说，“我其实是一名商业策略师，利用内容来解决商业问题。”

Her power is evident whenever she sits down with clients—and if it’s not, she makes it so. In a recent contract negotiation with an international events company, she was pretty blunt, explaining that other than herself, there were only two others who did comparable work. “These are my competitors,” she said. “They are both competent, and should you find them to be a better fit for your needs, here’s their number. I know them both.” Her revenue is up 40 percent since her evolution. “I know exactly where I stand and I know who I’m interchangeable with and who I’m not,” she said, and that’s made all the difference.

每当她与客户面谈时，她的实力都显而易见——即便没有，她也会想方设法展现出来。最近在与一家国际活动公司进行合同谈判时，她直言不讳地指出，除了她自己，只有另外两个人能提供类似的服务。“他们是我的竞争对手，”她说，“他们都很优秀，如果您觉得他们更符合您的需求，这是他们的联系方式。我认识他们俩。” 自从她做出改变以来，她的收入增长了40%。她说：“我非常清楚自己的定位，也知道谁可以替代我，谁不能替代我。” 正是这一点，让她取得了巨大的成功。

This chapter highlights the many different ways people come to understand their power and claim their leverage. Far from a one-size-fits-all prescription, power is unique to each individual and requires self-awareness to identify. Scores of myths and epic stories, from Black Panther to Wonder Woman to the Hunger Games, use this tension of the main character seeking their power as their driving force. Finding it is their hero’s journey.

本章重点阐述了人们理解自身力量并掌握权力的多种途径。权力并非千篇一律，而是因人而异，需要自我认知才能识别。从《黑豹》到《神奇女侠》再到《饥饿游戏》，无数神话和史诗故事都以主人公寻求自身力量的矛盾心理为驱动力。找到力量便是他们的英雄之旅。

Embracing difference

拥抱差异

Sallie Krawcheck has some pretty impressive credentials. She ran Smith Barney, Merrill Lynch Wealth Management, U.S. Trust, and Citi Private Bank, and was CFO of Citigroup. In the overwhelming male realm of Wall Street, she kicked ass as one of the few women. As she sees it, and as she tells it in her book Own It: The Power of Women at Work , she has come to see that she succeeded not despite her gender but because of the strength of her most female qualities.

萨莉·克劳切克拥有令人瞩目的资历。她曾执掌史密斯·巴尼、美林财富管理、美国信托和花旗私人银行，并担任花旗集团首席财务官。在华尔街这个男性主导的领域，作为为数不多的女性之一，她取得了卓越的成就。正如她在其著作《掌控一切：女性在职场中的力量》中所述，她逐渐意识到，她的成功并非源于性别，而是源于她身上最强大的女性特质。

Women have distinct strengths, she argues. Men do, too, she is quick to point out, and indeed her perspective isn’t one of male-bashing but of plugging diversity. But women tend to be more risk averse, she says, and risk aversion makes for stronger companies and better decisions. Women are skilled at managing complexity. They are more relationship-focused, they think longer-term, they prize a learning mind-set, and they value meaning at work. Each of these particularly “female” skills made her very good at what she did. For instance, her outlook on risk led her, early in her career as a research analyst, to call out the subprime lending practices in one of her reports, which she titled, “Whoa, Nellie!” This wasn’t in 2008 but in 1994, and her willingness to write about it was explained to her as a career killer. Though there were many causes of the financial crisis of 2008, Krawcheck sees the dearth of diverse voices in the room like hers as a central factor. Most of the decision makers on Wall Street, she said, were “people who had worked together for years, went to the same universities, sent their kids to the same schools, attended the same training programs, dined at the same restaurants, got promoted together, vacationed together, played tennis together, drank together, and sat on charitable boards together.” Her very difference, her very female approach to risk aversion, was what set her apart.

她认为，女性拥有独特的优势。她也很快指出，男性同样如此，而且她的观点并非贬低男性，而是强调多元化。但她表示，女性往往更倾向于规避风险，而规避风险恰恰能造就更强大的公司和更明智的决策。女性擅长应对复杂局面。她们更注重人际关系，更具长远眼光，重视学习型思维，并珍视工作的意义。正是这些独特的“女性”特质，让她在工作中表现出色。例如，她对风险的敏锐洞察力，促使她在职业生涯早期担任研究分析师时，就曾在一份题为《哇，内莉！》的报告中公开批评次贷危机。这并非发生在2008年，而是在1994年，当时有人告诉她，她敢于直言不讳会断送自己的职业生涯。尽管2008年金融危机的成因众多，但克劳切克认为，像她这样多元化的声音在决策层中匮乏是关键因素之一。她说，华尔街的大多数决策者都是“一起工作多年、就读同一所大学、送孩子上同一所学校、参加过相同的培训项目、在同一家餐厅用餐、一起晋升、一起度假、一起打网球、一起喝酒、一起担任慈善机构董事的人”。正是她与众不同之处，她独特的女性风险规避方式，使她脱颖而出。

Krawcheck believes her focus on relationships has made her better at asking for money, as she is able to see the bigger picture from all sides—a point integral to Chapter 5 of this book. When she was CEO at the research firm Sanford Bernstein, her focus on relationships also made her recognize that the firm could not authentically serve their clients because they had two sets of clients—investing clients and corporate clients—whose interests were inherently in conflict. Although most research departments in the industry did advise both, she recommended withdrawing from the investment banking business so they could truly serve investment clients. When the Internet bubble burst, most of the competition were slapped with hundreds of millions of dollars in regulatory fines. Krawcheck, in contrast, was featured on the cover of Fortune with the headline The Last Honest Analyst .

克劳切克认为，她对人际关系的重视使她更擅长争取资金，因为她能够从各个角度看待问题——这一点在本书第五章中至关重要。在她担任研究公司桑福德·伯恩斯坦（Sanford Bernstein）首席执行官期间，她对人际关系的重视也让她意识到，公司无法真正为客户服务，因为他们同时服务于两类客户——投资客户和企业客户——而这两类客户的利益本质上是冲突的。尽管业内大多数研究部门都同时为这两类客户提供咨询服务，但她建议公司退出投资银行业务，以便真正服务于投资客户。互联网泡沫破裂后，大多数竞争对手都被处以数亿美元的监管罚款。相比之下，克劳切克却登上了《财富》杂志的封面，标题是“最后一位诚实的分析师”。

Her relationship focus also cost her, and dearly. Sanford Bernstein lost money for years before the wisdom of her decision was clear. And when she was at Citigroup, she was fired after she pushed hard to reimburse some of their clients’ investment losses after Citigroup miscalculated risk on a group of investments. “I became obsessed, totally consumed with thinking about the clients whom we had let down,” she said of the time. “The clients whom we had built relationships with, who had trusted us to make the right investment decisions for them. And when I couldn’t think about them anymore, I thought about the long-term harm that we were doing to our business. We had shaken those clients’ confidence in us, so why would they ever want to invest their hard-earned dollars with us again?”
