她对客户关系的重视也让她付出了惨痛的代价。桑福德·伯恩斯坦公司多年来一直亏损，直到后来才意识到她当初决定的明智之处。在花旗集团任职期间，由于花旗集团在一组投资中误判了风险，导致部分客户蒙受损失，她力主赔偿，结果被解雇。“我当时非常执着，满脑子都是我们辜负的客户，”她回忆道，“那些我们曾与之建立关系、信任我们能为他们做出正确投资决策的客户。当我再也无法为他们操心时，我开始思考我们对公司业务造成的长期损害。我们已经动摇了客户对我们的信任，他们为什么还会愿意再次把辛辛苦苦赚来的钱投资在我们这里呢？”

But Krawcheck’s prioritization of the long term also has meant she’s landed now in a place that’s far better, as the founder of a digital investment platform for women, Ellevest, that is fulfilling and successful. She was fired, she came to see, for the same things that have also served her and will continue to serve her. “I was fired for being different, for challenging the majority opinion, for speaking up, for daring to go against the grain . . . for calling out the risk, prioritizing the long term, and for putting client relationships ahead of the short-term bottom line.”

但克劳切克对长远发展的重视也让她如今身处一个更好的境地：她创立了面向女性的数字投资平台Ellevest，这份工作既充实又成功。她后来意识到，自己被解雇的原因恰恰是那些曾经让她受益匪浅、并将继续让她受益的品质。“我被解雇是因为我与众不同，挑战主流观点，敢于发声，敢于逆潮流而行……因为我指出了风险，重视长远发展，并将客户关系置于短期利益之上。”

Women are different, she says. “And therein lie our greatest strength and competitive advantage in the modern workplace. . . . [I]t’s us women deciding to celebrate rather than apologize for all the amazing unique qualities that we bring to the table—and to give ourselves permission to act like our true selves at work.”

她说，女性与众不同。“而这正是我们在现代职场中最大的优势和竞争优势所在……我们女性选择庆祝而不是为自己带来的所有令人惊叹的独特品质道歉——并允许自己在工作中展现真实的自我。”

When we harness the potential of our difference, our story is one of power, not of lack. Former Xerox chief Ursula Burns was born a poor, African American female. Some said that meant she had three strikes. But as she told Time , “I grew up as an engineer in math and science, where it is mostly men. Mostly white men. . . . Again, difference is generally better. So you take the gender and the race differences and use them as a strength. They become a positive. You can perform as well as they can perform—or better—and you will be noticed. You have to have a continued focus and not bow to the many, many, many headwinds, but you can use them as an advantage.”

当我们能充分发挥自身差异的潜力时，我们的故事就讲述的是力量，而非匮乏。施乐公司前首席执行官乌苏拉·伯恩斯出生于一个贫困的非裔美国家庭。有人说，这意味着她天生就处于劣势。但正如她告诉《时代》杂志的那样：“我成长于一个数学和科学领域的工程师家庭，那里大多是男性，而且大多是白人男性……再次强调，差异通常意味着优势。所以，你要利用性别和种族差异，将它们转化为优势。它们会变成积极因素。你可以和他们一样出色——甚至更好——你也会因此脱颖而出。你必须保持专注，不向重重阻碍低头，而是要将它们转化为优势。”

Storytelling and persuasion

讲故事和说服

In a popular exercise I do in some of my classes, I give each student a paper clip and they have to trade it up over a period of several hours. To get them in the spirit, I show them a news clip of a Canadian man, Kyle MacDonald, who traded a paper clip all the way up to a house. When I tell them the kinds of objects that former students have traded up for—a mini fridge, a printer, and a trombone—they don’t believe it’s possible. Then I set them loose for just two hours, encouraging them to go around campus and negotiate in a way that fits their style.

在我一些课堂上经常做的一个练习中，我会给每个学生一个回形针，让他们在几个小时内用它换取更好的东西。为了让他们更有代入感，我会给他们播放一段新闻片段，讲述加拿大男子凯尔·麦克唐纳如何用一个回形针最终换到了一栋房子。当我告诉他们以前的学生都换到了哪些东西——迷你冰箱、打印机、长号等等——他们都难以置信。然后，我会让他们自由活动两个小时，鼓励他们在校园里四处走走，用他们喜欢的方式进行谈判。

My student Dylan Reim thought about how Kyle MacDonald had been successful. He hadn’t really just traded a paper clip—he’d become a news sensation when he got to the point of trading for a snowmobile, and so everyone wanted to be a part of the excitement. It was no longer about the object but about the story. Well, Dylan could do that. He came from a theatrical family that loved to dress up and stage elaborate Halloween productions. He worked for the school newspaper, so he was accustomed to organizing a narrative. Dylan could play a part, and he could welcome people to be a part of the story.

我的学生迪伦·雷姆思考着凯尔·麦克唐纳是如何取得成功的。他可不仅仅是用回形针交换——当他最终用回形针换到一辆雪地摩托时，他成了新闻焦点，人人都想参与其中。重点不再是物品本身，而是故事。迪伦也能做到这一点。他来自一个热爱戏剧的家庭，家人喜欢装扮，精心策划万圣节演出。他曾在校报工作，所以很擅长组织叙事。迪伦可以扮演一个角色，也可以邀请人们加入到这个故事中来。

He created a Facebook page, dressed in an over-the-top sequined jacket, and set up a trading post in the middle of campus that the Facebook page directed people to. He made a sign from materials he had around his apartment, but that was it.

他创建了一个Facebook页面，穿着一件夸张的亮片外套，并在校园中心设立了一个交易站，Facebook页面会引导人们前往那里。他用公寓里现有的材料做了一个招牌，仅此而已。

“I started getting a couple of people I’d never met, who thought, I want to be on that page ,” Dylan said. “That was exactly what I wanted. And the fact that I was having fun with it made me able to do it a lot better. I don’t think if I were calling friends saying, ‘Can I trade up?’ it would have worked as well. I had to feel like I wasn’t tricking others into working with me. Other people can get value for the exchange. They can see me as an equal, that I’m giving them something—they get to be part of it.”

“我开始遇到一些素未谋面的人，他们说，‘我也想加入这个项目’，”迪伦说道。“这正是我想要的。而且，我乐在其中，这让我能够做得更好。我觉得如果我只是打电话给朋友说，‘我能升级合作吗？’，效果肯定不会这么好。我必须感觉自己没有欺骗别人与我合作。其他人可以从这种交换中获得价值。他们会把我视为平等的一员，觉得我在为他们提供一些东西——他们也能参与其中。”

Dylan succeeded in this activity, ultimately trading up for a whiskey glass laser-etched with a mountain range, in large part because he understood his power—he could be theatrical and make people feel like part of a story. He used that power as leverage. He wasn’t asking for something for nothing; he was extending an invitation to be a part of something fun and quirky. He had something valuable to offer, and he used it.

迪伦在这项活动中取得了成功，最终换来了一个激光蚀刻着山脉图案的威士忌酒杯，这很大程度上是因为他明白自己的影响力——他能营造戏剧效果，让人们感觉自己是故事的一部分。他利用这种影响力作为筹码。他并非不劳而获；他是在发出邀请，邀请人们参与到一件有趣而奇特的事情中来。他拥有有价值的东西，并且充分利用了它。

The power of problem solving

解决问题的力量

My student Bradley—who owns and operates an event space in New Orleans—came to see me after class one day to say he was reluctant to break out of the fixed pricing structure used in his business. He had a quick, short sales cycle that he said worked for him—customers could clearly see a set menu of services and choose from it. Wham, bam, done. He didn’t think my emphasis on information exchange, on the importance of empathizing with the customer, applied to his company.

我的学生布拉德利在新奥尔良拥有一家活动场地并亲自经营。一天课后，他来找我，说他不愿意打破目前固定的定价模式。他采用的是快速高效的销售流程，他说这种模式很适合他——顾客可以清楚地看到服务项目清单，并从中选择。简单快捷，一气呵成。他认为我强调的信息交流以及与顾客共情的重要性并不适用于他的公司。

“I see it differently,” I said. There was so much potential with Bradley. He was an incredible “people person”—that much was clear. His classmates adored him, and he was always able to get great information whenever he was bargaining. He knew he was good at information exchange, he just didn’t believe that power could be harnessed to help his business. I encouraged him to spend more time up front getting to know his customers so that he could differentiate their needs and interests more effectively. I told him to leave behind his one-size-fits-all pitch, to approach every client with curiosity, as a problem solver and visionary. Bradley had reservations, so I asked what he had to lose. Like so many others in his class, he worked constantly, taking time from his family, and felt exhausted, stretched, and like he was running in place. Plus, if Bradley couldn’t grow his business, he put himself at risk for the next market downturn. He made a commitment to try.

“我的看法不一样，”我说。布拉德利潜力无限。他是个非常善于交际的人——这一点毋庸置疑。同学们都很喜欢他，而且他总能在谈判中获取有价值的信息。他知道自己擅长信息交流，只是不相信这种能力能帮助他发展事业。我鼓励他花更多时间了解客户，以便更有效地区分他们的需求和兴趣。我告诉他要摒弃千篇一律的推销方式，以好奇心对待每一位客户，把自己定位为问题解决者和远见卓识者。布拉德利有些犹豫，所以我问他有什么可失去的。和班上许多其他同学一样，他一直在努力工作，牺牲了陪伴家人的时间，感觉筋疲力尽，身心俱疲，就像原地踏步一样。而且，如果布拉德利无法发展自己的事业，那么在下一次市场低迷时期，他将面临巨大的风险。但他还是决定尝试一下。

Following our after-class discussion, Bradley got a call from prospective clients wanting to throw a bat mitzvah party for their daughter. He invited them in to tour his space and decided he would be more curious and spend more time with them. He asked all of his usual questions about the party itself, but he slowed down and made an effort to get to know them. The parents were both doctors who worked very hard. The dad was from Florida, and the mom was German. “It was amazingly easy and interesting,” Bradley said about learning more of the family’s story. The party was to be a Hollywood-themed bat mitzvah for their daughter, who as it happened went to school with Bradley’s son. Bradley also learned that the family had attended other bar and bat mitzvahs at his event space, and how convenient it was since it was only seconds from their temple—a fact Bradley knew but hadn’t before considered a huge benefit.

课后讨论结束后，布拉德利接到几位潜在客户的电话，他们想为女儿举办一场犹太女孩的成人礼派对。他邀请他们参观场地，并决定多花些时间与他们交流。他像往常一样询问了派对的相关事宜，但这次他放慢了节奏，努力了解他们。这对父母都是医生，工作非常努力。父亲来自佛罗里达州，母亲是德国人。“了解这个家庭的故事真是既轻松又有趣，”布拉德利说道。这场派对的主题是好莱坞，他们的女儿恰好和布拉德利的儿子是同学。布拉德利还了解到，这家人之前在他的场地参加过其他犹太男孩的成人礼和女孩的成人礼，而且场地离他们的犹太教堂只有几步之遥，非常方便——布拉德利之前知道这一点，但从未意识到这是一个巨大的优势。

The mom explained that the daughter had a grand vision of the night, but the parents were so busy with work-related travel that they couldn’t themselves put together all that their daughter was dreaming of, unless Bradley could do it for them. “This is when it became even more fun and rewarding,” Bradley reported to me later. “At my core, I love to help people and I love cool new things. I will pour myself into making this amazingly unique experience happen for people.” This was his power. “They always love the outcome and are very thankful, but the problem is I have not always considered myself, my time, my creative value, as valuable.”

这位母亲解释说，女儿对当晚的安排有着美好的憧憬，但父母因为工作出差太忙，根本无暇顾及女儿的梦想，除非布拉德利能帮他们实现。“正是在这个时候，事情变得更有趣、更有成就感了，”布拉德利后来告诉我，“我骨子里喜欢帮助别人，也喜欢新鲜事物。我会全身心投入，为人们打造这种独一无二的体验。” 这就是他的力量。“他们总是对最终的成果非常满意，也十分感激，但问题是，我以前并没有真正意识到自己、我的时间和我的创造力的价值。”

Being curious allowed Bradley to humanize the interaction and not approach it as just another transaction. Through this process, he realized that he was a partner in a shared goal. Once it came time to provide them a cost estimate, he gave them a much higher opening offer than he would have otherwise, talking himself out of second-guessing himself or “anticipating their pushback” and focusing instead on what it would truly cost to give them the caliber of event that they wanted with all the bells and whistles.

好奇心让布拉德利能够以人为本的方式与客户互动，而不是仅仅将其视为一笔交易。在这个过程中，他意识到自己是客户共同目标的伙伴。到了提供报价的时候，他给出了一个远高于预期的报价，避免了犹豫不决或“预料到客户的反对”，而是专注于真正能够满足客户所有需求，打造他们想要的高品质活动所需的成本。

Bradley could have put on a perfectly acceptable bat mitzvah that he made a small profit on. Instead he created a one-of-a-kind masterpiece centered on an exuberant young woman, whose love and passion for Hollywood were transformed into a custom-designed experience for her family and friends to enjoy. “When I gave the quote,” Bradley said, “the mom booked on the spot, leaving me knowing that they had that extra money for us to develop this great theme, and the satisfaction to know that individuals are motivated by more than money.” Saving money was not his clients’ interest—making their daughter happy was. Given their lack of time, it was easy to make the hiring decision and book the event. Bradley’s “ask” wasn’t out of line but rather perfectly reasonable. He hadn’t been greedy by any stretch of the imagination. He had just finally determined what his services and skills were worth.

布拉德利本可以办一场普通的成人礼，从中赚取一些利润。但他却打造了一场独一无二的杰作，以一位活力四射的年轻女子为中心，将她对好莱坞的热爱和激情融入到为她的家人和朋友量身定制的体验中。“当我报出报价时，”布拉德利说，“那位母亲当场就预定了，这让我知道他们愿意额外支付这笔钱来打造这个精彩的主题，也让我感到欣慰，因为我知道人们的动机不仅仅是金钱。” 省钱并非客户的目的——让他们的女儿开心才是。鉴于他们时间紧迫，所以很容易就决定聘请他并预定活动。布拉德利的“要价”并非过分，而是完全合理。他绝非贪婪。他只是最终确定了自己的服务和技能的价值所在。

Bradley’s leverage only grew from there. He started attending Seth Godin marketing seminars, which highlight empathy, and he doubled down on his company’s focus on it. “I started noticing that brides were emailing me at one forty-five, two, three in the morning, requesting to see the space. Well, obviously I wasn’t going to get out of bed and show them at that time, but I started thinking more deeply about why they were thinking about this at two in the morning, what it was they wanted to know, and how I could help them.” He wanted to make the whole process easier for them, so he decided to invest in a virtual tour with audio that brides and grooms could check out at any time that suited them, or whenever nervousness and insomnia hit.

布拉德利的影响力从此与日俱增。他开始参加塞思·戈丁的营销研讨会，这些研讨会强调同理心，他也加倍重视公司在这方面的投入。“我开始注意到，新娘们会在凌晨一点四十五分、两点甚至三点给我发邮件，要求参观场地。显然，我不可能在这个时候起床带她们看，但我开始深入思考，为什么她们会在凌晨两点考虑这件事，她们想知道什么，以及我能如何帮助她们。”他想让整个过程对她们来说更轻松，于是决定投资制作一个带有语音的虚拟导览，这样新人们就可以在任何方便的时候查看，或者在感到紧张和失眠的时候观看。

“Some people might approach their business thinking, ‘How do I make this easier on myself?’ and avoid the harder clients,” Bradley said. “But I think, no, it’s my magic sauce to make it easier on the client. That’s the differentiator with my company. And I love it if they’re tough—because I try hard, and so I get to show myself as above the competition,” he explained. It’s worked. His bookings last year were his best ever, and he’s set to be up 35 percent over that in the year to come.

“有些人做生意时可能会想着‘怎样才能让自己轻松点？’，然后避开那些难缠的客户，”布拉德利说。“但我认为，不，让客户轻松点才是我的秘诀。这正是我们公司的独特之处。而且我很喜欢难缠的客户——因为这样我会更加努力，也能展现出我超越竞争对手的优势，”他解释道。事实证明，这招奏效了。他去年的订单量创历史新高，预计来年还会增长35%。

The enduring power of authenticity

真实性的持久力量

When Sebastian Jackson, whom I introduced in Chapter 2, finally persuaded Wayne State University to let him open a barbershop on campus (after three tries!), his predominant feeling was gratitude. The way he saw it, he was someone who cut hair and wanted to open a barbershop, and he was happy to finally have the opportunity.

我在第二章中介绍过的塞巴斯蒂安·杰克逊，在三次尝试后终于说服韦恩州立大学允许他在校园内开设一家理发店，他当时最强烈的感受是感激。在他看来，他本来就是个理发师，一直想开一家理发店，如今终于有机会实现这个愿望，他感到非常高兴。

Part of his business plan from the beginning included bringing in interesting speakers to liven the place up and to build connections among the community who used the barbershop.

从一开始，他的商业计划就包括邀请有趣的演讲者来活跃气氛，并在光顾理发店的社区居民之间建立联系。

A friend of his commented, “This is a black barbershop.” Sebastian said it wasn’t, but his friend insisted. “I thought it was degrading our culture,” Sebastian said, when he thought of the stereotype of the African American barbershop as a place of community gossip. “I was looking to elevate the barbershop.”

他的一位朋友评论说：“这是一家黑人理发店。”塞巴斯蒂安说不是，但他的朋友坚持己见。“我觉得这贬低了我们的文化，”塞巴斯蒂安说，他想到人们对非裔美国人理发店的刻板印象——一个闲聊八卦的地方。“我当时是想提升理发店的档次。”

Sebastian ran from the stereotype, instead focusing on bringing through the door all kinds of people with all kinds of hair to be cut. By the second or third year of business, though, Sebastian understood the value he was bringing. “I was almost disrespecting the barbershop culture that’s been built,” he said. “As we grew, I saw we were bringing interesting people to Wayne State. We were giving people access to interesting people who would come to our barbershop.” He realized his shop, The Social Club, was playing a real role in reviving Detroit. “I realized that I have value to add—I’m black in a city that’s eighty-five percent black.” And although The Social Club welcomes all customers, he realized, “This is a black barbershop because it’s a black-owned barbershop.”

塞巴斯蒂安刻意回避刻板印象，而是专注于吸引各种各样的人，无论他们的发型如何，都来理发。然而，到了开业的第二年或第三年，塞巴斯蒂安意识到了自己带来的价值。“我当时几乎是在亵渎已经形成的理发店文化，”他说。“随着我们的发展，我发现我们为韦恩州立大学带来了许多有趣的人。我们让人们有机会接触到那些会光顾我们理发店的有趣的人。”他意识到自己的理发店“社交俱乐部”正在为底特律的复兴做出真正的贡献。“我意识到我能带来价值——在这个黑人占85%的城市里，我是一名黑人。”尽管“社交俱乐部”欢迎所有顾客，但他意识到，“这是一家黑人理发店，因为它是一家黑人拥有的理发店。”

His outlook has given him a lot of leverage in his business as he looks to grow and expand. “The people who are doing all this development [in Detroit] are looking to be inclusive. I’m from Flint, grew up in Detroit, so now they need that. They need The Social Club.” The very thing he was afraid of accepting, which was the authenticity of experience he could offer customers, is now his great leverage.

他的远见卓识为他拓展业务提供了巨大的优势。“底特律的开发商们都希望打造包容性。我来自弗林特，在底特律长大，所以现在他们需要这样的氛围。他们需要像社交俱乐部这样的场所。”他曾经害怕接受的——他能为顾客提供的真实体验——如今却成了他强大的优势。

I’ve seen so many people, like Sebastian, who struggle against a part of themselves that they’ve been conditioned to think is a weakness, when in fact it’s a strength. The racial baggage regarding the “barbershop” is an example of this; another is the trait of introversion.

我见过太多像塞巴斯蒂安这样的人，他们一直在与自身某些特质作斗争，这些特质被他们从小灌输为弱点，但实际上却是一种优势。关于“理发店”的种族偏见就是一个例子；内向的性格也是一个例子。

Susan Cain, an introvert like me, worked at a law firm and—believe it or not—was a negotiations consultant before turning to writing and lecturing. She noticed that introverts were constantly being told to get out there, to be around people, to be social, to be—in effect—something that they weren’t. Her TED Talk on the subject and her book, Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can’t Stop Talking , were immediate hits. It turns out there are a lot of us who don’t see our introversion as a superpower but would very much like to. And we should. Introverts notice things about people, they are careful, they are excellent listeners, and they think deeply. All of these traits are brilliant in a negotiation.

苏珊·凯恩和我一样是个内向的人，她曾在一家律师事务所工作，而且——信不信由你——在转行写作和演讲之前，她还是一名谈判顾问。她注意到，内向的人总是被要求走出去，多与人交往，多社交，实际上，他们被要求成为他们并非的那种人。她关于这个主题的TED演讲和她的著作《安静：内向者的力量》一经出版便大获成功。事实证明，我们当中很多人都不认为自己的内向是一种超能力，但我们非常希望自己能这样认为。而且我们也应该这样认为。内向的人善于观察他人，他们谨慎细心，他们是优秀的倾听者，而且他们思考深刻。所有这些特质在谈判中都至关重要。

The same is true for emotionality. When Julia signed up for my negotiations class, for instance, she was sure it would be a struggle. She had worked as a consultant before returning to business school at Wharton, and from her mentors and her work experience, she had become convinced that showing emotion and revealing vulnerability signaled weakness. The problem, as Julia saw it, was that she was a naturally empathetic, open person. She felt she would have to bury those aspects of her personality when she took my class.

情感方面也是如此。例如，朱莉娅报名参加我的谈判课时，她确信这会是一场苦战。在重返沃顿商学院之前，她曾做过咨询顾问，从她的导师和工作经验中，她一直认为流露情感和暴露脆弱是软弱的表现。在朱莉娅看来，问题在于她天生就是一个富有同理心、性格开朗的人。她觉得上我的课时，她不得不压抑自己性格中的这些特质。

Indeed, on the first day it probably seemed like she would. Without much preamble, I sent everyone off for a mock negotiation, and then when they returned I put the results on the board. Julia hadn’t done well. “The guy I went up against pulled the wool over my eyes,” she remembered. “Everyone was trying to win—everyone was viewing negotiation that way. I remember coming back to the room and being so embarrassed and thinking, how am I going to get through this class? I was too nice, I was gullible.”

的确，第一天她看起来好像会成功。我没怎么铺垫，就让大家去进行模拟谈判，等他们回来后，我把结果写在了黑板上。朱莉娅表现不佳。“跟我对弈的那个人把我耍得团团转，”她回忆道，“每个人都想赢——每个人都把谈判看作是赢家。我记得回到教室后，我尴尬极了，心想，我该怎么通过这门课？我太善良了，太容易上当受骗了。”

Soon after, though, I talked to the class about Brené Brown’s book Daring Greatly: How the Courage to Be Vulnerable Transforms the Way We Live, Love, Parent, and Lead , which focuses on the power of vulnerability. I connected it to negotiation, explaining that being open and telling someone how you feel in a negotiation can be a great source of power. “It resonated with me,” said Julia, “this assertion that being vulnerable can be powerful. Because vulnerability is the stuff of relationships, and relationships are the point of negotiation.”

不过不久之后，我跟班上同学们聊起了布琳·布朗的著作《敢于伟大：脆弱的力量如何改变我们的生活、爱、为人父母和领导方式》，这本书着重探讨了脆弱的力量。我把它和谈判联系起来，解释说在谈判中坦诚地表达自己的感受可以成为一种强大的力量。“我对此深有感触，”朱莉娅说，“这种‘脆弱的力量’的说法。因为脆弱是人际关系的基础，而人际关系正是谈判的本质。”

Julia went from viewing negotiation as an isolated, scary activity to grasping that negotiation is about emotional intelligence, being open with yourself and others about what you want and why. Now that she had the permission to be who she was, she realized that it was actually her greatest source of power. That doesn’t mean she “word-vomits,” as she put it. Words matter, and she is thoughtful about what she shares with others and how. But she is more likely to be forthcoming about what is hard and what isn’t. Now that she’s returned to her job as a consultant, she said, “Selling projects to clients, I see now, is a negotiation. We scope a piece of work to help them, and then we need to work with them to jointly determine what is most important to them, how we should tailor our focus and our team to best help them. We have to make trade-offs and be clear about expectations—what we will and won’t do. It’s about zeroing in on what they really need, and it doesn’t always mean that we just do more for them. We are not afraid to tell them that something they’ve asked us to help with isn’t our area of expertise or isn’t the best use of their money. Being open, being vulnerable, and communicating more through the process helps us do the work we’re best positioned to do and helps them make wise investments. I don’t go into these conversations stressed out. We’re understanding of their requirements. They’re understanding of ours. What’s to worry about?”

朱莉娅最初把谈判视为一项孤立且令人畏惧的活动，后来她意识到谈判其实关乎情商，需要坦诚地告诉自己和他人自己的需求和原因。如今，她终于可以做真实的自己，并意识到这才是她最大的力量源泉。但这并不意味着她会像她自己说的那样“滔滔不绝”。她很重视言辞，会仔细斟酌与他人分享的内容和方式。但她更倾向于坦诚地表达哪些事情难，哪些事情容易。现在她重操旧业做咨询顾问了，她说：“我现在明白，向客户推销项目其实就是一场谈判。我们会先确定一个项目的范围，然后与他们共同探讨对他们而言最重要的是什么，以及如何调整我们的工作重点和团队配置才能更好地帮助他们。我们必须做出取舍，并且明确双方的期望——哪些我们能做，哪些我们做不了。关键在于精准把握他们的真正需求，而这并不总是意味着我们要为他们做更多的事情。我们并不害怕告诉他们，他们委托我们帮忙的事情并非我们的专业领域，或者并非最划算的投资。在整个过程中保持开放、坦诚和沟通，能够帮助我们发挥自身优势，也能帮助他们做出明智的投资。我不会带着压力去进行这些对话。我们理解他们的需求，他们也理解我们的需求。这有什么好担心的呢？”

Dana Sicko, founder of Gundalow Gourmet, shared a lot of Julia’s characteristics—and her fears. “I went into business thinking, I’m a woman going into a very saturated field. I’m going to be bulldozed every time I talk to someone.” Then, in class, we talked about the power of empathy to make you a phenomenal negotiator. “This was right off of a week with my therapist where we were talking about how I have a lot of empathy,” Dana said. “Something I never thought would be a strength for me, I was told is. I’m emotionally intelligent, and that’s intrinsic to who I am. That gave me so much confidence when I realized it was my superpower.”

Gundalow Gourmet 的创始人 Dana Sicko 与 Julia 有很多相似之处——以及她们的担忧。“我当初进入商界时想的是，我是一个女人，要进入一个竞争非常激烈的领域。每次和别人交谈，我都会被人碾压。” 后来，在课堂上，我们讨论了同理心的力量如何让你成为一名出色的谈判者。“就在我接受心理咨询一周后，我们聊到了我非常有同理心，” Dana 说。“我以前从未想过这会成为我的优势，但咨询师告诉我，这确实是我的优势。我情商很高，这是我与生俱来的特质。当我意识到这是我的超能力时，我充满了自信。”

Ambassador Wendy Sherman wrote that in her negotiation with Iran over the country’s nuclear capacity, a turning point came when frustrated tears ran down her face as she spoke to her Iranian counterparts. As she remembers, they were stunned by her emotion, because “this weeping, viscerally direct Wendy was a person they hadn’t encountered.” It’s not that the moment changed the game they’d been locked in for months, and really, for years. “But something in the sincerity of my frustration,” Wendy wrote, “the realness of the moment, broke through. . . . [T]he fact is that when we are ourselves, even if that means letting our tears flow, we can be our most powerful.”

温迪·舍曼大使写道，在她与伊朗就该国核能力进行谈判的过程中，一个转折点出现在她与伊朗同行交谈时，沮丧的泪水夺眶而出。她回忆说，伊朗同行被她的情绪所震惊，因为“他们从未见过这样一个哭泣、如此真挚的温迪”。这并非意味着那一刻改变了他们几个月甚至几年以来一直僵持的局面。“但我的沮丧之情中蕴含着某种东西，”温迪写道，“那一刻的真实感，突破了一切……事实是，当我们展现真实的自我时，即使这意味着让泪水流淌，我们也能发挥出最大的力量。”

Experience matters

经验至关重要

Glen Cutrona is an architect who’s been in business for thirty years. The guy knows his way around a drafting board. Still, when meeting with prospective clients, he used to spend a lot of time talking about his experience, so that they would know just how qualified he was. He used to spend an inordinate amount of time agonizing over quotes, because he was afraid that if he priced something too high he would lose the customer. As a competitive guy, he desperately wanted to beat out whoever else was bidding on the job.

格伦·库特罗纳是一位从业三十年的建筑师，对绘图板了如指掌。即便如此，在与潜在客户会面时，他仍然会花大量时间讲述自己的经验，以便让他们了解他的资质。他过去常常在报价上花费大量时间，因为他害怕如果价格过高就会失去客户。他生性好胜，渴望在所有竞标者中胜出。

Glen was letting his competitors and the market define his value, a mistake. Glen had to recognize that his power was his experience. After thirty years, he knew better than most what it takes to do a job in a quality way. “There’s a certain standard of care that needs to be devoted to a project,” he explained. “People in the public do not know to what extent the services are. They don’t know what to ask for.”

格伦让竞争对手和市场来定义他的价值，这是个错误。格伦必须认识到，他的力量源于他的经验。三十年的从业经验让他比大多数人都更清楚如何才能高质量地完成工作。“一个项目需要达到一定的标准，”他解释说，“公众并不了解服务的水平，也不知道该提出怎样的要求。”

He has gotten pushback from prospective clients, who will say, “Well, this other architect costs one third less than you do.” Whereas in the past this would have kicked Glen’s competitive nature into gear, now it doesn’t. He just explains he couldn’t do a job to his standards for that fee, and he explains what is required to do his work in a high-quality way. “I still want to win, but win so that it’s good for everyone, including myself. I know that the list of services that I put on a job is what is needed to produce a good end product.” He’s not letting others place a value on him. “If you’re calling our firm, I don’t compromise.”

他曾遭到一些潜在客户的质疑，他们会说：“嗯，其他建筑师的报价比你低三分之一。” 过去，这会激发格伦的竞争本能，但现在不会了。他只是解释说，如果收费那么低，他无法达到自己的标准，并解释高质量完成工作需要哪些条件。“我仍然想赢，但要赢得对每个人都有好处，包括我自己。我知道我列出的服务项目清单，是交付优质最终成果所必需的。” 他不会让别人来衡量他的价值。“如果你打电话给我们公司，我绝不妥协。”

Glen no longer spends time telling clients about his qualifications—instead, he asks them questions. “If you know your stuff,” he said, “you don’t need to explain that to people.” He feels more confident, and since he is resting in his power of experience, he has all the leverage he needs.

格伦不再花时间向客户介绍自己的资历，而是直接向他们提问。“如果你对自己的领域了如指掌，”他说，“就无需向别人解释。”他感觉更加自信，而且由于他充分发挥了自身经验的优势，他已经拥有了所需的一切筹码。

“The results have been great,” Glen said. “My firm is doing significantly better. I don’t know that I’m doing much more work, but I’m pricing it correctly. We’re able to service our clients. Our end result has always been good, but now it’s better.”

“效果非常好，”格伦说。“我的公司业绩显著提升。我不知道我的工作量是否增加了多少，但我定价合理。我们能够更好地服务客户。我们的最终成果一直都不错，但现在更好了。”

Prepare, prepare, prepare

准备，准备，准备

Alan Harris owns a bridal boutique with his wife, Jeannine, and his daughter, Melissa, but he’s a data guy at heart. While his daughter has more of an eye on fashion aesthetics, Alan looks carefully at their inventory and implemented a system where salespeople record not only which gowns are sold but which are tried on.

艾伦·哈里斯和妻子珍妮以及女儿梅丽莎共同经营一家婚纱精品店，但他本质上是个数据控。女儿更注重时尚美学，而艾伦则仔细查看库存，并建立了一套系统，让销售人员不仅记录哪些婚纱售出，还记录哪些婚纱被试穿。

One day they got a visit from a sales rep for the line they do the most business with, and with whom they have an exclusive arrangement. “Your sales are going down,” the rep said. “We’re going to open up this line to a second store.”

有一天，他们接待了一位销售代表，这位代表负责销售他们生意最红火、也是他们独家经销的品牌。“你们的销售额正在下降，”销售代表说，“我们打算把这个品牌的销售范围扩大到第二家门店。”

Alan and Melissa were confused. “Wait a minute,” they said. “We don’t see our sales going down. So what’s the disconnect?”

艾伦和梅丽莎感到困惑。“等等，”他们说，“我们没看到销售额下降啊。这是怎么回事呢？”

The impasse was not resolved that day, but Alan and Melissa wrote a letter to the sales rep’s boss—who, they later found out, was actually her boss’s boss’s boss—and who acted on it quickly. The company executives invited them for an in-person meeting. Melissa brought a simple but thorough chart that demonstrated their sales—that all three lines from this designer had gone up, and that their dresses were getting tried on 90 percent of the time. In a simple format, Melissa was able to show precisely which dresses were being tried on, and that of the top twenty dresses tried on in the past six months, eighteen were from this designer.

僵局当天并未解决，但艾伦和梅丽莎给那位销售代表的上司写了一封信——后来他们发现，这位上司其实是她上司的上司——上司很快就采取了行动。公司高管邀请他们进行面谈。梅丽莎带来了一张简洁却详尽的图表，图表清晰地展示了他们的销售情况：这位设计师的三个系列的所有产品销量都增长了，而且他们的礼服有90%的试穿率。梅丽莎用简洁明了的方式，准确地展示了哪些礼服被试穿，并指出在过去六个月中最受欢迎的20件试穿礼服中，有18件来自这位设计师。

“We don’t see how you can say that they’re not going up,” Melissa said.

“我们不明白你怎么能说它们没有上涨，”梅丽莎说。

The design executives were appropriately impressed, and said so. “We have some graphs to show you too, but we can’t explain them as well as you can explain yours.”

设计部门的主管们对此印象深刻，并表示：“我们也有一些图表可以给你们看，但我们无法像你们那样解释得那么清楚。”

Melissa and Alan were then able to move the discussion toward what the real objective was. “What’s the partnership we can do to increase sales to brides? Let’s concentrate on that,” Alan said, which led to a much more cooperative discussion. “We set some good mutual goals,” Alan said, “and determined discounts associated with obtaining those goals. We talked about some things the design company could do to help us, like trunk shows.”

随后，梅丽莎和艾伦得以将讨论引向真正的目标。“我们能通过哪些合作来增加面向新娘的销售额？让我们集中精力讨论这个问题，”艾伦说道，这促成了一场更具合作性的讨论。“我们制定了一些双方都认可的目标，”艾伦说，“并确定了与实现这些目标相关的折扣。我们还讨论了设计公司可以为我们做些什么，比如举办巡回展。”

The design company then aired their grievance that their labels were removed from the gowns before they were tried on. “We pay to advertise on our website to push customers to your location, and you’re not featuring us by allowing our name to be in the dresses.”

这家设计公司随后表达了他们的不满，称他们的标签在试穿礼服前就被撕掉了。“我们付费在网站上投放广告，是为了把顾客引流到你们的店铺，而你们却允许我们的名字出现在礼服上，这简直是在破坏我们的形象。”

The two parties then turned to problem-solving this issue. The reason boutiques take labels out is that they don’t want brides to find a dress they like at the boutique and spend all of the salesperson’s time, but then—based on the designer and stock number—hunt around for the lowest price. Working together, they determined that going forward there was a way to take the stock number out but leave the designer name in.

双方随后着手解决这个问题。精品店之所以会移除标签，是因为他们不希望新娘在店内找到心仪的婚纱，浪费销售人员的所有时间，然后又根据设计师和库存编号四处寻找最低价格。经过协商，双方最终确定，今后可以移除库存编号，但保留设计师姓名。

“Can you put the labels back in that you’ve already taken out?” the design company asked.

设计公司问道：“你能把已经取下来的标签重新贴回去吗？”

Alan and Melissa said they couldn’t, because it was too time intensive. But they suggested that the design company could send someone to their store to do it.

艾伦和梅丽莎说他们做不到，因为这太费时间了。但他们建议设计公司可以派人到他们的店里来做。

All in all, Alan reflected, it was a really successful negotiation because everyone left happy. And the preparation they’d done—the rich data they’d collected—gave them credibility. “We were able to present facts, not emotions or feelings. So that helped,” he said. The data made clear, too, that a lot of designer companies sell wedding gowns. Alan and Melissa said they were actually questioning whether they should be doing 60 or 70 percent of their business with one company. “Our data gave us leverage to have that conversation.”

总而言之，艾伦总结道，这是一次非常成功的谈判，因为大家都皆大欢喜。他们所做的准备——收集到的丰富数据——赋予了他们可信度。“我们能够呈现事实，而不是情绪或感受。这很有帮助，”他说。数据也清楚地表明，许多设计师公司都销售婚纱。艾伦和梅丽莎表示，他们其实正在考虑是否应该将60%或70%的业务都交给一家公司。“我们的数据让我们有底气去进行这场对话。”

Valuing likability

重视讨喜程度

Though Chapter 2 focused on the troubles inherent in needing to be liked, there’s also no denying that likability is an asset. If you’re a good person, if you’re kind, people will want to be around you. Likable people tend to go far in life.

虽然第二章主要探讨了渴望被人喜欢所带来的种种问题，但不可否认的是，讨人喜欢确实是一种优势。如果你为人善良，待人友善，人们自然会想要和你在一起。人缘好的人往往更容易在人生道路上取得成功。

I’m a big proponent of kindness for an altogether unexpected reason: I don’t enjoy conflict, and whatever result I’m going for, I don’t want to get there having had a knife fight. I want to get there in a way that doesn’t make me feel like I’ve fought a war. I want to get there in a way that’s not gruesome. You can put in the effort to keep a conflict going, or you can think to yourself: You know what? Honey is just going to attract the bees.

我大力提倡友善，原因却出乎意料：我不喜欢冲突，无论最终结果如何，我都不想通过一场刀光剑影的搏斗来实现。我希望达成目标的方式不会让我感觉像是经历了一场战争。我希望达成目标的方式不会让人感到残酷。你可以努力维持冲突，也可以想：你知道吗？蜂蜜只会吸引蜜蜂。

There may be no better venue for practicing kindness and likability than at an airport—particularly after a stressful travel experience. I was recently at the Providence airport, a bit stressed because I’d just missed a flight. I had a negotiation ahead of me: I needed to talk to the customer service agent about what could be done, and hopefully I wouldn’t eat the entire cost of the ticket. I waited in line behind these two women who were taking turns yelling at the agent. The agent looked tired. When it was my turn, I went up and said, “So I missed that flight. I just want to know what my options are. And I don’t know what just happened with the people in front of me, but I’m sorry you have to put up with it. We can’t blame you.”

或许没有比机场更适合展现友善和亲和力的地方了——尤其是在经历了一次令人焦虑的旅行之后。我最近在普罗维登斯机场，因为错过了航班，心情有些紧张。我得和客服人员谈谈：我得问问有什么办法，希望能避免承担全部机票费用。我排在前面两位女士的队伍里，她们轮流冲着客服人员大喊大叫。客服人员看起来很疲惫。轮到我的时候，我走上前去说：“我错过了航班。我想知道我有哪些选择。我不知道前面那两位女士刚才发生了什么，但很抱歉让你们受罪。我们完全理解你们的感受。”

The agent smiled and sighed. She printed me a ticket for the next flight and said, “Here’s your ticket. Come back in two hours to board.” It’s true that she might have charged me the full fare, but it didn’t matter. My strategy of communicating kindly and respectfully was still better than any alternative. I felt good about giving her the respect that I felt she had been robbed of by the customers before me. And I was genuine—hers was not a job I would want!

售票员笑了笑，叹了口气。她给我打印了一张下一班航班的机票，说：“这是您的机票。两小时后回来登机。” 她或许收了我全价，但这并不重要。我友好而尊重的沟通方式仍然胜过任何其他选择。我觉得我给予了她应有的尊重，而这种尊重似乎被之前的顾客剥夺了。而且我是真心实意的——她的工作我可不想做！

John Lynch, whom I wrote about in Chapter 5, has long had a reputation for his likability. Although he was a madman on the field as an NFL safety, fiercely competitive and unwilling to take crap from anyone, off the field he was known as a sweetheart. He was all too happy to delegate negotiation responsibilities to his agent. He always felt that certain people were made to negotiate, and he wasn’t one of those people. “I wasn’t a hard-line negotiator,” he said. “I would always give in early and my agent would be like, ‘John, you have big leverage. You’re at the top of your game. You’re the best safety in the National Football League.’

我在第五章中提到的约翰·林奇，一直以来都以平易近人著称。虽然作为一名NFL安全卫，他在球场上是个“疯子”，极具竞争精神，不容任何人欺负，但在场下，他却是个出了名的和蔼可亲的人。他非常乐意把谈判的责任委托给经纪人。他一直觉得有些人天生就适合谈判，而他自己并非其中之一。“我不是个强硬的谈判者，”他说，“我总是会早早让步，然后我的经纪人就会说，‘约翰，你现在很有优势。你正处于巅峰状态。你是NFL最好的安全卫。’”

“What I did know is what made me happy,” he explained, “and I’d say, ‘Hey, I like playing for this organization. I like certainty. I know that. Let’s take the deal.’ I’d always leave him disappointed, but we always did kind of believe, whether it was going to buy a car or whatever, that maybe I was too nice of a personality to be a skilled negotiator.”

“我当时只知道什么能让我快乐，”他解释说，“我会说，‘嘿，我喜欢为这个球队效力。我喜欢确定性。我知道这一点。那就接受这笔交易吧。’我总是让他失望，但我们一直都觉得，无论是买车还是其他什么事，也许我性格太好，不适合谈判。”

But when he took my class, John killed it. He recognized that people with “nice” personalities could do well using just that trait and finding ways everyone could win. “I would say, from that class on, I’ve always had more confidence in those situations,” he said. Now that he’s the general manager of the 49ers and negotiates with agents constantly, he sees that directness and likability go hand-in-hand. “I used to think being direct was being confrontational,” he said. But now he recognizes its great value. “So many people posture,” he said, “and the guys who just say, ‘Hey, John, this is what it’s going to take’ are the ones I enjoy dealing with most. You learn to trust certain ones.”

但约翰上我的课时表现非常出色。他意识到，性格“好”的人可以充分利用这一特质，找到让大家都受益的方法。“可以说，从那堂课之后，我在这类场合总是更有自信，”他说。现在，作为旧金山49人队的总经理，他经常与经纪人谈判，他发现直率和亲和力是相辅相成的。“我以前认为直率就是对抗，”他说。但现在他认识到直率的巨大价值。“很多人都喜欢装腔作势，”他说，“而那些会直接说‘嘿，约翰，事情需要这样做’的人，才是我最喜欢与之打交道的人。你会慢慢学会信任某些人。”

Lynch felt this approach was particularly effective in the franchise’s signing of quarterback Jimmy Garoppolo. “We got on a plane and I just kind of started the meeting with [his agent] Don Yee by saying, ‘Listen, Jimmy hasn’t played a lot of football, but we have gotten to a point where we really believe he is our guy. We have the ability to franchise Jimmy and play that game, but that’s not what I want. I want to get a deal done, and Don, here’s my promise. We’re not going to come in low, so that you can counter high. We’re going to come in strong.’

林奇认为这种方法在球队签下四分卫吉米·加罗波罗的过程中尤其有效。“我们上了飞机，我直接和（他的经纪人）唐·伊开会，我说：‘听着，吉米打的比赛不多，但我们已经确信他就是我们要找的人。我们有能力给吉米贴上特权标签，然后玩这套，但这并不是我想要的。我想尽快完成签约，唐，我保证。我们不会先压价，然后让你再抬价。我们会全力以赴。’”

“That’s my style,” Lynch said. “If I have a style of negotiation, it’s let’s not beat around the bush . I’ll say, ‘We’re going to come strong and I want you to know that going in. Not saying that there’s not going to be any room for wiggle, because obviously, that’s a part of negotiation, but we’re not going to insult each other’s integrity, intelligence. We’re going to take a hard attempt at getting this done.’

“这就是我的风格，”林奇说道。“如果要说我的谈判风格，那就是直截了当。我会说，‘我们会全力以赴，我希望你一开始就知道这一点。’这并不是说完全没有回旋余地，因为很明显，谈判中总会有回旋的余地，但我们不会侮辱对方的正直和智慧。我们会尽全力促成此事。”

“In the past,” Lynch went on, “I would have thought, Oh. That’s too bold to try to do that . But what I’ve found is, it’s effective, because there’s no gray area for anyone.”

林奇接着说：“过去，我会想，哦，这样做太大胆了。但我发现，这样做很有效，因为对任何人来说都没有灰色地带。”

That’s not to say that Lynch isn’t aware that his reputation for likability might encourage some to take advantage. Sometimes people try, he said. “You have to be willing to say, ‘No. I communicated exactly what I told you. I understand you’re trying to do a job, but I want to be very clear, this is where we’re at.’ It’s like your kids. If you say you’re going to do something, you better be willing to do it.”

这并不是说林奇没有意识到，他平易近人的名声可能会让一些人有机可乘。他说，有时候确实会有人这么做。“你必须敢于说，‘不。我已经把话说清楚了。我知道你在努力工作，但我想明确一点，我们现在的情况就是这样。’这就像对待孩子一样。如果你答应做某件事，就最好说到做到。”

For someone like Lynch, finding ways to connect with those he’s negotiating with is pretty straightforward—they always will have a passion for football in common. It might surprise you, though, just how important finding common ground is. In his book Influence: The Psychology of Persuasion , seminal psychologist and thinker Dr. Robert Cialdini emphasizes how important similarity is in likability. The more time you spend with someone, the more familiar you become, the more you see you have in common, and the more you like them. In a study of MBA students, some were told to get straight down to business in a negotiation, whereas others were told not to negotiate until they’d exchanged some personal information with the other. They were instructed to “ identify a similarity you share in common, then begin negotiating.” The straight-down-to-business group came to a resolution 55 percent of the time, which isn’t awful, but the friendly group? They came to a resolution 90 percent of the time, and those resolutions were more advantageous to both parties.

对于像林奇这样的人来说，与谈判对象建立联系的方法相当简单——他们总会有共同的爱好——那就是足球。然而，找到共同点的重要性可能会让你感到惊讶。在《影响力：说服心理学》一书中，著名心理学家和思想家罗伯特·西奥迪尼博士强调了相似性在提升好感度方面的重要性。你与某人相处的时间越长，你们就越熟悉，你们的共同点就越多，你也就越喜欢对方。在一项针对MBA学生的研究中，一些学生被要求在谈判中直奔主题，而另一些学生则被告知在与对方交换一些个人信息之前不要进行谈判。他们被要求“找到你们的共同点，然后开始谈判”。直奔主题组的谈判成功率达到了55%，这还不错，但友好交流组的谈判成功率又如何呢？他们90%的情况下都能达成解决方案，而且这些解决方案对双方都更有利。

A nonprofit called PeacePlayers takes this principle and literally runs with it, as it uses sports as the common link between opposing parties. In places like Jerusalem, Jewish and Arab teenagers play on basketball teams together. In Northern Ireland, where less than 7 percent of schools integrate Catholics and Protestants, kids play sports on the same side. Ninety-one percent of them had never interacted with someone from a different background until they joined PeacePlayers, which is also active in Cyprus, South Africa, and parts of the United States. PeacePlayers is such a great reminder to me of why I love sports—it brings people together around a common cause, a universal language.

一个名为“和平球员”（PeacePlayers）的非营利组织将这一原则付诸实践，利用体育作为对立双方的共同纽带。在耶路撒冷等地，犹太裔和阿拉伯裔青少年一起在篮球队打球。在北爱尔兰，只有不到7%的学校实现了天主教徒和新教徒的融合，孩子们却在同一支队伍中并肩作战。在加入“和平球员”之前，他们中有91%的人从未与来自不同背景的人接触过。该组织在塞浦路斯、南非和美国部分地区也开展活动。“和平球员”让我再次感受到我热爱体育的原因——它能将人们聚集在一起，为了共同的目标，用一种世界通用的语言进行交流。

From kids to adults, from sports to nuclear war, common ground remains a powerful tool. Whenever Ambassador Sherman met with her Iranian counterparts, they could not shake her hand because they were conservative Islamists, and she was of the opposite sex. Instead of letting this be a point of division, Sherman told them that she’d grown up in an Orthodox Jewish neighborhood, where the Orthodox were not allowed to touch anyone of the opposite sex if they weren’t closely related. The conversation melted a little of the ice between them. “They could see me a little better,” Sherman wrote, “not just as a representative of the United States, or as an untouchable member of the opposite sex, but as a human being with a history and an appreciation for their cultural norms. After this, we still bowed instead of shaking hands, but the fact that we could not shake hands became not an obstacle but a point of commonality.”

从孩童到成人，从体育到核战争，共同点始终是一种强大的力量。每当谢尔曼大使与伊朗同行会面时，对方都无法与她握手，因为他们是保守的伊斯兰主义者，而她又是异性。谢尔曼并没有让这成为隔阂，而是告诉他们，她成长于一个正统犹太教社区，在那里，正统犹太教徒不允许与非近亲异性有任何身体接触。这段对话缓和了彼此间的隔阂。“他们能更好地看待我，”谢尔曼写道，“不再仅仅把我视为美国的代表，或一个不可触碰的异性，而是把我视为一个有血有肉、有历史、尊重他们文化习俗的人。此后，我们仍然以鞠躬代替握手，但无法握手这件事不再是障碍，而是成为了我们彼此的共同点。”

Fake it till you make it

假装成功直到你真的成功

As all experienced negotiators know, the best way to get leverage is to know you can walk away. To do this, you need to know your best alternative to a negotiated agreement, or BATNA. The stronger your BATNA, the stronger your leverage, because you know you can walk away—you don’t need this client or this business.

所有经验丰富的谈判者都知道，获得谈判筹码的最佳方法是确保自己可以随时退出。为此，你需要了解谈判协议的最佳替代方案，即BATNA。你的BATNA越强，你的谈判筹码就越大，因为你知道你可以随时退出——你并不需要这个客户或这笔生意。

But what if you do?

但如果你真的这么做了呢？

If that’s the case, then your mind-set is more important than your reality. If you feel that you don’t have power, you need to put mind over matter and exude strength anyway. You need to fake it till you make it. Take a more direct page from Erin Brockovich’s book. If you are just one attorney going up against three, you might have to change the optics a bit. This is the same reason that when you encounter a bear, you are supposed to wave your arms and make yourself look as big as possible. If you can’t authentically give others the perception that you have power, then you have to use some Jedi mind tricks.

如果真是这样，那么你的心态比现实更重要。如果你觉得自己无能为力，那就需要用意志力战胜一切，强装出强大的气场。你需要假装强大，直到真正强大起来。不妨直接借鉴一下艾琳·布罗科维奇的做法。如果你只是一个律师，要对抗三个对手，你可能需要稍微改变一下你的形象。这和遇到熊时要挥舞手臂，让自己看起来尽可能庞大的道理是一样的。如果你无法让别人真切地感受到你的力量，那就只能用一些绝地武士般的心理战术了。

One way to do this is by acting the part, as Brockovich did. Scientific studies have shown that when you force yourself to smile, even when you’re feeling like crap, you actually start to feel better because the physical act of smiling triggers a chemical reaction in the brain, releasing dopamine and serotonin. Similarly, if you behave in a dominant way even when you have no power, you actually begin to feel more powerful. It’s not just fake perception anymore, it’s real. Importantly, dominant behaviors are not shouting or bullying. Rather, they involve behaviors like making expansive gestures so you take up more space (think of bears again), speaking loudly, and being assertive. Although a study from the University of Southern California showed that this works, its authors caution that if your counterpart believes you’re acting as a way to gain status, it will backfire. So use dominant behaviors with caution.

一种方法是像布罗科维奇那样，扮演好自己的角色。科学研究表明，即使你感觉糟糕透顶，强迫自己微笑也能让你感觉好一些，因为微笑的这个动作会触发大脑中的化学反应，释放多巴胺和血清素。同样地，即使你没有权力，如果你表现得强势，你也会感觉自己更有力量。这不再是虚假的感知，而是真实的。重要的是，强势行为并非大喊大叫或欺凌弱小。相反，它包括一些行为，例如做出舒展的手势来占据更多空间（想想熊），大声说话，以及表现得自信果断。虽然南加州大学的一项研究表明这种方法有效，但研究人员也提醒，如果你的对手认为你这样做是为了获得地位，那么就会适得其反。因此，谨慎使用强势行为。

The important, groundbreaking work of Harvard research scientist Amy Cuddy showed that when you stand in a dominant posture—like putting your arms out wide or on your hips Wonder Woman style—for two minutes, your testosterone level goes up and your cortisol (stress hormone) level goes down, giving you a sense of higher confidence and lower stress reactivity. She suggests doing it for two minutes in private before going into that negotiation, job interview, or any situation where you fear being evaluated. Cuddy emphasizes the importance not of faking it till you make it but faking it till you become it. “We convince by our presence,” she wrote, quoting Walt Whitman, then added, “and to convince others we need to convince ourselves.”

哈佛大学研究科学家艾米·卡迪（Amy Cuddy）的重要开创性研究表明，当你保持一种强势的站姿——比如双臂张开或像神奇女侠那样叉腰——两分钟后，你的睾酮水平会上升，皮质醇（压力激素）水平会下降，从而增强自信心，降低压力反应。她建议在谈判、面试或任何你害怕被评价的场合之前，私下里练习两分钟。卡迪强调，重要的不是“假装直到成功”，而是“假装直到你真正成为那样的人”。她引用沃尔特·惠特曼的名言写道：“我们用自身的存在感来说服他人”，然后补充道：“要想说服他人，我们首先需要说服自己。”

Another Jedi mind trick is to simply imagine that you have more power. This takes the power of positive thinking to another level, but one that is grounded in research. In a series of experiments, those who were trying to sell a CD but had just one (weak) offer were asked to imagine having a strong offer. They performed as well as the sellers who weren’t imagining it but actually did have a strong alternate offer. Those who didn’t have a strong alternative offer and who didn’t imagine having one did not do as well.

另一个绝地武士的“心灵感应”技巧是想象自己拥有更强大的力量。这能将积极思考的力量提升到一个新的层次，而且这种提升是有科学依据的。在一系列实验中，那些试图推销CD但只有一个（较弱的）报价的人被要求想象自己有一个更强的报价。结果发现，他们的销售业绩与那些没有想象但实际上拥有一个更强备选报价的销售人员一样好。而那些既没有更强备选报价也没有想象自己拥有备选报价的人，销售业绩则不如后者。

You never want to go into a negotiation feeling desperate, or that you need that deal to feel complete. That deal will not define you. Sometimes you fight that inclination by looking inward and embracing your power—be it vulnerability, like the consultant Julia, or creative partnership, like event space owner Bradley. And sometimes when the chips are obviously stacked against you, you must dig even deeper, finding the grain of belief and standing on it strongly . . . even if for the time being, you’re standing on just one foot.

你永远不应该带着绝望的心情去谈判，或者觉得非得达成这笔交易才能感到完整。这笔交易并不能定义你。有时，你需要通过内省和拥抱自身的力量来对抗这种倾向——无论是像咨询顾问茱莉亚那样展现脆弱，还是像活动场地老板布拉德利那样展现创造性的合作。有时，当形势明显对你不利时，你必须更加深入地挖掘自身潜力，找到那一点点信念，并坚定地站在它上面……即使此刻，你只能单脚站立。

Resting in your power: Negotiating with bullies

掌控自身力量：与欺凌者谈判

My students constantly ask, “What if I’m negotiating with a liar?” “What if I’m trying to make a connection and the person rebuffs my attempts?” “What if all he does is shout (or tweet)?” They are accustomed to a world where it seems like bullying strategies work , even if the academic research, the world’s foremost experts on negotiation, and history itself say otherwise.

我的学生经常问：“如果我和一个说谎的人谈判怎么办？”“如果我想建立联系，但对方拒绝我的尝试怎么办？”“如果他只会大喊大叫（或发推特）怎么办？”他们已经习惯了一个似乎欺凌策略有效的世界，即使学术研究、世界顶尖谈判专家的观点以及历史本身都表明并非如此。

The thing is, there’s no one way to negotiate with a bully, and in all likelihood, it will take building on all that’s come in this book so far and trying several strategies. Do always bring open-mindedness and empathy to the process. The more you can understand where the bully is coming from, what her interests are, and why she behaves the way she does, the more insight you have into how to handle her. For instance, if she bullies because she is insecure, part of your task will be to help her feel she’s done well even if you’ve come away having met all of your objectives. Do still try to disarm her, because even if charm doesn’t work, it might, and you’ve got nothing to lose by trying.

关键在于，与欺凌者谈判并没有万能的办法，很可能需要结合本书目前为止所学的内容，尝试多种策略。务必始终保持开放的心态和同理心。你越了解欺凌者的出发点、她的兴趣所在以及她行为背后的原因，就越能洞察如何应对她。例如，如果她欺凌他人是因为缺乏安全感，那么即使你已经达成了所有目标，你的任务之一也是让她觉得自己做得很好。仍然要尝试化解她的敌意，因为即使魅力不起作用，也并非完全没有可能，尝试一下也无妨。

If your counterpart’s particular form of bullying is lying, a combination of preparation, information gathering, presence, and the emotional intelligence you’re bringing to bear should tip you off. Doing your research and due diligence before coming to the table will probably alert you to the person’s reputation. If, say, you are discussing the value of an object he’s selling, don’t take his word for what it’s sold for before. Ask to see the proof or find it on your own before going into the negotiation if you can.

如果你的对手惯用的欺凌手段是撒谎，那么充分的准备、信息收集、临场表现以及你运用的情商应该能让你有所察觉。在谈判前做好调查和尽职调查，很可能会让你了解对方的为人。比如说，如果你正在讨论他要出售的物品的价值，不要轻易相信他所说的售价。如果可以的话，在谈判开始前，要求查看证据或自行查找相关信息。

Take the long view. A bully ultimately earns a reputation, and people won’t want to negotiate with her or do business with her at all. Remember the study I cited in Chapter 7: People are much more likely to walk away if the person they’re negotiating with exhibits anger. Even if the bully looks like she won in the short term, as practically every Hollywood movie moralizes, we know the bully gets hers in the end.

要从长远角度考虑。欺凌者最终会落得个恶名，人们根本不会愿意与她谈判或做生意。还记得我在第七章引用的研究吗？如果谈判对象表现出愤怒，人们更有可能选择离开。即使欺凌者短期内看似获胜（就像几乎所有好莱坞电影所宣扬的那样），我们也知道她最终会自食其果。

Many voters admired President Trump for matching the bullying language of North Korea’s Kim Jong Un on the issue of nuclear weapons testing. In an oft-cited tweet from 2018, Trump wrote: “North Korean Leader Kim Jong Un just stated that the ‘Nuclear Button is on his desk at all times.’ Will someone from his depleted and food starved regime please inform him that I too have a Nuclear Button, but it is a much bigger & more powerful one than his, and my Button works!” For a time, it did seem that the North Koreans tamped down their nuclear weapons testing. Trump and his supporters felt vindicated. As I write this, though, North Korea has just test-fired short-range missiles, overseen by Kim Jong Un. The showdown does not look likely to end anytime soon.

许多选民赞赏特朗普总统在核武器试验问题上与朝鲜领导人金正恩针锋相对，使用了强硬的言辞。在2018年一条广为流传的推文中，特朗普写道：“朝鲜领导人金正恩刚刚声称‘核按钮始终放在他的办公桌上’。他那支衰败且粮食短缺的政权中，是否有人能告诉他，我也有一个核按钮，而且比他的更大、威力更强，我的按钮还能用！” 一段时间内，朝鲜似乎确实减少了核武器试验。特朗普及其支持者感到自己的判断得到了证实。然而，就在我撰写本文时，朝鲜刚刚在金正恩的监督下试射了短程导弹。这场对峙似乎短期内不会结束。

There are some who will insist that the only way to deal with a bully is to match him, tenor for tenor, shout for shout, punch for punch. Honestly, I just don’t see the point. It’s not going to make him respect you. Knowing your leverage will . In the end, there is no better way to negotiate with a bully than to know your own power. You can’t be boxed from side to side, or cowed, if you understand your leverage. And while ultimately the bully will ultimately be knocked down a peg, whether by you or someone else, you will still be standing tall.

有些人坚持认为，对付恶霸的唯一方法就是以牙还牙，以口舌之争，以暴制暴。说实话，我真不明白这么做的意义何在。那样做并不能让他尊重你，真正能让他尊重你的是了解自己的优势。归根结底，与恶霸谈判的最佳策略莫过于了解自身的力量。如果你明白自己的优势，就不会被他左右逢源，也不会被他吓倒。最终，无论恶霸是被你还是其他人制服，他都会受到打击，而你依然会昂首挺胸。

Jessica Johnson, the head of a security company whom I introduced in the last chapter, has dealt with her share of bullies. She recalled that when she hired someone from a much bigger company, the new hire confessed that when she shared her plans her former bosses had said, “You’re going to work for David, you know. They’re David, and we’re Goliath. We’re buying everyone up and we’ll buy them up, too.”

我在上一章介绍过的保安公司负责人杰西卡·约翰逊也曾遭遇过不少欺凌。她回忆说，当她从一家规模大得多的公司挖来一位员工时，这位新员工坦白说，当她分享自己的计划时，她以前的老板曾说：“你知道，你要为大卫工作。他们是大卫，我们是歌利亚。我们要收购所有人，也一定会收购他们。”

Jessica grinned. “I thought, wait, they must not have read the rest of the Bible, because we know how that story ends.” My thoughts exactly.

杰西卡咧嘴一笑。“我想，等等，他们肯定没读过圣经的其他部分，因为我们都知道这个故事的结局。” 我的想法也一样。

#↩

CHAPTER 10

第十章

how negotiation can save democracy

谈判如何拯救民主

I always have two TVs on in my apartment—one set to cable news, the other to ESPN. My obsession with news and politics rivals my obsession with sports. But unlike sports, the news typically brings me down (a common reaction from anyone who pays too much attention to it). It feels like one fight after another, with no one side getting through to the other. I recognize there has always been disagreement in politics. In fact, a thriving democracy needs opposing views. But what I see around me now isn’t a healthy difference of opinion. I see people yelling through bullhorns and then putting their hands over their ears when the other side wants to talk. It’s alarming and makes me think of what Abraham Lincoln once said: “America will never be destroyed from the outside. If we falter and lose our freedoms, it will be because we destroyed ourselves.”

我的公寓里总是开着两台电视——一台调到有线新闻频道，另一台调到ESPN。我对新闻和政治的痴迷程度不亚于对体育的痴迷。但与体育不同的是，新闻通常会让我感到沮丧（这是任何过度关注新闻的人的常见反应）。感觉就像一场接一场的争吵，双方都无法沟通。我知道政治中一直存在分歧。事实上，一个繁荣的民主社会需要不同的观点。但我现在看到的并非健康的意见分歧。我看到人们拿着扩音器大喊大叫，然后当对方想发言时，他们就捂住耳朵。这令人担忧，让我想起亚伯拉罕·林肯曾经说过的一句话：“美国永远不会被外敌摧毁。如果我们动摇并失去自由，那是因为我们自己毁灭了自己。”

When I leave the noise of news for a while, though, and enter my classroom, I immediately feel more hopeful. As we discuss and practice principles like asking questions and listening with authentic interest, going into conversations with open minds, being present, trying to understand without judgment, and establishing commonalities, it’s pretty clear that all of these skills apply to political conversations. We’re not using negotiation to heal democracy, but we should.

然而，当我暂时远离新闻的喧嚣，走进教室时，我立刻感到充满希望。当我们讨论和实践一些原则，例如提出问题、真诚地倾听、以开放的心态参与对话、全身心投入、尝试不带评判地理解以及寻找共同点时，很明显，所有这些技巧都适用于政治对话。我们目前还没有用谈判来修复民主，但我们应该这样做。

Democrats and Republicans alike are concerned about the divisiveness in America. Our reluctance to learn from one another and our dogged opinions create more barriers and division. Our anger, pain, and disappointment only further fuel these divisions, as do our biases. We come to conversations already convinced that we know everything. This is a terrible way to coexist with one another and will never be a successful negotiation.

民主党人和共和党人都对美国的分裂感到担忧。我们不愿互相学习，固执己见，只会加剧隔阂和分裂。我们的愤怒、痛苦和失望，以及我们的偏见，只会进一步加剧这些分裂。我们带着自以为是的态度参与对话，认为自己无所不知。这种相处方式极其糟糕，也永远不会带来成功的谈判。

Of course, there’s always been discord between the parties, but the divisions have grown exponentially in the past twenty-five years, and as a result very little gets accomplished on either side. The main accomplishment is a sowing of distrust and even hate for the opposition. Brett Kavanaugh won a seat on the Supreme Court by a vote of 50–48, divided by party. That’s not how it used to be. In 1993, Ruth Bader Ginsburg was approved for the Court by a vote of 96–3. On the other side, Antonin Scalia was approved in 1986 by a vote of 98–0. Though Scalia and Ginsburg had very different interpretations of the law, they had a famously close friendship.

当然，两党之间一直存在分歧，但过去二十五年里，这种分歧呈指数级增长，导致双方都鲜有建树。最大的“成就”是播下了对对方的不信任甚至仇恨的种子。布雷特·卡瓦诺以50比48的票数当选最高法院大法官，而这一票数按党派划分。这与过去截然不同。1993年，露丝·巴德·金斯伯格以96比3的压倒性优势当选大法官。另一方面，安东宁·斯卡利亚于1986年以98比0的压倒性优势当选。尽管斯卡利亚和金斯伯格对法律的解读截然不同，但他们之间却有着一段举世闻名的深厚友谊。

Hostility toward opposing views is one part of the problem, but so is our increasing isolation, our lack of a sense of belonging. The University of Chicago’s John Cacioppo has been studying loneliness for two decades, and he says the number of people who feel lonely has steadily risen over the years—with between 11 and 20 percent reporting loneliness in the 1970s and 1980s, rising to as high as 45 percent in 2010. Connecting is an active practice that requires physical presence, not just hitting a like button on social media. In an increasingly disconnected world, we can’t assume that social networks or anonymous comments on news outlets will do the work for us. We’ve got to go old school. We’ve got to consciously decide to engage, even when it’s easier not to. We cannot afford to just communicate with those who agree and count all others out. It’s true that we may not change minds. That happens with negotiations all the time—sometimes, there’s no deal. But we still have to come to the table.

对异议的敌意固然是问题的一部分，但我们日益加剧的孤立感和归属感的缺失同样重要。芝加哥大学的约翰·卡西奥波（John Cacioppo）研究孤独问题已有二十年之久，他指出，感到孤独的人数近年来稳步上升——20世纪70年代和80年代，有11%到20%的人表示感到孤独，而到了2010年，这一比例高达45%。建立联系是一种积极的实践，需要实际的互动，而不仅仅是在社交媒体上点个赞。在一个日益疏离的世界里，我们不能指望社交网络或新闻媒体上的匿名评论会替我们完成所有工作。我们必须回归传统。我们必须有意识地选择参与，即使不参与更容易。我们不能只与那些同意我们观点的人交流，而将其他人排除在外。诚然，我们可能无法改变别人的想法。这种情况在谈判中屡见不鲜——有时，根本无法达成协议。但我们仍然需要坐下来谈判。

“Throughout American history, important strides were made because people dared to share their political views with relatives,” wrote Karen Tamerius, founder of the progressive advocacy group Smart Politics. “The civil rights movement, the women’s movement, the antiwar movement, the gay rights movement, the struggle for marriage equality—all gained acceptance through difficult conversations among family members who initially disagreed vehemently with one another.” It’s easier to talk about lighter issues, sure, but when we sidestep harder conversations, we sacrifice opportunities to move the needle, even if just marginally so.

“纵观美国历史，许多重要进步的取得，都源于人们敢于与亲属分享自己的政治观点，”进步倡导组织“智慧政治”（Smart Politics）的创始人凯伦·塔梅里乌斯（Karen Tamerius）写道。“民权运动、妇女运动、反战运动、同性恋权利运动、争取婚姻平等的斗争——所有这些运动的最终被接受，都得益于最初彼此强烈反对的家庭成员之间进行的艰难对话。” 诚然，谈论轻松的话题更容易，但如果我们回避那些棘手的对话，我们就错失了推动社会进步的机会，哪怕只是微小的进步。

When you put the chapters of this book, then, to the test of negotiating with your neighbors about what should be done in your community, state, and country, you will see how when we hear each other— really hear each other—we have a shot at moving forward together instead of staying mired in gridlock or staying isolated in our corners. This chapter isn’t about who’s right and who’s wrong. Rather, the focus is that we’ve gotten to a place where we are very alone—and that is not democracy. Democracy demands that we engage and have the courage to show up. We can use the lessons of effective negotiation to help us.

因此，当你将本书各章节的内容运用到与邻居协商社区、州和国家事务时，你会发现，当我们真正倾听彼此的声音时，我们就有机会携手前进，而不是陷入僵局或各自孤立。本章并非评判对错，而是着重指出，我们已经陷入孤立无援的境地——这并非民主。民主要求我们积极参与，并勇于发声。我们可以运用有效协商的经验来帮助我们。

Start where they are

从他们所在的地方开始

Several of my favorite negotiation exercises test students’ ability to make very hard, ethical, values-based decisions. Some require teams to choose one life over another. There are never right or wrong answers. The point, rather, is to see how a group of individuals with different life experiences, demographics, values, and communication styles can come to an agreement when the stakes are high. I touched on this subject, on the subjective meaning of fair , when I wrote about the lifesaving dialysis machine in Chapter 5.

我最喜欢的几个谈判练习旨在测试学生在面对艰难抉择时，能否做出符合伦理道德且基于价值观的决定。有些练习要求团队在两条生命之间做出选择。这类练习没有对错之分。关键在于观察一群拥有不同人生经历、背景、价值观和沟通方式的人，如何在事关重大的情况下达成共识。我在第五章讨论救命的透析机时，也曾触及过这个话题，即“公平”的主观含义。

In the end of that exercise, each group announces who they chose, and why. After hearing each group’s decision, I ask if anyone in the group had a different perspective. In one class, I’ll never forget the young woman, Carolyn, who raised her hand to say she disagreed with her team. They had chosen the child, but she felt the CEO should be saved instead. I asked her why.

练习结束时，每个小组都要宣布他们的选择以及理由。听完每个小组的决定后，我会问组里是否有人有不同的看法。我永远不会忘记有一节课上，那位名叫卡罗琳的年轻女孩举手表示她不同意小组的决定。小组选择了救孩子，但她认为应该救的是首席执行官。我问她为什么。

“I’m from Kansas City,” she said. “Jobs are so important. Especially in a community like mine that hasn’t done well. This CEO is critical to that community—she’s irreplaceable.”

“我来自堪萨斯城，”她说。“工作太重要了。尤其是在像我所在的这种发展不太好的社区。这位首席执行官对我们社区至关重要——她是不可替代的。”

One of her classmates responded, “How do you know another CEO couldn’t come in and do just as good a job?”

她的一位同学回应道：“你怎么知道其他CEO就不能接手并做得一样好呢？”

“Because,” Carolyn argued, “ this is the CEO who has driven the company’s growth. The company is thriving because of her. She is the one who developed the jobs, she is the one who could keep people employed. And jobs in small towns are everything.”

“因为，”卡罗琳辩解道，“正是这位首席执行官推动了公司的发展。公司蓬勃发展全靠她。是她创造了就业机会，是她保住了员工的饭碗。而对于小城镇来说，工作至关重要。”

“Yeah,” said another one of her classmates, “but why couldn’t someone else run the company successfully so that jobs wouldn’t be lost? CEOs lose their jobs all the time and are replaced by someone else, and the company’s just fine.”

“是啊，”她的另一位同学说，“但为什么不能让其他人成功经营公司，这样就不会有人失业呢？CEO们经常丢掉工作，然后被其他人取代，公司也照样运转良好。”

Carolyn continued to repeat the same arguments, emphatically, and kept saying, “Yeah, but in places like Kansas City . . .”

卡罗琳继续强调同样的论点，并反复说道：“是啊，但是在堪萨斯城这样的地方……”

Finally one of her classmates said, “I’m confused. There are so many other people who could do that. Haven’t you been anywhere outside of Kansas City?”

最后，她的一位同学说：“我很困惑。有那么多人都能做到这一点。你难道没去过堪萨斯城以外的地方吗？”

Carolyn’s silence spoke volumes.

卡罗琳的沉默意味深长。

This was such a powerful moment. Carolyn was from an economically struggling community with a different relationship with employment than her peers had. They couldn’t make arguments that would make sense to her without first understanding where she was starting from. Tactics aside, the student who had essentially discredited Carolyn felt terrible. She was of Latin descent and had lived and traveled all around the world. She hadn’t even realized what assumptions she was making about Carolyn before the words were out of her mouth. Carolyn’s perspective was just so radically different from her own that she had quickly dismissed it as wrong.

这是一个意义非凡的时刻。卡罗琳来自一个经济拮据的社区，她与就业的关系与同龄人截然不同。如果不先了解她的处境，他们就无法提出让她信服的论点。抛开策略不谈，那个几乎否定了卡罗琳观点的学生感到非常懊悔。她有拉丁血统，曾在世界各地生活和旅行。在她开口之前，她甚至没有意识到自己对卡罗琳抱有怎样的成见。卡罗琳的视角与她截然不同，以至于她很快就断然否定了卡罗琳的观点。

In 2015, This American Life aired a story about people who canvassed in support of issues like gay marriage and abortion. The canvassers’ approach was different than you might expect. They did not approach a voter and say, “I think you should support gay marriage and here’s why.” Instead, they asked questions about the voter’s life. In one memorable conversation, the voter—who announced he was against gay marriage—started talking about his wife, who had died years before but whom he mourned every day. He talked about his love for her and how he wanted others to experience that kind of love, too. As the canvasser asked what his exposure to gay people had been, the voter talked about the lesbian couple who lived across the street, and how they were happy like he and his wife had been. He connected the dots himself by interacting with the canvasser—who was gay—on a very human level. When the canvasser asked him at the end of the conversation if he supported gay marriage, his answer had changed.

2015年，《美国生活》（This American Life）播出了一则关于支持同性婚姻和堕胎等议题的宣传活动的故事。这些宣传员的做法与人们的预期截然不同。他们并没有直接对选民说：“我认为你应该支持同性婚姻，原因如下。”相反，他们会询问选民的生活状况。在一次令人印象深刻的对话中，一位原本反对同性婚姻的选民开始谈起他已故多年的妻子，他每天都在思念她。他讲述了自己对妻子的爱，以及希望其他人也能体验到这种爱。当宣传员问及他与同性恋者的接触经历时，这位选民谈到了住在街对面的一对女同性恋伴侣，以及她们像他和妻子一样幸福美满。他通过与这位同性恋宣传员进行真诚的交流，将各种经历联系起来。当宣传员在谈话结束时问他是否支持同性婚姻时，他的回答已经改变了。

There is nothing about understanding another person’s point of view that is easy, particularly when it comes to political conversations. For when we are emotionally, economically, politically, or socially invested in a given side, it’s hard to separate emotion and stay in fact-finding mode.

理解他人的观点绝非易事，尤其是在政治对话中。因为当我们在情感、经济、政治或社会层面上对某个立场投入过多时，很难将情感剥离开来，保持客观事实的思考。

Controlling emotions in political conversations

在政治对话中控制情绪

Talking about politics with someone with opposing views requires you take Chapter 7 about presence and put it on steroids. Politics is so loaded that every Thanksgiving the Internet is packed with articles titled, “Ten Ways to Survive Dinner with Your Conservative/Liberal Family.” My best advice for when you feel flooded is to take a breath and to think strategically. What will happen if you lose your temper? What will you gain? Will you change anyone’s mind?

与持相反政治观点的人谈论政治，需要你把第七章关于临场感的讲解发挥到极致。政治话题如此敏感，以至于每逢感恩节，互联网上都会充斥着题为“与保守派/自由派家人共进晚餐的十种生存之道”的文章。当你感到情绪崩溃时，我最好的建议是深呼吸，然后进行策略性思考。如果你发脾气了会怎样？你会得到什么？你能改变任何人的想法吗？

There is no part of me that thinks that controlling your emotions is easy in these circumstances. If you are Jewish, descended from Holocaust survivors, or a person of color, it feels like a jarring attack for someone to defend the 2017 racist and anti-Semitic rallies in Charlottesville. Once they make their feelings known, you are starting that conversation from a place of feeling deeply disrespected. You are hurt. You want to go on the offensive, not hear what they have to say—you think they don’t deserve the respect of your attention. I don’t blame you. This is a huge task.

我完全理解在这种情况下控制情绪有多么困难。如果你是犹太人、大屠杀幸存者的后裔，或者有色人种，那么当有人为2017年夏洛茨维尔的种族主义和反犹太主义集会辩护时，你会感到一种强烈的冒犯。一旦他们表达了自己的立场，你就会感到自己受到了极大的不尊重，并以此为出发点展开对话。你会感到受伤。你想反击，不想听他们说什么——你觉得他们不值得你关注。我并不责怪你。这的确是一项艰巨的任务。

It is remarkable what can happen, though, when you just take a breath. Heather McGhee, an African American leader of a public policy organization, was a guest on CSPAN’s Washington Journal when Garry Civitello, a private citizen who was watching the show, called in to ask a question. “ I am a white male,” he said, “and I am prejudiced.” Heather’s eyes closed for a long moment. You can see her take a breath. Garry said, “What can I do to change? To be a better American?” As the Upstanders documentary series reported, Heather’s response—first thanking him for his honesty, and then telling him that he should turn off the nightly news, which just reinforces negative stereotypes; that he should read about African American history; and that he should engage with African Americans—started Garry on what Heather called “a walk.” He did all she suggested and more, periodically asking her advice, and the two became friends. Granted, this conversation started from a point of concession. Garry had an openness and curiosity that he made clear from the get-go. Still, he also had deep-seated ideas that cut to the core of Heather’s identity. It would have been easy for her to let the hurt take over and to blow him off. But she closed her eyes, took a breath, and welcomed him in instead.

然而，当你深吸一口气时，奇迹就会发生。希瑟·麦吉是一位非裔美国人，也是公共政策组织的领导人。她做客CSPAN的《华盛顿杂志》节目时，一位名叫加里·西维特洛的普通观众打来电话提问。“我是一个白人男性，”他说，“但我有偏见。”希瑟闭上眼睛，沉默了许久。你可以看到她深吸了一口气。加里问道：“我该如何改变？如何成为一个更好的美国人？”正如纪录片《挺身而出者》系列所报道的那样，希瑟的回应——首先感谢他的坦诚，然后告诉他应该关掉晚间新闻，因为新闻只会强化负面的刻板印象；应该阅读非裔美国人的历史；应该与非裔美国人交流——开启了加里希瑟所说的“自我探索之旅”。他不仅做到了希瑟的所有建议，还做得更多，并不时地向她请教，两人最终成为了朋友。当然，这段对话始于希瑟的让步。加里从一开始就展现出一种开放和好奇的特质。然而，他内心深处也有一些根深蒂固的想法，直击希瑟的内心深处。希瑟本可以轻易地被伤痛吞噬，对他不屑一顾。但她却闭上双眼，深吸一口气，敞开心扉地接纳了他。

Not everyone has prejudices as extreme as Garry’s, but biases can be very deeply ingrained, and everyone has them in one form or another. Remembering this, I find, is helpful to tempering strong reactions. In Todd Rose and Ogi Ogas’s book Dark Horse: Achieving Success through the Pursuit of Fulfillment , they make the point that even a hundred years after Copernicus shared his clear logic about why the earth orbited the sun and not vice versa, few believed it. “Assumptions are very stubborn things,” they write, “particularly when they are stitched into the fabric of everyday reality.” Galileo then discovered four moons orbiting Jupiter, proving Copernicus correct, but “when he invited his geocentric-minded colleagues to peer through his telescope to see the moons for themselves, many insisted they could not see what Galileo claimed they should see. Some declared it hurt their head just to look.” The moral I take from this story: Bias is not about you, it’s not about me, it’s about all of us, and so you can’t lose your mind whenever someone says something stupid, because we all do. Or, in the words of Malcolm X, “Don’t be in such a hurry to condemn a person because he doesn’t do what you do or think as you think. There was a time when you didn’t know what you know today.”

并非每个人都像加里那样抱有极端偏见，但偏见可能根深蒂固，而且每个人都或多或少存在偏见。记住这一点，我认为有助于缓和强烈的反应。在托德·罗斯和奥吉·奥加斯的著作《黑马：通过追求成就感获得成功》中，他们指出，即使在哥白尼清晰阐述了地球绕太阳运行而非太阳绕地球运行的逻辑一百年后，也很少有人相信。“假设是非常顽固的东西，”他们写道，“尤其当它们融入日常现实的肌理时。”伽利略后来发现了木星的四颗卫星，证明了哥白尼的理论是正确的，但“当他邀请那些持有地心说的同事们通过他的望远镜亲眼观察这些卫星时，许多人坚称他们看不到伽利略所说的景象。有些人甚至声称光是看着就头疼。”我从这个故事中得到的教训是：偏见并非关乎你我，而是关乎我们所有人。所以，当有人说了蠢话时，你无需大惊小怪，因为我们都会犯错。或者，用马尔科姆·X的话来说：“不要急于谴责一个与你行为或想法不同的人。你也曾有过不了解你今天所了解的一切的时候。”

Assume you need to explain

假设你需要解释

In the movie Hidden Figures , based on the lives of three African American women who pushed through racism and sexism to make a mark at NASA in the 1960s, mathematician Katherine Johnson returns to the office soaking wet after a break. Her boss, irritated by her long absence, calls her to task in front of the rest of the office. Angry and fighting tears, she then gives a monologue that is arguably the most powerful in the film:

在电影《隐藏人物》中，三位非裔美国女性克服种族歧视和性别歧视，在20世纪60年代的NASA取得了卓越成就。影片中，数学家凯瑟琳·约翰逊休息后浑身湿透地回到办公室。她的老板对她长时间缺席感到恼火，当着所有人的面训斥了她。凯瑟琳愤怒地强忍着泪水，发表了一段独白，这段独白可以说是整部电影中最震撼人心的片段：

There’s no bathroom for me here. (“What do you mean there’s no bathroom?”) There is no bathroom. There are no colored bathrooms in this building. Or any building outside the West Campus, which is half a mile away. Did you know that? I have to walk to Timbuktu just to relieve myself. And I can’t use one of the handy bikes. Picture that, Mr. Harrison. My uniform. Skirt below my knees, my heels, and a simple string of pearls. Well, I don’t own pearls. Lord knows you don’t pay coloreds enough to afford pearls! And I work like a dog, day and night, living off of coffee from a pot none of you wanna touch. So, excuse me if I have to go to the restroom a few times a day.

这里没有我的厕所。（“什么？没有厕所？”）真的没有厕所。这栋楼里没有有色人种专用的厕所。西校区以外的任何一栋楼都没有，而西校区离这里足足有半英里远。你知道吗？我得走到天涯海角才能上厕所。而且我也不能用那些方便的自行车。想象一下，哈里森先生。我的制服。及膝的裙子，高跟鞋，还有一串简单的珍珠项链。可是，我没有珍珠项链。老天爷知道，你们给有色人种的工资根本不够买珍珠项链！我像条狗一样日夜不停地工作，靠着你们谁都不想碰的咖啡壶里的咖啡度日。所以，如果我一天要去几次厕所，请别介意。

It was the first moment in the film when she did not act the part she was expected to play—that of a demure, subordinate computer (she was even called a “computer”). She was emotional, and it was personal. No one in the room with her could deny the pain. She tapped into their capacity for empathy, putting them in her high heels and asking them to imagine what her life was like.

这是影片中她第一次没有扮演人们预期的角色——一个温顺、顺从的电脑（她甚至被称作“电脑”）。她情绪激动，而且是真情流露。房间里的每个人都无法否认她的痛苦。她唤起了他们的同理心，让他们设身处地地感受她的处境，让他们想象她的生活是怎样的。

We all must do what Katherine did. We assume that of course someone can see what we’re up against as a black/white/religious/atheist/man/woman—isn’t it obvious? And if they can’t see, why is the onus on us to tell them? Remember, though, the illusion of transparency: the belief that what you feel (or want) is crystal clear to others, even though you have done very little to communicate it. There is reality, and then there is perception, and the two are not the same. Although of course most people working at NASA in the 1960s had to recognize that it would be hard to be an African American woman working there, until Katherine showed her humanity and put them in her shoes, they didn’t connect the dots of what she was up against.

我们都必须效仿凯瑟琳的做法。我们理所当然地认为，无论黑人/白人/信教者/无神论者/男性/女性，别人都能看出我们所面临的困境——这难道不显而易见吗？如果他们看不见，为什么我们要主动告诉他们呢？然而，请记住“透明”的错觉：人们会误以为自己的感受（或愿望）对他人来说一目了然，即使你几乎没有做任何努力去表达。现实和感知是两回事，二者并不相同。当然，20世纪60年代在NASA工作的大多数人都意识到，作为一名非裔美国女性在那里工作会很艰难，但直到凯瑟琳展现出她的人性光辉，并设身处地地为他们着想，他们才真正理解她所面临的困境。

A modern example comes out of the #MeToo and feminist movements, and an increasing number of women asking to be heard. Author Kimberly Harrington wrote about the plea for understanding in Medium : “We—who live in these bodies and are used to holding keys clutched between fingers when walking to the car and who are used to being passed over for a promotion in favor of an incompetent male coworker who is just better at bluster—are asking our partners to assume experiences they have likely never had, and likely never will. We are asking them to be better, instantly. We are asking them to be us.” Even the most caring and helpful of men may not grasp the weight of what women carry unless they are told, and they listen, and they try to empathize.

现代的例子来自#MeToo运动和女权主义运动，越来越多的女性发出自己的声音，要求被倾听。作家金伯利·哈灵顿在Medium上撰文呼吁理解：“我们——生活在这些躯壳里，习惯于走到车旁时紧紧攥着钥匙，习惯于升职时被一个只会吹牛却能力不足的男同事抢走——却要求我们的伴侣去体验他们可能从未经历过，也可能永远不会经历的事情。我们要求他们立刻变得更好。我们要求他们变成我们。”即使是最体贴、最乐于助人的男性，如果得不到女性的倾诉，也未必能真正理解她们所承受的重担，除非她们倾听，并尝试去理解。

The dangers, of course, are of feeling that you do not need to explain—that you should not have to explain—or, worst of all, that it’s pointless to explain because the other side “will never understand.” When we take these positions, we invite a pendulum swing. We do not find common ground, because we’re not even looking for it. Instead we commiserate with friends and invite in the confirmation bias we talked about in Chapter 5. And on and on the miscommunication goes.

当然，危险在于你会觉得无需解释——甚至不应该解释——或者，最糟糕的是，你会觉得解释毫无意义，因为对方“永远不会理解”。当我们抱持这种态度时，就等于自找麻烦。我们找不到共同点，因为我们根本没有去寻找。相反，我们只是和朋友们互相安慰，并引入了我们在第五章讨论过的确认偏误。如此循环往复，误解不断滋生。

When I watched the movie Hotel Mumbai , I was so struck by its handling of this issue that I scrambled around in the dark theater to find a notebook so I could jot it down. In the midst of telling a remarkable and heartwrenching story, it also demonstrates how we negotiate our biases in the most human of interaction. Hotel Mumbai , of course, is based on the attack of the elite hotel—a symbol of capitalism—in India in 2008. As terrorists with machine guns stormed the building, a Sikh waiter named Arjun working in the hotel restaurant managed to lead a group of guests to a safe part of the hotel. The group became more and more frightened as the death and carnage was more evident, and one older British guest became completely paranoid and her instability threatened to put them all at risk. The chef whom Arjun worked under explained that Arjun’s turban made the guest uncomfortable and that he should take it off. Knowing little about the turban or why he wore it, she associated Arjun with one of the militants who had stormed the building.

看完电影《孟买酒店》后，我对影片处理这个问题的方式深感震撼，以至于在黑暗的影院里四处寻找笔记本，想要记下来。影片在讲述一个非凡而又令人心碎的故事的同时，也展现了我们在最人性化的互动中如何克服自身的偏见。《孟买酒店》的故事取材于2008年发生在印度的一起恐怖袭击事件，这家高档酒店是资本主义的象征。当时，持机枪的恐怖分子冲进酒店，一位名叫阿琼的锡克教服务员在酒店餐厅工作，他设法带领一群客人逃到了酒店的安全区域。随着死亡和惨状越来越明显，这群客人也越来越害怕，其中一位年长的英国客人变得极度偏执，她的精神状态极不稳定，危及到所有人的安全。阿琼的老板解释说，阿琼的头巾让这位客人感到不舒服，让他摘掉。她对头巾一无所知，也不知道他为什么戴头巾，于是把阿俊和冲进大楼的武装分子之一联系起来。

Now, for Sikhs, it is not a small thing to take off a turban. Arjun was never, ever without it and clearly didn’t want to remove it, but neither did he want to defy the chef or let the British woman’s paranoia put their group’s safety at stake. So he went over to the woman. He introduced himself. He took a picture out of his wallet of his pregnant wife and their daughter. He explained that he was a father, and that he was a Sikh. He explained that Sikhs practice peace, and explained why he wore a turban and that he had never before taken it off. He emphasized that he was a family man and wanted the group to survive, but that he recognized she was uncomfortable with what he wore on his head. He told her that since she was a guest and guests came first, that he would take it off if it would make her feel better. The woman said no. It was such a powerful negotiation, and one where had Arjun chosen not to explain himself, things could have gone much differently.

对锡克教徒来说，摘下头巾可不是一件小事。阿琼从来都戴着头巾，显然他也不想摘，但他既不想违抗厨师的命令，也不想让那位英国女士的疑神疑鬼危及他们一行人的安全。于是，他走到那位女士面前，做了自我介绍。他从钱包里掏出一张他怀孕的妻子和女儿的照片，解释说自己是一位父亲，也是一位锡克教徒。他解释说锡克教徒崇尚和平，并解释了自己为什么一直戴着头巾，以及他以前从未摘下过。他强调自己是一位顾家的男人，希望大家平安无事，但他明白那位女士对他的头巾感到不自在。他告诉她，既然她是客人，客人至上，如果摘下头巾能让她感觉好些，他愿意摘下来。那位女士拒绝了。这是一次意义非凡的交涉，如果阿琼当时没有解释，事情的结局可能会截然不同。

Tell stories

讲述故事

In the words of Righteous Mind author Jonathan Haidt, “The human mind is a story processor, not a logic processor.”

用《正义之心》作者乔纳森·海特的话来说，“人类的思维是故事处理器，而不是逻辑处理器。”

Perhaps that’s why a recommended way to increase your empathy is to read fiction. It makes sense: The phrase “lose yourself in a book” means to figuratively occupy the world and viewpoints of the characters on the page. Researchers at the New School even found that those who read literary fiction were more empathetic.

或许正因如此，阅读小说被推荐为提升同理心的一种有效方法。这不无道理：“沉浸于书中”意味着设身处地地感受书中人物的世界和视角。新学院的研究人员甚至发现，阅读文学小说的人更具同理心。

Dr. Michelle C. Pautz, a researcher out of the University of Dayton who has studied the power of film to change minds, said, “Discussing race relations/racism is still hard for Americans and an often taboo subject, but one can much more easily talk about a movie that might then lead to conversation about those more sensitive topics.” Remember how when Philadelphia came out, starring Tom Hanks, it helped destigmatize AIDS? Part of the reason was that finally people were talking about a subject that it was much more comfortable to avoid.

来自代顿大学的研究员米歇尔·C·保茨博士研究了电影改变人们观念的力量，她说：“对美国人来说，讨论种族关系/种族主义仍然很困难，而且往往是一个禁忌话题，但人们更容易谈论一部电影，而这部电影可能会引出关于这些更敏感话题的讨论。”还记得汤姆·汉克斯主演的电影《费城故事》上映后，是如何帮助消除人们对艾滋病的歧视的吗？部分原因是人们终于开始谈论这个他们过去避而不谈的话题了。

The connection of all of this to negotiation is yet again empathy, the heart and soul of good negotiation practices. Stories help us humanize fraught issues, break stereotypes, and let down our protective guard, and from there we are better able to communicate. It’s why, in a discussion about health care, it’s more effective to tell the story of your brother who struggled to pay his medical bills when he had brain cancer than it is to quote politicians—or statistics—on either side. Or, in a conversation about gun control, to explain that you are not an advocate of people gunning others down, but that in the remote countryside where you live, police aid is not right around the corner and your gun is thus your only source of protection. Just as you are listening to their story, you must share your own.

这一切与谈判的联系最终还是在于同理心，它是良好谈判实践的核心和灵魂。故事能帮助我们把棘手的问题人性化，打破刻板印象，放下戒备，从而更好地沟通。这就是为什么在讨论医疗保健时，讲述你哥哥患脑癌后难以支付医疗费用的故事，比引用任何一方政客的言论或统计数据都更有效。又比如，在讨论枪支管制时，你可以解释说你并不支持人们开枪杀人，但在你居住的偏远乡村，警察无法及时赶到，所以你的枪是你唯一的自卫手段。正如你在倾听他们的故事一样，你也必须分享自己的故事。

Keep talking: Going from dispute to understanding, no matter how hard it is

继续沟通：从争论走向理解，无论多么困难

I said I shy away from talking about politics in the classroom, but sometimes it comes up and the conversation needs to run its course. About a week after the horrific hate-crime killing of Jews at their synagogue in Pittsburgh’s Squirrel Hill neighborhood, I taught a class in Chicago. It was a fantastic group of easygoing, intelligent, highly engaged students, and the classroom was filled with light banter all morning long. One of the students, an older Latina woman named Sofia, caught my attention because she was just so outgoing. She ran a successful staffing firm and was clearly quite the saleswoman, too—she was charming and engaged everyone in conversation.

我说过我不太喜欢在课堂上谈论政治，但有时候话题难免会涉及，而讨论也需要顺其自然。在匹兹堡松鼠山社区犹太教堂发生骇人听闻的仇恨犯罪枪击案大约一周后，我在芝加哥上了一堂课。学生们性格随和、聪明机智、积极参与课堂，整个上午教室里都充满了轻松愉快的交谈。其中一位名叫索菲亚的拉丁裔年长女性引起了我的注意，因为她非常外向。她经营着一家成功的招聘公司，显然也是一位出色的销售员——她魅力十足，总能和每个人聊得来。

We split into groups to do a mock negotiation, and when people came back with their results, no one had done very well, but Sofia had gotten the lowest sales price of all in her negotiation with Noah. As we debriefed the negotiation as a class, I said, “So Sofia, what happened?”

我们分成小组进行模拟谈判，大家回来汇报结果时，发现没有人表现得特别好，但索菲亚在与诺亚的谈判中拿到了最低的售价。全班一起讨论谈判结果时，我问索菲亚：“索菲亚，到底发生了什么？”

She smiled and shrugged. “So what happened was that I negotiated with Noah and he beat me badly. But I’m not surprised. He’s a Jew,” she said by way of explanation.

她笑了笑，耸了耸肩。“事情是这样的，我和诺亚谈判，结果他狠狠地揍了我一顿。但我并不感到意外。他是个犹太人，”她解释道。

I stopped cold. Everyone did. You could hear a collective intake of breath throughout the room. It took me a moment to recover, and I prodded Sofia a little bit, sure that she’d realized she’d put her foot in her mouth and would walk her way back from the statement. But she just dug herself deeper. She explained to me and the rest of the class how she worked with a lot of Jewish people, and that they’re such savvy and capable businesspeople. This was clearly her way of saying she respected her Jewish colleagues, but the room was having a hard time hearing or accepting the explanation.

我顿时愣住了。所有人都愣住了。整个房间里都响起了一阵倒吸冷气的声音。我愣了一会儿才回过神来，然后轻轻地提醒了索菲亚一下，心想她肯定已经意识到自己说错了话，会赶紧收回刚才的话。但她却越描越黑。她向我和其他同学解释说，她经常和犹太人一起工作，他们都是非常精明能干的商人。这显然是她表达对犹太同事尊重的一种方式，但大家似乎很难听进去，也很难接受这种解释。

Sofia was drawing from hurtful stereotypes, but it was clear to me that wasn’t what she was about. She was just genuinely impressed by these friends of hers and connected their money-savvy to their Jewishness. It was a biased and rough-around-the-edges approach, not to mention tone-deaf, but it wasn’t grounded in hate. But I knew, given the immediate, collective reaction in the room, that the class couldn’t necessarily see what I saw in that moment. The air itself felt clouded by emotion and judgment.

索菲亚的言论带有伤人的刻板印象，但我很清楚，这并非她的本意。她只是真心佩服她的朋友们，并将他们的理财能力与他们的犹太身份联系起来。这种做法带有偏见，也略显粗糙，甚至有些不合时宜，但并非出于仇恨。然而，从当时教室里同学们的反应来看，我知道他们未必能理解我当时的感受。空气中弥漫着情绪和评判的气息。

A man in the back raised his hand and said in a shaky voice, “I just need to speak. Sofia, this is just so hurtful.” The rest of the class, regardless of their race and ethnicity, piled on, taking turns to apologize to the man for Sofia’s statements.
