Sofia, meanwhile, looked stunned. She’d had no idea what she’d unleashed. She tried to explain herself. I encouraged everyone to be calm, to measure their words, and to hear one another. One woman offered that people who were attacking Sofia were hypocritical because everyone nurses stereotypes in private—Sofia had just made hers public. The man who’d been the first to call out Sofia said he knew Sofia meant no harm, but her statement still hurt.

后排一个男人举起手，声音颤抖地说：“我必须说几句。索菲亚，你这样说太伤人了。”班上其他同学，无论种族和民族，都纷纷上前，轮流向那位男士道歉，替索菲亚的言论道歉。与此同时，索菲亚看起来惊呆了。她完全没有意识到自己说了什么。她试图解释。我鼓励大家冷静下来，注意措辞，倾听彼此。一位女士指出，那些攻击索菲亚的人很虚伪，因为每个人私下里都会有刻板印象——索菲亚只是把自己的刻板印象公之于众而已。第一个指出索菲亚错误的男人说，他知道索菲亚没有恶意，但她的话仍然伤人。

After a while Noah raised his hand. “Can I say something, since this started with me and Sofia?” Noah turned to Sofia. “I forgive you, Sofia,” he said. “And it didn’t surprise me,” he said to the rest of the class, “because I wear a yarmulke, and I know and expect the reaction that I get when I walk in the room sometimes. I don’t like it, but I’ve unfortunately come to anticipate it.”

过了一会儿，诺亚举起了手。“既然这件事是从我和索菲亚之间开始的，我能说句话吗？”诺亚转向索菲亚。“我原谅你，索菲亚，”他说。“这并不让我感到意外，”他对班上其他同学说，“因为我戴着犹太小圆帽，我知道也预料到我走进教室时有时会得到怎样的反应。我不喜欢这样，但很不幸，我已经习以为常了。”

At that, I suggested that we take a break to let the emotion level of the room come down a little bit. I noticed Sofia grab not just her purse but her bookbag—a sign that she wasn’t planning to come back. I think Sofia deeply regretted the course of events but also felt victimized by the way everyone had ganged up to denounce her.

于是，我提议我们先休息一下，让房间里的气氛缓和一下。我注意到索菲亚不仅抓起了钱包，还抓起了书包——这表明她不打算回来了。我想索菲亚对事情的进展深感后悔，同时也觉得自己受到了大家的联合谴责，成了受害者。

As I suspected, Sofia didn’t return. I worried we’d go back to where we started, not talking to one another.

正如我所料，索菲亚没有回来。我担心我们会回到原点，彼此不再说话。

Somehow, we got through the course material for the rest of the afternoon. When we were finishing up, I noted that it had been a long day, and a hard day, and in a lot of ways a really important day. I wasn’t just pouring sugar over a bad situation—there were positives. We moved from hurt and pain to forgiveness and understanding. We were living through an intense, divisive period in history, but as a classroom we’d come together and talked through it—we hadn’t shut down or shut one another out. That’s a real impulse, that urge to think, Oh, they are so different from me that they’ll never understand . When we do that, we grow further apart. Invite, don’t indict. I asked them to return to what we’d talked about all morning, before Sofia’s comment, which was empathy. I reminded them we had one less person in the room now, and urged the class to reach out to Sofia if they felt moved to.

不知怎的，我们还是完成了下午剩下的课程内容。快结束时，我意识到今天很漫长，也很艰难，但在很多方面，这都是非常重要的一天。我并非在粉饰太平——也有积极的一面。我们从伤痛走向了宽恕和理解。我们正经历着一段充满分裂的历史时期，但作为一个班级，我们聚在一起，共同探讨——我们没有封闭自己，也没有互相排斥。那种“哦，他们和我如此不同，他们永远不会理解我”的想法，其实很常见。当我们这样想时，我们之间的距离只会越来越远。要邀请，而不是指责。我请他们回到我们上午讨论的话题，也就是索菲亚发言之前讨论的同理心。我提醒他们，现在教室里少了一个人，并鼓励同学们如果觉得有必要，就主动联系索菲亚。

I heard later that Sofia did return to class the following week (it wasn’t one I taught) and was welcomed with open arms.

后来我听说索菲亚下周就回到了课堂（不是我教的那节课），受到了热烈的欢迎。

In retrospect, that day in class, though exhausting, was both meaningful and remarkable. After all, hard things are hard. Our discussion taught the students more about negotiation than a case study ever could. We moved from pain and judgment to healing.

回想起来，那天的课堂虽然令人疲惫，却意义非凡，令人难忘。毕竟，困难的事情总是难的。我们的讨论比任何案例研究都更能教会学生们谈判的技巧。我们从痛苦和评判走向了治愈。

This was by no means the only time someone made a misplaced statement in one of my classes. Sometimes they dissipate the second they’re spoken. But we’re in a different moment now—Jews feel targeted. Minorities feel targeted. Women feel targeted. Men feel targeted. The word that keeps coming to mind is raw . But when someone is raw, we frequently avoid the subject altogether rather than engage. And that, ultimately, is why I was so happy with the way Sofia’s class ended up. We were raw—all of us—and we worked through it. We had the courage to stay at the damn table, and to return to it the next week.

这绝不是我课堂上唯一一次有人发表不合时宜的言论。有时，这些言论一出口就烟消云散了。但我们现在所处的时代不同了——犹太人感到自己被针对。少数族裔感到被针对。女性感到被针对。男性也感到被针对。我脑海中不断浮现的词是“赤裸裸的”。但当有人赤裸裸地表达自己的感受时，我们往往会选择完全回避这个话题，而不是去深入探讨。而这，最终也是我为什么对索菲亚那堂课的最终结果感到如此欣慰的原因。我们所有人都很赤裸裸地表达了自己的感受，但我们努力克服了它。我们有勇气留在桌旁，并在下周继续讨论。

Focus on what works

专注于有效的做法。

The most fundamental strategy of politics is to focus on what isn’t working for voters. That’s how campaigns persuade them to vote another way. Pick your issue: health care, immigration, crime—every political challenger is going to say it’s broken and that they can fix it.

政治最根本的策略就是聚焦选民不满的方面。竞选活动正是以此来说服选民改变投票意向。随便挑一个议题：医疗保健、移民、犯罪——每个政治挑战者都会说这些问题出了毛病，而他们能解决。

I wonder, though, if the world really is as bad off as politicians would have us believe, or if maybe we’re just not talking about the good news. Because again, that’s all I see when I go into the classroom. The many stories I’ve told in this book don’t begin to scratch the surface of the transformations I’ve seen in students over the years. It’s not just that they’ve learned to get better deals (although they do), but they grow, they change, they self-correct, they change the ways they relate to and engage with others. They are kinder to themselves, and they are kinder to others. I’ve met very few people who are dead-set in their ways. And that is something to be very hopeful about, no matter the nature of the conversation. They are what keep me coming back, and what will always keep me coming back . . . because they prove to me that negotiation works.

不过，我一直在想，世界真的像政客们说的那样糟糕吗？或者，我们只是忽略了那些好消息？因为每次走进教室，我看到的都是好消息。我在这本书里讲述的许多故事，仅仅触及了我这些年来在学生身上所见证的转变的冰山一角。他们不仅学会了如何争取更好的条件（虽然他们的确做到了），更重要的是，他们成长了，他们改变了，他们自我纠正了，他们改变了与他人相处和互动的方式。他们对自己更友善了，对他人也更友善了。我很少遇到固执己见的人。无论谈话的内容是什么，这都是一件令人充满希望的事情。正是他们让我坚持下去，也永远让我坚持下去……因为他们向我证明了谈判是有效的。

#↩

acknowledgments

致谢

This was a daunting and demanding process from beginning to end, with stories that span so many different chapters of my life. As such, there are far too many people to thank, so here’s a collective note of gratitude to my family and friends—my tribe and constant source of inspiration. A special thanks to my sister, who encouraged me to share my story and not worry about judgment. That conversation was everything!

从始至终，这都是一个艰辛而漫长的过程，其中穿插着我人生中许多不同的篇章。因此，要感谢的人实在太多，所以在此，我要向我的家人和朋友们——我的家人和源源不断的灵感之源——表达我们共同的感激之情。特别感谢我的姐姐，是她鼓励我分享我的故事，不要担心别人的评判。那次谈话意义非凡！

A few people have been particularly instrumental in making this book possible. A big thanks to Howard Yoon for your encouragement and support. This book was an idea for so long, with many different iterations. I appreciate you walking alongside me as we discovered the right direction for the right time. Thanks to everyone on the Avery team who helped shape and advance this book. A special recognition for my editor, Lucia Watson, for her discerning insight, thoughtfulness, and vision. I’m so grateful to my early readers, Jill Hudson and Ken Shropshire, for their smart and gracious feedback. Jenna Free, what can I say? We’ve learned and grown together. Through it all, you’ve been patient and open-minded, boosting me and challenging me when I needed it the most.

这本书的出版离不开几位人士的鼎力支持。特别感谢Howard Yoon的鼓励和支持。这本书的构思酝酿已久，经历了多次修改。感谢你一路陪伴我，最终找到了合适的方向和时机。感谢Avery团队的每一位成员，是你们的帮助让这本书得以成型和推进。特别感谢我的编辑Lucia Watson，她拥有敏锐的洞察力、周到的思考和卓越的远见。我非常感谢我的早期读者Jill Hudson和Ken Shropshire，他们给予了我宝贵而中肯的反馈。Jenna Free，我还能说什么呢？我们一起学习，一起成长。一路走来，你始终保持着耐心和开放的心态，在我最需要的时候给予我鼓励和挑战。

Teaching was never something I imagined pursuing. Ken Shropshire, I have no idea to this day what you saw or how you knew, but you believed. You encouraged me to teach even when I thought it was improbable. Thank you for friendship and mentorship and opening the doors for me at Wharton.

我从未想过自己会从事教书育人的工作。肯·什罗普郡，直到今天，我仍然不知道你看到了什么，也不知道你是如何知道的，但你相信我。即使在我认为这条路走不通的时候，你也鼓励我去教书。感谢你的友谊和指导，感谢你为我打开了沃顿商学院的大门。

I am forever grateful to John F. W. Rogers and my entire Goldman Sachs Foundation family for their support and encouragement. Special thanks to Rita McGlone and my colleagues at the Wharton School for inviting me to teach in the Goldman Sachs 10,000 Women initiative at the American University in Cairo. That program was life-changing in more ways than I can count.

我永远感激约翰·F·W·罗杰斯以及高盛基金会全体成员的支持和鼓励。特别感谢丽塔·麦格隆和沃顿商学院的同事们邀请我参与高盛“万名女性”项目，并在开罗美国大学任教。这个项目从各个方面改变了我的人生。

I’m so thankful to the many people who agreed to share their stories in this book, allowing my readers to learn from your triumphs and obstacles. You were generous with your time and unwavering in your honesty.

我非常感谢众多愿意在本书中分享他们故事的人，让我的读者能够从你们的成功和挫折中汲取经验。你们慷慨地抽出时间，并且始终坦诚相待。

Last but not least, I want to thank my students, who always commit to their learning with courage and conviction. Their experiences are at the heart of this book. They know me best and see me in my power and, often, my vulnerability. Thank you for opening my heart and mind and enriching my life in so many ways.

最后，我要感谢我的学生们，他们始终以勇气和信念投入学习。他们的经历是本书的核心。他们最了解我，见证了我的力量，也常常看到了我的脆弱。感谢你们打开我的心扉，启迪我的思想，并以各种方式丰富了我的人生。

#↩

notes

笔记

Chapter 1: How Our Stories Sell Us Short

第一章：我们的故事如何低估了我们

Margarita Mayo . . . wrote in the Harvard Business Review : Margarita Mayo, “The Gender Gap in Feedback and Self-Perception,” Harvard Business Review , August 31, 2016, https://hbr.org/2016/08/the-gender-gap-in-feedback-and-self-perception .

玛格丽塔·梅奥 (Margarita Mayo) 在《哈佛商业评论》上写道：玛格丽塔·梅奥，《反馈和自我认知中的性别差距》，《哈佛商业评论》，2016 年 8 月 31 日，https://hbr.org/2016/08/the-gender-gap-in-feedback-and-self-perception。

“The data is pretty grim” : Katty Kay and Claire Shipman, The Confidence Code: The Science and Art of Self-Assurance—What Women Should Know (New York: HarperCollins, 2014), xviii.

“数据相当糟糕”：凯蒂·凯和克莱尔·希普曼，《自信密码：自信的科学与艺术——女性应该知道什么》（纽约：哈珀柯林斯出版社，2014 年），第十八页。

they see more incidents as worthy of apology : Rachael Rettner, “Study Reveals Why Women Apologize So Much,” Live Science , September 27, 2010, https://www.livescience.com/8698-study-reveals-women-apologize.html .

她们认为更多事件值得道歉：Rachael Rettner，“研究揭示了女性为何如此频繁地道歉”，Live Science，2010 年 9 月 27 日，https://www.livescience.com/8698-study-reveals-women-apologize.html。

“We are never in a room” : Oprah Winfrey, “Wes Moore: Is Your Job Your Life’s Purpose?,” podcast audio, Oprah’s SuperSoul Conversations , OWN, May 21, 2018, https://podcasts.apple.com/gb/podcast/wes-moore-is-your-job-your-lifes-purpose/id1264843400?i=1000411964463 .

“我们永远不会在一个房间里”：奥普拉·温弗瑞，“韦斯·摩尔：你的工作是你的人生目标吗？”播客音频，奥普拉的超级灵魂对话，OWN，2018 年 5 月 21 日，https://podcasts.apple.com/gb/podcast/wes-moore-is-your-job-your-lifes-purpose/id1264843400?i=1000411964463。

the more positive our narrative, the better our results : Daniel J. Tomasulo and James O. Pawelski, “Happily Ever After: The Use of Stories to Promote Positive Interventions,” Psychology 3, no. 12A (December 2012): 1191, http://dx.doi.org/10.4236/psych.2012.312A176 ; Martin Seligman et al., “Positive Psychology Progress: Empirical Validation of Interventions,” American Psychologist 60, no. 5 (2005): 410, http://dx.doi.org/10.1037/0003-066X.60.5.410 .

我们的叙述越积极，结果就越好：Daniel J. Tomasulo 和 James O. Pawelski，“从此幸福快乐：利用故事促进积极干预”，《心理学》3，第 12A 期（2012 年 12 月）：1191，http://dx.doi.org/10.4236/psych.2012.312A176；Martin Seligman 等人，“积极心理学进展：干预措施的实证验证”，《美国心理学家》60，第 5 期（2005 年）：410，http://dx.doi.org/10.1037/0003-066X.60.5.410。

Chapter 2: When We Undercut Ourselves to Please Others

第二章：为了取悦他人而牺牲自己

The men’s requests for more money exceeded the women’s by nine to one : Linda Babcock et al., “Nice Girls Don’t Ask,” Harvard Business Review , October 2003, https://hbr.org/2003/10/nice-girls-dont-ask .

男性要求更多钱的人数是女性的九倍：琳达·巴布科克等人，“好女孩不问”，《哈佛商业评论》，2003 年 10 月，https://hbr.org/2003/10/nice-girls-dont-ask。

a correlation between sociotropy and eating more around others : Julie J. Exline et al., “People-Pleasing through Eating: Sociotropy Predicts Greater Eating in Response to Perceived Social Pressure,” Journal of Social and Clinical Psychology 31, no. 2 (2012): 169, https://doi.org/10.1521/jscp.2012.31.2.169 .

社会依赖性与在他人面前进食增加之间的相关性：Julie J. Exline 等人，“通过进食取悦他人：社会依赖性预测在感知到社会压力时进食增加”，《社会与临床心理学杂志》31，第 2 期（2012 年）：169，https://doi.org/10.1521/jscp.2012.31.2.169。

the solution is redefining what it means to be a good manager : Elizabeth Grace Saunders, “Stop Being a People Pleaser,” Harvard Business Review , October 30, 2012, https://hbr.org/2012/10/stop-being-a-people-pleaser .

解决方案是重新定义成为一名优秀管理者的意义：伊丽莎白·格雷斯·桑德斯，“停止取悦他人”，《哈佛商业评论》，2012 年 10 月 30 日，https://hbr.org/2012/10/stop-being-a-people-pleaser。

He aimed to get rejected every single day : Alex Spiegel, “By Making a Game out of Rejection, a Man Conquers Fear,” Morning Edition , NPR, January 16, 2015, https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2015/01/16/377239011/by-making-a-game-out-of-rejection-a-man-conquers-fear?t=1556281440846 .

他的目标是每天都被拒绝：Alex Spiegel，“通过把拒绝变成游戏，一个男人战胜了恐惧”，《早间新闻》，NPR，2015 年 1 月 16 日，https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2015/01/16/377239011/by-making-a-game-out-of-rejection-a-man-conquers-fear?t=1556281440846。

Chapter 4: Getting the How Wrong

第四章：搞错多少

the chief “stays behind the flock” : Joe Campolo, “Mandela—Master Negotiator,” Campolo, Middleton & McCormick, LLP blog, March 27, 2014, http://cmmllp.com/mandela-master-negotiator/ .

首领“留在羊群后面”：乔·坎波罗，“曼德拉——谈判大师”，坎波罗、米德尔顿和麦考密克律师事务所博客，2014 年 3 月 27 日，http://cmmllp.com/mandela-master-negotiator/。

“five-second rule” : David McCandless, “51 Favorite Facts You’ve Always Believed That Are Actually False,” Reader’s Digest , https://www.rd.com/culture/false-facts-everyone-believes/ , accessed May 25, 2019.

“五秒规则”：David McCandless，“你一直相信的 51 个最喜欢的事实，但实际上是错误的”，《读者文摘》，https://www.rd.com/culture/false-facts-everyone-believes/，访问日期：2019 年 5 月 25 日。

negotiating the purchase of Lucasfilm : PON Staff, “The Star Wars Negotiations and Trust at the Negotiating Table,” Harvard Law School, Program on Negotiation (PON) blog, May 7, 2019, https://www.pon.harvard.edu/daily/business-negotiations/a-forceful-deal-george-lucas-puts-his-trust-in-disney/ .

谈判收购卢卡斯影业：PON 工作人员，“星球大战谈判与谈判桌上的信任”，哈佛大学法学院谈判项目 (PON) 博客，2019 年 5 月 7 日，https://www.pon.harvard.edu/daily/business-negotiations/a-forceful-deal-george-lucas-puts-his-trust-in-disney/。

the achievements of women are viewed more critically : Madeline E. Heilman et al., “Penalties for Success: Reactions to Women Who Succeed at Male Gender-Typed Tasks,” Journal of Applied Psychology 89, no. 3 (2004): 416, http://dx.doi.org/10.1037/0021-9010.89.3.416 ; Madeline E. Heilman and Michelle C. Haynes, “No Credit Where Credit Is Due: Attributional Rationalization of Women’s Success in Male-Female Teams,” Journal of Applied Psychology 90, no. 5 (2005): 905, http://dx.doi.org/10.1037/0021-9010.90.5.905 ; Madeline Heilman, “Gender Stereotypes and Workplace Bias,” Research in Organizational Behavior 32 (2012): 113, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.riob.2012.11.003 ; Rhea E. Steinpreis, Katie A. Anders, and Dawn Ritzke, “The Impact of Gender on the Review of the Curricula Vitae of Job Applicants and Tenure Candidates: A National Empirical Study,” Sex Roles 41, no. 7–8 (1999): 509–510, https://link.springer.com/article/10.1023/A:1018839203698 .

女性的成就往往受到更严格的审视：Madeline E. Heilman 等人，“成功的惩罚：对在男性性别刻板任务中取得成功的女性的反应”，《应用心理学杂志》89，第 3 期（2004 年）：416，http://dx.doi.org/10.1037/0021-9010.89.3.416；Madeline E. Heilman 和 Michelle C. Haynes，“功劳得不到应有的赞扬：对女性在男女团队中取得成功的归因合理化”，《应用心理学杂志》90，第 5 期（2005 年）：905，http://dx.doi.org/10.1037/0021-9010.90.5.905； Madeline Heilman，“性别刻板印象与职场偏见”，《组织行为研究》32 (2012): 113，https://doi.org/10.1016/j.riob.2012.11.003；Rhea E. Steinpreis、Katie A. Anders 和 Dawn Ritzke，“性别对求职者和终身教职候选人简历审查的影响：一项全国性实证研究”，《性别角色》41，第 7-8 期 (1999): 509-510，https://link.springer.com/article/10.1023/A:1018839203698。

Chapter 5: The Power of an Open Mind

第五章：开放心态的力量

64 percent of people who supported same-sex marriage chose to take less money so as not to have to read the opposing view : Jeremy Frimer, Linda J. Skitka, and Matt Motyl, “Liberals and Conservatives Are Similarly Motivated to Avoid Exposure to One Another’s Opinions,” Journal of Experimental Social Psychology 72, no. 1–12 (2017): 10, https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2953780 .

支持同性婚姻的人中有 64% 的人选择少拿钱，这样就不用阅读反对意见了：Jeremy Frimer、Linda J. Skitka 和 Matt Motyl，“自由派和保守派同样有避免接触彼此观点的动机”，《实验社会心理学杂志》72，第 1-12 期（2017 年）：10，https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2953780。

“Our brains are better at processing faces that evoke a sense of familiarity” : Jennifer Eberhardt, Biased: Uncovering the Hidden Prejudice That Shapes What We See, Think, and Do (New York: Viking, 2019), 14.

“我们的大脑更擅长处理那些能唤起熟悉感的面孔”：詹妮弗·埃伯哈特，《偏见：揭示塑造我们所见、所想、所为的隐藏偏见》（纽约：维京出版社，2019 年），第 14 页。

bias is triggered by stress : Eberhardt, Biased , 85.

偏见是由压力引发的：Eberhardt，《偏见》，85。

change their foot pursuit policies : Alisa Chang, “MacArthur Genius Recipient Jennifer Eberhardt Discusses Her New Book ‘Biased,’” All Things Considered , NPR, March 26, 2019, https://www.npr.org/2019/03/26/706969408/macarthur-genius-recipient-jennifer-eberhardt-discusses-her-new-book-biased .

改变他们的徒步追踪政策：Alisa Chang，“麦克阿瑟天才奖获得者詹妮弗·埃伯哈特讨论她的新书《偏见》”，《万事皆知》，NPR，2019 年 3 月 26 日，https://www.npr.org/2019/03/26/706969408/macarthur-genius-recipient-jennifer-eberhardt-discusses-her-new-book-biased。

that percentage rises to 87 percent : Erik Larson, “New Research: Diversity + Inclusion = Better Decision Making At Work,” Forbes , September 21, 2017, https://www.forbes.com/sites/eriklarson/2017/09/21/new-research-diversity-inclusion-better-decision-making-at-work/#3fca39af4cbf .

该百分比上升至 87%：Erik Larson，“新研究：多样性 + 包容性 = 更好的工作决策”，福布斯，2017 年 9 月 21 日，https://www.forbes.com/sites/eriklarson/2017/09/21/new-research-diversity-inclusion-better-decision-making-at-work/#3fca39af4cbf。

“nonhomogenous teams are simply smarter” : David Rock and Heidi Grant, “Why Diverse Teams Are Smarter,” Harvard Business Review , November 4, 2016, https://hbr.org/2016/11/why-diverse-teams-are-smarter .

“非同质团队更聪明”：David Rock 和 Heidi Grant，“为什么多元化团队更聪明”，《哈佛商业评论》，2016 年 11 月 4 日，https://hbr.org/2016/11/why-diverse-teams-are-smarter。

how offensive the clothing designs were : Anne d’Innocenzio, “Gucci, Prada, H&M—Fashion Brands Blunder over Racial Sensitivity,” Stuff , February 18, 2019, https://www.stuff.co.nz/business/world/110664121/gucci-prada-hm—fashion-brands-blunder-over-racial-sensitivity .

服装设计有多么冒犯人：Anne d’Innocenzio，“Gucci、Prada、H&M——时尚品牌在种族敏感性方面犯错”，Stuff，2019 年 2 月 18 日，https://www.stuff.co.nz/business/world/110664121/gucci-prada-hm—fashion-brands-blunder-over-racial-sensitivity。

Participants didn’t want to hear the opposing position : Tom Jacobs, “Why We Shut Ourselves Off from Opposing Viewpoints,” Pacific Standard Magazine , June 14, 2017, https://psmag.com/news/why-we-shut-ourselves-off-from-opposing-viewpoints .

参与者不想听到相反的观点：汤姆·雅各布斯，“为什么我们封闭自己，拒绝接受相反的观点”，《太平洋标准》杂志，2017 年 6 月 14 日，https://psmag.com/news/why-we-shut-ourselves-off-from-opposing-viewpoints。

Fresh Air host Terry Gross : Jolie Kerr, “How to Talk to People, According to Terry Gross,” New York Times , November 17, 2018, https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/17/style/self-care/terry-gross-conversation-advice.html .

Fresh Air 主持人 Terry Gross：Jolie Kerr，“根据 Terry Gross 的建议如何与人交谈”，《纽约时报》，2018 年 11 月 17 日，https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/17/style/self-care/terry-gross-conversation-advice.html。

“The difference between appreciation and flattery?” : Dale Carnegie, How to Win Friends and Influence People , rev. ed. (New York: Simon & Schuster, 1981), 30.

“欣赏和奉承之间的区别是什么？”：戴尔·卡耐基，《人性的弱点》，修订版（纽约：西蒙与舒斯特出版社，1981 年），第 30 页。

how much curiosity like this matters in personal relationships : Patricia Donovan, “Study Finds That Curiosity Is Key to Personal Growth in Many Spheres, Including Intimate Relationships,” University at Buffalo, News Center, December 16, 2002, http://www.buffalo.edu/news/releases/2002/12/5996.html .

这种好奇心在人际关系中有多重要：Patricia Donovan，“研究发现好奇心是个人在包括亲密关系在内的许多领域成长的关键”，布法罗大学新闻中心，2002 年 12 月 16 日，http://www.buffalo.edu/news/releases/2002/12/5996.html。

a dress that some viewers swore was white and gold : Jonathan Mahler, “The White and Gold (No, Blue and Black!) Dress That Melted the Internet,” New York Times , February 27, 2015, https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/28/business/a-simple-question-about-a-dress-and-the-world-weighs-in.html .

一些观众发誓说，这条裙子是白色和金色的：乔纳森·马勒，“这条白色和金色（不，是蓝色和黑色！）的裙子让互联网为之倾倒”，《纽约时报》，2015 年 2 月 27 日，https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/28/business/a-simple-question-about-a-dress-and-the-world-weighs-in.html。

Chapter 6: The Power of Empathy

第六章：同理心的力量

“Let’s talk, Eddie” : L. Gregory Jones, “Leadership as Loving Enemies,” Faith and Leadership , January 4, 2009, https://www.faithandleadership.com/content/leadership-loving-enemies .

“我们来谈谈吧，埃迪”：L. Gregory Jones，“领导力作为爱的敌人”，信仰与领导力，2009 年 1 月 4 日，https://www.faithandleadership.com/content/leadership-loving-enemies。

Lt. Jack Cambria prizes empathy as a critical negotiation tool : Pervaiz Shallwani, “Life Lessons from the NYPD’s Top Hostage Negotiator,” Wall Street Journal , August 28, 2015, https://www.wsj.com/articles/life-lessons-from-the-nypds-top-hostage-negotiator-1440726792 .

杰克·坎布里亚中尉重视同理心，认为它是谈判的关键工具：Pervaiz Shallwani，“纽约警察局顶级人质谈判专家的人生经验”，《华尔街日报》，2015 年 8 月 28 日，https://www.wsj.com/articles/life-lessons-from-the-nypds-top-hostage-negotiator-1440726792。

influence “is all about relationship building” : Gary Noesner, “The Best Books on Negotiating and the FBI Recommended by Gary Noesner,” Five Books , https://fivebooks.com/best-books/gary-noesner-on-negotiating-and-the-fbi/ , accessed May 26, 2019.

影响力“完全在于建立关系”：Gary Noesner，“Gary Noesner 推荐的关于谈判和 FBI 的最佳书籍”，Five Books，https://fivebooks.com/best-books/gary-noesner-on-negotiating-and-the-fbi/，访问日期：2019 年 5 月 26 日。

“I believe that’s what Israeli parents would want for these kids” : Ben Rhodes, The World As It Is (New York: Random House, 2018), 201.

“我相信这就是以色列父母希望这些孩子拥有的”：本·罗兹，《世界本来的样子》（纽约：兰登书屋，2018 年），201。

a group of researchers studied reactions to opening offers : PON Staff, “Win Win Negotiation—Managing Your Counterpart’s Satisfaction,” Harvard Law School, Program on Negotiation (PON) blog, December 24, 2018, https://www.pon.harvard.edu/daily/win-win-daily/win-win-negotiations-managing-your-counterparts-satisfaction/ .

一组研究人员研究了对开场白的反应：PON 工作人员，“双赢谈判——管理对方的满意度”，哈佛大学法学院谈判项目 (PON) 博客，2018 年 12 月 24 日，https://www.pon.harvard.edu/daily/win-win-daily/win-win-negotiations-managing-your-counterparts-satisfaction/。

“a negotiation isn’t about only money” : Michael S. Hopkins, “How to Negotiate Practically Everything,” February 1, 1989, https://www.inc.com/magazine/19890201/5526.html .

“谈判不仅仅是关于金钱”：迈克尔·S·霍普金斯，《如何谈判几乎所有事情》，1989 年 2 月 1 日，https://www.inc.com/magazine/19890201/5526.html。

“both sides were making a sacrifice” : Charalambos Vlachoutsicos, “Empathetic Negotiation Saved My Company,” Harvard Business Review , October 24, 2013, https://hbr.org/2013/10/empathetic-negotiation-saved-my-company .

“双方都做出了牺牲”：Charalambos Vlachoutsicos，“同理心谈判拯救了我的公司”，《哈佛商业评论》，2013 年 10 月 24 日，https://hbr.org/2013/10/empathetic-negotiation-saved-my-company。

Chapter 7: Wherever You Are, Be There Fully

第七章：无论身在何处，都要全身心投入

she noticed everything about her counterpart, Iranian foreign minister Javad Zarif : Wendy Sherman, Not for the Faint of Heart (New York: PublicAffairs, 2018), 43.

她注意到了她的同行，伊朗外交部长贾瓦德·扎里夫的一切：温迪·舍曼，《不适合胆小者》（纽约：PublicAffairs，2018 年），第 43 页。

more distractible than goldfish : Kevin McSpadden, “You Now Have a Shorter Attention Span Than a Goldfish,” Time , May 14, 2015, http://time.com/3858309/attention-spans-goldfish/ .

比金鱼更容易分心：凯文·麦克帕登，“你现在的注意力持续时间比金鱼还短”，《时代周刊》，2015 年 5 月 14 日，http://time.com/3858309/attention-spans-goldfish/。

the mere presence of your phone is distracting : Adrian F. Ward et al., “Brain Drain: The Mere Presence of One’s Own Smartphone Reduces Available Cognitive Capacity,” Journal of the Association for Consumer Research 2, no. 2 (2017), https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/full/10.1086/691462 .

手机的存在本身就会分散注意力：Adrian F. Ward 等人，“脑力流失：智能手机的存在本身就会降低可用认知能力”，《消费者研究协会杂志》2，第 2 期（2017 年），https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/full/10.1086/691462。

they checked their phones an average of every twelve minutes while on vacation : “Americans Don’t Want to Unplug from Phones While on Vacation, Despite Latest Digital Detox Trend,” press release, Asurion.com, May 17, 2018, https://www.asurion.com/about/press-releases/americans-dont-want-to-unplug-from-phones-while-on-vacation-despite-latest-digital-detox-trend/ .

他们在度假期间平均每十二分钟查看一次手机：“尽管出现了最新的数字排毒趋势，但美国人在度假时并不想放下手机”，新闻稿，Asurion.com，2018 年 5 月 17 日，https://www.asurion.com/about/press-releases/americans-dont-want-to-unplug-from-phones-while-on-vacation-despite-latest-digital-detox-trend/。

“you remember who you were as a reader” : Maryanne Wolf, Reader Come Home: The Reading Brain in a Digital World (New York: HarperCollins, 2018), 2.

“你会想起你作为读者的过去”：玛丽安·沃尔夫，《读者回家：数字世界中的阅读大脑》（纽约：哈珀柯林斯出版社，2018 年），第 2 页。

“I saw my expression as a stranger might perceive it” : Michelle Obama, Becoming (New York: Crown, 2018), 61.

“我以陌生人的视角审视了自己的表情”：米歇尔·奥巴马，《成为》（纽约：皇冠出版社，2018 年），第 61 页。

“It was okay, in other words, to be myself” : Obama, Becoming , 89.

“换句话说，做我自己是没问题的”：奥巴马，《成为》，第 89 页。

the party who was angry did not in fact claim any more value for themselves : Keith Allred et al., “The Influence of Anger and Compassion on Negotiation Performance,” Organizational Behavior and Human Decision Processes 70, no. 3 (1997), https://doi.org/10.1006/obhd.1997.2705 .

愤怒的一方实际上并没有为自己争取到任何更多价值：Keith Allred 等人，“愤怒和同情对谈判绩效的影响”，《组织行为与人类决策过程》70，第 3 期（1997 年），https://doi.org/10.1006/obhd.1997.2705。

more likely to walk away : Jeremy A. Yip and Martin Schweinsberg, “Infuriating Impasses: Angry Expressions Increase Exiting Behavior in Negotiations,” Social Psychological and Personality Science 8, no. 6 (2017), https://doi.org/10.1177/1948550616683021 .

更有可能离开：Jeremy A. Yip 和 Martin Schweinsberg，“令人恼火的僵局：愤怒的表情会增加谈判中的退出行为”，社会心理学和人格科学 8，第 6 期（2017 年），https://doi.org/10.1177/1948550616683021。

Chapter 8: Assume Abundance

第八章：假设资源丰富

“almost universally reviled” : Olga Khazan, “Why Do Women Bully Each Other at Work?” The Atlantic , September 2017, https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2017/09/the-queen-bee-in-the-corner-office/534213/ . Allison S. Gabriel et al., “Further Understanding Incivility in the Workplace: The Effects of Gender, Agency, and Communion,” Journal of Applied Psychology 103, no. 4 (April 2018): 362–382, http://psycnet.apa.org/doiLanding?doi=10.1037%2Fapl0000289 .

“几乎人人唾弃”：奥尔加·哈赞，《为什么女性会在工作中互相欺凌？》，《大西洋月刊》，2017年9月，https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2017/09/the-queen-bee-in-the-corner-office/534213/。艾莉森·S·加布里埃尔等人，《进一步理解职场不文明行为：性别、自主性和亲和力的影响》，《应用心理学杂志》103卷，第4期（2018年4月）：362-382，http://psycnet.apa.org/doiLanding?doi=10.1037%2Fapl0000289。

“to bring people to their senses rather than to their knees” : Neil Katz and Kevin McNulty, “Interest-Based Negotiation,” Maxwell School of Citizenship and Public Policy, 1995, https://www.maxwell.syr.edu/uploadedFiles/parcc/cmc/Interested-Based%20Negotiation%20NK.pdf .

“使人们恢复理智，而不是屈服”：尼尔·卡茨和凯文·麦克纳尔蒂，《基于利益的谈判》，麦克斯韦公民与公共政策学院，1995 年，https://www.maxwell.syr.edu/uploadedFiles/parcc/cmc/Interested-Based%20Negotiation%20NK.pdf。

“ethical fading” : PON Staff, “Why Is Sincerity Important? How to Avoid Deception in Negotiation,” Harvard Law School, Program on Negotiation (PON) blog, January 7, 2019, https://www.pon.harvard.edu/daily/conflict-resolution/why-we-succumb-to-deception-in-negotiation/ .

Because of Morgan’s integrity, Carnegie was loyal to him : Michael Benoliel, Done Deal (Avon, MA: Platinum Press, 2005), 114.

由于摩根的正直，卡内基对他忠心耿耿：迈克尔·贝诺利尔，《成交》（马萨诸塞州埃文：白金出版社，2005 年），第 114 页。

“to develop a nice relationship with the public” : Paul B. Brown and Michael S. Hopkins, “How to Negotiate Practically Anything,” interview with Bob Woolf, Inc. , February 1, 1989, https://www.inc.com/magazine/19890201/5526.html .

“与公众建立良好的关系”：Paul B. Brown 和 Michael S. Hopkins，“如何谈判几乎任何事情”，Bob Woolf 采访，Inc.，1989 年 2 月 1 日，https://www.inc.com/magazine/19890201/5526.html。

“She literally convinced the union” : Fast Company Staff, “Fresh Copy: How Ursula Burns Reinvented Xerox,” Fast Company , November 19, 2011, https://www.fastcompany.com/1793533/fresh-copy-how-ursula-burns-reinvented-xerox .

“她真的说服了工会”：Fast Company Staff，“新鲜文案：乌苏拉·伯恩斯如何重塑施乐公司”，Fast Company，2011 年 11 月 19 日，https://www.fastcompany.com/1793533/fresh-copy-how-ursula-burns-reinvented-xerox。

people share more when others reveal sensitive information : Leslie K. John, “How to Negotiate with a Liar,” Harvard Business Review , July–August 2016, https://hbr.org/2016/07/how-to-negotiate-with-a-liar .

当其他人透露敏感信息时，人们会分享更多：Leslie K. John，“如何与说谎者谈判”，《哈佛商业评论》，2016 年 7 月至 8 月，https://hbr.org/2016/07/how-to-negotiate-with-a-liar。

the listener doesn’t even notice that they’ve deflected the question : John, “How to Negotiate with a Liar.”

听者甚至没有注意到他们已经回避了这个问题：约翰，“如何与说谎者谈判”。

Chapter 9: Claiming Your Power

第九章：掌握你的力量

Most of the decision makers on Wall Street : Sallie Krawcheck, Own It: The Power of Women at Work (New York: Crown Business, 2017), 7.

华尔街的大多数决策者：Sallie Krawcheck，《掌控它：女性在工作中的力量》（纽约：皇冠商业出版社，2017 年），第 7 页。

“We had shaken those clients’ confidence in us” : Krawcheck, Own It , 4.

“我们动摇了客户对我们的信任”：Krawcheck，《Own It》，4。

“you take the gender and the race differences and use them as a strength” : Ursula Burns, “Ursula Burns: First Woman to Run a Fortune 500 Company,” Time , http://time.com/collection/firsts/4883099/ursula-burns-firsts/ , accessed May 28, 2019.

“你要利用性别和种族差异，并将其转化为优势”：乌苏拉·伯恩斯，“乌苏拉·伯恩斯：第一位执掌财富 500 强公司的女性”，《时代》周刊，http://time.com/collection/firsts/4883099/ursula-burns-firsts/，访问日期：2019 年 5 月 28 日。

Kyle MacDonald, who traded a paper clip all the way up to a house : “From Paper-Clip to House in 14 Trades,” CBC News , July 7, 2006, https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/from-paper-clip-to-house-in-14-trades-1.573973 .

Kyle MacDonald 用一个回形针换了一栋房子：“从回形针到房子，14 次交易”，加拿大广播公司新闻，2006 年 7 月 7 日，https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/from-paper-clip-to-house-in-14-trades-1.573973。

a turning point came when frustrated tears ran down her face : Sherman, Not for the Faint of Heart , xvi.

转折点出现在她沮丧的泪水顺着脸颊流下来的时候：谢尔曼，《胆小者勿入》，第十六章。

“identify a similarity you share in common, then begin negotiating” : Robert Cialdini, “Principles of Persuasion,” video, Influence at Work , https://www.influenceatwork.com/principles-of-persuasion/ , accessed June 1, 2019.

“找出你们的共同点，然后开始谈判”：罗伯特·西奥迪尼，《说服原则》，视频，职场影响力，https://www.influenceatwork.com/principles-of-persuasion/，访问日期：2019 年 6 月 1 日。

“not an obstacle but a point of commonality” : Sherman, Not for the Faint of Heart , 39.

“这不是障碍，而是共同点”：谢尔曼，《胆小者勿入》，第39页。

force yourself to smile : Nicole Spector, “Smiling Can Trick Your Brain into Happiness—and Boost Your Health,” NBC News , November 28, 2017, https://www.nbcnews.com/better/health/smiling-can-trick-your-brain-happiness-boost-your-health-ncna822591 .

强迫自己微笑：妮可·斯佩克特，“微笑可以欺骗你的大脑，让你感到快乐——并促进你的健康”，NBC 新闻，2017 年 11 月 28 日，https://www.nbcnews.com/better/health/smiling-can-trick-your-brain-happiness-boost-your-health-ncna822591。

if your counterpart believes you’re acting as a way to gain status : Michael Schaerer, Martin Schweinsberg, and Roderick Swaab, “Imaginary Alternatives: The Effects of Mental Simulation on Powerless Negotiators,” Journal of Personality and Social Psychology 115, no. 1 (2018), https://psycnet.apa.org/record/2018-13326-001 .

如果你的对手认为你这样做是为了获得地位：Michael Schaerer、Martin Schweinsberg 和 Roderick Swaab，“想象的选择：心理模拟对无权谈判者的影响”，《人格与社会心理学杂志》115，第 1 期（2018 年），https://psycnet.apa.org/record/2018-13326-001。

when you stand in a dominant posture : Amy Cuddy, “Your Body Language May Shape Who You Are,” TED Talk video, 2012, https://www.ted.com/talks/amy_cuddy_your_body_language_shapes_who_you_are?language=en .

当你以支配性的姿势站立时：Amy Cuddy，“你的肢体语言可能会塑造你是谁”，TED演讲视频，2012年，https://www.ted.com/talks/amy_cuddy_your_body_language_shapes_who_you_are?language=en。

“to convince others we need to convince ourselves” : Amy Cuddy, Presence: Bringing Your Boldest Self to Your Biggest Challenges (New York: Little, Brown, 2015), 41.

“要说服别人，我们需要先说服自己”：艾米·卡迪，《存在：将你最勇敢的自我带到你最大的挑战中》（纽约：Little, Brown，2015 年），第 41 页。

simply imagine that you have more power : Schaerer et al., “Imaginary Alternatives.”

想象一下你拥有更大的权力：Schaerer 等人，“想象的替代方案”。

Chapter 10: How Negotiation Can Save Democracy

第十章：谈判如何拯救民主

the number of people who feel lonely : Laura Entis, “Loneliness Is a Modern Day Epidemic,” Fortune , June 22, 2016, http://fortune.com/2016/06/22/loneliness-is-a-modern-day-epidemic/ .

感到孤独的人数：Laura Entis，“孤独是现代流行病”，《财富》杂志，2016 年 6 月 22 日，http://fortune.com/2016/06/22/loneliness-is-a-modern-day-epidemic/。

“difficult conversations among family members who initially disagreed” : Karin Tamerius, “How to Have a Conversation with Your Angry Uncle over the Holidays,” New York Times , November 18, 2019, https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/11/18/opinion/thanksgiving-family-argue-chat-bot.html .

“最初意见不合的家庭成员之间进行艰难的对话”：卡琳·塔梅里乌斯，“如何在假期与愤怒的叔叔进行对话”，《纽约时报》，2019 年 11 月 18 日，https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/11/18/opinion/thanksgiving-family-argue-chat-bot.html。

the canvasser asked him at the end of the conversation if he supported gay marriage : Ira Glass, “The Incredible Rarity of Changing Your Mind,” podcast audio, This American Life , WBEZ Chicago, April 24, 2015, https://www.thisamericanlife.org/555/the-incredible-rarity-of-changing-your-mind . (Note that although a study used in this episode was later discredited, the canvasser’s conversation with the voter remains accurate.)

在谈话结束时，拉票员问他是否支持同性婚姻：伊拉·格拉斯，《改变主意的罕见性》，播客音频，《美国生活》，芝加哥WBEZ电台，2015年4月24日，https://www.thisamericanlife.org/555/the-incredible-rarity-of-changing-your-mind。（请注意，尽管本期节目中使用的一项研究后来被推翻，但拉票员与选民的对话仍然准确。）

“I am a white male,” he said, “and I am prejudiced” : Heather McGhee, “‘What Can I Do to Change? You Know? To Be a Better American?’” Interview with Heather McGhee, CSPAN’s Washington Journal via YouTube, August 20, 2016, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BsUa7eCgE_U ; Daniel Smith, “A Friendship for a More Tolerant America,” New Yorker , December 25, 2016, https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2017/01/02/a-friendship-for-a-more-tolerant-america .

“我是一个白人男性，”他说，“而且我带有偏见”：希瑟·麦吉，“‘我能做些什么来改变？你知道吗？成为一个更好的美国人？’”希瑟·麦吉访谈，CSPAN华盛顿期刊，YouTube，2016年8月20日，https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BsUa7eCgE_U；丹尼尔·史密斯，“为了更宽容的美国而建立的友谊”，《纽约客》，2016年12月25日，https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2017/01/02/a-friendship-for-a-more-tolerant-america。

Galileo then discovered four moons orbiting Jupiter : Todd Rose and Ogi Ogas, Dark Horse: Achieving Success through the Pursuit of Fulfillment (New York: HarperOne, 2018).

伽利略随后发现了木星的四颗卫星：托德·罗斯和奥吉·奥加斯，《黑马：通过追求成就感获得成功》（纽约：哈珀柯林斯出版社，2018 年）。

“no colored bathrooms in this building” : Hidden Figures , 20th Century Fox, released December 25, 2016.

“这栋楼里没有有色人种的洗手间”：《隐藏人物》，20 世纪福克斯公司，2016 年 12 月 25 日上映。

“asking our partners to assume experiences they have likely never had” : Kimberly Harrington, “When Will It Be Times Up for Motherhood and Marriage?,” Medium , July 20, 2018, https://medium.com/s/story/when-will-it-be-times-up-for-motherhood-and-marriage-2766d311bfae .

“要求我们的伴侣假设他们可能从未经历过的事情”：Kimberly Harrington，“母性和婚姻的时代何时结束？”，Medium，2018 年 7 月 20 日，https://medium.com/s/story/when-will-it-be-times-up-for-motherhood-and-marriage-2766d311bfae。

those who read literary fiction were more empathetic : David Comer Kidd and Emanuele Castano, “Reading Literary Fiction Improves Theory of Mind,” Science 342, no. 6156, DOI: 10.1126/science.1239918.

阅读文学小说的人更有同理心：David Comer Kidd 和 Emanuele Castano，“阅读文学小说可以提高心智理论”，《科学》342，第 6156 期，DOI：10.1126/science.1239918。

“one can much more easily talk about a movie” : John Guida, “How Movies Can Change Our Minds,” New York Times , February 4, 2015, https://op-talk.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/02/04/how-movies-can-change-our-minds/ .

“人们可以更容易地谈论一部电影”：约翰·圭达，《电影如何改变我们的想法》，《纽约时报》，2015 年 2 月 4 日，https://op-talk.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/02/04/how-movies-can-change-our-minds/。

#↩

about the author

关于作者

Mori Taheripour is a faculty member in the Legal Studies and Business Ethics Department at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, where she teaches Negotiations and Dispute Resolution at the undergraduate, graduate, and executive levels. Repeatedly recognized for her outstanding abilities as a faculty member, Taheripour is a five-time recipient of awards for excellence in teaching. She also co-founded the Wharton Sports Business Initiative (WSBI), a partnership among top business leaders, faculty, and students that generates and disseminates knowledge about the sports industry through educational programs, high-level student consulting assignments, global forums, and research. Taheripour earned her MBA from the Wharton School and her BA in psychology and pre-medical studies from Barnard College/Columbia University.

莫里·塔赫里普尔 (Mori Taheripour) 是宾夕法尼亚大学沃顿商学院法律研究与商业伦理系的教员，教授本科生、研究生和高管级别的谈判与争议解决课程。塔赫里普尔教授因其卓越的教学能力而屡获殊荣，曾五次荣获教学卓越奖。她还联合创立了沃顿体育商业倡议 (WSBI)，这是一个由顶尖商业领袖、教员和学生组成的合作项目，旨在通过教育项目、高水平学生咨询任务、全球论坛和研究，创造并传播体育产业知识。塔赫里普尔教授拥有沃顿商学院的工商管理硕士学位，以及巴纳德学院/哥伦比亚大学的心理学和医学预科学士学位。
